name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before we start the debate on the future of Europe with Prime Minister Plenković of Croatia, I want to remember the terrible attacks that rocked Afghanistan last week. A few days after the attack on the Inter-Continental Hotel in Kabul, an ambulance-bomb was detonated, another attack targeted the Marshal Fahim Military Academy, and finally it was hit the headquarters of the NGO Save the Children. These attacks, with dozens of innocent victims, unfortunately add to the long list of terrorist acts that have been affecting the whole world for too many years. Today more than ever we have a duty to remember all the victims. To their families I want to address, on your behalf, the condolences and solidarity of this Parliament. To all those who continue to operate on the ground in situations of difficulty and danger I mean: don't abandon, we stand by you. We all have a responsibility to continue working to promote a political solution for peace in Afghanistan.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate with Prime Minister Andrej Plenković of Croatia on the future of Europe (2018/2533 (RSP)). Before giving the floor to Prime Minister Plenković, whom I thank for acceding to our invitation — I also greet him because he was, at the beginning of this parliamentary term, a member of this Assembly —, I remind you. that you can request the “catch the eye” using the electronic voting device. To introduce your request, enter the voting card and use any of the electronic voting buttons. I am now going to open the system which will remain open during the intervention of Prime Minister Plenković. I now give the floor to Prime Minister Plenković, so that he can explain to the House his ideas and the ideas of his government on the future of Europe.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Croatian Prime Minister. — Dear President of the European Parliament, Dear Antonio, Honored Vice-Presidents, Leaders of Political Groups, MEPs, Honored President of the European Commission, Dear Jean-Claude, Honored Minister of the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council, dear friends. It's good to be back. It takes leaving the Parliament to arrive at the podium. I am glad to see friends and feel the positive atmosphere of Strasbourg. It is my pleasure as Prime Minister of the Republic of Croatia to speak today about the future of Europe. This year Croatia will mark its fifth year of membership in the European Union. This is an occasion to recall our demanding accession process, as well as the fact that the European Community recognised Croatia internationally on 15 January 1992. It returned to the political map of the world after nine centuries as an independent state, to the intersection of Central Europe and the Mediterranean. Croatian people, that day, as well as the day of accession to the European Union, still remember today with a lot of emotions. The fall of the Berlin Wall marked the rejection of communism and the victory of democracy across Central and Eastern Europe. Although we also sought to return to the auspices of democratic Europe, this period and events in the early nineteenth were extremely unfavorable and difficult for Croatia. At the end of the twentieth century in the heart of Europe we were unfortunately forced to defend our freedom from military aggression. The siege and destruction of Vukovar, the first European city destroyed after World War II. The bombing of medieval Dubrovnik. Thousands killed, wounded and hundreds of thousands displaced permanently marked this painful period. In the war that ended in 1995. Croatia suffered damages reaching 150% of pre-war GDP. You can only imagine how much this has slowed our social and economic transformation. Even though we were among the more developed transition economies before the war, in the 1990s, because of all of the above, we lost a step in relation to others and entered the European Union in 2013 instead, if not any of that war, probably 2004. It took almost a quarter century for Croatia to recover, change and develop, rebuild, build and today become one of Europe's most attractive tourist destinations, visited by 18 million guests last year. Tourism today represents almost 20% of our GDP and we are the first in Europe by the number of tourists per capita. As prominent elements of our cultural heritage, invention, innovation, I will remind you that Croatia has 23 listed goods on the UNESCO World Heritage List, on our city, Rijeka, which will be the European Capital of Culture in 2020, to the Croatian tie, which, as we see here, won the world even long ago, as on Nikola Tesla, a native of Croatia, without whose inventions we would be sitting here today in the dark. Today, one of the fastest electric cars in the world is produced in Croatia. One Croatian company enables 4 billion people in the world to communicate digitally via SMS. At the same time, I am aware that a number of demanding structural reforms are ahead of us that need to provide a better quality life for our citizens. My government is determined to implement them. We have positive macroeconomic indicators. We record economic growth of 3%, growth in industrial production, investment, exports, as well as growth in employment, wages and social benefits. We have significantly reduced public debt, achieved budget surplus and have the lowest unemployment so far. In addition to the efforts of the Government, this also reflects the positive effects of Croatian membership in the European Union. Moreover, as the Government that won the election in 2016 on a pro-European agenda, we are actively rethinking the future of our common Union. Mesdames et Messieurs, j'ai consacré 25 ans d'action politique et de travail professionnel afin que la Croatie moderne fasse siennes les valeurs européennes. Mes compatriotes qui ont, hélas, eu à connaître la guerre n'en apprécient aujourd'hui la paix que davantage. Il n'y a pas si longtemps, la démocratie n'était qu'une aspiration lointaine, alors qu'aujourd'hui nous vivons les valeurs et les libertés européennes. Nous avons un souvenir très clair de ce que signifie ne pas pouvoir bénéficier des mêmes chances de développement économique et social, de liberté de circulation, d'échange d'étudiants ou d'innovation technologique, si bien qu'aujourd'hui nous mesurons parfaitement toute la valeur ajoutée et les avantages que nous procure l'appartenance à l'Union européenne. Je le mesure d'autant mieux que j'ai moi-même activement œuvré aux négociations d'adhésion de la Croatie et conduit la campagne référendaire pour notre entrée dans l'Union. Durant un an, cela a été pour moi l'occasion d'aller au contact de mes concitoyens afin de leur expliquer les bénéfices de l'adhésion. Ainsi, avec ma double expérience de député croate et européen, mais aussi celle de premier ministre et de membre du Conseil européen, je mesure parfaitement les différents intérêts qui cherchent à affaiblir et à fragmenter le projet européen. Sans perdre le sens des réalités politiques, je pense qu'il est essentiel de renouveler ensemble les idées européennes, en renforçant nos politiques communes et en faisant un usage intelligent de nos ressources budgétaires, le but étant que nos concitoyens ne soient pas indifférents à l'Europe, voire hostiles à son égard. Au contraire, ils doivent en ressentir tous les bénéfices, se l'approprier et prendre activement part à la poursuite de sa construction, car il y va avant tout de leur intérêt. Nos concitoyens doivent percevoir plus clairement les bénéfices que l'appartenance à l'Union leur apporte au quotidien. Ils doivent mieux saisir l'enjeu de notre action, de quelle manière, et surtout à quelle fin, nous la conduisons au niveau européen. Enfin, ils doivent en réaliser la finalité, qui est de mieux servir l'intérêt général en joignant nos forces. Nous devons montrer par des actes concrets que les institutions européennes agissent pour chacun de nos concitoyens. Cela ne peut se faire qu'avec le soutien du Parlement européen. Aussi, je vais tâcher de vous livrer ma vision pour l'avenir de notre Europe. J'aimerais aborder les défis auxquels nous devons faire face, la nécessité de renforcer notre légitimité démocratique, nos priorités extérieures ainsi que les politiques internes cruciales, qu'il nous faut soutenir par des moyens budgétaires appropriés. Signore e signori, la riunione a Roma dello scorso 25 marzo, con la quale abbiamo celebrato il 60° anniversario dei trattati di Roma e adottato la dichiarazione che indica la via al nostro futuro comune, è stata un passaggio importante per la discussione che ci troviamo ad affronttamo ad affronttamo oggi sul futuro Dell'Europa. Quasi un anno fa, noi leader europei siamo fit invitati e incoraggiati dal Santo Padre a perseverare nel cercare di restituire la speranza ai nostri cittadini e a continuare ad adoperarci per il loro benessere. In quell'occasione, il Presidente Tajani ha tenuto un brillante discorso, per il quale vorrei ancora una volta congratularmi con lui. Sicurezza, terrorismo, attacchi cibernetici, scontri nelle aree vicine, cambiamenti demografici e migrazioni in aumento, cambiamenti climatici, disuguaglianze sociali e gap digitale: queste sono le sfide che affrontiamo quotidianamente e che impongono la necessità di adeguarvi le principali decisioni strategiche. Al giorno d'oggi queste sfide acquistano una nuova dimensione e pongono davanti a noi un nuovo compito: essere uniti nel dare la risposta. L'unità però non deve intendersi meramente come la somma numerica dei paesi membri, ma deve essere rafforzata dalle nostre particolarità nazionali e dai raggiungimenti individuali. La stessa unità deve rispecchiarsi nelle nostre politiche e bilancio comuni, a nonché nelle attività e nell'operato sinergico tra le istituzioni europee e gli Stati membri. Negli anni passati, y processi elettorali in varie parti d'Europa sono stand in buona parte contrassegnati dalla crescita del populismo e dell'euroscetticismo, come diretta conseguenza delle sfide di cui ho parlato. Dopo aver dimostrato che siamo in grado di affrontale con successo, è importante proseguire sulla stessa strada per arrivare pronti alle elezioni del 2019 e per consolidare la fede nel progetto europeo. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we must also work together to find answers to challenges posed by the United King's Withdrawal from the European Union. As I have repeatedly said on many occasions since 2013, before the referendum, I see this as a bad decision. It was a lose-lose situation for the United Kingdom and for the European Union as a whole. As a European, I respect the decision but I regret it. The UK's exit is a result of populism and a campaign of disinformation, demonstrating the consequences that a lack of information about the EU has for its citizens. I hope that the procedure in accordance with Article 50 will lead to an agreement on orderly withdrawal, ensuring legal security and clarity for citizens and business communities on both sides. It is particularly important to settle the rights of citizens on the basis of equal treatment. This means that Croatian citizens too must be treated equally when it comes to their access to the UK labour market. We must maintain unity in the process of negotiations, and our future relationship should be based on our mutual interests. In further building a European project, it is important to ensure democratic legitimacy. The European Parliament represents the strongest link between decisions at European level and our citizens, and we need to further strengthen this link. I therefore support the continued application of the concept of spitzencandidates through which citizens can more easily recognise the face and ideas of the future president of the European Commission, such as my friend Jean-Claude Juncker, as a spitzenkandidat on the EPP winner list in 2014. In the context of the debate on amending electoral legislation, we should ask ourselves whether we are at the level of Member States, given the weather restriction, sufficiently organizational, legally and financially ready for the establishment of transnational lists. I welcome the proposal prepared by the European Parliament on its new composition, according to which Croatia receives an additional MEP. National parliaments also have an important place in strengthening the democratic legitimacy of the European Union. Therefore, after returning to Zagreb, I introduced the practice of plenary debate in the Croatian Parliament after each formal meeting of the European Council. This gives me the opportunity to introduce MEPs and my fellow citizens to the most important European topics, thus contributing to the European trend of dialogue with citizens, which I strongly support. In our further work, I think that we need to strengthen the application of the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality and make decisions as close as possible to our fellow citizens and therefore welcome the establishment of a special working group. A few words about the policy of enlargement. Croatia is a testament to the transformative strength that the perspective of membership in the European Union carries, but also a proof that the Union is a peace project that strongly contributes to reconciliation and confidence building. It is precisely this attractive strength that we need to use to make our environment better and more resilient, and thus make ourselves stronger, safer and more prosperous. The European Union continues to be a community that many want to join, namely my six neighbouring countries in Southeast Europe, their closest neighbours, but also Turkey, but not only them but also part of our wider neighbourhood. I know of the ambitions of our friends in Ukraine, a country I followed daily while working here alongside you. Promises to candidates and potential candidates should be fulfilled just as those states need to meet the set conditions and criteria and implement the necessary reforms, always with the evaluation of the individual achievements of each of these states. Sehr geehrte Damen und Herren! Es freut mich, dass die Europäische Kommission gerade heute eine neue Erweiterungsstrategie für den Westbalkan vorstellen wird. In dieser strategie gilt es vor allem, Bosnia and Herzegovina besondere Aufmerksamkeit zu widmen, das genauso wie Kroatien eine schwere Wegstrecke hinter sich gelassen hat. Es ist ein Staat mit einer spezifischen Staatsordnung, bestehend aus drei constitutiven Völkern — Kroaten, Bosniaken und Serben —, deren gleichberechtigte Stellung zusammen mit den anderen Volksgruppen die Grundlage für die Zukunft ist. Erst mit der festen Verankerung im europäischen Wertverständnis kann Bosnien-Herzegowina seinen Bürgern eine sichere und stabile Zukunft garantieren. Das wünscht sich auch der Großteil seiner Bürger, und zwar auf der Grundlage einer gleichberechtigten Wahlgesetzgebung. In unserer europäischen Nachbarschaft, im östlichen und südlichen Teil Europas, stehen wir vor großen sicherheitspolitischen Herausforderungen. Deshalb ist es das strategische interesse aller EU-Mitgliedstaaten, seinen Nachbarn bei der Festigung und dem Ausbau einer prosperierenden, friedensorientierten, stabilen und vor allem demokratischen Staatsordnung zu helfen. Das ist der Einsatz den wir alle geben müssen, um den Schutz und die Sicherheit der europäischen Bürger zu gewährleisten. Ladies and gentlemen, many challenges and threats seek a stronger, more engaged and assertive role for the European Union in global relations. A commitment to an international order based on respect for democracy, internationalist law, the rule of law and human rights is a key investment in strengthening the role of the Union as a global factor and promoter of multilateralism. To achieve our global ambitions, we need a stronger, more effective common foreign security and defence policy. Equally important is our development assistance, which, as global leaders, contribute to the fulfilment of the UN's Sustainable Development Goals. We have the resources to do that, and I believe the political will to make it happen. Terrorist attacks on European soil, as well as other threats, show that Europe is vulnerable and that its security should be taken care of within and outside its borders. This will contribute further strengthening our defense capabilities and cooperation in the security and defense field. Therefore, I welcome the establishment of permanent structured cooperation in whose projects, namely five concrete ones, Croatia will participate. Strengthening cooperation and coordination with the North Atlantic Alliance remains crucial, while ensuring compatibility, synergy and effectiveness of joint action. Protecting the Union's external borders is one of our most important tasks. The measures we are taking to this end at European level should ensure equal treatment of all members and all citizens. Full implementation of systematic checks at the border between members when only one of them is in the Schengen area, which is the example of Croatia and Slovenia or Croatia and Hungary, has shown that there may be a problem for freedom of movement within the European Union, but with open and sincere cooperation and partnership between these three countries we have successfully solved these problems. Croatia is already making its contribution to border protection, and our next major key European goal is to enter the Schengen area. Therefore, in this we also support our friends from Bulgaria and Romania. Our ambition is to fulfil the Schengen criteria as soon as possible and thus pave the way for a Council decision, while I expect your support here in the European Parliament. This is important for Croatia, it is important for the security of the whole European Union and these issues must not be linked to any other unrelated processes or topics. The particular challenge of past years is the migration one, which has not only a security but also a humanitarian dimension. While we are recording a reduced number of entrances to the territory of the European Union, we still need to be vigilant and continue to invest in our own capacity to cope with this challenge as well as to help source countries of migration. To successfully respond to this challenge, it is necessary to complete the reform of the European asylum system. Solidarity, in my deep opinion, should remain one of the foundations of our joint action. In this spirit, in which twenty-five years ago every sixth inhabitant in to my country being an exile or refugee, Croatia conducts its share of responsibility for the policy of resettlement and resettlement. Mr. President, the European Union accounted for a third of the world's GDP in 2004, and today accounts for less than its quarter. It is therefore necessary to continue to work towards concluding trade deals with third countries as this is a stake in the further economic growth and prosperity of our people. It is important to strengthen relations with key strategic partners and further deepen transatlantic ties. One of our greatest achievements is the internal market. It is at the heart of the European project and is crucial for the competitiveness of our economy. After years of deadlock due to the global financial crisis and recession, economic growth has returned. In Davos two weeks ago, we noted that it is growing worldwide, growing European, but I am glad that the Croatian economy is growing, and it is important to keep this trend. Measures arising from the Single Market Strategy are our common responsibility, and in the internal market it is necessary to stop discriminatory practice of standards in the quality of food and other products because we cannot have two categories of consumers within our Union. With the intensification of measures to deepen the internal market in all respects, it is necessary to adapt it to modern challenges, especially the digital age in which we live. Therefore, we need to build a functional, single digital market as soon as possible, to give a boost to new jobs, increase investment competitiveness and innovation. Croatia contributes to this development of public electronic services, we have 685 of them, and we are particularly proud of those such as e-prescription in health care, which other countries have recognized, as well as e-newborn service, which since last week has enabled child birth reports online. Mr. President, in 1960 every seventh inhabitant of the world lived on the territory of the European Union, while today only every fifteenth inhabitant of the world lives in it. According to Eurostat, in 2060 in this area will live only every twentieth inhabitant of the world is evidence of the worsening demographic picture of Europe, which causes numerous challenges for our countries, including in the field of labour and social policy. One of our achievements is our social model, which we need to further improve, fostering dialogue with social partners and social cohesion. We are facing the application of the principle of the European Pillar of Social Rights as the basis for establishing a fair labour market and social security system, as well as caring for our pensioners. We must continue to build a European Energy Union and ensure our citizens access to sustainable, safe and affordable energy. It is therefore important for us to develop strategic energy projects aimed at diversification and security of supply. For Croatia, I especially highlight the project of the LNG terminal on Krk, which is a strategic project of my Government and which has already received financial support from the European Union, thus positioning Croatia on the energy map of Europe. On the other hand, we will fulfill all the obligations of the Paris Agreement and strive to continue on our tradition of the country that had the first hydroelectric power plant in Europe in 1895 to develop the production of electricity coming from renewable sources, and in consumption in Croatia the share from renewable sources It is already at 29%, thus practically ten years earlier we met the European 2030 targets. In terms of transport, I will only single out a strategic project for us, the most visible project financed by the European Union in this multiannual financial framework, which is the project of the Peljesac Bridge that physically connects southern Croatia, Dubrovnik you all know about, with the rest of Croatia and the European Union. Dear friends, all our goals, policies and ambitions or everything we do requires adequate financial resources. In planning the next Multiannual Financial Framework, we need to start from what kind of Union we want. For me it is a Union that ensures the economic growth and development of its members, which is globally competitive, in which employment is growing, and especially the prospects of young people. A Union that encourages the balanced development of Member States, which builds the economic, social and territorial cohesion of our regions, a Union that provides security for its citizens, protects its external borders and is capable of responding to all security threats, a Union that invests in education, culture and Creation, research and development, which adapts to modern challenges and the digital economy, a Union that is financially stable, sustainable and capable of protecting citizens from possible financial crises, guided by the principle of solidarity and finally a Union which is a key political player in global governance, with defense capabilities, free trade promoter, leader in development assistance, environmental protection and the fight against climate change. In the next Multiannual Financial Framework, the basic principle of financing should be European added value. And therefore, we need to keep the elements of the existing system of own funds that work well and that maintain the principles of simplicity and transparency, and in the context of introducing new own funds, we should avoid creating an additional tax burden for citizens. Although Croatia is not yet a member of the euro area, Croatia wants to contribute to the further development of the economic and monetary union. In June 2017, we emerged from the Excessive Budget Deficit procedure and continue to implement a national reform programme aimed at accelerating real convergence towards the euro area and eliminating excessive macroeconomic imbalances. Joining the euro area is Croatia's strategic goal. The government and the Croatian National Bank presented a strategy for introducing the euro, which opened the process of public consultation. Today, Croatia meets almost all the criteria for the introduction of the euro and our goal is to enter the exchange rate mechanism, the so-called Exchange Rate Mechanism 2 as soon as possible. In January this year, the Croatian Parliament ratified the Treaty on Stability, Coordination and governance in the Economic and Monetary Union, and I had the honor of participating in December as the first representative of Croatia at the Euro Summit. In conclusion, I would like to point out that our dialogue on the future of the European Union is as important as the outcome of this process. We saw the reflection documents produced by the Commission, we listened to our citizens, and we talked to each other at the levels of parliaments and governments. Many ideas are discussed and different scenarios are being considered. Our path to the future should be a way forward and not backward. Croatia joined the European Union to be an active and responsible member and to work with other partners to further build and develop the European project. Croatia, which longed so much to be again a part of Europe, today wants to be a part of its inner circle. This is why I place emphasise on Schengen and the eurozone. This is the reason behind our decision to participate in permanent structured cooperation (PESCO), and the reason why our next goals are, as I have said, Schengen and the euro. I work wholeheartedly towards achieving these goals every day, together with colleagues in my government, convinced that this is in the best interests of Croatian citizens. In further building our future, equality is important to all of us: equality of states, citizens and opportunities. For the credibility of the European project and our reputation in the world, it is vital that we act as a family brought together by mutual trust. It is very important that Member States that have differences on bilateral issues approach them in good faith and constructively. Compromise is the building block on which European Union was constructed. Inclusiveness is also important for Croatia. No matter how fast or how much further we advance in these integration processes, each process be open to all members on equal terms. Our achievements are our strongest tools in building our common future. They need to unite us because we can move forward only if we stand together. A strong Europe primarily also means strong Member States, but, at the same time, the pooling of sovereignty at the level of the EU makes our countries stronger, for their benefit and for the benefit of our fellow citizens across our Member States. We also want strong European institutions which, on the basis of their Treaty powers, work for the benefit of every citizen of the Union. In that respect, Croatia is looking forward to its Presidency of the Council, in two years' time in the first half of 2020, as an opportunity further to build and promote the European project. Our priorities will be growth, development, connectivity, security and enlargement. I look forward to working with Romania and Finland — in the trio — and in intensive cooperation with Parliament. Croatia will be taking over the Presidency after the formation of new institutions and our task will be to bring forward new ideas in the period lies which lies ahead of us at the beginning of the next decade. With its values and freedoms, quality and way of life, and the highly competitive social market economy, Europe needs to reassert as a role model that will inspire people across the world to build a better future. Dear friends, it is up to us all to deliver. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr Prime Minister, thank you for emphasizing the importance of cooperation between your government, Croatia, and the European Parliament, which wants to continue to be central in the debate on the future of Europe. During his speech, Prime Minister Plenković put a number of problems on the table which will then be at the heart of the debate that will take place. The first comment is that of the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, to whom I gladly give the floor.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Commission. — Mr President, honourable Members, it is a great pleasure to welcome my good friend Prime Minister Andrej Plenkovič to the debate today. I knew him when he something about Influential Member of this House and of his Parliamentary Group. Andrej, we miss you in this House, but we welcome you in your new function, which is not as new as it seeems because you have established a Europe—wide reputation. Thank you for being here today. Croatia is both an example and an inspiration for what our Union Should aspire to be in the future. Croatia is a young member — not a new member but a young member — of the European Union, but a nation with a long and inspiring history; a nation which has shoot courage in self-defence and show construction when it comes to Europe. With growth now above 3% in 2017 and unemployment set to fall by six percentage points from 2016 to 2019, Croatia is a symbol of what can be experienced by working together in our Union. Working together in our Union is another way to address the budgetary problems we have to face. J'aime bien la rhétorique enthousiaste de presque tous les governments — il y a des exceptions tout de même — lorsqu'il s'agit de l'organisation de l'avenir de l'Europe. Or, il faut mettre en concordance les discours et les réalités budgétaires. L'Europe, telle qu'elle est, avec les aspirations qui sont les siennes, avec les ambitions qu'elle Nourrit, avec les ambitions et les obstacles qu'elle proclame, ne peut pas vivre à l'intérieur du carcan actuel de l'organisation budgétaire. J'ai été longtemps premier ministre et ministre des finances, donc je ne plaiderai pas pour une augmentation du budget sans bornes et sans limits. Tel n'est pas mon propos. Mais je voudrais que nous nous mettions d'accord au cours des onze mois à venir, sur les objectifs de l'Union. Il faut d'abord se mettre d'accord sur le contenu et ensuite sur les chiffres. Je n'aime pas ce débat qui consiste à fixer des limits budgétaires sans avoir évacué — si j'ose dire entre nous —, le débat sur les ambitions futures de l'Europe. d'Abord le contenu, puis les chiffres et non le contraire. Par conséquent, concentrons-nous sur le contenu de nos politiques. (Applaudissements) Évidemment, il y a unanimité au Conseil. Les uns disant qu'ils ne veulent pas payer plus et les autres disant qu'ils ne veulent pas recevoir coins. C'est une équation qui ne fonctionnera pas. Il faudra faire des économies réelles dans plusieurs domains, mais des économies qui ont un sens. Il faudra Traduire en chiffres les politiques de cohésion et la politique agricultural commune. Mais je m'incris en faux contre cette volonté stupide, passagère, irréfléchie qui consiste à organiser un attentat sur les politiques de cohésion et sur la politique agricole commune. ça ne fonctionnera pas et la Commission ne suivra pas ce chemin. Mais là où des économies intelligent peuvent et doivent être faites, nous ferons des propositions dans ce sens. Andrej Plenković a cité plusieurs exemples de politiques de cohésion intelligent. Évidemment, la Commission accompagnera favorite, en mettant à disposition les fonds néessaires, ce project concernant le pont Pelješac. something like that... but we know where it is, and we will support this project, as we support everything which is being done in Dalmatia. Thesis are important Croatian and European projects, and the review for the next budgetary period cannot have as an aim a reduction of the support we are providing for this important Croatian and European project. (Applause from one person) Is there only one Croatian in the room? We want to do it, even without applause. (Applause) You are welcome. Oui, si j'annonçais le financing d'un pont sur la Seine, tout le monde applaudirait, mais ce project en Croatie est aussi important que ceux réalisés en Europe occidentale. Il ne faut pas oubier le développement des nouveaux pays Membres. I wanted a sentence on the enlargement policy of the European Union Union say. We will talk about this today at the Commission meeting, which starts at one o'clock. That's why I'm in a bit of a hurry, because I have to prepare this. We are going to set the Balkans strategy today. I would like to say a few words in this context. It is wrong to say that I or the Commission had said that by 2025 the accession of Serbia and Montenegro must be under the roof. No, this is an indicative date, an encouragement date, so that those concerned will set out consistently. I said when I took office that there would be no enlargements before 2019. This has caused excitement here in the house, which has caused excitement throughout the region. And now this indicative date for Serbia and Montenegro — these are the two most advanced countries — is causing excitement. You have to choose: either or. Either you want enlargement to the Western Balkans and with the Western Balkans, or you don't want it. I would like the Western Balkans to be able to join the European Union if the conditions are met. They are not at the moment, and they are all still far from meeting the conditions. But we need to tackle our partners in the Western Balkans in a handful manner, we must help them to take this difficult path. Croatia has been able to take this difficult path successfully. However, I would also add, given this problem, the border conflict between Croatia and Slovenia, which needs to be resolved — and this is a bilateral problem, but it is also a European problem. The Commission has offered its assistance. This outstretched hand is received only by finger. This problem between Slovenia and Croatia must be addressed as a matter of urgency. (Applause) And the Commission — I agree with Andrej and others here on this — will make an offer to solve this problem. But I Add, also in view of this problem: there will be no further accession of the Western Balkans without the border conflicts being resolved beforehand. (Applause) This game, which consists of saying, “We'll solve the problem sometime after joining,” won't happen a second time — not with me. These problems must be resolved before accession or no further accession will take place. In this respect, Croatia and Slovenia have a responsibility here. The problem must be solved before any other accession occurs. I wanted to make this clear here. Just as clearly and clearly — and I am grateful to Andrej for saying this — I would like to comment on the question of the top candidates. I have an almost established impression that some in the European Council are attributing this tiny democratic progress, which some of us shared responsibility to each other, to what was the state of the Treaty in 1957. We are in 2018, we need more democracy, and I am working very energetically and vigorously to ensure that there will be a top candidate of the major political party families in the next European elections. Whoever turns this back... (Applause) I'm just saying: the danger is great. Although we in this House — most of us — believe that we need these top candidacies, there is almost a majority in the European Council — as I feel, predict — almost a majority against this. This is a conflict between the political parties. This would be a conflict between this House and the European Council, and we must overdraft this conflict in such a way that what we have achieved in 2014 will take place again in 2019, irrespective of the Commission's record. And there is no contradiction between the idea for which I expressed my sympathy, the transnational lists and the Top nominations. Anyone who sees the area of conflict here is — yes — in favour of transnational lists, but actually opposed to the innovation of the top candidates that we introduced in 2014. And that is why we must be close together in terms of top candidacy. We have to do this because this is about the democratic substance of the European Union.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you President. The European Parliament shares the position in favour of Spitzenkandidat — I will repeat it to the Council at the next meeting of the European Council — as we share the position on a budget European Union politician. It's not a matter of money, it's a matter of priorities to choose. There will soon be a series of reports on own resources, and for example we want all businesses to pay in the same way. Web giants cannot be privileged over other businesses. Now let's start listening to representatives of political groups. The first to speak is Mr Manfred Weber, on behalf of the Group of the European People's Party. (The system for electronic recording of requests for the “catch the eye” is closed)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome Prime Minister Plenković. It is a great thing for us to welcome him back again to this Chamber. And Prime Minister, I would like to thank you, first of all, for your commitment today to your and our vision of a democratic Europe. Your clear idea that Parliament is the place where we decide, especially on the Commission President, is absolutely crucial and clear, and I hope you can convince a lot of your friends and colleagues in the European Council, in a few weeks’ time. Croatia is our newest Member State but Croatia is already a key driver for European integration. Croatia’s achievement proves to all in the region that, through hard work, persistence, political courage and determination, EU membership is not only within reach but also of great benefit to all of us. Croatia is a success story and a model for a lot of Balkan states, so congratulations on what you have achieved, Prime Minister. Colleagues, the idea of today’s debate on the future of Europe with Andrej Plenković (last time it was with Leo Varadkar) is to talk more generally about the future of this continent, our continent, and I want to talk today about identity. I want to talk about nations. For the PPE Group, it is clear that the nation states are the fundament of Europe. Europe is not possible without national pride, the history of our countries and the cultural heritage of our nations, but I think there is more when we talk about identity. When we look at the people of Scotland, South Tyrol, Sicily, and the Basque region, they feel they are British, Italian or Spanish citizens but they are also rooted in their regions. There is a double identity on this continent, so why should there be only national pride? Why should it not be possible to combine this with regional and European pride? Here, in this House, and all over Europe, many politicians from the extreme right are telling people that their nation is the only thing, and to hell with Europe and Brussels. Politically, this is one of the key questions we have to answer in the debate about the future of Europe. I give a clear and personal answer: Bavaria is my home – hundred and fifty years ago we were an independent kingdom as Bavarians. Germany is my nation, with all the beauty and richness of the German culture, but also the unthinkable barbarism of the Nazi time. And I am a European. With heart and mind I love and live the European way of life and I will not allow any extremist or nationalist to hold these identities in contradiction: they belong together. (Applause) Let us look at Croatia when we talk about this. Croatian history has proved over the last centuries that neither big trading powers, such as the Venetian Duchies, nor big empires, such as the Ottoman Empire or the Austro-Hungarian dynasty, nor deals between powerful states behind closed doors at the Vienna Congress, nor fascists nor communists have guaranteed Croatia’s independence and interests. Only a democratic Europe, acting together, has been able to protect self-determination, security, peace and prosperity for the Croatian people. Croatia is the best example when thinking of the future of Europe together as a national identity. There is another important point. Let us imagine for a moment that the nationalists had won – Europe without a European Union, without Brussels or Strasbourg. Does anybody think that medium-sized and small Member States would then have any influence? Prime Minister Plenković has a say today in the European Council because a unanimous decision is necessary. Without such structures and without the European Union, I am sure that an intergovernmental Europe would be organised and led only by Germany, France and a few of the other nations. That is not the idea of Europe. We are equal, we are all Europe, and that is our future idea. So the nationalists are stupid and naive. They have not learned from history and they weaken the power of their own people. Everybody who believes in strong nations must be in favour of a united and democratic Europe. I spoke about identity and I want to add another aspect. When you fly from Lisbon to Tallinn, or when you fly from Helsinki to Sicily, you see a lot of diversity: food, music, languages and traditions. Our continent is so rich and so colourful, and I like it, but we have one thing in common: in the middle of every village, town and city, with only a few exceptions, there is a Christian church. Christmas, Easter and Pentecost are holidays we all share. We have to stick to our Christian heritage. Our democracies, welfare states and social market economies came into being only because of our Christian values of responsibility, solidarity and freedom. We have to protect our European way of life by preserving our Christian values. It is clear that faith is a private thing, but for our societies, and for Europe, there will only be a Europe that sticks to its Christian heritage, or no Europe at all. (Applause from the PPE Group)

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome Prime Minister Plenković back to the European Parliament. Prime Minister, you came to discuss with us the future of Europe and to do this we must know where we come from. Like many of us, you come from a region, the Balkans, which has been at the centre of European history. I would even say it has been its destiny region. Its history has taught that peace in Europe can never be taken for granted. The Balkans also tell us that history does not provide the answers. Moving forward means no longer being obsessed with the wars of the past. A European perspective for the Western Balkans is the right answer. Our Group is supporting this endeavour by the Commission. From your government, Prime Minister, we expect a clear commitment to peace in the Balkans and respect for neighbouring countries’ borders and integrity. We also call on Croatia to respect arbitration decisions between Croatia and Slovenia. History teaches us that a good future is not possible with extreme nationalism and racism. I am deeply worried by the recent racist attacks in Italy and I am sad to say that they could also have happened in other Member States. Our Union is not just a market: it is built on values, the rule of law and democracy, and it does not always deliver. A European democracy needs more open and inclusive institutions. We need bold decisions in order to overcome mistrust and apathy. Let us give our electorate the opportunity to choose a transnational list, giving people the right to choose this democracy. We also support the idea of a Spitzenkandidat for the Commission Presidency, as it improves participation, but we should not be obsessed with institutional reforms. Sometimes it is hard for ordinary people to follow what we are discussing. Institutions must serve the people’s interests and not the other way around. Europe has to deliver by changing our lives for the better. Too many people in Europe are unhappy with the status quo. They want decent jobs, safe pensions and fair treatment when they are sick. All of us want a good future for our children. It is time to engage for a more social Europe, with a European minimum wage, with no social dumping, and with better and longer maternity and paternity leave. This is why the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) will be crucial. Brexit cannot be an excuse to undermine the European budget. The Union must have more resources, its own resources, in particular to accompany the ecological transition towards a new, more sustainable development model. There is no future for a continent when too many young people are stuck in precariousness and unemployment. We need to invest in the future. We need a strong initiative for public investment and we have to rethink the dogma of austerity. After Brexit, a new-found awareness of the importance of the European Union is growing. We cannot disappoint our citizens again: they will not give us a second chance. We must deliver now, but we can do so only if we are looking forward – not looking to the past – and in a courageous and inclusive way. (Applause)

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: on behalf of the ECR Club. — Mr. President, Honored President of the Croatian Government, colleagues and colleagues, it is my special honor and pleasure to discuss the future of Europe with the Prime Minister of the country from which I come. This is the first time in this way we have exchanged views with the leading man of the Croatian executive on the challenges facing the European Union. Croatia has long been coy when it comes to European issues. I am extremely pleased that this government has changed that and that it is seeking to pursue a proactive policy at a European level. As an MEP, I can testify to very constructive cooperation with state institutions on many issues that are important for Croatia and the European Union, which was often not the case before. This government is finally thinking in European frameworks, but I'm afraid it has still failed to convince citizens of the importance of their participation in European policies. Accordingly, Croats are poorly taking advantage of the benefits of membership in the Union and this is a challenge we have to work on. Unfortunately, for most Croatian citizens, life has not changed for the better since 1 July 2013, so it is understandable that they do not consider membership in the Union a particularly success. Of all the members, Croatia is behind Croatia only Bulgaria, which is slowly catching up with a higher growth rate. In its Country Report, the IMF writes that the process of implementing structural reforms in Croatia has slowed down after joining the Union and that the investment climate is poor compared to comparable economies. In such circumstances, we should not be surprised that citizens do not show a greater interest in European policies, institutions and elections. That is why, Mr. President of the Croatian Government, I would like to encourage you to continue to change these unfavorable circumstances and not to stop in implementing reforms. It will sound a little incredible to many, but for the future of the European Union it is of great importance that countries such as Croatia are satisfied with it. States that have no imperialist ambitions, but their voice in the world can be boosted by membership of the Union. Countries that are not had a large and rich market, and by joining the Union they got exactly that. States whose citizens have felt dictatorship and authoritarian rule on their skin and in the Union still see freedom from repression and high democratic standards. If Croatia and its members sharing similar problems of the past and the challenges of the present in the Union do not see the added value and embodiment of their decades-long aspirations, then it has no future. If the European Union is a playground only for the great and powerful who will impose their will on the smaller and weaker, it will never fulfil all its potential. That is why, Mr. President of the Croatian Government, I hereby invite you to articulate at the Brussels table an authentic Croatian position that will not follow preset models and other people's ambitions. May all your initiatives be the fruit of the will of Croatian citizens who want a strong Europe, but not without a prosperous, stable and sovereign Croatia.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Prime Minister, I will not go too far in history to praise the European vocation of Croatia like my dear friend Manfred Weber, but I have a few shorter sentences about that. I did campaign in Croatia in 2014 together with Nino Jakovčić, so I have seen in Istria in Croatia how all these new companies raise the growth that is there since the entry of Croatia into the European Union. I mostly visited wine estates with him, I have to tell you, but it is impressive what is happening economically in Croatia. I will pick and choose two points on the reform of the European Union. The first is on the new financial framework.  It is clear that it is a crucial thing and I ask one thing of the Council, to accept that in the future it cannot be as in the past. This Parliament will request a say on the expenditure and on the income. It has to be finished that this is the only parliament worldwide that has no say on the income of the European Union. That has to stop now. This is a full parliament and we will have a Multiannual Financial Framework in which both Council and Parliament, based on proposals from the Commission, will be responsible.  The second thing is the Spitzenkandidat. You were a Spitzenkandidat, Mr President, and I think you have said exactly what is at stake. The Spitzenkandidat is a gain in the democratic process and we cannot lose it. In my opinion, the best way not to lose it is to embed this system in a democratic process. Because Spitzenkandidaten where there is a backroom deal inside a political party or between political parties – I can tell you – people are not very involved in this. You need to involve the citizens. You need to give them the possibility to vote directly for a Spitzenkandidat, not only a Spitzenkandidat from their country, but the Spitzenkandidaten from other countries, so all Europeans have to have this possibility. Therefore, I think it is necessary to embed the Spitzenkandidaten in transnational lists, the first on the transnational list is the Spitzenkandidaten. That is the system and it gives the power to the citizens to vote for him. So there is no contradiction between both concepts. I think, Manfred, this Parliament has to unite between both concepts and if we do not do it, we risk losing everything in this fight and that we cannot afford in the European Union.  Finally, my third point on the Western Balkans. We are all in favour, my Group is in favour, of the entry of these countries under the conditions set by the Commission and, in that respect, I hope that Croatia can, again, with their Slovenian friends, give a good example, and find a fast—track solution for the border issue as fast as possible, based on the arbitrage that has been made.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (GR) Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome to Parliament. Mr Juncker, ladies and gentlemen, no one can conceal the institutional, social and political crisis that the Union is experiencing. If the impoverishment of peoples, high unemployment - particularly among young people, lack of solidarity, large democratic deficits, xenophobia and racism could be concealed, we would not even have this debate today. We need an immediate change of direction from the policies of austerity and unbridled market freedom, from the policies of militarisation and lack of social solidarity. The austerity policies imposed on the peoples through the coordination of the economic policies of the Member States and the discipline of economic indicators at all costs are pushing the Member States into a continuous “dismantling” of the social state. The proposals put forward, for example on an economic suprise, will unfortunately lead to a deepening of anti-democratic and unpopular economic governance for the euro area and will perpetuate the widening of social inequalities in the European Union. The Commission's declarations so far on a social pillar of the European Union and on social justice have proved to be a smokescreen. The recent results of the discussions on the European Social Pillar, among the Heads of Member States of the Union in Göteborg, are a social 'placebo', as the European press has aptly described it. There is no legal commitment to the Member States and not a word about the human right to decent work. On the contrary, measures are being promoted towards further liberalisation and deregulation of industrial relations. In this neoliberal and antisocial context, xenophobic racist movements are exploiting the humanitarian crisis caused by neoliberal austerity policies through racist rhetoric. They are capitalising on the impoverishment of workers, the contraction of the social state, the continued reduction of wages, pensions and labour rights, and they are making new electoral victories by strengthening their strength. Refugee streams are treated with violence and inhumanity. Thousands of refugees are left to their fate, left to drown in the Mediterranean, while the Union raises new walls by creating a fortress Europe. At the same time, wars in our region are intensifying, the most recent example being Turkey's attack on the Afrin region in Syria. Ladies and gentlemen, in the face of this all-out attack on the peoples and workers, the positions of the GUE/NGL remain positions of principle. We call for the immediate lifting of neoliberal austerity policies. The peoples need public investment that will create decent new jobs with full workers' rights, through re-industrialisation and support for the real economy. Only such policies will strengthen the social state and allow social development. At the same time, we are calling for a common, human and permanent asylum system that guarantees human rights and human dignity. A system that will ensure legal and safe routes for refugees, humanitarian visas and strengthening family reunification, and equitably distribute the burdens of refugee flows. The new defence policy announced last summer to strengthen the defence industry serves only to strengthen NATO's operational capability and to participate in new interventions and warfare. The example of the Turkish invasion of Afrin, Syria against the Kurds, where the Turks fight and attack with German tanks and the Kurds defend themselves with German anti-tanks, is typical. This is where further militarisation and support for arms exports leads; new wars and new wars conflicts. Ladies and gentlemen, the neoliberal recipes of austerity, memoranda and the prevalence of the laws of the market and militarisation have been tested and failed. It is the policies that caused a humanitarian crisis. The future of Europe lies in social development, social justice and solidarity. It is in the further involvement of citizens, by strengthening the powers of the European Parliament, as well as by strengthening and expanding civil liberties. It is in peace and peaceful coexistence, both within and outside the Union.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Prime Minister to Parliament and to thank him very much for joining this debate about the future of Europe.  Prime Minister, I think it is particularly nice to have this debate with the Head of the newest of all the Member States, as one would think that the newest Member State would have the most to say about the future. But, unfortunately, it seems that many in your country – and also many in your party – are actually holding on to the past. While it is of course important to remember the past and to learn from it, it is also important to make peace with previous enemies. After all, this is what the European Union is all about. We have learned from the past, and we have decided never again to allow war to happen. We want to finally overcome nationalism, and we want to prosper together with our old enemies. I hope that Croatia will do the same, and that especially you – as the leader of the country – will do your utmost to overcome the shadows of the past.  The future of Europe, as I see it, lies in creating the future of the people who live in Europe. This means enhancing their quality of life, improving social policies, and guaranteeing human rights. When I say human rights, I mean the rights of all humans. I am sad to see that, despite the economic improvements in Croatia that have already been mentioned, social inequality seems to be increasing rather than decreasing. This is a trend that we see in many European countries, and it is a trend that we urgently need to address. Refugee rights are human rights too, and I hope that you, Prime Minister, will not allow push—backs to happen in the future and that you will investigate the push—backs that have already happened from Croatia. Regarding women’s rights, it is 2018, and Croatia – together with other Member States – has unfortunately still not ratified the Istanbul Convention. How can it be that there is even a question about whether we should protect women from violence? How come this is still a debate? How come we are not moving on with this?  Finally, the future of all of us depends on how we treat our planet. Croatia is an example of a beautiful, resourceful country that can really show other European countries the way ahead. You said that you want to be on the energy map. I think Croatia has plenty of resources to be on the map of renewable energies and to be at the forefront. Therefore, I would urge you to reconsider your plans for those LNG terminals in the northern Adriatic, and also to reconsider some other huge development plans – like golf courses – because those would hurt not only the environment, but also local businesses. Be the example: show the way to do economy and ecology together. Europe can learn a lot from Croatia, but for that you need to be ambitious. The future of Europe is built by Europeans. It is what we make of it. I believe that civil society is a very important partner in this aim and needs to be supported. We should strive to end hate in Europe, to overcome nationalism and to strive together for a better and a common future. Your country, with its history and its geographical position, can be a prime example for all of that. The future can be bright, but only if we make it so.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — It is good that, at last, at least, the future of the European Union is being discussed. This is clearly finally acknowledging that the present is not so good and it does not satisfy us. Problems with migrants, social exclusion, unemployment, many others, the more we discuss, the more these problems become clear, sometimes exacerbated. But only three hours once a month of such discussions in the European Parliament as the head of government of one country is, in my understanding, too little. The approach of the Head of Government of the twenty-seventh country of the European Union to the problems and the sharing of proposals with the European Parliament at the earliest spring of twenty years. Do we have so much time for discussions alone? And while it was mentioned that the Prime Minister's approach would be, it is still very interesting to hear what exactly Mr Prime Minister thinks about the creation of a European Security and Defence Union. I have understood that you are in favour of increasing the scope and effectiveness of defence costs. Or maybe it's better to invest in education, culture, social activities, science, sport? What about globalisation, Prime Minister, do you treat it positively or negatively? Should the European Union not defend small countries like your Croatia and my Lithuania? Could you present your concrete approach to the aspiration for Catalonia's independence? Would you see the position of the European Union as a gendarman of nations or would you advocate democratic processes? Do you support the introduction of a single European currency in all Community countries? It would be good if we were to think together about tackling demographic problems and promoting birth rate. How not languages, but real solutions to reduce youth unemployment? And the ball of problems caused by migration — what's the solution? Democracy problems should not be forgotten either. In the countries of the Community, it is necessary to hold referendums on the future of the European Union, at least on the direction of whether people are in favour of strengthening the union of autonomous states, while maintaining strong and sovereign national states? Do you want a new European federation without autonomous states? I believe that the upcoming elections to the European Parliament next year are just an excellent opportunity to hold such a referendum in each country.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have the impression — between smiles, congratulations, applause — that there is someone who remembers the orchestra playing on the Titanic before the boat sank. I'm worried, as a dad before I was an Italian citizen. I feel someone says more immigrants have to be taken in. Croatia want to enter the euro and enter the Schengen system. Be careful! In Italy, over the last few years, 600 000 fake refugees have landed, not from the war but that the war brought us home. In one year, crimes carried out by foreign nationals were 250 000:55% theft, 51% exploitation of prostitution, 45% of extortion, 40% of rapes, i.e. 1 500 rapes in one year. What about Europe that does? Nothing, indeed recognizes the figure of the climatic immigrant, as if we don't have enough problems already. I felt the hypocrisy of the abuse of the words “democracy and human rights”, while in the past few hours the Turkish dictator Erdogan, dictator of that country whom someone would like to join the European Union, was welcomed with all honours in Rome. I remember that this country does not recognize the genocide of one and a half million Armenian citizens, the first holocaust in history, and therefore I am ashamed at the sole idea that such a dictator could quietly be greeted with all the honours in a country like mine and that someone thinks Turkey can enter Europe, unless there are series A deaths and series B deaths, and among the dead of series B the Armenians and maybe the Italians infoibed by communists and partisans titini forgotten by everything and everyone. We are bad on immigration and we are worse at work: 30 million unemployed in Europe, 3 million unemployed in Italy, 5 million poor people in Italy, 3 million workers exploited in black. And Europe, governed by the Juncker Commission, obviously helps the big ones and slaughters the little ones. What you could wait for different from someone who has been for almost twenty years in government of a tax haven like Luxembourg, which helped multinationals evade paying taxes where they had to pay them, slaughtering artisans, traders, professionals and small business owners. And then comes the banks directive, which helps German banks, comes the Bolkestein directive that helps multinationals. We're with the little ones, President. We would like to defend our agriculture, our rice, our oil, our milk, our wheat, our fish and our way of life. I heard the group leader Weber, who gave a good speech. There are more homelands, there are more peoples, there are more feelings of belonging. The problem is not populism, nationalism, xenophobia and racism. The number one problem right now is Islamic terrorism and unemployment that is leading peoples to fight back. Someone is afraid of elections. Someone fears the election. Someone fears elections and the vote of Italians. It means you have a problem. If you are afraid of the free vote of citizens, it means that this EU is the Titanic that is sinking. We will put it all: Either Europe changes or the peoples will change it, starting from 4 March in Italy. For someone comes first the bankers, multinationals and immigrants, for me and the League come first the Italians. Thank you and best wishes to everyone, we need it.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr. President! Speaking of the future of Europe, the main question is: should we continue on the Lisbon road, towards increasingly robust integration, or do we need cooperation to keep Member States' autonomy better? The answer must be made in the light of Brexit. Syed Kamall, Head of the European Parliament for British Conservatives, said that the departure of a Member State must lead everyone to a deep reflection on the state of the European Union. Excessive centralisation of powers for the benefit of the institutions is a problem, the citizens of the Member States do not feel the European Union as their own. In recent years, referendums and elections have shown that the peoples of Europe reject the model of a federal state. The Union should respect its Member States and become a community of cooperative nations. On the other hand, Martin Schulz said that the United States of Europe must be created by 2025, and those countries who do not want this should quit. A few words about who are pro-Europeans? Those who are on the Lisbon road are giving themselves the right to be pro-European, who are otherwise anti-European. A deterrent example of this was given by Manfred Weber in his current speech. Those who want more autonomy in the Member States have classified them as dangerous nationalists and summarised our perception in the following statement: we say hell with Europe. How dare you accuse us of this because we're on a different path? President Tajani, do you think it is possible to have a constructive debate in this Parliament about the future of the European Union if the leader of the largest faction qualifies those who have different views in such an exclusion manner?

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Prime Minister of Croatia. – Mr President, dear friends, thank you for the initial round of comments on the speech I delivered at the beginning of this great opportunity to discuss the future of Europe with you. Several points on several questions and comments. First, on Jean-Claude’s comment on balancing the enthusiasm, ambition and the financial realism of what we would like to see implemented, what policies should be the guiding lines of our project and which budgetary means we have available. The fact that the UK is leaving is – as I know thanks to my earlier position as a Member of the Committee on Budgets here – not a positive thing. It is a downside. Let’s be very clear about it: we have a downside. We all know that more or less 10 Member States finance around 80% of our budget. This is something we don’t widely publicise, but these are the facts, and the catch in the negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework will be how to fill in the void which will be there. Can we have enough resources to implement all the objectives of our policies? Will this require more contributions from all Member States? Are some countries willing to increase it or to remain in the framework of what they are paying or contributing today? The situation is not the same if you are looking at it from the optics of the countries which contribute with a substantial percentage, or coming from a country with more modest economic and financial abilities where the increase would not be so dramatic. So after the analysis which we have made in Croatia if there were an increased demand from our side we would be willing to do it, to be very clear at the beginning. When it comes to issues of enlargement, something that several of you have mentioned, if ever there was a policy or a dossier that we know more than well it is enlargement. It is a very positive coincidence for me that the Commission will come up with a paper during the college a few hours later, bringing forward, as you said, the indicative timeline for the countries that remain within the group that we called the Western Balkans. They are divided into three groups. Serbia and Montenegro as the countries that negotiate, Albania, our friends in Macedonia – who are now negotiating the issue of the name with Greece more intensively, and from what I understand, with a bit more optimism on finding a solution as the second group – and then Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Kosovo, as the final two. My country has no dilemma. First of all, we are helping all of them already. You are not aware of that, but so many Croatian experts are engaged in one way or another, transferring the freshest knowledge on the process of accession negotiations to all of our neighbours. We also know that, as Jean-Claude has said, the bilateral issues should not obstruct or slow down the process of any country’s accession to the EU. We know it better than you, if I may be very clear. Having spent basically my entire life dedicated to the objective that one day my country would be around this table, I know what it means to lose a couple of years in the accession process. In my modest assessment around five years were lost, due to two main reasons. One relating to the bilateral issues, and the other to wider international conditionalities. Five years from a historical perspective might not seem a lot, but it is an awful lot when you consider what it means to invest or lose in your economic, social development and take the benefits of EU membership. This is something I know well. That is why I see the role of my country as a bridge, as a facilitator and as someone who will advocate further enlargement. There is no dilemma for us: we want to follow up on what the Bulgarian Presidency is doing in Sofia in May and that is the EU-Western Balkans summit after 15 years when it was last held in Thessaloniki. The first one was held in Zagreb. I was one of the organisers of it. My ambition is to have one in 2020, twenty years later, and we are trying to give a push because having the future of our neighbours anchored in the EU is positive for Croatia. It will help us to address all the residual and open issues which stem from the times when Croatia, as I said at the beginning, was a victim of aggression. That’s why we will do our utmost to help all of our neighbours, especially Bosnia and Herzegovina. Here we all have a historical responsibility, and that is why I mentioned it at the beginning, to safeguard the full equality of all the three constituent peoples and all other groups in the country. When it comes to the issue of Slovenia, which you have raised, Slovenia is a friend of Croatia. It is the only country in our history, over many centuries, with which we have never had any conflict, which is rare in our part of the world, almost an exception. This is not perhaps the best forum or the place to go into details of our border issue, but what I would like to stress here is my government’s readiness and openness to solve this issue in a manner which would be acceptable for both countries, taking into account the interests of both Slovenia and Croatia. That is what I proposed to Miro Cerar about a month and a half ago, because at this a moment we have a good opportunity to do it. At the same time, those of you who are following this in a little more detail will know that Croatia’s Parliament has withdrawn from the arbitration process that was facilitated by the EU in 2009 in order to unblock 14 chapters of the accession negotiations at a time stalled by Slovenia because of the fact that it was unfortunately the Slovenian representatives who violated the arbitration rules and violated in international law. We were there in good faith and we were investing all our efforts in this. So what we need to do now is find a compromise where both Slovenia and Croatia can be happy. I am willing to do that. I have the courage to do it, but the only thing I cannot do is close my eyes and say ‘no, everything was okay’. This is something I cannot do. But what I can do is to refrain from any unilateral actions, refrain from making this state-to-state problem into a citizens’ problem. This is what I can do, and some of you know what I mean, and that includes fishermen. Because I do not think that is smart and that is useful. On the contrary, it can create an environment where it will be more difficult to achieve an agreement. So from my point of view, with a bit of patience, with a bit of a sense and sensibility we can make progress, while refraining from unilateral actions, because even if arbitration was to be considered under international law both countries have to agree for it be implemented. Things are relatively clear to all of those who know a bit more detail. I will do everything in my power to eliminate tensions and ensure that a solution is found. At the same time, let me be very honest and clear with all of you. There are so many other still open bilateral issues among many Member States and they never arrive on the table of the European Council, or the European Parliament. This is something we should remember. A few points on the social elements that you mentioned. On the social elements it was a very timely initiative that we had in Goteborg, initiated by Sweden. The social pillar principles, 20 of them, are items that we can all improve on a national level. I am in favour of social dialogue with our social partners, both at European and national level. We have taken account of the fact that minimum wages and the average salary have increased, and that major tax reform which we have undertaken at national level has had an overall positive impact on our citizens, including on the demographic issue by leaving more money to mothers and fathers, by via some additional allowances for those with children and larger families. These include subsidising interest rates on the housing loans and a number of other measures that we have taken in order to address the most critical issue, a structural issue affecting my society at least, and that is the question of demographic revitalisation. A few points on the Spitzenkandidaten and transnational lists. In the last elections in 2014 I was privileged to be on the list of the Croatian EPP family and I was always mentioning Jean-Claude at every single event we had – and he was more popular than he can imagine! But it took us a lot of effort to communicate to Croatian voters who Jean-Claude was. It wasn’t always easy, it took me a lot of effort, as Dubravka and Ruža and the others know, so my point is that we have to be realistic. We have different budgets for campaigning, we have different legislative frameworks for campaigns. We have an issue of accountability to our constituency. I am very much, as you can see, a pro-European leader of the Croatian Government, but I need to see that it is the right time and that there is sufficient preparedness. We need to look at things from all aspects. So I advocate the Spitzenkandidaten, absolutely. Are we ready for transnational lists, will they be adequately and fairly represented everywhere across the 27? For that I would need to see a little more concrete evidence that it is feasible. This is what I think from the experiences I have had personally so far and the consultations with my friends. A few points on the issues of climate change, renewable energy, and the protection of nature. You are right. We are lucky to have such a place in Europe, with all the benefits of being on the Adriatic and the Danube, being a country which is really rich in water and natural resources, but we are also aware of our energy needs. So we are looking at the ecological aspects of every single project in a very detailed manner in dialogue with local communities and in dialogue with the NGOs looking at various projects and various items. On the Istanbul Convention, which you have mentioned, few people know that Croat experts initiated the whole exercise within the Council of Europe just next door here. Here we signed it in 2013. I don’t know why the Social Democratic government at the time didn’t pass to the step of ratification. It remains a mystery to me because they had two years. What I have done is ensure we have completed the public consultation. The process of preparing the legislation to forward to Parliament is almost over. Unfortunately, the debate on this Convention which was there, in my view, to protect and prevent violence in the family – especially violence against women – has somehow acquired a different dimension in many public debates, a sort of gender ideology debate which is trying to put a different angle on the substance. I am willing to debate this within the Croatian Parliament, within the political parties and with the public, and try to distinguish the wood from the trees. This is my task ahead in the months which will follow. Finally, an issue of identity, which was rightly mentioned by Manfred, thank you very much. We have always longed to be part of this European project. It was on the lips of most of the Croats ever since we became independent in 1990. And therefore the national identity which we acquired, in terms of international recognition and finally having our own state after nine centuries, is very strong. We will nurture it and respect it Ruža, as you know. But at the same time, trying to build this European project from the perspective of a country that is aware of what war means – and luckily most of your generations in your Member States are not aware of this – gives me another argument that this very project should be strengthened by all means, and by consensus if possible.

name: Francis ZAMMIT DIMECH
text: — Sur President, huwa ta' unur u pjair li niddiscustu, fil-preżenza tal-prim Ministru tal-kroazja, it-theme tal-futur tal-ewropa. Naseb anki dak kollu li huwa qalilna dalgodu, dwar ir-referenza gall-waqga tal-ajt ta' Berlin u anki dwar il-valuri communion tagna, lili jfakkarni anki fil-kliem li kien qalilna preiżament wara l-kollass tal-kommu awtur Francis Fukuyama fil-ktieb tiegu, “The End of History”, “The great ideological struggles of the past were over, now that Western values have captured the world”. Il-futur tagna nemmen li jrid jibqa' marbut anki mal-geruq tagna, mar-reba fuq in-nazzjonaliżmu, mar-reba fuq il-fruntieri, mar-reba fuq il-firda u l-mibegda, mar-reba fuq dak kollu li totalitarjaniżmu. U galhekk nemmen ukoll li l-ewropa trid tibqa' t-tarka tal-valuri tagna, tal--arsien tad-drittijiet fundamentali tagna billi anki tkun marbuta ma' aktar opportunitajiet gall-futur tagna kollha.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear Prime Minister, it is a pleasure to see you again among us and it was also a pleasure to hear some of your statements. In particular, as many Members have pointed out, we have a big problem on the future budget of the European Union if we want to ensure, at the same time, traditional but important policies such as cohesion and the new policies we are committing to.
