It is therefore important to know that there is a willingness of Croatia to work together with the other countries for a reasonable increase in the budget in relation to the new functions. Secondly, thank you also for your strong support for the Spitzenkandidat procedure. We would be pleased, in favour of transnational lists, to explain how much the two things can be linked to Create a European political debate area in which everyone can participate. We voted that the number of candidates on the list is equal to that of the current members of the European Union. So the possibility for everyone is certainly there and I would be pleased to explain how this could be possible.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Prime Minister Plenković on becoming prime minister and say that we still miss him on the Committee on Foreign Affairs. I, too, regret Brexit as a destructive act against the EU, which – no matter how much reform it requires – is still the greatest peace and prosperity project. Alone, Britain cannot face the common challenges of climate change, mass migration or international terrorism, for example. The UK’s decision now to leave the single market and customs union will also weaken both parties, and poses big problems at the Irish border.  I also hope that the UK can stay plugged into security and defence structures by cooperating closely with PESCO, and as rapporteur of the Parliament for Montenegro, I also hope that the UK can stay engaged in joint projects in the Western Balkans. Stability in the Western Balkans must be a common priority for all of us. Lastly, I also see some merit in making European Parliament elections far more relevant to the people by the Spitzenkandidat process and the transnational lists.  Congratulations, and I think that Croatia is a great member of the European Union.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister: it is very nice to have, as the second Prime Minister, someone from a country like yours: someone from a country which is very close to me, and which has done a tremendously good job – I can see this, as a very frequent visitor and part-timer in your country.  Now, two points from my side. As concerns the Western Balkans, I think that not just among the Western Balkan colleagues here, but among many of us, you have full understanding and support: first point. On Schengen, once Croatia will complete and comply, it should be in: second strong point.  Finally, on the transnational lists, I understood the position you have taken – a position in terms of more debate, more clarification, right timing – but how would you see the process between now (the Spitzenkandidaten) and, in the future, transnational lists? What is it that we could fine—tune that the Croats and the Czechs could better understand the institute of the Spitzenkandidaten?

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome Prime Minister Plenković. As a country on Europe’s eastern border, it is regrettable that Croatia has played a role in the creation of ‘Fortress Europe’. ‘Fortress Europe’ has no place in our future and we cannot sit in a Brussels bubble, surrounded by sea and barbed wire, while those fleeing war and discrimination are turned away and forcibly returned to Turkey, Libya and Serbia, or worse still, left to die in our seas.  The future of Europe should also not include a Europe where minority populations continue to face persistent discrimination. Populations like the Roma and traveller communities are not treated equally in my own country, Ireland, or in yours, Mr Plenković.  The future of Europe should also be rooted in its history. The EU was established as a peace project but it is now paving a future for itself in militarisation and the war alliance of Permanent Structured Cooperation on security and defence. A militarised Europe will create a future with more insecurity, more wars and more money for war, at the expense of the social protections that Europe once treasured.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Prime Minister Plenković for joining us. Prime Minister, I would like to ask a couple of questions regarding the remarks you made on the budget.  You said there should be an intelligent way of dealing with the budget. Can you be a bit more precise? What would your intelligence tell us about own resources of the European budget? When you say no new taxes, where should we get new resources from? Maybe you have an idea. Also, where should we reduce expenditure? The President of the Commission has said we have to cut somewhat our expenditure on agriculture and on regional policy. Where is your priority for making cuts to free up resources for new necessary expenditure? Finally, what is your position on what some people call the ‘weaponisation’ of the European budget, meaning the proposal that the budget should be used to cudgel some governments into policies that are objectionable to the rest of us?

name: Marco VALLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sorry that there is no one from the Commission at this time to represent, because there are also very important points about the Eurozone that needs to be pitted. The future of the European Union also has as its core what is the future of the Eurozone and there are proposals on the pot that need to be pitted, such as turning the European Stability Mechanism into the European Monetary Fund. Many political groups are in favour of this initiative, but create tools to go finely to help states when they are in fiscal trouble without first creating the conditions to solve the heavy economic imbalances from which the Eurozone suffers are incomplete solutions. We would have to find ways to create tax transfers from surplus countries, such as Germany and Holland, and solve the problem of big tax havens, as you said too, President Tajani. Founding countries such as Holland and Luxembourg must contribute to this Eurozone situation. And then you have to find a solution for sovereign debt. We cannot suffer what are the conditions of the 2011 crisis yet. We need to find a solution because quantitative easing won't last forever.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome once again to the European Parliament. In the absence of time, I wonder how can there be a future in Europe when there is no solidarity between European countries? The example of Greece is typical, which the European Union has impoverished for eight consecutive years with the memorandum. How is it possible to make progress in Europe when the European Union forces states to impoverish their citizens? How is it possible to make progress in Europe when we cannot guard our national borders, which are - supposedly - guarded by the European Border and Coast Guard, and we cannot handle the problem of illegal immigrants? How can progress be made in Europe when in practice the Schengen Convention has been abolished? Finally, how is it possible to make progress in Europe when we want to accept Turkey which, apart from the genocide of the Armenians mentioned, is responsible for the genocide of the Greeks of the Black Sea and Asia Minor and at the moment does not recognise Cyprus? How is it possible, then, to make progress in Europe with all this?

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Prime Minister of Croatia. – Mr President, I have a few remarks on this first round of catch-the-eye. First of all, on the issue of defence, which Charles Tannock mentioned, I believe that strengthening European defence is very important, given the wider context of the challenges we have when it comes to security. Having seen what we have discussed over the past couple of years, one of the first things I did as Prime Minister was to put through the new national security strategy, a new system of homeland security, and to increase our defence budget. We are in the process of acquiring new jet fighters. I want to be a credible country with capabilities that can increase and be inter-operational with other allies within NATO and with partners in the European Union. That is why we are participating, with almost 450 Croatian military personnel, in various operations across the world, be it with the UN, NATO or the European Union. On the UK’s exit, I think the critical thing is to find what type of future contractual relationship we will forge between the United Kingdom and the EU. I think it was Walter Hallstein who said that association can be membership minus one percent, or cooperation plus one percent: that is a very large span for what we can put into the new contractual relationship. This is a choice. It is a political choice, in a strange situation, when someone is actually about to leave. In my view, that will be critical in the next phase of the negotiations with London. Regarding the Spitzenkandidat and transnational lists, I have a practical concern. The budget in my country currently for the whole list for the campaign is EUR 200 000. If a colleague wants to campaign he has EUR 200 000 for the whole length of the campaign. As a candidate, how do you think he will campaign in Turku, in Braga, in Palermo or somewhere on the shores of Bourgas in Bulgaria? He cannot do it. This is the problem. We should invest a little bit more practical thinking in this: probably increasing the limits of financing, finding ways to ensure that the new system not only underpins the person who is a candidate for the future presidency of the European Commission but also gives equal opportunities to someone from what I would call a ‘notorious’ political family or someone from a big country with a strong media presence, or someone from a smaller country. This is my concern and I do not see the answer in the debate so far. As I said, we need to have equal chances in this exercise. In my view, the way it is now being contemplated is not entirely fair. That is why I have very clear reservations at this stage. I am not saying we will not find a solution. When it comes to the Multiannual Financial Framework, you mentioned that I said we needed to find smart approaches. The smartest way is to know what you want, what your political priorities are, and then attach the financial means to those priorities. For a couple of years, I have been following the work of the group of experts led by Mr Monti – so often eloquently represented by Alain Lamassoure – on the reform of the own resources system. This is absolutely key if we want to avoid the debates that Mr Verhofstadt mentioned when we asked if it is the Council which decides on income and Parliament which decides on expenditure. This is essential. We always debate in the nitty-gritty negotiations and trilogues in a short time in order to achieve a political goal. Therefore, finding a balance between research, innovation, the digital economy, youth, jobs, and traditional policy areas, such as regional policy development or agriculture or defence, is always a challenge. I believe that if we understand what the challenges will be in the next decade we can find consensus, especially now when – after the 2016 blues, after the Brexit referendum and with the political developments in 2017, especially the enthusiastic approach of President Macron of France, and the likely formation of another German Government led by Chancellor Merkel – we have gone, in football terms, from a 0-1 to a 2-1 situation. That gives me hope and optimism for the strength of the European project, including the debate on the financial framework.

name: Ivo BELET
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Prime Minister Plenković for being in this House, which is very familiar to him.  Prime Minister Plenković, I would like to come back to the security issue which you referred to a few minutes ago. Of course, it is an important issue. Taking into account the international context, it is very turbulent and you already referred to this, but should we not accelerate our efforts to enhance defence cooperation? You referred to defence fighters but should we not invest more in common defence material, on a common platform, in order to be interoperable and to make the European defence capacity more robust? The advantages are obvious. The synergies are obvious. I think we can assume that citizens support it, so are you ready to support this line and really invest in initiatives in order to accelerate this common European defence initiative?

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, tax evasion and tax dumping among Member States – some transformed into tax havens or hubs for money laundering, crime and corruption, as LuxLeaks, Panama Papers and Paradise Papers show: this is what is fuelling growing inequalities and the consequent populism, nationalism and citizen distrust in the European governments and in the Union. So, Prime Minister, if you agree that the EU needs additional own-resources, is it not time for the Council to act for tax harmonisation – namely, setting a minimum corporate tax base to fight tax dumping in the unfair competition that is going on in the single market? And is it not smart, fair and necessary for the EU, in the context of the multiannual financial framework, to indeed enact the financial transaction tax that has already been agreed by 11 Member States and, considering the evolution of the digital economy, a tax on the robotisation of production? Would this not be also a way to regenerate income for Member States, and not just the Union?

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: — Mr. President of the Croatian Government, your personal contribution to the pro-European agenda in Croatia is a great deal. Your pro-European policy and views are known both in Croatia and in this home. Croatia's progress in structural reforms under your Government is visible in all segments of social development and these achievements strongly integrate Croatia into the European Union. The Schengen area is one of Croatia's priorities. Do you expect the Croatian approach to be realized for the mandates of this composition of the European Commission and the European Parliament? Protection of external borders, as you yourself said, is an important issue. Do you think that this Parliament and the Council should support that the entry and exit system for registration of entry and exit data of third-country nationals crossing the external borders of the Member States of the European Union should include the Republic of Croatia in implementation from the very first moment as it is primarily a security issue?

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister Plenković, welcome back to the European Parliament and welcome to this forum about the future of the European Union. We first heard Ireland – a veteran, 45 years in the European Union – and now we have Croatia, the newest accession. Both have histories of success and progress, most notably in the case of Croatia overcoming terrible episodes of war and conflict, which is yet to be completed, with the cross-border tensions with Slovenia. Many of us here are convinced that Europe, the European Union, has been in a protracted crisis, dragging its feet and hounded by nationalists, populists and europhobes. And do you know what? Many of us here think the problem is about the Council. It is about a lack of vision to face, in a European fashion, the eurozone needs, globalisation and, most notably, the refugee crisis. It is about a lack of solidarity, and also of backing for the democratic principle of Spitzenkandidaten and transnational lists. Many of us here in the European Parliament would uphold a majority backing this democratic principle. It is about time that the European Council did its part of the job. Is it ready to either go European or face nationalist regression? That is the question.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President; Prime Minister, welcome. I share your sorrow about Brexit. On the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity, I think that our lack of respect for both principles contributed to the effect of the referendum in the UK, rather than populism and external intervention. Unfortunately, it is still visible in the EU institutions. On foreign policy principles, I note that the Russian Ambassador receives royal treatment in the institutions, just as Moscow is a destination of political travellers, and unlike the treatment given to the Ukrainian Ambassador and Kyiv. Please ensure in Council that our focusing on the Western Balkans does not take other challenges off the European agenda.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: — Thank you for your speech, Mr. Prime Minister and welcome back to the European Parliament. I want to ask you three questions. Subsidiarity is a word you mentioned yourself. Your colleague, former president, Mr. Weber spoke of dual identities, regional and national. My question is do you really want to implement subsidiarity and do you see it as the right principle for the European Union, of course in that case for our country? As you have said yourself, a government that is closer to citizens can perform its obligations better. Another question is related to Uljanik, where you also played a significant role and I want to ask you globally, do you see shipbuilding as a true European industry where one product, which is a ship, will be a common European product? The third issue is related to the Western Balkans. In some ways I am sure that you will be one of those people who will advocate and be for the entry of all Western Balkans countries into the European Union, but I wonder and I would like to hear a political response what does Mr. President Vucic come soon to Zagreb mean and what does he bring to the Western Balkans?

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: — Of course, it's nice to talk about the future of Europe and Croatia, but we cannot pass the fundamental values without which the future of the European Union cannot and refuse to imagine, and among them is absolutely the rule of law, which is actually the foundation of European values and prerequisites for the realization of everything. And if we fall for the rule of law, we fall practically like Europe. I wish you, Mr. Hang. Plenkovic, so that you as Prime Minister, as you said, of the State of Croatia, would understand and actually add your contribution to the fact that, in the case and in the European spirit, the implementation of arbitration decisions is also handled in the case and in the European spirit, in the case of an arbitration decision between the Croatian and the Slovenian borders. This one, of course, is unambiguous, binding, outright, really judicata and we can't negotiate on it, of course, and also so I would suggest to Mr Juncker, who has offered his help, first of all, can of course help by clearly, unambiguously, without suppression that arbitration decisions must be made for all responsible members in the European Union.

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: — Mr President, we have five options ahead of us for the future of the European Union presented to us by the Commission. What have they in common? Fundamentally the common denominator is to keep power “in Brussels.” And I would like to ask that we extend the considerations with two other options as well. First, a responsible politician must always think about the crisis option and have a crisis scenario ready. And I wish, please, that we broaden the debate on considerations as well as such situations. And then please one more variant. Because we are still struggling with a demographic deficit and we should start a debate on the democratic scenario of the future development of the European continent. About a scenario that would be based on rational deregulation, a scenario in which it stops paying: “We know what's good for you, and we'll command you”, a scenario that will be based on that politicians will say to citizens and voters, “We will listen to you. “

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Prime Minister of Croatia. – Mr President, thank you very much for a series of questions on defence. Yes, Croatia wants the European Union to go in the direction of strengthening defence cooperation. If there is one area since 1993-99 that has evolved rapidly, it is certainly that one and, as I already said at the beginning, our commitment is strong and it is clear. The way we are building our own capabilities is in the direction that we are not there in a declaratory manner but in an operational manner. So from that point of view, a plus. When it comes to the Schengen entry-exit system, you know that we got the envelope when we were negotiating our accession of EUR 120 million to increase the capacities of the Croatian police, of the Croatian border system to surveil our borders and it is perhaps the best absorption of all the funds that we have. We have so far, at the level of contractual arrangements, about 50% above the total allocation for Croatia, which is just over EUR 10.3 billion. We have more or less contracted EUR 5.2 billion. When it comes to Schengen we have actually absorbed 98%. Given the migratory refugee crisis a few years ago we were the country that today looks at this issue in a way that our focus should be on protecting the external borders of the European Union, on preventing further migratory flows at the source of the crisis – failing states, wars, conflicts, poverty and other reasons why people are looking towards Europe from the continents which are around us. The entry-exit system, yes. Preparation for Schengen, whether it is formally within the mandate of this Parliament, I would be very happy if we could achieve that. We will try to do the maximum but you know it is a decision both of the Council and needing the support of the European Parliament. We didn’t opt for barbed wire on our borders but we are protecting our borders with our forces and strengthening our capacities if and where there is a need. When it comes to the issue of minorities, which was mentioned earlier by one of the colleagues, perhaps you don’t know, but the Croatian Parliament has a fixed quota for eight members of parliament from minorities – three from the Serbian minority, and today we also have representatives of an Italian minority. We have a representative of the Hungarians, of the Czechs, and of the Roma as well, which is very important because this was mentioned in one of the debates earlier where there was an insinuation that we do not protect the Roma minority enough. On the contrary, we have a special operational programme for minorities where we have invested a lot and one Albanian minority lady representative. Why am I saying this? All eight of those minorities are members of my parliamentary majority, which I personally wanted to be like that because I feel that the minorities in any European country, and especially in Croatia with all the historical legacies that we have, can better cater for their needs, their priorities and their position in our society if they are within the majority and influencing the policies of our country. That is why this is a very dear subject for me from a principle point of view, with all the European values always in mind. When it comes to the three questions of my colleague Nino Jakovčić: on subsidiarity, absolutely yes. You are aware that my ambition is to involve – first of all when it comes to the European national level and the multi-layered governance – the Croatian parliament more than before. That is why I am there every single time after I come back from the European Council. I spend hours trying to promote the substance of the European dossiers to the Croatian MPs and to the Croatian public. No one has ever thought of doing this before and not even deliberated it. This is an idea that I want, where the national parliaments have a role to play in our legislative pipeline, more than today. Second, on Uljanik and on the shipping industry and the shipyards in Croatia. In our accession process if there was one critical issue on the agenda it was in Chapter 8, it was competition, state aid, how to help the shipyards in distress. It actually cost a lot of money in the Croatian budget. Some of them are stable, restructured and ordering new ships. Some of them occasionally have difficulties in the market which has globally completely altered to what it was before. You know it and I know it. The decision on Uljanik was a political choice, as we were convinced that this shipyard in Pula – which is also the co-owner of a shipyard in Rijeka, the 3. Maj, and which employs together more than 5 000 people – has the potential to find a strategic partner, restructure and have long-term viability of production. This is why we believed it was a good choice, and that is why we explained to the European Commission to give us a go-ahead in this decision. On the visit of President Vučić, I don’t see that much mystification as is flowing around in the media. I see President Vučić almost every two months in various international fora. There are items on the agenda which should be addressed – the question of missing persons, border issues, war damages if you like, the laws which Serbia has passed in order to increase its jurisdiction when it comes to the prosecution of war crimes beyond its own territories... We have debated this in this House. I don’t want to enter into that. But there is goodwill on the Croatian side to sit down and try to understand how we can surmount the obstacles. This is the object. The normalisation agreement between the two countries dates from 1996. There are always political connotations when different personalities are involved, and this visit therefore has an extra careful element in the whole process of its preparation. On the arbitration and Slovenia, dear colleague Šoltes, you can present it the way you said: yes, everything was perfect, a textbook case, fantastic behaviour, never better, and we should definitely try to copy the process for all the other open border issues. I, unfortunately, cannot agree with that, and you know it. I am even hesitating to be as explicit as I perhaps should in this forum, but I will repeat to you again, let’s refrain from unilateral action. Let’s find a way for both Slovenia and Croatia to find a commonly acceptable fair and reasonable solution to the border issue. In my view it is an overblown topic both politically and in the media. Nothing dramatic has happened to any of our citizens. But that will happen if one of the countries chooses the path of unilateral actions and fines. This is something I really regret and it was not the choice of my country. The goodwill is there. I know that the Prime Minister Cerar and the entire Slovenian Government have taken some positions – there are elections very soon in Slovenia – but despite that, we are open for dialogue and also, if you like, some good ideas from our friends that might help us in that direction.

name: Henna VIRKKUNEN
text: — Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for a very good speech. Croatia is a success story in many ways, and it is great that you are ready to act as a bridge builder throughout the Balkans as your neighbours strive towards membership of the European Union. At the same time, however, when we talk about the future of the EU, I think that we must now tackle two issues in particular as members of the European Union. One of these concerns European values. We know that at the moment, unfortunately, we have Member States that do not adhere to our common values regarding respect for human dignity and human rights, freedom, democracy, equality and the rule of law, which are aligned as the main objectives of the EU. The second issue relates to the fact that once we have made a decision, Member States must comply with it. We know there are problems with this. Until these things are fixed, the EU will not be able to restore credibility. We need to be able to respond more quickly to these things, and now that the EU financial framework is being reformed, are you prepared that these countries, which do not comply with common rules, could also be cut in funding in the future?

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister. Prime Minister, I expect you to listen to what I say from my seconds, please very much. I appreciate what you said and the vision you presented corresponds to my vision, but you hesitated to say whether the current state of the nation corresponds to your vision. I am from Romania, we have 10 years of accession, you have used keywords here - subsidiarity, to act in the interests of citizens, Schengen area. I want to ask you... and maybe you're still listening to me... (President interrupted speaker) I did not finish, Mr President, because the Prime Minister does not want to listen to my speech. So, I ask you Prime Minister: do you believe that the current state of the nation corresponds to what you presented as a vision? We are talking here about subsidiarity, acting in the interests of the citizens, the Schengen area, the fact that we have a budget on the euro area and a budget on the non-euro area. Do we have one Europe or not? What is your opinion that there are stigmatised states, such as Romania and Bulgaria, which meet the Schengen area conditions and are not approved in the Council? What do you think of the fact that there is only for two states a MCV? What unity are we talking about and what to say to citizens, because you have used the terms 'to explain to citizens the benefits of the European Union'? I would like you to answer me in your speech.

name: Franck PROUST
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, the future of Europe is everyone's business and our role here is to tell the truth. To say what we have accomplished since 2014 and to say with lucidity what does not work, without hypocrisy. A recent example is the modernization of trade defence instruments. On this point, we have made progress in increasing our anti-dumping taxes, but the Member States have not assumed to abolish the application of the 'lesser duty', a symbol of naivety that takes away the truly punitive value from anti-dumping taxes. This “lesser right” should no longer be the rule but the exception in trade defence. This is the fight we have to fight. Between the dream and incantation of some and the extremist and populist dangers of others, there is a path of realism and efficiency, the one we defend. We refuse to see Europe move away from the peoples and say 'no' to the unnecessary, unfair and unenforceable gadget of transnational lists. We are one of those who act to ensure that Europe's action is tightened up on priorities. Either some still defend the soft consensus, or we are making the bet of a Europe that is moving faster, perhaps at different levels of integration, with strong markers to give visibility and legibility to Europe's action. Prime Minister, that is what our fellow citizens expect.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: — Your messages are extremely important today, especially in light of the strategy of enlargement to the Balkans. You know that we accept with concern your conduct of the Government following the decision of the arbitral tribunal between Slovenia and Croatia. You heard President Juncker that no other country will enter the Union again if it doesn't save borders. We have a solution, arbitrarily. This is not a question of some brand new compromise. What will be your message to the countries of the Western Balkans if Croatia does not respect the arbitration verdict and there will be no solution on the border? Will you take responsibility for the countries that will remain in front of the door? You guarantee that you are willing to do anything to get our country out of a situation that primarily harms our people, but today you have not convinced me. You know that Croats spend their holidays every winter at ski resorts, Slovenians on the Croatian coast and our common concern and responsibility is to maintain friendly and good neighbourly relations.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Mr Verhofstadt has drawn attention to the fact that this Parliament cannot have its own revenue. There is, however, a good reason for this, because this Parliament is not elected by the same election. Not all European citizens have the same say when it comes to revenue. There are six Members from Malta in this Parliament. If we were to elect Parliament by the same election, there would have to sit here about a thousand Members from Germany — relative to six Members from Malta. No Taxation without representation, that has been in place for 250 years. We have a gross distortion here — Parliament is not representative. That is why it makes sense for Parliament to receive its revenue from parliaments at Member State level which have been elected by the same election. This is important to remember. There is no right, no democratic legitimacy, for the taxation of European citizens based on the European Parliament. This right is at Member State level for good reason.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: — We were colleagues, it's probably a pleasure when you have more time in this plenary hall, I have one minute. At this minute, I would like to say that I congratulate Croatia for its success and believe that it can be a real example and invitation to all candidate countries seeking membership in the European Union. But I have to say some things about our bilateral relations as well. You have heard today the support of a large part of this Parliament resolving our bilateral, I would say redundant dispute on the basis of an arbitration tribunal. Of course, the arbitration tribunal is the one that decides this, but at some point the abuse was made or not, the court ruled that there was no such abuse that would make arbitration impossible, and it made a decision that you do not want to implement. I would say, Mr. Prime Minister, I invite you to solve this problem in the spirit of good neighbourhood, lasting good neighbourhood, and therefore we also need some respect for international law and the principles of good neighbourhood.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: — Mr. President, it's been a long time this morning, you had an excellent comprehensive opening speech and these answers. Less more you answered all the questions. I would like to congratulate you on the European vocation of Croatia, on your mainstream politics you lead. I hope you will not allow cheap populists and extremists to take the lead in Croatia, and at the same time I hope you will take care of national interests. Here you have repeatedly emphasized both Schengen and the eurozone. Of course I hope that by the end of the mandate of this Commission we will be in Schengen. I would also like you to explain a little better what the interests of Croatian entry into the eurozone are. You said we want to be in the inner circle of the Union and that is what you and we here insist on who support you. Also, you explained beautifully that all the benefits we have from the European Union, which is what Mr. Juncker mentioned, Peljesac Bridge, and he said that there would be applause here to build a bridge on the Seine, and we might not have reacted for the Pelješac Bridge. However, it is a big deal on the part of the European Union. Likewise LNG terminal and renewables for which we have already reached the levels we needed.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Prime Minister Plenković, I greatly appreciated your report and your speeches. His being deeply pro-European gives us the opportunity to reflect together with some optimism about Europe's future. In the uncertainty that reigns internationally, Europe has a duty to take the leading role at the world level, setting the way to confront fears and move forward with determination towards policies of the future, the path of which is already laid out. Inescapable steps for this objective are the adequate support for the conversion of the linear economic model towards the green economy and the circular economy and the achievement of greater social cohesion and economic. It is therefore obliged to address with determination the issues of immigration, fiscal fairness and the fight against inequalities which, if still ignored, risk undermining the tightness of the European Union. In this context, the role played by Croatia is a key role in promoting stability and peace in the Balkans, but also in addressing challenges with Italy and other Adriatic countries Macroregionals that we have in front of.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Croatian Prime Minister — Here is one answer in Croatian for my friends from Slovenia, since both Tanja and Ivo have reopened this issue of bilateral relations between Croatia and Slovenia, an example towards other countries. The position of Croatia is very clear and you know it very well. Whether we qualify something as a small abuse or a failure, as if skiing is at stake or are we going to say that this is a violation of international law, it is now up to the assessment of you or us, in terms of the Slovenian or Croatian side of what was in the arbitration process. What you also know, and we know, is that Croatia made the decision of the Croatian Parliament at the time I was in this forum, not in that convention of the Croatian Parliament and that it is unanimous and firm. That's why I said that this moment, when we have an arbitration judgment that you want to implement, and we don't acknowledge it, we need to find a political and legal way to reconcile those views and use the opportunity to resolve the border issue. What I also very clearly mean is that people who are neither Slovenes nor Croats understand, that this issue is being de-dramatized: it is not a question on which the fate of either Slovenia or Croatia depends. And that's why it was even strange for me to hear rhetoric about Slovenian laws that would take care of those Slovenes who stayed on the unhappy side of the border. I prefer to talk about Slovenia as a country that had the slogan Sunny side of the Alps. I don't see in that point. The point is that we are close, that we are friends, that we go skiing, and you come to the sea and I want it to stay that way. I do not want one problem, interstate, to be transferred to the level of concrete, ordinary people, and in this particular case, especially fishermen. And that's why I underline that we are open to both dialogue and agreement and to the solution of the issue, but that issue is not as dramatic as it seeks to portray it. This is what we managed in Croatia, for the first time in the last 25 years that we have not had any great drama in the Croatian public on this issue. It It hasn't happened to us yet, and you know what it's been like in the past years. Basically, we are here to solve the problem, but try to understand the realities of both political and legal, and factual, after all, that have happened. As far as these other topics are concerned, the issue of the rule of law which is trying to contextualize a little in this context is of course crucial and important for Croatia. This initiative was ultimately the fruit of the previous convention of the Parliament, the European Parliament and the previous Commission, and in some ways we continued it at this time. It is essential that, at national level and in dialogue, first of all with the European Commission, ways are found to address issues that we have different views and therefore believe that the mechanisms of dialogue available to us, in accordance with the contract, can lead to a solution. As for Bulgaria and Romania in Schengen, I already said in my opening speech that I support it, that I think it would be useful and good. You have this mechanism of cooperation and verification since 2007, when you became a member. Those of us who became later don't have it. We felt at that point that it was good not to have one because we have met the criteria for so long that we were convinced that such some kind of post-accession monitoring was not necessary for us and that we could find other ways to comply with our obligations and look at it so. And that is why I believe that your success according to Schengen would be our success, and we will fulfill the criteria as far as technical criteria, border control and guarantee the tightness of the external border of Croatia. Issues of populism and Euroscepticism, yes, exactly, I am very clear, and this is what I am saying in Croatia, a lawyer advocating for the political mainstream because it brings stability, predictability; continues on the basis of this European project built by our founding fathers and many politicians and parties and statesmen and parliamentarians who have built it for the last nearly seventy years. What we are witnessing, we are witnessing at the European level and at the level of all our debate, that many in today's digital communication space use all these means to market their ideas. Sometimes these ideas are not always supported by accurate and reliable information. I think for the future of our democratic debate, in general democratic processes, we must strive very well to distinguish between what is accurate and true and what is not. Here I see the key to a future democratic debate that will answer the issue of populism at the level of member states, which, as we know, is also reflected in European elections.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President! First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks for the speeches we have heard, which express a great European perspective. And I am also convinced that this European spirit will lead to ways to resolve the dispute between Slovenia and Croatia. After all, Europe's aim is to make borders insignificant. This may be a way for both nations to find each other and solve this. However, I would also like to make a comment on what Mr Lucke said: the European Parliament is fully legitimised; the Federal Constitutional Court has confirmed this. And we need to see that every state has two seats in the US Congress. Then the US Senate would not be legitimized to collect taxes. Here in Europe, we have a higher degree of balance between large and small countries in a two-chamber system than in Germany, for example. We do not have full parity of votes in the European Parliament. However, the larger countries in the Council are ultimately stronger than the smaller ones. This is not the case in Germany in the Federal Council. That is why we should not engage in such a detailed debate that the legitimacy of this European Parliament, elected by the people, is being called into question by the European people.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, you opened your speech on the added value for citizens of a country, including yours, membership of the European Union. You also touched on the question of your neighbourhood and you have been open, under certain conditions, to allowing these countries, in turn, to have access to the European Union — I thank you for that. The Balkan War, I want to say the wars, have indeed left traces. I know, as a member of the EU-Balkan friendships, all the questions asked about reconciliations and I am convinced that there is a path if there is will. I was able to recall at the last EU-Kosovo meeting that France and Germany were able to achieve this reconciliation in order to create the European Union, a union of peace, security, freedom and economic prosperity. Croatia can have a leading role for a return to living together in this geographical area of the Balkans so often mistreated throughout history. I have no question for you, I simply encourage you to continue the dialogue with your neighbours.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Prime Minister of Croatia, let me remind you that Skopje is recognised by the European Union as' FYROM 'and not as' Macedonia ', as you wrongly called them a moment ago. I therefore call on you to make it up to you, because 'good accounts make good friends'. In relation to the European Union, emphasis on the part of the Union must be placed on the abandonment of neoliberalism, austerity and violent fiscal adjustment. Social Europe must be built, which guarantees a fair distribution of the wealth produced and social justice. In the institutional sphere, the Union must respect the sovereignty of its Member States and their national identities. To be supported and to act in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality. Only a Europe based on nation-states and peoples can be an alternative to the Europe of banquocracy and multinationals.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: — Mr President, at present, it seems to me, the major problem facing the European Union is the refusal on the part of several Member States to accept any burden with regard to the reception of refugees or asylum seekers. These same states — and among them the biggest beneficiaries of the cohesion funds — even oppose the application of European law by categorically refusing to apply quotas. It is unacceptable, unacceptable. There is no shortage of words to describe this behaviour, which is incompatible with the Copenhagen criteria, which the candidates for accession had to comply with at the time of their entry into the Union. What should be done from your point of view to putting an end to this mixture of indifference, selfishness, nationalism and irresponsibility? Which initiatives and reactions do you think most appropriate to this phenomenon?

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: — Mr President, I too would like to mention a mistake made by my friend Andrej Plenković. This is a political mistake, in the sense that as far as we refer to the state that is the northern neighbour of Greece as pure “Macedonia” and as long as we give them the false impression that they are the descendants of Alexander the Great and that these are the Macedonians, so we Greeks must that we collectively have a problem of national conscience, so we move away from the prospect of their accession to the European Union. Because even if the Greek government accepts some compromises, even if Greek MEPs accept some compromises, the Greek people are completely incompatible on these issues and will not accept them. After all, at a rally held last Sunday in Athens and I was there, hundreds of thousands of Greeks expressed their will to stop the presentation of our northern neighbour under the name “Macedonia”. That is why I want my friend, Andrej Plenković, to make the necessary correction.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome to a common area with which you are quite familiar. I wish every success in your work. I will begin by saying that 2018 has been declared a year of cultural heritage. Cultural heritage is about the past, but that is what defines the values for our common European future. I agree with the previous speaker that our common cultural future, as a European one, must be based on honesty and truth and not on the lies of Skopje. Now, in relation to our common European future, I would like to hear your views on two issues. Firstly, in the northern occupied part of Cyprus, which is part of the European Union, there is an unprecedented destruction of ancient monuments and churches. Secondly, I would like your opinion on our common European future based on defence cooperation. I wish you every success in your work again.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his fine speech a month after our own Prime Minister, Leo Varadkar, was here. It was great to have two big men representing two small countries as Prime Ministers here in Parliament. You as babes of the European Parliament, we as veterans. Both equally important and committed. You spoke a lot about security; I just have a quick question for you. You mentioned about building an LNG terminal; I want to ask you how important that is in the security supply for your country. Was there opposition to it or full support for it, and what is the cost to the State? Keep up the good work.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister, Croatia and my country, Romania, have an important role to play to engage more with our neighbours, bearing in mind that providing a clear European perspective to all the Western Balkan countries would act as a catalyst to accelerate the pace of reforms. At the same time, we have to continue to support the countries of the Eastern Partnership, especially the three countries associated with the European Union – the Republic of Moldova, Ukraine and Georgia – to come closer to the European Union.  Please, Prime Minister, do not lose this window of opportunity to overcome old painful grievances that still exist in the Balkans. We should give a clear perspective to south-eastern Europe for development, peace, and of course taking more care of their citizens within the European Union.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: — Welcome and thank you for your clear words on the future of Europe. I welcome Croatia's European ambitions and wish her to qualify for first speed. I do not dramatize the border between Croatia and Slovenia, but I want to be very precise. We are no longer looking for a solution because the border in the assistance of the European Commission, after a failed bilateral, was legally determined by the arbitration tribunal. The court has completed its work, despite the Croatian qualifications of Slovenian conduct. So, we are looking for a path to implementing the judgment. I am grateful to the Commission for the offer of mediation and to you for being open to dialogue. In fact, you have already given the answer, and it is not necessary to add it again. I have a question, however. Central Europe is increasingly forming itself as a political entity with its political and cultural identity and also with its clear views on the future of the European Union. What do you think of that?

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: — Dear President Plenković, good afternoon. The integration of the Western Balkan countries into the European Union will undoubtedly affect the future of the whole of Europe. Later in the day we will hear the presentation of Johannes Hahn, Commissioner for European Cooperation, Neighbourhood Policy and Enlargement Negotiations regarding a new strategy for the Western Balkans. It is a very ambitious document that provides for the possibility of Montenegro and Serbia joining the European Union by 2025. Do you believe that such a timeline is possible? I ask you this, bearing in mind the experience of Croatia joining the European bloc. Croatia's accession to the EU was possible earlier, but this was slowed due to the border problem with Slovenia. This issue has not yet been fully resolved because you do not want to accept the arbitral tribunal's decision from last year and argue that this issue is better resolved bilaterally. You also have unresolved border issues with Serbia and Montenegro. Can these issues be resolved within a reasonable time or will your country be taken as Slovenia has treated you?

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: — Mr. Speaker of Parliament, I welcome the Prime Minister of the Republic of Croatia. Dear Andrej, thank you for the excellent and comprehensive speech on the future of the European Union and congratulate you on the economic results and good indicators in the Republic of Croatia, for the acceleration in the use of European funds and especially on the adopted strategy for entering the euro zone, in which the importance of convergence of the Republic of Croatia, i.e. growth and development, in order to make the eurozone our natural environment to which we belong. I have a question about cohesion policy. I am glad that in your speech you have highlighted the importance of cohesion policy that President Juncker also confirmed. In addition to the financial envelope, the rapid adoption of implementing rules related to cohesion policy is very important if we are to be successful in the next period. What activities do you intend to take to speed up the adoption of the regulation and to be done by the end of the convocation of this Parliament and the European Commission?

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Mr. President! Dear Prime Minister, dear Andrei, I find your commitment to European construction as convincing and, knowing you well, credible. However, our common future, the success of European construction, is seriously jeopardised by one or more Member States breaking funds, pursuing anti-EU, undemocratic policies, or abusing the idea of solidarity and defending our common security interests. So my question is: as an important neighbour and ally of Hungary, and as an important leader of the European People's Party, what do you wish and can you do to curb Viktor Orbán's anti-European rampage?

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Prime Minister of Croatia. – Mr President, thank you very much for this opportunity. I see that voting time is approaching, so the plenary is filling up a little more than in the hours before, but that is absolutely normal and to be expected. First of all, let me conclude with some general remarks. Your initiative of holding a debate here in plenary in Strasbourg with the prime ministers or heads of state or government of the EU Member States on the future of Europe is really useful and timely, and it will contribute to the strategic decisions which are ahead of us. I feel enriched by your comments. I feel more up to date in terms of the direction that the political parties in the European Parliament are taking. That is very important for me, because, being fully occupied at national level, sometimes we do not fully grasp the trends at European level. There were several comments in the last round of questions, one of them on the cohesion policy and implementing measures, which Ivana has just mentioned. I think that for Croatia, which is undergoing a first seven-year multiannual financial framework, the experience is critical with a view to improvement for the next seven years. And you have been working on this issue as closely as anyone here in this forum, Ivana. What I would like to see is swifter absorption, clearer competences, a procedure that is transparent and efficient, and that finally EU financing is more visible, clearer and more recognisable for Croatian citizens. Therefore, we shall urge, at European level and at national level, the adoption of the new legislative mechanisms that are tending in that direction. The comments made by Alojz are basically along the same lines as those of all the Slovenian colleagues. I think I have addressed this issue adequately. My message is clear. The open issues which exist among Member States should be resolved by negotiations, and by using various instruments of international dispute settlement, notably peaceful ones. We believe that these processes should be credible and clean, and that is the only way for the results to be accepted and implemented. This is the key message. Croatia has no ambition to stall or make more difficult our neighbours’ path to the EU. On the contrary, we have been very much a bridge, an influencing country that has unselfishly offered all the experience which is most recent, and thus most relevant for their path to the European Union – trying to address the questions that were mentioned by some of the Members. I am also grateful that the only MEP still serving from the first directly elected Parliament, my friend Elmar, took the floor and mentioned the concept of equality and the representation in this House. I think that the right balance needs to be struck. It is not as easy for those national delegations which are less numerous to cover all the work of such big and important institutions. I know for a fact that smaller and bigger countries sometimes lose sight of one another’s viewpoints because we do not really understand the other’s concerns. The Croatian Government that I head is, as you know, a reformist government, a government which will do its utmost to make my country part of the inner circle – Schengen, the eurozone and various other forms of enhanced cooperation – and to strengthen our own internal institutions and our European credibility and responsibility. In that respect, dialogue with the European Parliament will be something that we will take into account and take on board when preparing our presidency of the Council, which is envisaged for the first semester of 2020. I thank you all very much for this opportunity. It has been a pleasure to be back with you in Strasbourg. I think that, in this parliamentary term, the European Parliament has done a lot in terms of important and relevant legislative acts of the European Union with long-term consequences.  (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I too thank Prime Minister Plenković, on behalf of the whole Parliament, for his willingness and for his willingness to answer in a concrete and timely manner to all the questions that had been put to him. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – When it comes to the future of Europe, we should give a strong political signal that Western Balkans are a key element to build a better EU. Together, we share the European values and the idea of long-lasting peace, stability and, consequently economic-growth. I welcome President Andrej Plenković’s statement that Europe needs to reassert itself as a role model that will inspire people across the world to build a better future. It is not conceivable without a clear commitment to improve connectivity in the region. Besides the value derived from cooperation at the official level, good neighbourly relations will accrue further benefits by working together, cooperating in the fields of culture, education, business and many others. There is still more to be done on the level of civil society initiatives, where efforts would have a direct impact on citizens. Future generations need to feel closer to each other, in particular in the regions of the Western Balkans, with its societies that have been through conflicts in the past. Prioritizing the Balkan region in the EU agenda is crucial to ensure preconditions for increased youth mobility and thus help further educational, employment and cultural co-operation opportunities in the Balkans.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. — Tuesday (6. 2. 2018) there was a discussion with Croatian Prime Minister Andrej Plenkovic. It discussed the future of the European Union, starting with open calls on several fronts such as economy, security and terrorism, education and culture, migration and accession of the Balkan countries. On the part of the Croatian Prime Minister, the problem of growing regional populism has been raised in particular. He encouraged the avoidance of demagogic tendencies often through a discussion of an informational nature on the EU dossier. He also recalled that strong efforts to integrate the Western Balkans into the EU continue. However, the European Parliament, which supports this process by step-by-step harmonisation steps, highlights the shortcomings that will have to undergo in the near term of the Balkan country in terms of strengthening the rule of law, fundamental rights or the fight against corruption.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. — (PT) The Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) represents the fundamental instrument that determines the budgetary policy of the European Union. It sets for a minimum period of five years the annual expenditure ceilings per heading in accordance with the political priorities approved by all the Member States. Despite the fact that we are still in full force of the 2014-2020 MFF, the discussion on the next MFF after 2020 has already begun. The European Commission will present a first proposal as early as May of this year, and the debate has already begun. We have heard many calls for the need for a budget tailored to the ambitions of this EU, but the fact is that the next MFF already has its outlines well defined. Just read the latest strategic documents produced by the European Commission, from the White Paper on the Future of Europe to the Reflection Paper on the Future of EU Finances to guess what might be the key direction of the next EU budget. In general, what we can see is a MFF with fewer resources, more oriented towards new priorities such as “security and defence” with the arms race and its amputated redistributive dimension and increasingly subordinate to so-called conditionality.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Before the vote I would like to inform you that, as requested by Mr Demesmaeker last plenary, I have written to the Spanish authorities to ask for information on the visit by Mr Demesmaeker and other Members of Parliament to prisons of Madrid. I received the requested information. According to the Spanish authorities, everything took place regularly and there were no violations of Spanish law. I will send the reply to Mr Demesmaeker and the text of the answer is available from my Cabinet for anyone who wants to learn about it.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: The next item is the votes.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, I am getting very concerned. We are supposed to have immunity in this House, but every single time, we seem to be removing the immunity of honourable Members. I don’t care whether the person is a fascist, a communist, a democrat or whatever they are: I will go to the barricades to defend their rights. What worries me is that if you keep on lifting this immunity, the immunity itself becomes a farce, and there is no point in speaking freely in this House if you do not have the protection of this House. So can I encourage Members – and could I ask you, Madam President – that we should not continually remove waivers of immunity from people simply because he might be a member of the Front National. It is simply not enough.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Mr Coburn, I can assure you that the debate and the hearing have been conducted in the Committee on Legal Affairs, but I take note of what you have said.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, in May 2016 when geo-blocking was presented, a lot of promises were made to our citizens: that they would be able in the future to see their favourite films, TV series and songs that were not available in their country of origin. However, we deceived our citizens: the compromise on which we are voting is very limited. It will allow a Swedish customer who wants to buy a toaster to go to the German website and buy it – but only if he can secure the delivery by himself. It will allow a Danish family to buy a trip directly to an amusement park in France and without being directed to the Danish website. Oh, how big! I am voting in favour of this compromise because of the advantages it still gives to our citizens, but at the same time I’m thinking: ‘come on, we could have done much, much better’.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, 63% of EU websites use geo-blocking tactics which discriminate against online shoppers based on their place of residence or so-called temporary location. I believe that this violates our ambitions to create a genuine digital single market, and thus these practices should be tackled. Therefore, I truly welcome the Commission’s strategy based on more transparency and a ban on blocking website access, as well as defining situations in which geo-blocking would not be allowed. The decision we just made is truly going in the right direction.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President! The common European single market is, in my opinion, our greatest value, but in the age of electronics and the internet, it is difficult for the single European market not to include the digital market as well. So we're moving in the right direction. We are making a change in terms of unjustifiable discrimination on grounds of residence or place of business, let alone nationality. We will also have restrictions on charging additional fees or redirecting pages. In contrast, it is also fair to say that this is only a step in the right direction, not a good solution, because we have quite a few exemptions here. The one that is perhaps most important to any ordinary citizen is all copyrighted fields. Unfortunately, you still won't be able to travel, watch movies or TV shows.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Madam President, I supported the proposal for a regulation abolishing geoblocating because this practice is contrary to the freedoms of the internal market. Eliminating discrimination on a geographical basis will help increase cross-border trade. In addition, Bulgarian and European consumers will be able to shop more easily online and will have more choice and opportunities to benefit from lower prices. Bulgarians rank twelfth in the ranking of the most discriminated citizens by online retailers. Offering different prices based on geographical location is a pure sample of discrimination, which we need to end an hour sooner. With the adoption of the regulation, my fellow citizens will be able to shop online at more affordable prices, book holidays and use their credit card abroad seamlessly. Last but not least, I share the view that, at the same time, we should not create an excessive burden on business. We must not forget that small and medium-sized enterprises are the engine of the European economy. I believe that we should create incentives for their development, not obstacles.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! Geographical blocking is evidence of the existence in Europe without borders of very significant and severe borders. We cannot say that these are virtual boundaries, rather that they are boundaries in the virtual world. Geographic blocking is also evidence of business models with services inadequately tailored to the customer. I point it out because it affects extremely many citizens, including those who use content on the internet for educational purposes. I would like to thank the rapporteur who prepared this report extremely efficiently. I would like to emphasise on this occasion that, despite the better than roaming pace of debate on this report, we are acting extremely slowly all the time. One important thing must be borne in mind: if the European Parliament and the European Commission are losing out in the public eye, it is mainly through the free response to these problems, which, as you can see in this room, affect many people and require very smooth action.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I would like to explain why I supported the draft regulation, which ultimately received a lot of support from 557 Members and Members. And I would also like to thank my colleague Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein, who has pushed for the acceptance of this report. The Regulation is intended to enable and facilitate citizens to purchase long-distance goods and use services throughout the European Union. A clear ban on geographical blocking is proposed and specifies under what conditions the redirection may occur, as well as what cannot be considered discriminatory. For now, the blocking ban and related bans will apply only to some goods and services. Thus, electronically supplied services that are copyrighted are excluded. I agree with that restriction. In fact, the conditions would need to be set so that the extension of access to audiovisual works does not occur at the expense of copyright.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President! I voted in favour of the report on area-based content restrictions. The so-called geoblocking and other discrimination on the basis of residence or residence within the internal market were a clear obstacle to the completion of the internal market, including the digital internal market. Elimination of these practices is absolutely necessary, since while online sales of goods and services are dynamically increasing within the internal market, the number of cross-border online purchases is very low. The removal of unjustified area-based restrictions would, according to a number of studies, reduce prices and contribute to economic growth. I also welcome the fact that the report acknowledges that there are companies, especially SMEs, which, due to their size and potential, do not want to target cross-border customers. This is why it is important to point out that traders who do not target cross-border markets are not obliged to transport goods or services outside the territory.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: – Madam President, markets in certain Member States are small, and e-commerce and the digital single market provides endless opportunities for businesses to expand those markets. Unfair practices of unjustified geo-blocking often prevent consumers from ordering a product and services in other Member States or having to pay higher prices than the locals. The removal of such artificial barriers means that European consumers should be able to purchase products and services from the retailer or supplier of their choice from other Member States. They should have wider cross-border access to products and services, and smaller businesses should have access to bigger markets that are potentially more profitable. So, under the new rules, consumers will be able to choose from which website they wish to buy goods or services without being blocked or automatically rerouted to another website due to their nationality, place of residence, or even their temporary location. This is the essence of the geo-blocking proposal that we voted for today.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Madam President! Although we value the European Commission's efforts to create a single copyright market, the current amendment to the regulation is not enough for the 50 million citizens of national or linguistic minorities in the European Union. The Audiovisual Media Services Directive should also be adapted to the needs of citizens and the free reception of media content should not be impeded by trade agreements which do not take account of the linguistic and cultural diversity of individual Member States. It is an insult to citizens when the service provider restricts access to a media service purchased by them, where appropriate, to a sports broadcast, by reference to the contractual obligation of territorial geocoding. The fact that the mother tongue of millions of EU citizens does not match the official language of their country cannot deprive them of pursuing an international sporting event in the language of their choice if they otherwise subscribe to that broadcaster.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Madam President, I am very happy to support this regulation, this proposal, because this is a clear thing where we can show the citizens of the European Union how Europe contributes to their more interesting, a fuller and more comfortable life. This regulation, as my colleagues said here, will lead to citizens being able to buy goods online within the European Union better. It detracts from geographical blockage, and I think it's good for us to talk about it a lot, because especially in the countries of Central Europe, where lately the idea of European integration has been going through a crisis , it is necessary to tell citizens permanently what a particular European Union is doing for them, how it improves their lives. And this is the specific story of a specific European Union legislation that allows a normal citizen to get to goods on the internet better, get those goods in a larger supply and at a better price. So thank you and I was happy to support that suggestion.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, to what problem is this proposal a solution? We are talking about highly competitive developed markets where there is no evidence of market failure and where individual businesses are pricing according to what they regard as the most profitable way of doing it. Why do we – sitting in this Chamber with absolutely no idea of what those considerations and calculations are for individual enterprises – presume to tell them what their own pricing structure should be? There is a legitimate role for government in setting overall regulations. It is, I would say, legitimate, for example, for this Chamber and for the European Union as a whole to say that you shouldn’t discriminate against goods or services on grounds of nationality, that you are providing a level playing field for consumers, but this is going way beyond that measure – which, by the way, I think the UK should retain after Brexit. This is telling individual companies that, regardless of what their own plans and their own profits show, they need to follow some arbitrary political criteria of ours rather than their own commercial considerations. Guys, we are not the best people to decide that.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Madam President! I abstained because a few things were sensible here, but I completely support Mr. Hannan because there are a few things unacceptable out there. There's an assumption that the seller wants not to sell to someone. Normally, sellers want to sell. Just please understand the dealer from Estonia that he can sell on certain terms to a customer from Estonia, but to cover the cost of transport to Portugal it is something other than to cover the cost of transport to Estonia. Second, it violates the principle of freedom of contract. I might want my car not to drive Germany. I have the right to say — because I don't like Germans — that I won't sell this car to any German or anyone who doesn't sign that he won't sell that car to a German man, and he won't sign the same clause. This interference is a violation of freedom of contract. This of course is crazy, but also people who have quirks have a right to exist in our world too. And besides, I think the European Union should be destroyed.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: Thank you, Mr Korwin-Mikke. I would now like to give the floor to the rapporteur, Ms Thun und Hohenstein, for her reaction.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: rapporteur. — Madam President! Sorry to take the time. I was already making my point in the discussion yesterday. I don't know if this time is for reacting or asking questions, but neither Mr Hannan has graciously come to read this report, nor Mr Korwin-Mikke, because you tell gentlemen such nonsense and conductive that the hair on the head of oak stands. No one is forcing anyone to ship, to apply the rules of countries to which their business is not guided. That's where there are special facilitations for sellers not to block, but they can sell under the laws they know, which they apply in their own country, or where they have their business. The point is not to discriminate against the consumer. Sell, but on the basis of the seller, if he does not direct his business. Read before you scream.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, bhí áthas orm bheith i láthair agus páirt a ghlacadh sa díospóireacht seo oíche aréir go déanach. Agus bhí gach duine ag moladh an jab iontach a rinne Róża Thun agus a comhghleacaithe chun feabhas a dhéanamh ar na moltaí a tháinig ón gCoimisiún. Agus de bharr na hoibre sin beimid in ann an margadh aonair digiteach a chur chun cinn san Aontas. Faoi láthair, mar a dúradh, tá 63% de na láithreáin ghréasáin ag déanamh blocáil ar chustaiméirí nó á gcur ar bhóthar eile. Ní nach ionadh mar sin nach mbíonn ach 15% dár siopadóirí ag déanamh siopadóireacht trasna teorainn ar an idirlíon. Agus anois, tiocfaidh deireadh le sin. Beidh tionscail in Éirinn níos cinnte faoi na dlíthe agus beidh custaiméirí in ann carr a cheannach, nó ticéid a cheannach, nó pé rud is mian leo a dhéanamh anois dá bharr. Míle buíochas. Go raibh maith agat.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I supported this outcome of the trilateral negotiations. It was certainly very tricky to negotiate a compromise, but the result is a directive that aims to implement a commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 43% by 2030. It is a compromise that is acceptable. It is ambitious, but at the same time realizable. It includes measures to prevent so-called carbon leakage and shift investment to other countries. Leaving the reduction coefficient at 2.2% is also a better solution than increasing it. I also find it important in the negotiated compromise that the most efficient industries will have more allowances for free. This is a very important measure that encourages innovation and modernisation, which also increases overall competitiveness.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, today we voted on the new framework for the European trade in pollutants for the period after 2021. This also provides for the creation of a modernisation fund financed by the sale of 2.5% of the total allowances. Unfortunately, in the European Commission's initial proposal, Greece, despite the economic crisis and the fact that it has lost more than 25% of its GDP, could not benefit from European funding totalling more than one billion. The European Parliament, following my amendment, corrected this injustice and called for a change in the base year for the fund, from 2013 to 2014, so that Greece can also participate. This fund could finance projects such as the interconnection of mainland Greece with the Aegean islands and Crete, renewable energy sources and environmentally friendly technologies. Unfortunately, however, based on the creation of the special mechanism, as decided, we will get half the money as a country, and here we are not a full member. This development is at the expense of the Greek Government, but above all it is borne by the rigidity of other Member States which do not respect the economic situation of Greece.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President! On 15 July 2015, the European Commission published its proposal for the fourth phase of the ETS. The proposal aims to achieve the EU's greenhouse gas emissions target by 2030, at least 40 percent, while ensuring protection of European industry against the risk of emissions and support the European industry and energy producer innovation and modernisation of sectors in the decade after 2020. I, together with the rapporteur, support the proposal as part of the 2030 climate and energy package. Indeed, the Member States participating in the Paris Agreement have undertaken to keep the global average temperature rise well below two degrees Celsius in order to combat the worst adverse effects of climate change.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Madam President! I abstained because the solutions adopted in the report, which calls “cost-rational emission reduction and low carbon investment,” reduce the possibility of financing under fossil fuel-based investment compensation mechanisms, even such, which are economically efficient and are characterized by low emissivity. Thus, the name of this report is only and exclusively the name. We propose solutions to invest in modern coal technologies that will give a real chance to lower environmental polluting emissions. Furthermore, the ECJ reform interferes with the right of Member States to decide on the energy mix, and that right should remain the exclusive competence of the Member States in accordance with the Treaties.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, I voted against this provisional agreement because the European Union Emissions Trading Scheme has been an unmitigated failure. It has generated two billion excess tons of ozone damaging gases. It has generated 600+ million tons of excess CO2 via the Linking Directive. It has created a EUR 23 billion tonne windfall for the European Union’s largest emitters.
