It has created the world’s biggest VAT fraud and it has created a system of stolen credit netting hundreds of millions for organised crime. This provisional agreement, as usual, ducks the reality and promotes dangerous practices cloaked in commercial investment strategy, because the EU is compounded all of the problems I mentioned by strive towards alternative technologies for fossil fuel generation, notably carbon to help capture and storage, which are clearly demonstrated to be uneconomic and damaging. So, quite frankly, this was an appalling Directive.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: — So, I am not the most satisfied with what reform envisages, especially because I find it simply not ambitious enough, and when we listened to the big words in the adoption of the Paris Agreement, we somehow thought that these commitments constitute serious action with concrete activities, but this did not happen, and these actions that are taken, nevertheless, are insufficiently resolute, the more they would be said shy of moving forward. But to not only be critical is also an important direction forward, mainly because of these dividing rights surpluses, because it is clear that emissions trading means, in some ways, also laundering the bad conscience of big polluters. And here Europe must be determined in all segments if it wants to seriously protect the environment for our offspring.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, this report is very important as it reports on the Eurosystem’s Monetary Policy 2016. We have emphasised that the European Central Bank should remain free of any political interference and reaffirmed the European Central Bank’s mandate for price stability, which was especially crucial in response to the crises and the challenges. In addition, we called on the European Central Bank for more transparency and accountability, especially towards the European Parliament, and stressed that it is of the utmost importance that ECB actions are complemented by sound fiscal policies and structural reforms performed by Member States to generate growth and jobs, apart from stability.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President! Today's debate and ballots took place at a unique time, it must be acknowledged. Ten years ago, the global financial crisis broke out, which also affected Europe and the Member States of the European Union. But also because we had a very deep meltdown in the Wall Street stock market in the United States yesterday, the biggest collapse just since 2008. The declines also saw stock markets in Japan, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Shanghai. So it is worth, remembering those bad times, to think of the European Central Bank as an institution that guarantees Europe's financial security. In this regard, the ECB should be commended for its contribution to economic development in recent years, including by lowering interest rates and asset purchases.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Madam President! While I endorsed the report on the ECB's annual balance sheet, I believe that the gap between good economic development on the one hand and a prolongation of the ECB's expansionary monetary policy on the other should not continue to grow. Yes, there is a risk of price bubbles on the stock market, especially in the real estate market. The ongoing low interest rate policy has a negative impact on pension systems and on private savings. It must be time to end the bond purchase programme of 30 billion euros per month — please from September this year. In one thing, however, I absolutely agree with Mr Draghi: monetary policy measures alone cannot solve economic problems in many Member States. We need ambitious structural reforms, sound financial management and compliance with the Stability and Growth Pact instead of undermining it. This is the only way to sustainably ensure a positive economic development in the euro area.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, the 2016 Annual Report on the European Central Bank makes - in essence - libations to Mr Draghi and the ECB's activities as a whole. First of all, we should point out, as we said in yesterday's speech, that the European Central Bank must return the profits from the Greek Treasury bonds, which it bought at a 40% discount and is paid at 100%. Bonds which were excluded from the PSI and the procedure followed, whereas the bonds of the insurance funds were cut. Therefore, all profits from SMPs and ENFAs, all profits from the European Central Bank and the Eurosystem should be returned to Greece in order to support employment, because the country is currently facing huge unemployment problems due to the Memorandum of Understanding policy of the troika and Mr Draghi.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, I supported this text which we voted on today. The text welcomes the Commission’s communication on accelerating clean energy innovation. We needed this action and we got this result today. This proposal lays out a strategy using a market-based approach, which would help to accelerate private investment to boost clean energy innovation. I am very hopeful that in this way we can ensure a better funding of energy science and technology, and create a dynamic business environment for energy innovations. The environment will benefit from those innovations and people will live in a cleaner environment as well.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President! It must be emphasised in this debate that the European Union is the leader of the world's struggle for climate and environmental preservation, but we are not among the top of those countries that are effectively investing in clean energy innovation. So changes are needed. What? Firstly, inter alia, the coherence of the European Union and the Member States Secondly, the coordination of EU, national and regional research and innovation programmes — today there is no — and, of course, financial support, but in terms of this, I would like to say that long-term funding certainty and long-term legal certainty are fundamentally important. Unfortunately, in Member States, investments in energy are investments for 12, 15, 20 years, and laws or financing can change within a few years. This, of course, prevents effective action.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! We passed the Commission's proposals in a single vote, but it doesn't mean it went so easy. Several dozen agreed compromises and a lot of work, primarily done by the rapporteur Jerzy Buzek, were needed. I would like to stress that the Commission and European Parliament's support for these proposals is to build Europe's security. The geographical compatibility of the place of energy production with the simultaneous reception of this energy is the safety of Europe, because it means independent of external suppliers. I would also like to stress the necessity of long-term policy in this matter and point out that this report is a very serious and extremely difficult challenge. With the very slow pace of implementation of the records that got there, there is no chance of success.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: — Madam President, I have given my support to the report on accelerating innovation in clean energy, because I believe that renewable energy sources and good regulation of the internal energy market can ensure security of supply and energy efficiency in European Union after 2020. At the same time, however, I am very concerned about the high rate of energy poverty in the European Union, which, according to some estimates, affects every one in ten citizens. The country most at risk of energy poverty in the European Union is my Bulgaria, where every third household falls under the category of “energy poor”. A few of these households belong to elderly people with low pensions. This factor must be taken into account in the European Union's clean energy plans and help these people through investments in renewable sources and energy that can easily and cheaply reach the most vulnerable.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, I believe that the report on accelerating innovation in clean energy, which was famously hosted by colleague Buzek, is a good response from the European Parliament to the Commission Communication, because it enriched its communication with some important aspects. I consider an accent to a comprehensive strategy for exporting technologies for sustainable and clean energy as the greatest contribution of this report. The European Union is ahead of the rest of the world in this area, and there is a demand for these technologies. So their exports have great economic potential that our industry can exploit. I certainly also agree with the emphasis this report places on clean energy innovation from below, i.e. citizens and municipalities. In Europe and the Czech Republic, we have a number of successful examples of households and whole municipalities that are energy self-sufficient and do not defuse the environment in any way. We should further support such an approach.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President! I also supported the report on speeding up clean energy innovation with my vote. The report describes that the ways of producing, transferring, storing and using energy have undergone a huge transformation. However, the clean energy report does not even include nuclear energy at the level of mention, as long as it emits fewer greenhouse gases, such as carbon-based energy generation, the use of nuclear energy also poses a significant risk.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Madam President! Of course, I voted for the project “Accelerating innovation in clean energy, because I think that, above political divisions, we want people in Europe and the world to breathe indeed air that is healthy and clean. It is worth noting on this occasion that this acceleration of innovation in clean energy should not discriminate against any of the sources of energy, and unfortunately I feel that the European Parliament is, however, constantly discriminating against modern coal technologies that are an opportunity. Innovations in the field of modern coal technologies are a chance to reduce energy poverty just in Poland. We have a mine like that! We are a state standing on coal. If we get the money for modern coal investments, the air in Poland will be cleaner and healthier.

name: Christelle LETARD-LECHEVALIER
text: — Madam President, we are in favour of making energy efficiency and energy storage a priority, and electro-mobility is a future solution for energy independence. The policy to support innovation and the development of renewable energies is also interesting. Here we appreciate the willingness to seek competitive alternative energies, but regret that this programme is linked to the ubuesque objectives of the Energy Union. The scheme creates incentives for private investment, leaving the sector to finance most of the projects. The projects supported are therefore linked to innovation in the energy sector, but always with a search for concrete development and profitability, which we approve. Priorities set by the programme, the willingness to find indigenous sources of energy, the participation of the private sector and the interest of funded projects could make it possible to vote in favour of the text. However, the submission to the Energy Union, which we are opposed, and the demand to see Horizon 2020's ninth framework programme increase by 40 billion, or 50% of its budget despite Brexit, urges us not to support this text and to give preference to abstention.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission, on zero tolerance of female genital mutilation (FGM), by Vilija Blinkevičiūtė on behalf of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (O—000003/2018 – B8—0005/2018) (2017/2936(RSP)).

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Author. — Today, on the International Day against Women's Organ Mutilation, we must take more action to combat all forms of violence against women and girls, as the European Union is committed to working together to stop female genital mutilation and, at the same time, to support the states the efforts of members in this area. According to the World Health Organisation, around two hundred million women and girls are currently experiencing the consequences of female genital mutilation worldwide, and the European Institute for Gender Equality reports women and girls affected by this mutilation in at least thirteen European countries. Member States of the Union. Thus, female genital mutilation, along with other forms of gender-based violence, is a way of controlling the female body and violates women's right to health, safety, integrity of the body and, in some cases, even the right to life. Criminal law of all Member States of the European Union provides, directly or indirectly, for the protection of girls and women against female genital mutilation, but we in the European Parliament are particularly concerned that it seems ineffective because only a few cases. This can be and for many reasons. It is therefore very important that we remove obstacles to the rights of the Member States to bring cases of female genital mutilation, taking into account, first of all, the interests of the child, because this shameful procedure is carried out by girls before they reach adulthood. Of course, prevention would be a much more effective and more desirable way to combat this phenomenon. Unfortunately, this is not always possible. Therefore, we must also ensure that prosecution can take place, that it serves as a deterrence and at least protects future victims. Speaking about prevention, it should be noted that female genital mutilation is one of the most predictable forms of gender-based violence. Therefore, I would like to call on the Commission and the Member States to ensure decisive preventive action for refugees camps. I also urge and respect the Commission to continue to include prevention of female genital mutilation and other harmful practices in integration procedures and the Asylum Migration Integration Fund and to provide important information through the EU Asylum Agency. Another preventive measure would be the setting of the highest level of protection for an asylum seeker when asylum is requested for reasons related to female genital mutilation, of course in the context of the reform of the European asylum system and the revision of the asylum directives. Stakeholders seeking to eliminate this practice take the view that cross-sectoral cooperation should be strengthened and that the problem of female genital mutilation is included in all sectors: health, social work, asylum, education, law enforcement, justice, child protection, media and communication, because the ongoing female genital mutilation or danger has a multifaceted impact on the lives of girls and women. In all these sectors, measures must be put in place to provide adequate protection and services to the affected women, girls or potential victims. Another fifteen years later, the Commission informed Parliament about its actions to eliminate female genital mutilation. However, today, once again, I ask the Commission to provide an overview of the progress made and of the actions taken until now. What has the Commission done to include the prevention of female genital mutilation in all the relevant policy and legislative programmes of the various Directorates-General to ensure that this issue is addressed in all these sectors? What further steps are being taken on integrated policy measures and what cooperation mechanisms are being implemented? In addition, how will the Commission integrate its efforts and coordinate Member States' actions to combat female genital mutilation through a broader programme to combat gender-based violence under the Istanbul Convention? And how will the issue of female genital mutilation be addressed through the newly launched EU-United Nations flagship initiative on the elimination of violence against women and girls? Thank you and look forward to the answers.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by thanking the European Parliament, and in particular the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality, and its Chair, Ms Blinkevičiūtė, for putting this important topic on the agenda today, on the occasion of the International Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation. I remember our past discussions on this subject, and I am happy that the European Parliament is shedding light again on this evil practice.  I want to say a few words about statistics, but whenever we start speaking about figures, we forget that we are speaking about real people and real tragedies of women and children, women and girls. So let me share two stories with you. Last year, I met Ms Assiatou Diallo. She is now 49. She underwent FGM when she was 3 years old. Now, she is the mother of two teenage girls aged 16 and 18. She arrived in Belgium from Guinea 10 years ago: she escaped in order to save her girls from undergoing female genital mutilation.  I wish you could all meet her. Her life has not been easy. But she is active in the Groupe pour l’Abolition des mutilations sexuelles féminines, a Belgian NGO, and she speaks loudly about the need to stop the practice. I have also read the story of Jaha Dukureh, who is 24. As an infant growing up in Gambia, she experienced female genital mutilation. As she describes, it took away a part of her femininity, her ownership of her body. Some girls, including her half-sister, who died from complications resulting from being cut, even lose their lives.  We must keep in mind these real stories of real women and girls. We must think about them. We must work for them and we must fight those who are committing this horrible crime. Neither custom, tradition, culture, privacy, religion nor so-called honour can justify violence. Let me come back to statistics. Estimates show that at least half a million of the girls and women who have suffered female genital mutilation live in Europe in 13 EU Member States. The Commission has been active in working towards prevention, as well as ensuring adequate support for victims since 2013, mainstreaming the importance of preventing and eradicating female genital mutilation, and actively contributing to several services.  We believe that it is important to work on different areas at the same time and to tackle the issue from different angles and across the portfolios. This is why the communication is an Action Plan built around five priority areas: the first is improving knowledge and data; the second, supporting sustainable social change; the third, priority protection; the fourth, prosecution; and the fifth priority is combating FGM worldwide.  Within our rights, equality and citizenship programme we have issued a specific call on projects relating to female genital mutilation and other harmful practices. The last call, worth EUR 9.7 million, closed in November 2017, and a new call, worth EUR 10.6 million, will open on 8 March this year. Moreover, the European Institute for Gender Equality has developed a common methodology and indicators to estimate the risk of FGM. Under the heading of development policy outreach outside the EU we are one of the main contributors to the United Nations Joint Programme on the Abandonment of FGM. Through the programme, to which the EU contributes EUR 11 million, more than 1.5 million girls and women have received mutilation-related protection and care services. In addition, since 2016 the EU has supported seven projects implemented by civil society organisations in third countries to put an end to this practice. The ‘Spotlight Initiative’ intends to target specific issues and prevalent forms of gender-based violence in different global regions, in a comprehensive manner and on the basis of evidence. In Africa, for example, the priority is to eliminate female genital mutilation.  The role of the Commission also consists of disseminating training materials for legal practitioners through the European e-Justice portal. One thing must be emphasised here. FGM is a crime in all EU Member States. Its criminalisation is also required under the Istanbul Convention, and its victims therefore also fall within the scope of the Convention’s prevention, support and protection measures in those Member States that have ratified the Convention. So far, there have been 17 within the EU. All the others, which have started the process of accession through signing, are now assessing their legal frameworks. The way to ratification is not always easy, and recently we have seen very worrying signals in several Member States whereby the issues of ideology and religion have been brought into the discussion. But the Convention is clearly about protecting girls and women from violence based on the fact that they are women, nothing else, and nothing less.  The efforts to combat FGM and support its victims are integrated into EU legislation, notably the Victims’ Rights Directive. The reform of the Common European Asylum System put forward by the Commission in 2016 aims to reinforce the protection safeguards available to persons with special needs seeking asylum in Europe. Relevant provisions of the Reception Conditions Directive stipulate that victims should receive the necessary medical and psychological treatment, and staff working with them should have appropriate training. Female genital mutilation has to stop in Europe. It is a crime in all Member States, but girls continue to be cut. The legal framework is important, but it is not enough, unfortunately. The research by the European Institute for Gender Equality for the new study to be published in May clearly shows that in order for the rules to work, the police and the courts must enforce them and prosecute those responsible for crimes. Training for people implementing the law is vital, combined with raising awareness of the legislation amongst the communities involved. We must work together with all stakeholders at all levels, from our political dialogues with national administrations to our support for doctors, religious leaders and parents determined to eradicate female genital mutilation once and for all.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Commissioner, thank you for putting real people behind those statistics. I think that is very important in this debate.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, today on International Day against Female Genital Mutilation we give a voice to the hundreds of millions of girl victims. Let’s join forces and say loud and clear: ‘my issue too. For everyone, everywhere’. FGM is a harmful practice that can have serious consequences, including physical and psychological damage on girls. We are talking about little girls as young as four to eight years old. And no culture, no tradition can justify this terrible violence. As co-rapporteur on the Istanbul Convention, as you mentioned Madam Commissioner, we call once again on all Member States to ratify and enforce the Convention fully. It criminalises FGM. It provides strict sanctions and medical and psychological support for victims. Member States must do more faster and better to combat impunity, bring perpetrators to justice, work on prevention, identify girls at risk at an early stage, provide access to health care and reproductive services and train professionals. Member States should also fully implement the Directive on protection of victims and consider, as you said, FGM in the asylum process. The victims should be considered vulnerable groups. Madam Commissioner, I fully support the EU commitment to step up cooperation with third countries, providing technical assistance to encourage the adoption of laws banning FGM, and ensuring that these laws are fully enforced. But no sustainable change can happen without involving the local communities, and we need to work hand in hand with civil society at grass-root level to empower girls to speak up and to change behaviour, to promote changed behaviour, including in refugee camps, as was said here, for girls on the move. I fully support the FGM European network and many other children’s rights champions and I welcome them to the European Parliament today. Let’s support their campaign wholeheartedly. It is about girls’ dignity, it is about the integrity of their bodies, it is about gender equality. With the EPP Group and the Intergroup on Children’s Rights, we continue to be committed to zero tolerance of FGM and all forms of violence against women and girls.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, Commissioner, we have already spoken here about figures and the human faces of women and girls: 200 million girls and women who have been destroyed after their genitals have been mutilated. This brutal practice is not exclusive to other continents. Also in Europe there are 500 000 women and girls who have suffered these practices, even at the country level: in my case, in Spain, there are 17 000 girls at risk of female genital mutilation. We're talking about a brutal practice. We are talking about the worst form of gender-based violence that exists right now and — as I say — we are no stranger to it. Therefore, the Commissioner has been talking about this strategy in the European Union on which we must focus all our efforts and our willingness to improve the quality of the actions that are being carried out at the moment: the training of medical personnel; the training of education staff; making it possible to prevent this. situation so that it does not take place in Europe. But also through the European Union's cooperation policy and foreign policy, we must keep our proposals on this matter firm in order to prevent women around the world from suffering this immense perversion, because we speak — I say again — about the worst form of gender-based violence. And it is also a reason why women are seeking asylum in the European Union and therefore we need to speed up the procedures in this regard and ensure that all women asylum seekers in the European Union can have their status as refugee women in order to prevent this reality from continuing and continuing to be considered as a reality inevitable in the world. This is the worst manifestation of gender-based violence and there must be a European strategy on this issue. The United Nations says we can end this reality in a generation. If there is really will, in our hands is that we can put an end to it.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President! Both clitoridectomy, the most prevalent form of excision, and other treatments of this type are classified from the point of view of medicine as severe bodily harm endangering not only the health but also the lives of women due to serious physical and mental complications. In Europe, these practices are punishable, but for now without consequences for people coming from non-European countries. It seems necessary that both the European Parliament and other institutions influence countries where the procedure is permissible and counteract it by eliminating it entirely from legal order and social practice. Estimates speak of about 200 million maimed women, particularly in African countries, and this requires awareness and education, including the criminal responsibility of parents and guardians who give their underage, unaware children of this kind of violence. Beyond education by means of all forms of transmission and the possibility of prevention, attention should be paid to the health consequences and suffering of women being crippled throughout their lives and human rights abuses. Sexual abuse, which is given as more-reasons for mutilation, would be worth preventing not through sexual education (sometimes having pornographic characteristics), but as part of the education to live in the family, promoting premarital purity or marriage, as it demonstrates spiritual human development and its humanity.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the inhuman practice of cutting female genitals in fact reflects a deep-rooted inequality between the sexes and constitutes an extreme form of discrimination against women and girls. There is no place for such a practice in a civilised society. Today is the International Day of Zero Tolerance for Female Genital Mutilation (FGM). However, it is important to remember that we have to fight this human rights violation every single day of the year. This is not just happening outside our continent. This is a practice – as we heard from our colleagues here in the House – also inside the EU, probably in most of our Member States. I want Member States to mainstream the prevention of FGM into all sectors: health, social work, asylum, education, child protection and media. Cross—sectoral cooperation is the key to fighting this inhuman practice. This cooperation will serve to disseminate acquired knowledge and foster an enabling environment for collective social change and, above all, it will contribute to an improvement in the well—being of young women and girls where FGM is practised. Actions speak louder than words. We have a shared responsibility to fight this practice, and I thank the Commissioner for presenting to us the concrete measures taken in order to mainstream FGM prevention. The Istanbul Convention is the first treaty to recognise that FGM exists in Europe and that it needs to be systematically addressed. Therefore, I urge the Member States which have still not ratified the Istanbul Convention finally to do so. I call on the Bulgarian Presidency to accelerate the process on their side, because it is their issue too. It is highly important that the EU cooperates in this matter and finds a unified approach to fighting violence against women and to fighting female genital mutilation. The time for zero tolerance is now. (Applause)

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President! We are very united in this House, Commissioner, that we need to do more to combat FGM, both in our home countries and globally. But if we want to achieve success with that then we need to see that FGM is a form of violence against women, among others. A patriarchal attack on women's bodies and sexuality, just like so much other violence, just like other attacks on our bodies. In that sense, working against FGM is, for me, part of the feminist sisterhood; the struggle for our bodies, our right to decide over them, the right to our sexuality. And in this sense, FGM should be part of a comprehensive strategy to combat violence against women and girls. A strategy we are still waiting for, Commissioner. What we also need to do to be successful is to learn from the organisations and actors who have worked in different countries for decades with very little means to combat FGM, and that is often in other parts of the world. We must also demand, as some colleagues have said, that women and girls who are exposed or at risk of FGM receive asylum here with us. And last, but perhaps greatest of all: provide more support to women's organizations that work tirelessly, but by far too little means. What we don't need, colleagues — we'll probably hear it from far-right actors later here — what we don't need is for racists around Europe to instrumentalize some form of violence against women to whip up more of their racist or anti-refugee policies. We in the left will never accept that. Fighting FGM is about feminist sisterhood, and that's something we will do together.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, female genital mutilation is without a doubt a form of violence against girls and women. It is a violation of women’s rights. Therefore there must be no place at all for that practice in our societies and no tolerance towards those who still carry it out or justify it. But do we want to eradicate it only with law enforcement and criminal proceedings? Working together with communities is key to achieving the abandonment of this practice. Families from practising communities who live in Europe must have the opportunity to participate in debates about sexuality, women’s rights and female mutilation. We know that the active involvement of schools, professionals and men in this debate is fundamental to break the silence that surrounds this harmful practice. Let me give Catalonia as a clear example of working hand-in-hand with communities to eradicate FGM. In our country we have taken great steps in this direction and we have it in mind to keep doing so. We know that building trust between communities and professionals is a slow process that needs commitment from every stakeholder, and sound interprofessional and inter—administrative coordination to detect, analyse and intervene in cases of risk. It is also vital to establish contacts with NGOs working in the countries of origin and to support them so that they can follow up on the girls who live in Europe when they travel to visit their families, when the risk of genital mutilation is higher. So let us together put an end to FGM. It is our issue too.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Jourová, today, on the world day against female genital mutilation, we renew the request to the European Commission of concrete policies to stop this inhumane crime. A vile abuse that perpetuates female subjugation by permanently injuring the reproductive apparatus and causing, throughout the life of the woman, pain during the sexual act and often death at the time of childbirth, striking her in the body and in the intimate, depriving her of the very pleasure that can arise from sexuality and transforming it from human being to a simple reproduction container for the use and consumption of man. It is not acceptable that this is practiced either within the European Union or in the rest of the world, but above all these actions cannot be justified by attributing them to mere religious, sexual convictions, skewed sociological and cultural. Let us put a final end to this problem, because it is all of us, as stated today's slogan “IsMyIssueToo”.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Madam President, the figures and statistics concerning female genital mutilation (FGM) are terrible in the world, but also in Europe. Commissioner, as you said, one million victims in thirteen Member States. This reality is far too present today in Europe. Our duty is to do everything we can to stop this threat to our young European girls. Rarely, you admit in your resolution that these barbaric practices are carried out by civilizations and immigrant populations. All right, but what are you proposing to fix it? A reform of the Union's immigration procedures to make maiming an automatic ground for asylum. Do you not think that this will create a new air call for immigration from Africa and the use by smugglers of mutilation to ensure the passage through Europe? It will not offer the women victims you think you are defending with this text solutions, quite the contrary. You offer them cruelly new hope knowing full well that it is only illusory. I already imagine your next resolution, which will undoubtedly propose family reunification for the relatives of the victims. Mr Macron's France is also ahead of you on the subject, since the French government's bill on immigration facilitates the arrival of the families of victims. Combating genital mutilation collaboratively at the international level is an effective solution to help eradicate these horrors, especially in the countries of origin of FGM, for example assisting in the installation of hospitals, providing care, psychological listening, but also restorative surgery, training and training and training. access to education for all young people, girls and boys. (The speaker refused a “blue card” question by Ms. Corraza Bildt)

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Dear ladies! Three million girls are drastically mutilated every year. The procedure for genital mutilation is already performed on several or dozen years old girls, often during the first menstruation. The procedure involves the excision of the clitoris, in drastic cases also the smaller labia and the larger part of the labia. This operation is performed, often in hygiene conditions, in many countries in Africa and Asia, but also in Europe, in immigrant environments from these areas. It is estimated that in 2016 there were two hundred million women who were mutilated in this way. In cultures where these cruel customs apply, the procedure is intended to introduce the girl into the world of adulthood, integrate into the community, make her pure and faithful to her future husband. In fact, it's torture, the source of infections, serious illnesses, neuroses and even the death of girls and women. Attempts to crack down on the phenomenon in Africa and Asia through legal bans have so far failed to produce satisfying results. Also in the European Union, where five hundred thousand mutilated women live, and where in every member country we have criminal laws to prosecute the perpetrators of these cruel acts, there have been only a few criminal trials. The question for the European Commission is: why can't we still cope with this phenomenon? Why can we neither apply the law effectively nor effectively apply prevention? And why is this cruel custom, this cruel kind of violence against women still going on in our countries, where — it would seem — we have every way to reduce this habit? Just one more sentence: I believe that medicalization, which is used by some countries as an attempt to get out of this crisis, as harm limitation, is a very bad solution, and that we should use other policies that will effectively lead us out of this disaster.

name: Anna HEDH
text: Madam President! Madam Commissioner! Female genital mutilation is one of the cruelest expressions of men's oppression of women. Men take power over women by denying them the right to their own body and their own sexuality. It is a terrible abuse of girls and women's sexual freedom and integrity as well as of their physical and mental health. The abuse is done not solely through physical violence but also psychologically and sexually. The problem not only bottoms in religion or identity but is an expression of patriarchate and men's superorder over women. One estimate is that half a million women in the EU live with the scars of FGM and 90,000, a fifth of them, live in my own native Sweden. These women need to be given the right to good and well-functioning clinical care but also the right to see psychiatry. Efforts must also be made to strengthen preventive work so that these abuses never again happen. We need to strengthen cooperation between all the institutions of society to access the problem. We need to educate ourselves on the issue, collect data at national and EU level on the scale of the problem. We need to lift the child perspective on a wider front, as it is primarily young girls who suffer the abuse. The issue must not be isolated, it must not stand alone but we need to put it in a greater context and understand that FGM is a matter of violence. It's 2018 now, it's more than high time that member countries started respecting girls and women's own bodies.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President, Commissioner. Female genital mutilation, which means partial or complete removal of the external female genital organs, the shredding of the clitoris, the cutting of the labia or even the sewing of the vulva. All horrible! But we need to name it to clarify the suffering that girls and young women are experiencing around the world. Worldwide? Yes, some 200 million women are victims of these heinous practices. But not only in Africa and the Middle East, no, but also in Europe. I would like to thank my party colleague Annette Walter-Kilian, who has provided me with information from the Health Working Group. 180 000 girls strikes this terrible fate every year in Europe, and even in Germany it affects at least 25 000 women — with a high number of hits. Unequivocally, female genital mutilation is an act of violence that corresponds to murder — not a religious act, not a tradition. It belongs banned and persecuted, the level of information and prevention work on the ground has been decisively strengthened and guarantees the protection of those affected — in Europe and the world. Let's fight for it together.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Madam President, Commissioner, eradicating genital mutilation is a long-term work that will only succeed if we approach it from the perspective of human rights, child protection and gender policies. The key is prevention. In order to be effective, it is imperative that communities incorporating populations at risk participate in a task that concerns all of us. It should focus on community and intercultural integration and be supported by networking of social, health and educational professionals. We cannot fall into the mistake of stigmatizing or generating double victimization of people threatened by genital mutilation. To convince and empower from a work that focuses on defusing the beliefs that give rise to this practice are the keys to a professional performance guide developed by the Basque Institute for Women, Emakunde, which is delivering good results. Commissioner, how is the exchange of good practices being organised in this area so that we can enrich the approach with which we act on genital mutilation in the European Union?

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, women know best what to do with their bodies. Neither the state nor the church nor husbands nor parents nor anybody else should tell them what to do with their bodies. This is the very basic of sexual self-determination, and female genital mutilation is one of the most massive attacks on this sexual self-determination. It is violence and it can never be justified by tradition or religion or anything else. We know what is best for our bodies. We know when to have sex, we know when not to have sex. We know when to have babies and we know when to have a relationship, and with whom. In order to end female genital mutilation, we need to ratify the Istanbul Convention all over the European Union. It is high time, we need to step up. We need to stop this horrible practice and we need to stop telling women what to do with their bodies, because they themselves know best.

name: Margot PARKER
text: – Madam President, today is the international day of zero tolerance of female genital mutilation, a day with which to raise awareness of this barbaric practice. This appalling violation of the human rights of millions of women and young girls is being applied to our most vulnerable. There were 5 391 newly reported cases in the United Kingdom for the period of 2016 to 2017. The NHS recorded that the most common age range for this vile practice were children between the ages of five and nine years old. However, we know that FGM is carried out on those as young as new-born girls. These are just the reported figures. The scale of this is far greater: 200 million girls and women globally have undergone FGM. This form of torture is damaging both physically, psychologically and can result in death. We cannot accept such a crime in the name of tolerance, political correctness or cultural sensibilities. This crime cannot go unpunished in the name of humanity.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to start by reading the words: “Without being circumcised I would never have been considered a woman, I would never have married, nor would I have ever had children. A useless being, for them I could also die.” These are the strong words of Nice Nailantei Leng'ete. Nice, aged just nine, decided to oppose his family's will, to oppose its traditions. Nice has seen many of her peerages lose their lives after the cut. Nice is a young Masai woman who, after escaping infibulation, decided to devote her entire life to the fight against this harmful and violent practice. With the help of the NGO Amref managed to study, becoming an educator for women's reproductive health. With this knowledge she managed to convince elders in her community that a change was necessary. Safer new practices that saved thousands of women. Today Nice is Amref ambassador for the worldwide fight against female genital mutilation. This little great woman wanted to change things and with the study she could do it. Rising migratory phenomena bring with them traditions and cultures that cannot be ignored. Think of all those second generation women and girls, European women born and raised with our customs, squeezed between two cultures. So let's give them a voice, let's give them support and information centers for them and their families, let's give them a chance to make a difference, as Nice taught all of us.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. It was right that all of you who have spoken now looked at the victims. - It's right. I would now like to focus very specifically on the perpetrators, and I do not mean the mothers who are often involved in the mutilation and lead the girls to mutilation, but I mean the actual perpetrators. The actual perpetrators are the men who believe that female genital mutilation is the preparation for marriage. I mean the men who are not willing to marry an equal woman, but only a woman who may be partially killed. I am now addressing you in particular, Commissioner: of course, our first duty is to look at the victims. But our second duty is to ensure that education, prevention, all these things happen on the men's side. As long as there is demand — and please forgive me for this difficult word in this context — but as long as there is demand for circumcised women, as long as there are men who say, “I only marry a woman who is circumcised! “, as long as there will be circumcision. I also call on the men here in Parliament to finally work to talk to their comrades and to ensure that men also make themselves strong. Only a very, very, very weak man—a very, very weak man—wants a mutilated woman as a wife. A strong man wants a woman who faces him, feels the lust, the love that healthy children can bear. That's a strong man. Help us to make it clear who is weak here and who is strong. (The speaker refused to answer a question by Mr O'Flynn under the blue card procedure.)

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: - Madam President! Dear ladies! Today we celebrate the International Day of Zeric Tolerance for Female Gender Mutilation. The statistics on this crime are appalling: two hundred million women in the world. From this problem there are no free women and girls in the European Union either. This problem is growing with the growing migration crisis, and today we are debating this issue in the European Parliament. Part of us show empathy and sensitivity towards women and girls who are brutally mutilated. I thank the Commissioner for presenting the programme that the Commission is implementing more or less effectively, but is taking action to protect girls and women, for education and good prevention. But let's look at ourselves: how do we discuss women's issues? The left side gets angry at the right side, and the right doesn't necessarily want with the left side of the room to discuss this issue. Even the common standing for the picture in the name of the stigma of this procederer causes irritation to the left of the European Parliament. Dear Lord! Less ideology, less blackening, more reflection! Only together can we lead to women's economic empowerment cause them to truly feel strong and free, and that there is no authorisation for such brutal treatment.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: — Madam President, many of us, I hope even unanimously, in this Chamber want to put an end to genital mutilation, which are horrors still too often present in many countries. Prohibition by law is the minimum that can and should be made in this case. But the prohibition alone is not enough to abolish these crimes. Yes, it's a crime. We must go beyond the legal prohibition. Legal and financial means must be given, inter alia, to translate this ambition into reality and to put in place strategies aimed at eliminating this violence, to which millions of girls still face helpless. It is therefore important to mobilise, as part of a strategy to be undertaken by the Commission, all means, including unwavering support for UN actors, such as the United Nations Population Fund, whose interventions are very promising. I know that for co-financing this kind of program. Therefore, and I shall conclude on this point, it seems to me to be wise to raise the threat of making official development assistance dependent on the willingness of the recipient country to put an end to crimes for which there is no mitigating circumstance.

name: Linnéa ENGSTRÖM
text: Madam President! Imagine someone would grab a rusty razor blade and then cut into your lower abbe—it's impossible to imagine, right? Yet this is a reality for millions of women worldwide. Every day, 8000 girls are genital mutilated. In Sweden, 10,000 of girls are at risk. It is about violence against women in its very harshest form, all to curb women's opportunity for pleasure and self-determination over their own bodies. We in the European Parliament, we are addressing this fight today against the ancient tradition that is a continuing abuse of the sexual freedom of girls and women and their physical and mental health. Female genital mutilation is also a full reason to get asylum. There is a consensus that this is a human rights violation. Yet several EU countries make the assessment that women who were genital mutilation should not be allowed to stay in the Union. We need a global gathering against this refutable custom, and for more and more countries to ratify the Istanbul Convention. It's really about violence. Only then will we come to terms with this problem.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: — Madam President, the European Institute for Gender Equality reports victims of female genital mutilation in about half of the Member States of the European Union. In 2015, the Commission affirmed that “it is essential to raise awareness of public opinion, especially in communities that carry out such mutilation”. This confession pointed to the origin of these appalling practices, punishable by imprisonment in my country, France. In 2016, the UN had 200 million women victims of genital mutilation. Half of the 55 African States are still affected, as are Yemen, Iraq and Indonesia. Every year, 3 million young women are excised, or six per minute. Thus, cooperation between the public health, justice and children's services is more necessary than ever in order to prevent, treat and, of course, punish the facts in order to protect potential other victims.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Madam President, 200 million women and girls have been victims of female genital mutilation, of whom 500 000 live here on our European continent. This year three million girls can once again become victims of this atrocity. It can never be justified either by religion or by honor or by tradition or by custom. It's violence and it's a crime. It is the most extreme violence against human rights. A dark room, a dark hut in the field, a broken glass, a blade, a razor blade, the thorns of a wild bush are enough for this atrocity, which causes — we have said here— pain unsurpassed all life, that women be insensitive from that moment on to sexual pleasure, infections, trauma, physical pain and psychic, unbearable menstrual pains in some cases and, in many, also death as a result. It was African women who asked the United Nations for zero tolerance against female genital mutilation and it was they who have put themselves on the front line for eradication, and that is why I end with a few words from one of these African women: “My daughter is five years old and will remain intact. You will not miss a day of school because menstruation consumes pain. You will be able to play and run without fear of breaking your points. He will never curse that a woman was born.” Today we have an opportunity here to cooperate, to protect and eradicate female genital mutilation in the world. We have an opportunity to bet on the culture of peace and end the culture of violence.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, Hibo Wardere is a Somali-born British woman. At six years old, she was subjected to type 3 female genital mutilation (FGM), the most extreme form of cutting. Fahma Mohamed is a Bristol teenager who, together with her friends and teacher, famously worked with Integrate UK to take a stance against FGM by singing and rapping. I am proud of these women and others in my country who have overcome the stigma of FGM and who campaign to end the practice, whilst also fighting racism and Islamophobia. FGM is a totally unacceptable practice, and in order to bring it to an end we must understand the complexity of the phenomenon. FGM is a part of a continuum of violence against women. It’s an extreme manifestation of patriarchy but it is not the only one. In order to eradicate FGM, it is important to view it as a form of violence against women and girls, and as one of the multiple avatars of society’s policing of women’s bodies and sexuality. FGM must also be understood as a cultural practice often viewed as beneficial for the victim. FGM is more common in families where the parents’ background includes a low level of education, and this demonstrates the importance of empowering women, not only when it comes to sexual and reproductive health but also from an economic, political and educational perspective. Involvement in political and social processes is always beneficial but it holds particular relevance when it comes to ending all forms of violence against women and girls. Lastly, we must bear in mind that FGM is practised in many countries, including in Europe. In the UK, many girls are at risk of falling victim of mutilation. It is time the EU and Member States embraced a real and viable strategy to end FGM on their territory, and therefore the ratification and implementation of the Istanbul Convention is our best hope. We must join up the dots and understand the reasons for all forms of violence against women and girls.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Madam President, the oral question talks about the best way to mainstream FGM prevention. I would like to say that best way to do that is through prosecution, and I am going to do confine my remarks to that subject. In France, I understand, over 120 parents and two practitioners have been prosecuted in over 50 criminal cases. By contrast, in the UK no successful convictions have been brought to date, despite the existence of a specific Female Genital Mutilation Act, from 2005. We don’t see enough emphasis placed on securing successful prosecution. It is not enough to have legislation in place if it is not used. Indeed, a landmark UK case collapsed due to lack of preparedness by the Crown Prosecution Service. There is clear evidence that if a mother has been cut then a daughter has an 80% chance of being subjected to mutilation. These women are fellow Europeans. Their problems are our problems and I would ask you specifically, Madam Commissioner, to request information from Member States on prosecutions and ask them why it is not happening quickly enough and what they are going to do to improve it. Because, in my view this has been going on a long time, it is the only way we are going to make it stop. (The speaker declined to take a blue-card question from Patrick O’Flynn) Madam President, I make it a policy not to accept blue—card questions from UKIP. I don’t give them any more oxygen.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: — Madam President, female circumcision is a barbaric custom. There are about 140 million women living in the world today who have ever been subjected to this ignominious and dangerous operation. About 15 years ago, when I lived in Kenya as a filmmaker, I was given the task of making a film about female circumcision, a 90-minute documentary I was back then along with a small crew in a village in the Samburu tribe filmed. It's called “Josephine — African Story”. Men didn't have access to their own circumcision. Here belongs to the award of our female cinematographer, whose professionalism was able to deepen the concussion she was subjected to. Josephine — a 12-year-old Samburu baby girl — lay on the mlath in front of the hut, crying in pain and humiliation. Babice did her own “operation” with a blunt razor blade. It took about five minutes. Then the women carried Josephine to a hut decorated with flowers. The men, meanwhile, danced and celebrated the event by drinking tea with milk. Why am I telling you all this, ladies and gentlemen. In Europe, superstition prevails that only Muslims practice this medieval custom in Africa. It's not true. Josephine was a Christian, her parents were Christian, her wife with a razor blade was a Christian. Like other Samburu baptized decades ago by Italian missionaries. The barbarity of female circumcision is not confessively conditioned. He has nothing to do with faith. It is a manifestation of primitive common law.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: — Madam President, female genital mutilation is barbaric acts that must obviously be condemned and which I condemn. But here I have heard equally barbaric remarks, and to those I want to shout to them the following thing: “Suffering has neither borders nor political colour. Suffering is like the right, it is universal.” Then I would like to tell the Commissioner that the years follow each other and are similar. We always have the same debates and, however, despite our speeches full of good feelings, it has been said, these barbaric acts continue and it is criminal. By 2030, unfortunately, 15 million new victims will grow these ranks. So what are we doing? I look at the Commission's Spotlight initiative with great hope, hoping to be reassured about the real impact it will have on these women and girls left behind. Can a society continue when part of its youth, a priori vital force of development, is set aside and suffering. Therefore, there are two major investments that have no price! Two! The first is access to health. We need to increase the financing of family planning. The Commission must therefore increase its financial commitment to the 2020 family planning programme. We need to include sexual and reproductive rights in our estimates and therefore put an end to hypocrisy. The second investment is education, everywhere and for all, since no tradition can justify any sexual violence whatsoever. This is also why funding family planning is a crucial priority. It's not me who says it, it's Salamita, this 14-year-old Malian girl, who says: “At the health center, I learn a lot. I learned about the consequences of circumcision, for example. I didn't dare talk about it at home. Now I'm being listened to by my family because the information comes from the health centre.” It is by educating girls that we can save all generations to come. Therefore, Commissioner, by grace, enough speeches, acts. It's urgent and it's now!

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: Madam President, today we give our voice to the more than two hundred million women and girls who have suffered female genital mutilation, because it is the most serious violation of human rights. And not just one, but several: the right to safety, health, physical integrity, and the most important of them all - the right to life. They're not worth more excuses. I don't care if it's cultural, but how can parents tell a girl they're going to mutilate her and put their four sentinel siblings to watch her? How can they hit her with an electrical cable and reduce it so that the mutilator arrives and remove the clitoris? This girl's body, Janeth, survived, but her soul stayed on the road. In more than twenty-nine countries in Africa and Asia, it continues to be practiced. And the laws are not complied with. And we can't say it's a distant thing. There are more than 500 thousand girls who have suffered it on European soil. In my country, Spain, eighteen thousand girls are at risk of being mutilated. That is why we have to fight firmly. And it's not just zero tolerance, but about zero impunity. For this it is very important the training of police, judges, asylum officials, doctors, educators... Prevention, education and awareness-raising is the key. But all this must go hand in hand with criminal law. Victims, mostly minors, had the right to live protected and the State must ensure them. It is not a local problem, ladies and gentlemen, it is a global problem, and that is why we all need to be on board to prevent millions of girls from continuing to lose not only their dignity, but also their lives on a daily basis.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has already been said that half a million women in the European Union and 200 million in the world have suffered the trauma of genital mutilation. These mutilations reflect deep gender inequalities and are an extreme form of discrimination against women and girls. These practices also violate their rights to health and safety and physical integrity, and it is vital that the international community, governments and civil society mobilize against this form of violence. I think that preventing this violence should remain a priority for the European Union. Support should be provided for NGOs active in this field, to promote coordinated and systematic initiatives with third countries where female genital mutilation is practiced and continue to practice concrete prevention and awareness projects. For example, a good practice carried out in Europe is the study carried out last year by the European Institute for Gender Equality, intended to provide an estimate of the number of girls at risk of mutilation in six countries of the Union. We therefore continue to work on concrete projects that lead to the eradication of this atrocious practice and we must invest in assistance, culture and education, with greater determination. Europe cannot fail to take into account the worrying data emerging every day and must strengthen cross-sectoral cooperation. Finally, I think it is fair to point out that this of FGM is just one aspect of the big issues that are affecting women and discriminatory policies against them. And we absolutely cannot forget that.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the message on our t-shirts is clear: let us stop female genital mutilation as soon as possible. Or should we rather say “sexual mutilation”? Indeed — I stress this — it is the sexual organs of these women that are destroyed and it is a reflection of deeply rooted gender inequality. In October, in Parliament, I heard an account of a victim of circumcision explaining how she watched her two girls day and night, in the street, in front of school, in front of her house to prevent them from being abducted and excised. It's a freezing story. What should we do for these millions of victims, also in Europe? Investing in education, obviously, changing mindsets, also, promoting sexual and reproductive rights and adapting our legislative arsenal. The Istanbul Convention is a legally binding international treaty calling for the penalization of sexual mutilation so that it is duly sanctioned. Ratification by Member States that have not yet done so — and too many — and by the European Union will therefore be a fundamental step. It must be ratified and implemented as soon as possible so that the perpetrators are punished.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the protection of human rights must always have a priority position here. Female genital mutilation is far from a practice attributable to health reasons, as someone says, but on the contrary they can often have terrible effects on health and well-being too Psychic of the little girls who undergo them. They are carried out for cultural, religious and social reasons. It is pure and alone violence on those who suffer it. I believe it is essential to call a joint effort between the Commission and the Member States so that this barbarous practice may end, in accordance with the provisions of the Istanbul Convention on the fight against gender violence. We must strive, as well as to put an end to this tribal practice, which is still in use in evolved countries today, to give effective support to the victims and to facilitate that cultural change which we have between our tasks, necessary so that we no longer have to talk about FGM.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Madam President, genital mutilation is a brutal form of violence against women and girls, which must be no place in 21st century Europe. I believe that we all in this House share a view on the need for better prevention and education, the importance of empowering women, but also the necessity of stricter sanctioning those who forcibly subject women and girls to this beastly procedure. But I'm sure we won't agree that this issue has become an important European challenge at all. In an attempt to dilute dominant Christian culture and value distance Europe from its roots, liberals have for decades championed loose immigration policies and the right of cultural and religious minorities to live under their own rules. The scourge of female genital mutilation in Europe is just one of the manifestations of such a damaging policy. Not all world cultures in their original form are compatible with the European system of values and their members must be required to be required upon arrival... (The president took the speakers away from the word.)

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, today on International Day Against Genital Mutilation, I am delighted that we are making our voice heard very loudly here in the European Parliament. The voice in the debate here has been very loud and clear. The figures are hallucinating: 200 million girls worldwide, but also 180 000 girls a year in Europe. So we need to make efforts to stop this. These practices are hallucinatory. I met victims in Africa. I met a girl who thought she was going to a party. But when she got there, she was led into the back room and she was stripped of her clitoris with a very blunt, dirty razor. Infections followed. Horrible scenes! Actually, we should not allow this in 2018. And we know that a multidisciplinary approach is needed. We must focus on prevention and repression, on action in African countries, but also here in Europe. (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: — In FGM, we can not talk about it differently than something inadmissible, discarded. It is an interference with the dignity of the individual, the interference with fundamental rights, the right to a normal future. There is, of course, no apology for such conduct, and we cannot seek neither in the religious nor in the tradition itself. So this is an act that we cannot say otherwise than violence, and together, of course, we must end this painful practice in Europe, but also together with the United Nations in the context of other countries. This act of course needs to be condemned, because if we think that at least 200 million girls and women live with these injuries, we must act immediately because that figure will be even higher in the future, and we have to work a lot on education, on awareness and also in health care and take care of criminal frame and punishment.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Madam President, Waris Dirie, with her famous autobiography 'Desert Flower' in 1997, broke the silence about the barbaric custom of clitoridectomy. Since then 21 years have passed, the Western world has become aware, the UN has conducted persistent information campaigns, but the custom - if one can call it that way - has not been uprooted. Tradition survives in 28 African countries, Middle East and Asian countries, mainly Yemen, Iraqi Kurdistan and Indonesia. However, it extends from African countries to regions which have not so far had such a tradition, such as Iraq. Girls who are ignorant, helpless and terrified do not resist the razor, the knife, the piece of glass or whatever is the instrument of torment. From infancy until the age of fifteen, they undergo surgery, under terrible conditions, under pressure from their entire community and especially the family. Unfortunately, even today, in the countries of Europe where there are large immigrant communities, clitoridectomies are still being carried out, even by doctors. The World Health Organization estimates that 150 million women on the planet have undergone clitoridectomy and that every year the number increases by 2 million.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, Commissioners, dear colleagues, the International Zero Tolerance Day for Women's Genital Mutilation is celebrated on 6 February. I think this is an important day, in which all women in the European Union want to raise awareness of citizens, regardless of age or social category, about the violation of human rights in these situations, which seriously endanger life and dignity to the woman. A better understanding of the phenomenon will help prevent and combat it. The statistics are worrying. At least 200 million girls who are alive today in 30 states have suffered genital mutilation. I believe that there is insufficient data at Union level to show the size and nature of this phenomenon, especially since most women do not report those cases, nor do they feel encouraged to do so. This is also the reason why official data of the criminal judicial system record few cases that are reported. We must not forget at the same time that, many times, the authorities considered non-governmental organizations as... (the speaker was interrupted by the president).

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, on the occasion of the international day against female genital mutilation, the Union must send a decisive signal of zero tolerance towards those who impose such practices. At present, 140 million women and girls in the world are subjected to this form of gender violence. It is therefore necessary to impose harsh penalties on those responsible. In addition, it needs protection for victims. Above all, however, an extensive prevention campaign must be launched, since sexual mutilation is being implemented due to specific anachronistic traditions, mostly in African countries. Consequently, the Member States must ratify and immediately implement the Istanbul Convention on Combating Gender Violence. Further measures need to be taken by the Union and the European Commission, but these measures do not constitute an excuse or even an incentive to encourage the illegal immigration of women into the European Union.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Madam President, today in the European Union the blades are threatening to mutilate more than 180,000 girls here in our territory. Female genital mutilation is a terrible threat to the health and integrity of girls and women who suffer from it, because it not only has enormous consequences, such as cysts, infections, infertility, but it is a very serious violation of human rights, which also comes from an aberrant view of women: they are seen as property of parents and husbands and are regarded as objects that incite sin. Ignoring it or attenuating it is anything but progressive, comrades. The United Nations envisages the eradication of this practice in its 2030 Agenda and the Istanbul Convention obliges all signatory countries to criminalize ablation and protect girls, that is, obliges us, the European Union, to prevent and protect and prosecute and criminalize those who perpetrate any form of violence against the woman. Gentlemen, I believe that the feminist cause must be global, not local, and I encourage everyone to share this rejection because it is also our problem.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I think it is extremely important that we have had this debate, and I thank all the honourable Members for their contributions because we need to understand what we are facing when we talk about female genital mutilation. What we are facing is not just habit or stereotype or tradition: it is the problem of taboo, and taboo is something which is deeply rooted in society and is sustainable over centuries. Some of you spoke about the need to change the culture. I fully agree with that, but it will need more time and more intensive action, and also public debate because one of the features of the taboo is that it is something we do not speak about, something we do not want to hear about, something which we close our eyes to, and we don’t want to deal with the problem. That is why it is so important to discuss it. Also, I want to thank all of you who emphasised the importance of the Istanbul Convention and its ratification in all the Member States. I can tell you I feel a certain bitterness after some recent debates in certain Member States, because I heard opinions from some national parliaments that the Istanbul Convention goes against the traditional family, or against the best traditions in the EU. We have to fight that opinion and we have to convince those who want to defend traditional family, by saying that it is not a good tradition to accept and tolerate violence against women and children. We still have many Member States which have not yet ratified the convention, so I want to ask all of you, who can influence public opinion and political decision making in your states, to please do that, because we need it. The Istanbul Convention is a very efficient legislative instrument, not only against female genital mutilation but also against forced marriages, forced abortions and forced sterilisation – all those horrible things which women in the EU still have to face. We must help to ensure they are not exposed to such practices, and female genital mutilation is a particularly barbaric habit that we have to get rid of. Let’s protect good traditions in the EU. Let’s not protect traditions which serve as an excuse for barbaric habits. I agree with all of you who spoke about the need to come forward with efficient actions along the lines of prevention, protection and prosecution. I fully agree. I am sure that the Commission will propose a series of actions along those lines. To conclude, I would like to share with you some experience from practice, taking the example of the field of prevention. We try to involve men, as well as women, in prevention, and we have heard many good reflections from fathers who have started to fight against this practice, saying that their daughters must not be exposed to it. This is a good sign, although we need many more to get on board. As for prosecution, it has some downsides because what see in practice is that girls are taken for a holiday to Africa, where this procedure is done. The crime has thus been committed outside the EU, where there is no European jurisdiction, and it is extremely difficult to prove that those who took the girls to Africa knew what was going on. It is difficult to prove, and we have to do much better in that regard. There is also a connection with prevention and the need to ensure that society does not turn a blind eye, because very often it is known beforehand that a girl is planning to go to Africa. At school, or in the neighbourhood, people may be aware of this. We therefore need society too to be active and to help potential victims of this horrible practice. My last comment is on prosecution. Some of you spoke about female genital mutilation being both physical and psychological torture. We have horrible cases in which family members – mothers, grandmothers, fathers – have been prosecuted for this practice, or for assisting with it on their daughter or granddaughter. Then the victims have experienced further trauma by seeing their mothers or fathers prosecuted. These are the reflections from practice which show that this is an extremely complex phenomenon, requiring a very careful but proactive approach. I am sure that, when we join forces in making the links between prevention, protection and prosecution, we can change a lot, but we have to work together. Thank you very much, once again, for this debate.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 7 February 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Female Genital Mutilation is a crime that cannot find justification in culture or tradition. It is a violation of the human rights of more than 200 million women and girls worldwide. It is estimated that more than 500,000 women in Europe have been victims of this practice, with more than six thousand cases in Portugal. We cannot accept these figures, which must urge us to act more determined when another International Day of Zero Tolerance to Female Genital Mutilation passes. If we do nothing, the number of victims will never stop growing and millions more women will see their lives affected by a barbaric practice that prevents their full affirmation and undermines equality. In the European Union there are measures that we must take. Within the framework of the Common European Asylum System we must guarantee refuge for those who flee from this barbaric practice. In development cooperation we must consider eradication policies. Within Europe, we must ensure that criminalisation is more effective monitoring and more efficient prevention and awareness.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. — On 6 February we celebrated the International Day against Female Genital Mutilation, a brutal practice suffered by 200 million girls and women around the world, including in the EU, where an estimated 500 000 women and girls have been victims of this barbarism. This year three million girls can become new victims of this atrocity, which does not admit justification by tradition, religion, honor and much less to increase the value of a woman as a mere commodity. It is the worst form of gender-based violence that exists right now. It is a crime against fundamental human rights such as physical integrity and sexual and reproductive health, because these women suffer terrible pains throughout their lives. The UN says we can end this reality in a generation. We need a European strategy aimed at improving the prevention and training of medical and educational personnel, and which supports the fight against this inhuman practice as an integral part of the EU's Foreign and Cooperation and Development Policies. It is also important to expedite the procedures for granting asylum to women who request it while fleeing this perversion.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. — The practice of female genital mutilation should become a thing of the past as soon as possible. Living in the modern world, we sometimes do not even realize such practices and situations, and they happen in our close surroundings.
