I support the Istanbul Convention, which establishes that culture, customs, religion, tradition or so-called 'honour' cannot justify any act of violence against women and, in accordance with Article 38 of the same Convention, Member States are obliged to criminalise female genital mutilation as well as incitement. compulsion or influence on girls to undergo this procedure. This practice inflicts the physical, psychological and emotional consequences that girls and women can feel all their lives. I believe that international organisations and states need to step up their efforts, primarily by creating links and links between different regions, stakeholders and sectors in order to cooperate actively with each other in order to manage to abandon unnecessary practice. The work of organisations working with communities on the ground in and outside the EU is essential to prevent and raise the level of awareness of the people. Integration of prevention of female genital mutilation into all sectors, in particular healthcare (sexual and reproductive health), social work, asylum, education (sex education), law enforcement, justice, child protection and media and communication would contribute to a faster eradication of this terrible, unnecessary and harmful to women, practices.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: in writing. — Two types of work must be done in the EU to end the mutilation of girls: preventing mutilation and helping victims of mutilation. I'm talking about the latter. In many EU countries, talking about circumcision is taboo and low at public level. Who, for example, can a child turn to in the event that they have been mutilated either at a very young age or later? There may be no one among school friends who can understand, and telling a school health nurse or teacher doesn't necessarily feel good. EU countries must actively promote peer support networks. In particular, mutilated people in their teens need others in the same situation, as well as adults with whom to go through the issue. In addition to this, it is the duty of all Member States to identify the prevalence of mutilation and to train health professionals to confront the mutilated and advise on matters of physical and mental health related to mutilation. In addition to this, it is necessary to ensure that the mutilated know where to get help and information. Of course, the most important thing is the cessation of mutilation!

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. — On 6 February we celebrated the International Day against Female Genital Mutilation, a brutal practice suffered by 200 million girls and women around the world, including in the EU, where an estimated 500 000 women and girls have been victims of this barbarism. This year three million girls can become new victims of this atrocity, which does not admit justification by tradition, religion, honor and much less to increase the value of a woman as a mere commodity. It is the worst form of gender-based violence that exists right now. It is a crime against fundamental human rights such as physical integrity and sexual and reproductive health, because these women suffer terrible pains throughout their lives. The UN says we can end this reality in a generation. We need a European strategy aimed at improving the prevention and training of medical and educational personnel, and which supports the fight against this inhuman practice as an integral part of the EU's Foreign and Cooperation and Development Policies. It is also important to expedite the procedures for granting asylum to women who request it while fleeing this perversion.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. — Female genital mutilation is still extremely common in several societies, while being harmful to health, dangerous and degrading. Despite the fact that the incidence of genital mutilation has decreased, it is still a major problem that needs to be solved. The resolution calls for the continuation of the United Nations Action Plan for Sustainable Development until 2030 tackling gender-based violence and to pay attention to the problem particularly in areas such as health, social work, asylum procedures, education, law enforcement, child protection and media and communication. To acknowledge and eradicate the problem in these societies, it is important to educate people, do prevention and clarification work. In addition to educating girls and women, it is also important to train social and medical professionals, community and religious leaders, and police and law enforcement officers. And, of course, it is important that EU Member States, which have not yet ratified the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Prevention of Violence Against Women, do so immediately.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: According to UNICEF, about 200 million girls worldwide will have been victims of Female Genital Mutilation, with reports of 80 cases of girls victims in Portugal in 2016. Female genital mutilation is one of the most sordid forms of violence against women, practiced in childhood, which inflicts life-long emotional damage and affects the most vulnerable: girls up to the age of 15. It constitutes a serious violation of their rights, which causes infections, diseases, complications in childbirth and irreparable injuries to their physical, sexual and psychological health, and may even cause their death. It is important to define concrete objectives, measures and commitments for the eradication of female genital mutilation, with a strong emphasis on the health and sexual and reproductive rights of women worldwide. It is essential to criminalize and punish criminals, but also to prevent. To bring awareness and awareness actions to the communities where these crimes are perpetrated. Educate new generations for women's rights. The fight to eradicate female genital mutilation is inseparable from the fight to protect and strengthen women's sexual and reproductive rights, access to education and, in particular, sex education, and to improve maternal and child health, for a path of progress and social justice.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: in writing. — Female genital mutilation is a cruel violation of the human rights of girls and women. More than 200 million worldwide are affected by this serious form of violence. Up to 3 million girls are circumcised annually. Female genital mutilation means lifelong, sometimes life-threatening consequences for victims. It is a global problem that does not stop even at the gates of Europe. It is estimated that there are more than 500 000 women in Europe who are affected by this violence. Female genital mutilation must end! Let's work together to leave girls exactly as they were born: perfect!

name: Bart STAES
text: in writing. — Genital mutilation in women (FGM), which intentionally injure the female genitals without medical reasons, is motivated by cultural, religious or social motives, and occurs in young girls up to 15 years of age. Health benefits are not there. On the contrary, it can cause serious problems. Short-term infections, as well as sexual problems in later age. According to UNICEF, some 200 million girls and women worldwide are victims of genital mutilation. Half of these women live in three countries: Egypt, Ethiopia and Indonesia. Today is the international day against female genital mutilation. The question to the Commission on zero tolerance is therefore right and I fully support the resolution. The resolution calls on the EU and those Member States that have not yet signed the Istanbul Convention on the fight against gender-based violence to do so. That treaty contains a ground to make FGM punishable. It also calls for an explicit criminalisation of FGM and for the highest standards of protection for asylum seekers applying for asylum on FGM related grounds, as part of the reform of the Common European Asylum System and the revision of the Asylum Directives, and through the new EU Asylum Agency.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: in writing. — According to the World Health Organization, there are currently 140 million women and girls worldwide living with the effects of female genital mutilation. This is a serious form of violence against women and girls and means lifelong, sometimes life-threatening consequences for victims. Year after year, up to 3 million girls are additionally circumcised. This cruel violation of women's human rights does not stop at Europe either. The European Institute for Gender Equality is found to be victims in at least 13 EU countries and more than 500 000 women affected. Female genital mutilation is a criminal offence in all EU Member States. Nevertheless, it takes more than laws to finally put an end to this tradition-based violence against women and girls.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: in writing. — Time to take force against FGM, once and for all! Conscious violence against girls and women through genital mutilation may no longer occur in the Member States. Member States can act in a united way on this important issue. The United Nations and WHO estimate that 125-140 million women and girls have been genital mutilated and are injured for life, forever. The so-called EIGE report shows that 13 member states of the EU are in one way or another allowing this to happen. Sweden is one of the countries with the largest chunk of migrants originating from so-called FGM/C risk areas. This needs to end. It is important to point out that this is not an issue underlying asylum law, mainly because this will encourage genital mutilation with a view to gaining asylum. Genital mutilation is only to be seen as a gross crime and nothing else. Member States can join forces to demonstrate that this is not acceptable, as it is not worthy of a modern Europe, for young girls to be genital mutilated.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice—President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the decision adopted on the EU Enlargement Strategy – Western Balkans (2018/2517(RSP)).

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me start by thanking Parliament for the opportunity we have to share something that is very important in our eyes and which we have adopted today: a strategy on the Western Balkans. This is a fundamental pillar, I would say, of the work that Commissioner Hahn and I together with the President and all of our colleagues have done in these months and years to reconfirm, recommit and give strong credibility to the European Union perspective of the entire region of the Western Balkans.  I say European Union perspective, I do not say European perspective, because we have to start from the simple truth and the self-evidence that the Western Balkans are European already. They are part of Europe historically and geographically. If you look at the borders, the Western Balkans are within the Member States of the European Union. We share a cultural heritage, we share the same interests at present, and we share some of the challenges at present, and we will share a common future inside our European Union. There is in the Western Balkan strategy which we have just adopted, a clear path indicated for the Western Balkans and for all our six partners in the Western Balkans to finally join the European Union on a merit—based process but with a clear, political commitment on our side to have this perspective credible and finally coming through. Over the last three years, we have achieved already incredible results. Our investments are increasing in the Western Balkans, our economic ties are as strong as they have ever been. Our trade is constantly growing – I believe it’s 75% or something like this. Our security is more and more connected and our foreign and security policy is more and more coordinated. Out of the six, two of the Western Balkan partners we have – Montenegro and Albania – are 100% aligned with our common foreign and security policy positions. This means that we are together already, and we have seen this very clearly. A couple of years ago, when we called on them to manage together the refugee flows that were crossing the Balkans, we realised that we were one. We were, as we say in the Mediterranean, on the same boat. We were on the same side of the problem and of the solution. So now we are facing a reality which is that the Western Balkans are European. They want to clearly invest in the future membership of their countries in the European Union. The people, especially the younger generations, are determined to see their future inside the European Union and the leaderships have shown commitment and political courage to make the reforms needed to bring their countries in that direction. This strategy today gives a shared, unequivocal, concrete perspective for European Union integration for each and every one of the six partners. It has its own pace, with its own specificities and different conditions but the direction is clear, and it is one direction. I would like to stress this, because the strategy addressing the entire region and each of the six individual is an important element if we want to understand the sense of direction of the region. The region will succeed together or fail together. There is no possibility for dividing the prospects. Again, obviously it is merit—based, but history and geography tells us the perspective is one, and as one we address this situation in the strategy. Of course, at the core of all of this process is the need for reforms; not the European Union need for reforms but the citizens of the Western Balkans’ need for reforms. Wherever you travel in the Western Balkans, young people especially tell you that they feel Europeans. They want to have the same opportunities, the same guarantees, the same standards and rights, the same rights, the same fundamental freedoms, the same systems of governance and the same environment that our friends, colleagues and relatives share inside the European Union, and this means the citizens of the Western Balkan countries are asking for reforms so that they can enjoy the same rights, protections and standards as the citizens of the European Union.  Over the last few years Commissioner Hahn and I have been travelling very often to the entire region. We have seen and we are seeing a lot of ongoing reforms, with courage and determination and in the best cases with an approach that is an approach of national unity, because these challenges are never wise to be taken as political divides but more as a generational challenge for the leaderships of these countries. All of this has told us a simple truth. As I mentioned, the people and the leaders of the Western Balkans have made a clear choice – the choice of bringing their countries inside the European Union – and today we are telling them that we have made the same choice. We are not setting a target nor a deadline, but we are setting a realistic perspective of timing – 2025 as a perspective. The process is merit—based and it depends on the pace and the success of negotiations and reforms, and let me stress this very clearly that this is a realistic perspective which is true for the countries that are currently negotiating, but also for the countries that will start negotiations in the coming months – and I believe and hope that there will be others starting negotiations soon – which will have exactly the same realistic timeframe and perspective. As I said, this is a challenge and this is a process, not for one or two countries, but for the entire region. In the past few years, as I was saying, we have seen great determination and commitment from citizens and from leaders in the region. It has not always been easy. Actually, it has been very difficult from time to time. There have been political crises; there have been difficult political and electoral cycles; there have been slower and faster periods of progress. Overall, though, the sense of direction in these years has been absolutely clear. All of the six have always kept moving forward towards the European Union integration path. The sense of direction has been clear. The point is sustaining the sense of direction, bringing results and walking this path together. When we talk about the path towards the European Union, there is plenty of langue de bois – benchmarks, chapters, criteria. Once someone from the region told me: ‘my citizens couldn’t care less about how many chapters we open or we close. They don’t ‘get’ what it means by opening or closing chapters’. I think that many citizens actually get it very well, but the point is that this is not about technicalities or bureaucracy. This is real life; things that have an impact on societies that transform societies from within. It’s about guaranteeing opportunities and European standards in different fields from the economy to fundamental rights and freedoms, just to mention a couple of them. The whole process might sound technical, but it is indeed not abstract at all. It has concrete impact, it is real and it is already taking place. The process itself is leading to transformation that is positive, both for the economies and for the societies and for the governance. This strategy reconfirms a commitment and makes it explicit and clear. As I said, the door is open, we want you in. There is a need for some work to be done on both sides and we are ready to do this work together, but it also means a couple of months of very intense work that we have ahead of us. We have come somehow to the moment of truth: 2018 can be the year when this process becomes not only more credible, but also irreversible. We will have the Commission’s annual report in April; we will have the EU Western Balkans Summit in Sofia – the first one for 15 years, Thessaloniki was the last on – and ultimately possible Council decisions in June. The strategy supports this agenda with very concrete initiatives that I imagine Commissioner Hahn will describe in more detail. Six of them will cover all the key areas and I would just mention the headlines: rule of law, security, social and economic development, connectivity and the digital agenda – and let me translate this as it also means, for example, bringing the costs of roaming down which is one of the very concrete things that has an impact on the citizen’s life – support for reconciliation and good neighbourly relations. We have ahead of us very intense and ambitious months. Together we can make 2018 a turning point – the moment when the progress towards EU membership becomes irreversible and tangible for all. Our message is: ‘Let’s make it happen’. We are not passing a message saying that you need to be patient. This is not the message we are passing to our friends in the Western Balkans. The message is: ‘Let’s make it happen’. Let’s bring the Western Balkans inside the European Union not in a faraway future but in our generation on the basis of serious, concrete and tough work that we are ready to do together with our partners in the region. Let me add two last words. One is that this is a reflection also on the future of Europe, and it is not by chance that President Juncker mentioned this in his State of the Union speech here in this Parliament in September. This means that the European Union is imagining and considering its future not with 27 Member States but potentially with more, and we say this clearly in the strategy and are starting to get ready for that. Obviously, this doesn’t only depend on us. It depends on the path we will walk together. However, we are serious on this and I guess this is the first time, in these difficult times, that we are seriously having a reflection on that and I think this is a major step forward. My second and last point is that this is a challenge, and a generational challenge, not just for the Commission, not just for our partners in the Western Balkans, and not just for the Council. This is also a challenge for the European Parliament and I believe that we need to be in this together. The role that the European Parliament has played in our relations with the Western Balkans has been critical. I believe we need to continue working together to make this a success and to make this happen.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, from my side thank you for the opportunity to discuss the very timely Western Balkans Strategy adopted by the Commission today. I would like to use the opportunity to thank the House for all your valuable support in the past couple of years, for your interest, and your dedication in dealing with this issue. In particular, I know many Members are travelling to the region, working and dealing with people, including colleagues, in the region, and it is extremely important to embrace our friends in the region in this way in order to make progress. I believe today is a big day for the countries of the Western Balkans and also for the European Union. Maybe some colleagues in the Western Balkans have not yet discovered the fact that it is a big day, but some things take time. That we have decided on and adopted the Balkans Strategy today is, in a way, a window of opportunity, in particular for the countries in the region. We confirm that the door to our Union remains open: it is open beyond any doubt, with, as Federica Mogherini has already said, a 2025 perspective. Not more, but not less, and I think this is important to recall. Our six partners in the region are already part of Europe, not only geographically but also emotionally and culturally. They are surrounded institutionally by EU Member States. Also, the European project would not be complete without them. We have a common heritage, a history, and a common future defined by our shared opportunities and challenges. The migration crisis, for example, has shown very clearly that there are certain topics on which, in a way, borders do not exist when it comes to addressing a particular topic affecting all of us. The Union has repeatedly affirmed this European perspective and we have created positive momentum over the last few years, in difficult times. But we must now go a strategic step further. We must use our ‘soft power’ of attraction, this magnetic force of the European Union, more efficiently and smartly. Because inclusion is the best security policy for European citizens. The firm, merit-based prospect of EU membership is in our own political, security and economic interest. It is a geostrategic investment in a strong, united Europe, based on common values, and we must not leave a vacuum on our doorstep for others to step into. That is why today we reaffirm this shared European perspective, this commitment to a Union that is ready to expand. Let’s be clear: a credible enlargement perspective is not a free lunch. It requires a tough transformation from our partners. They must now ‘walk the talk’ and deliver. The criteria are clear and they will not change: they are not technical, but are essentially about European values. It is important to stress that the Balkans Strategy is not an invitation or an opportunity to soften our conditions or our agreements – quite the opposite. It must be clear that we will stick to what has been agreed and what is necessary for the future. Therefore, progress along their EU path depends fully on the objective merits and concrete results achieved by each individual country. There are no shortcuts on this European path. Despite all the progress in the countries, a lot remains to be done, and we are very clear about this in the strategy. The Western Balkans countries must now urgently tackle the key areas, starting with the rule of law, fundamental rights and the fight against corruption and organised crime. Also, on economic reforms and tackling high unemployment the countries must make significant progress. One thing is especially important. All countries must work even harder on reconciliation and ensure good neighbourly relations. All pending bilateral issues must be settled in a binding way ahead of accession. Let’s be clear, and I think this was already stressed and mentioned today by President Juncker: the European Union and its Member States will simply refuse to import unresolved status issues, so any new Member State has to resolve its bilateral conflicts and issues with neighbouring countries. The Union itself must also improve its support. This strategy therefore includes, as already mentioned by the High Representative, six new flagship initiatives with, altogether, 57 very concrete individual, innovative actions. It is about the rule of law, security and migration; a focus on socio-economic development; increasing connectivity, including the aforementioned digital agenda and pushing harder for reconciliation. The Union itself needs to ensure that it will be ready – institutionally and financially – to welcome new Member States once the conditions are met. This will include specific provisions in the next multiannual financial framework, and refocused pre-accession aid before that. Until 2020, we will not need additional money but we will be able to provide the necessary financial means – it is about EUR 500 million – by restructuring and by further and better targeting of our current budget. I want to be very clear about another key point of the strategy: all Western Balkans countries can move on the EU path in a 2025 perspective. Yes, Montenegro and Serbia are the current so-called front-runners, but others can catch up, and present front-runners can fall behind if they don’t deliver. So it is not 100% sure who will cross the finishing line first. As a sailor, I might say: enlargement remains a regatta and not a convoy. So once again, 2025 is not a fixed target. It is an incentive. There are no guarantees. It is actually very ambitious, but doable: a best-case scenario, if you like. Whether it is achieved or not will depend entirely on the merits and results of each country. We are not giving a present to the Western Balkans. Joining the EU is a generational choice based on fundamental values. We are making them a sincere and transparent offer. The Union, but especially the leaders of the region, must now show and assume responsibility for making this historical opportunity a reality, and respond to the European aspirations of their citizens. In that respect, I strongly believe that this perspective date can provide the necessary positive pressure in order to tackle all the necessary issues and reform necessities. In this strategic project, once again, we both count on the continued support of this House because, as was said, a lot has been done but much more will have to be done in the next couple of months and years.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen. Federica Mogherini and Johannes Hahn have both just pointed out that the six countries of the Western Balkans are important partners of the European Union. We are closely connected geographically, culturally and economically. The stability, security and prosperity of our entire continent can only be ensured in the long term if we, as the European Union, help these six countries to overcome structural challenges and regional tensions. Today's strategy sets out a concrete path and a detailed action plan for these countries to become a member of the EU. This underpins their European perspective. From my own experience as permanent rapporteur for Serbia, I know that the prospect of joining the EU has already helped to implement necessary political and economic reforms and improve people's daily lives. These incentives need to be maintained and further developed, and that is why the strategy now presented is an important signal. I would like to express my gratitude to Federica Mogherini and Johannes Hahn and all other stakeholders for their good preparatory work. Nevertheless, the requirements are clear: the specific date of accession of a new Member State will depend solely on when the country actually and fully fulfils the strict legal, political and economic conditions. As different as the six countries of the Western Balkans are, they all face similar challenges. This must be tackled in a sustainable way: strengthen the rule of law, guarantee the fight against corruption and organised crime, freedom of expression and media, make the economies more competitive and bilateral conflict in the spirit of good neighbourly to solve relationships. Each of the six Western Balkan countries must be assessed on the basis of its own performance. We should encourage and actively support them in this.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, it is not by chance that we are discussing today the strategy on the enlargement towards the Western Balkans during the Bulgarian Presidency. It is certain that enlargement towards the Balkans will remain a priority of the Union in 2018 and equally in 2019 during the Romanian Presidency. While looking to the future, I can only start by stating the obvious, and the most important thing, namely that our Union is not completed nor safe or stable without the Western Balkans. This region is key for the stability and the security of our Union and for its citizens. And the integration of the Western Balkans into Europe is in the interests of both sides. This is why the S&D Group has always been the first promoter of enlargement as one of the most successful EU policies. Today we are facing common challenges in the region which include migration, radicalisation, the rise of nationalism, tensions and terrorism. It is important not to lose momentum and come together with a common answer to the very many problems. We are the only reliable and credible partner in the region for the region. This strategy is a step in the right direction, but we need to do more than talk, and this has to be reflected in the future multiannual financial framework. What we need today is more EU initiatives, programmes and investment in the region. Considering the rising inequalities in the region, it is necessary to focus on the real social policies and programmes to tackle the problems of growing gaps. The Balkans were playing with history and nationalism. This is exactly where our Union should play an important role in fostering more regional cooperation, cohesion and dialogue. I will conclude by saying that we will be judged by history if this day turns a historical page for our Western Balkans.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I am very pleased to say, on behalf of the ECR, that much of the accepted thinking over the last year regarding the enlargement strategy has finally found its way into the official policy published this afternoon. All countries of the Western Balkans have a natural place in the European Union and each of them shares a strong desire to join. Fulfilling these ambitions must be a key priority in the coming decade. As rapporteur for Montenegro, I am very pleased to see 2025 affirmed officially now as a target date for accession. The support for a merit—based regatta principle in which each country is assessed on its own merits and rights is also to be welcomed. Montenegro is doing particularly well. The ‘more for more’ approach is vital to maintaining confidence in the process and to preserving the integrity of a rules-based approach. New EU Member States should also not seek to discriminate against those still waiting in the queue to join over border issues. 2025 is some way off still, but we cannot ignore rising scepticism in some parts of the EU to all future enlargement, with particular concerns about corruption and organised crime, and we may even see one referendum on the issue in France. I sincerely hope that the UK, which has invested a lot of political capital in the stability of the Western Balkans over many years, is still able to carry on participating in joint EU projects post—Brexit. The glue that holds the region together is Euro-Atlantic integration, and any disruption would have devastating consequences across the whole continent. My hopes had been raised that we were very close to securing a solution to the Macedonia name question finally. I welcome the recent efforts from both sides’ governments on this matter, although it now seems that such hopes have been dashed by populist protest, which is deeply regrettable. But, nevertheless, the Western Balkans is a key part of our continent and they all belong in the European Union in the future.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — I would like to recognise the Commission for, as it says in its document, a credible perspective of enlargement and enhanced cooperation with the Western Balkans. The ALDE Group supports the process of enlarging the European Union to countries in this region, believing that the integration of the entire Western Balkans will contribute to the stability and progress of our continent and security. I welcome the Commission's decision to continue its membership negotiations with Serbia and Montenegro, assuming that opportunities for new member accession can be realized by 2025. Depending on the achievements and fulfillment of accession conditions, the strategy also opens the door to Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo. This is even more important than the said date. Respected, except necessary reforms in the exercise of the rule of law, fundamental rights, independence of the judiciary, the functioning of democratic institutions, the inclusivity of parliaments and the coordination of the ruling coalitions with the opposition when it comes to reforms directly related to the European perspective, seems important to highlight the following. The countries of the Western Balkans will have to more effectively discard nationalism, leave the past to history, regulate open border issues. There is a warning that the EU will not accept into its membership of countries that bring old conflicts into the Union. I find equally appropriate a reminder that members of the European Union are not taking advantage of their status for pressures and to blackmail candidates. The Western Balkans is a region seen in the European Union as a whole as a potential added value to the political, economic and cultural diversity of our continent. This is the reason why the countries of this area also strive for good neighbourhood and cooperation with each other.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (EL) Mr President, we agree in principle with the High Representative that these countries already belong to Europe and should support the will of their peoples to join the Union. It is our duty as the European Union to stand alongside these states and their citizens and to be useful in their efforts to build democracies that respect the rule of law and human rights. We must help these countries in their efforts to combat the corruption that is plaining them and in their efforts to become members of the European Union, so that they can leave hatred and nationalism in the past. In this endeavour we must avoid imposing economic policies which have shown that they are not in the interests of the citizens. The citizens of these countries expect support from us rather than the remote imposition of policies which only cause dissatisfaction.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: on behalf of the Verts/Ale Group. — If I repeat the words of Commissioner Hahn, today is a big day for the Western Balkans. And today we are witnessing that the European future for all countries of the Western Balkans is clearly expressed before the Western Balkans. So today's message is clear — the European Union will expand, the door has opened wide. And it is, in fact, a document that is aligned exceptionally positively. And so ahead are periods of opportunity, periods, of course, also reform. Periods of many efforts, as well as at the end of the results. And I am convinced that today's document also gives Europe a clear message that without the countries of the Western Balkans, there will be no stable European Union and a peaceful European Union. And this, of course, is also a period of opportunity for both sides. Today, we must say, of course, that the European Union is one of the largest trading partners of the Western Balkans with an annual value of more than 43 billion euros, also the largest donor and donor of financial assistance. I am sure that, of course, financial assistance needs to be upgraded, but also with proper control and proper control, because there are still quite a few topics that are not closed and which will be the subject of many countries' negotiations. In particular, with regard to corruption, organised crime, independence of justice, of course, the freedom of the media. But I am sure that the Western Balkans, in all its beauty, also has a huge willingness to change and finish these things. Some more to finish. It is clear that the bilateral issues that matter before entry must also be resolved. Also, the issue of the border, where the Commission was able to get acquainted with the issue of Croatia and Slovenia very well today. And just a few more — I wish the rule of not regatta combat, but of regatta cooperation prevails.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it won’t surprise anyone in this Chamber to hear me say that I oppose any further expansion of the European Union into the Western Balkans. We have seen the damage that the European Union has done in southern Europe and further to the east. It is possible to be friendly, close and supportive to a nation without consuming and subjugating it, and this is something the Commission should learn in its dealings with all European nations. This whole policy is, to my mind, nothing but naked imperialism or, as it is often described, neo-colonialism by other means. Mr President, I am astounded that we are conducting this debate just a few hours after the European Parliament released its strategy at 14.20 this afternoon. This lack of transparency would be more concerning to me, and indeed my constituents, had my country not taken the wise decision to leave.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, by the relaunch of negotiations with the Western Balkans, announced this year by Jean-Claude Juncker in the traditional State of the Union speech, as well as in the programme of the new Bulgarian Presidency, the European Union is trying to stop Brexit's scathing disavowal. But fifteen years after the 2003 Thessaloniki Summit, which was intended to be the first milestone of this long road map, this new enlargement has never appeared so chimerical. Indeed, not only is the lack of progress evident on most of the negotiating chapters, but the enthusiasm on both sides has been considerably blunt since, in addition to the massive disapproval of public opinions of the historic Member States, 51% of Serbs aged 18 to 29 declared themselves hostile to accession in 2016. How could it be otherwise, when the future is now written in Moscow, Dubai and Beijing, where all of these states believe that they find the foundations for economic and diplomatic cooperation in good faith and without political conditionality? This is evidenced by Serbia's key role in restoring the 370 km of railway lines linking Belgrade to Budapest, in the Chinese hegemonic project for new silk roads. Clearly, the European Union no longer embodies an unsurpassed horizon, and the revival of national passions puts its disembodied project against the current meaning of history.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, one of the main mistakes of the European Union's foreign policy for many years has been its identification with US policy. This prompts it to make decisions against its interests many times. This is exactly what is happening with the decision to speed up the accession processes of the countries of the Western Balkans into the European Union. This policy poses risks because, with the exception of Serbia, which has made significant progress, the other countries are far from meeting the Copenhagen criteria. On the other hand, the United States urges to quickly integrate Skopje into NATO in order to avoid possible intervention by Russia, and is pushing everyone in this direction. However, in Skopje there is instability and irreparable aspirations against Greece. Kosovo is the most corrupt country in Europe, and Albania, controlled by Turkey, is harboring the expansionist aspirations of a minority in the country against Greece. If we add to these issues the problems of illegal immigrants and the internal problems of the European Union, the risk of destabilising the European Union becomes significant. That is why Europe's expansion to the Western Balkans must not be hasty.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: — Mr President, High Representative, Commissioner, the new strategy on enlargement is an opportunity to strongly reaffirm our commitment to the region and finally offer a credible prospect for enlargement for the countries of the Western Balkans. A credible perspective means for me to give clear time benchmarks and dates for all countries in the region and not just for two. There is a whole generation that has only experienced the expectation of accession to Europe, a Europe to which they belong historically and culturally. This lack of clear prospects leads young people to leave their country. This is clearly seen in Bosnia and Herzegovina, a country for which I am rapporteur. We must therefore give hope to the countries of the region on their European future. This is a must for encouraging the transformation of these countries and lasting reconciliation. The six-point action plan, annexed to the strategy, could prove useful. At the same time, as Commissioner Hahn said recently in Sarajevo, there can be no free lunch. The adoption of these strategies should be a time of responsibility for the authorities of the countries of the region. Progress towards Europe will depend on their seriousness in reforms, especially as regards fundamental rights, the rule of law and the fight against corruption. These key areas must be placed strongly at the top of our priorities for enlargement. As I said every time I met with political representatives from these countries, these are the real priorities.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: Mr President! This is a good day — a good day for the countries of the Western Balkans, but also a good day for the European Union. We welcome the enlargement strategy presented because it can bring a new momentum to our process. It is another sign to our friends in the Western Balkans that we are serious, and it is a clear sign to the people of the EU that we take their concerns seriously. This strategy is part of an overall picture; reforms are needed — in the countries of the Western Balkans and in the EU — for integration to be successful. Actually, there is no shortage of good words and good intentions, but there is a lack of implementation and speed — on both sides. The strategy is surprisingly concrete. My group supports these efforts, and we will also be surprisingly concrete in the debate on the MFF when we talk about IPA funds. I do not want to go into individual countries here, because we will do so in the country reports in April, but of course more chapters need to be opened in the negotiations for Serbia and Montenegro. And we call for negotiations to be opened with Albania and Macedonia before the end of this year. Albania has worked its way, and in Macedonia we would also show that we no longer allow ourselves to be blackmailed by backward-looking nationalists — neither by those in Thessaloniki, nor by those in Skopje or by those in Brussels. This Parliament has always been committed across political groups, and we will continue to do so in the future. We hope that the parliaments of our partners will also like this constructive cooperation, which will not go without discussion and controversy in detail. We do not include governments in the EU, but the peoples of the Western Balkans. That is why a perhaps more intensive dialogue between us and the opposition parties in the region is also important, because they also represent a large part of the population.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Mr President, Madam and Mr Commissioners, we cannot help but congratulate the Commission on its decision today and for starting this process. And we cannot help but rejoice that it confirms one of the goals of the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council of the European Union. I would just like to remind you that this process began with the signing of the historic Neighbourhood Treaty with the Brotherly Republic of Macedonia. The European Union must be completed in this part of the continent — there is no doubt about that. Of course, after the necessary changes and measures, the accession of the Western Balkan countries will complete the process of building the European Union — I repeat — in this part of the continent. Particularly pleasing are the processes in — I repeat — our brotherly Republic of Macedonia. Of course, all candidates must fulfil the membership conditions that all other countries have gone through and resolve all contentious issues with their neighbours. This is especially true for the Republic of Serbia, for example, which, in addition to having to choose which world it wants to belong to, must begin to really respect the rights and legitimate interests of recognized national minorities on its territory, especially in the western Bulgarian outskirts.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: — Mr. President, due to the importance of the Western Balkan countries to the European Union, due to the exposure of this area to the influence of external factors whose interests and values were once contrary to the values of the European Union and due to the difficulties and possible dangers facing Western countries The Balkans, I fully support the new orientation, the enhanced engagement of the European Union in the Western Balkans, this strategy and initiatives of the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council of the European Union as well as the Sofia summit dedicated to the countries of the Western Balkans. I want to emphasize two things in particular: I understand 2025 not as a restriction as a goal, but as a positive perspective for both member states and for the countries of the Western Balkans, which each must be measured according to their own achievements and, secondly, because of the similarity and connectivity of this area this project can fail only if it is common and complete.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: — Mr President, if we are to discuss the countries of the Western Balkans and their ambitions for joining the European Union, we must first and foremost remember that Serbia is the key country in this region. A prodious effort by a number of European Union politicians to weaken this state has borne fruit. Instead of Yugoslavia and Albania, there are two small member states — Croatia and Slovenia. Albania, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina with an arrangement that strongly resembles the confederation, Montenegro, which separated from the remnant Yugoslavia only thanks to a very special voting mechanism at the referendum, and Macedonia, which moreover must not even be called Macedonia. There is a complex religious and national situation in all non-EU member countries, and all these states have an association treaty with the EU as well as differently conceived treaties on the free movement of persons. EU policy seeks to subordinate the foreign policy of these states to their notions, and the convulsive effort to secede the province of Kosovo from Serbia is worthy of the greatest scorn. It is time to take clear positive action towards the states of the Western Balkans, so I welcome this discussion.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, if I may make this small comment. I am only the second woman after the High Representative who has spoken in this debate. Especially keeping in mind the very important Resolution 1321, we should make sure that female voices are also heard in these debates. It is of the utmost importance in order to create an accession process that is inclusive and that is democratic. I was born in the 1980s and as a child growing up ... (The President interrupted the speaker due to a problem with interpretation) Mr President, it was so confusing for the interpreters that when they finally heard a female voice they could not interpret any more, I think that must have been the case! As I said, I grew up in the 1990s and one of my earliest childhood memories is a crying Bosnian woman on the television. I went to school with classmates who were called Franjo, Dušan and Damjan, because their parents had to flee the Western Balkans. And for me personally, it will be the greatest pleasure to see all countries of the Western Balkans join the European Union. But at the same time, I must also very clearly say that we also need to make this process a success for minorities in the Western Balkans. We need to state very clearly that without clear progress when it comes to human rights, when it comes to the rule of law, when it comes to the rights of minorities like LGBTI, we cannot have accession at the moment. We need to be absolutely clear about this, and I hope that very soon I can welcome all those citizens of the Western Balkan states to join the European Union.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Thank you. I have given you more time because I did interrupt you, but I have to leave the gender balance to the political groups. That is something that is subject to deliberations in the groups.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, fifteen years have passed since the Thessaloniki summit and the promise of a European perspective for the Western Balkans. This promise today comes back to being priorities. The Bulgarian Presidency has chosen and there is talk of a possible and credible timing for Serbia and Montenegro to reach our family by 2025. Important challenges remain and steps to be taken: the normalization of relations between Belgrade and Pristina, alignment with the acquis communautaire, the fundamental border problem that needs to be solved preemptively to prevent even playing games from politique politicienne. But the tools we have at our disposal: parliamentary diplomacy, a strong involvement of civil society and especially young people, the real engine that can lead political forces to make those reforms necessary to reach us. The strategy for enlargement and the preparation of a joint summit in May testify to our attention. Now we must facilitate this process for credible integration which awards those who go farthest — more for more, less for less —, for a stronger and more credible Europe, for an enlarged Europe capable of being more and more a global player.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Enlargement to include the countries of the Western Balkans, so to list them: we are talking about Serbia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Kosovo, Albania, Macedonia and Montenegro. A prospect of accession in seven years is announced here. If we look at the economic reality, political reality and social reality in these countries, we must state that seven years are clearly too short. Thirty years, that would perhaps be a credible, sensible perspective, and we should all have learned from the mistakes of the rash accession of the past. Mrs Mogherini, even if you are leaving the Chamber, make a personal comment: if you are the only concrete example of the benefits that citizens will come up with lower roaming charges, then the policy is at kindergarten level, and this is not at all appropriate for the matter when these countries join the EU.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Mr President, how did the current mosaic of state bodies in the Western Balkans come about? The bombings of the European Union and NATO, which dismantled Yugoslavia and relaid the borders with the blood of the peoples. And today, the European Union has the audacity to call on prosperity and peace to extend to the Balkans. They divide and bleed the peoples, inciting unstory and dangerous irredentims. They do not guarantee peace and prosperity, but war for their interests, as with claims of NATO allies - see. Turkey and Albania - against Greece. It is urgent to integrate Skopje, Albania and Serbia and strengthen their influence against Russia and China, controlling energy and transport roads and markets. This is the main issue that the Syriza/ANEL government is involved in Greece, again doing dirty work to upgrade the Greek capital, but also those who, taking advantage of popular concerns, confine themselves to nomenclature, with rallies stigmatized by nationalist and fascist forces, downgrading the dangers of irredensification, as well as the dangerous role of NATO and the European Union. Eliminating irredentism in the Macedonian Constitution, guaranteeing borders,... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the presentation of the European Union's enlargement strategy to the Western Balkans. After a period of stagnation in the development of relations between the European Union and these countries, the strategy sends a strong sign that they are not forgotten and have a clear European perspective, but it all depends on them. What you said there was no guarantee of the date is extremely important. But without the full European integration of the Western Balkans, the project of peaceful reunification of Europe will remain incomplete. This is one of the reasons why Bulgaria and the Bulgarian Presidency have put as a top priority the need for a clear European perspective for the countries of the region. A step towards this is to ensure connectivity for the countries of the Western Balkans, which is in the interest of both the citizens of the European Union and the citizens of these countries, contrary to what my colleague just said — transport, energy, education and digital connectivity. I also hope that both Commissioner Gabriel and Bulgaria will have success in finding such a road map for reducing roaming in the Western Balkans. There are many historical wounds in the Balkans, which can heal only on the path of European integration. It is the only medication that can prevent them from reopening. In this regard, I welcome the signing of the treaty between Sofia and Skopje. The protests that we are now watching on the streets of Thessaloniki and Athens, as well as such signals by quasi-nationalist forces in Skopje against attempts by the government of Mr Tsipras and Mr Zaev to find a solution to the name dispute, are not in the interest of the citizens of the region. In view of the strong support and the specific dates for the start of negotiations, I hope the parties will have the courage to find a common solution.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: — I am pleased that for the first time in fifteen years and promises from the Thessaloniki Summit, we have a strategy on the table that has an unequivocal message: The Union wants the Western Balkans as part of its family, values, shared history and future. The strategy represents a clear commitment and encouragement to Western Balkan countries, but at the same time puts responsibility in the hands of leaders in the Western Balkans, who can only seize this historic opportunity if they implement urgent reforms and give citizens a decent life. The process of joining the Union is not merely a technical process, opening and closing chapters, it is about adopting a system of values on which our societies operate. I often hear from people in the region that they want more democracy, less corruption, the rule of law, independent media and an independent and functioning judiciary. Young people in the Balkans want to stay in their countries, but only if they have job opportunities. I therefore expect leaders in the region to show their actual commitment to Union values by their behaviour, rather than simply on paper. Without the Western Balkans, the historic European Union project will never be completed. Together, we will be a stronger bloc that will more easily overcome the many social challenges of an increasingly connected world. The people of the Balkans, colleagues and colleagues, are very gloomy past, and they want a bright future that can only be brought by membership in the Union.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Mr. President, further enlargement in the area of Southeast Europe is an important step in the development of this area, but also the European Union itself and therefore must be done in the right way and at the right time. Whether this happens in 2025 is less important, it is important that it happens after all those states meet clearly defined criteria. At present, I must admit, we are very far from this goal because the main challenges, such as the recognition of Kosovo by Serbia, ensuring the equality of Croats in BiH, the agreement on the name of Macedonia, border disputes, effective prosecution of war crimes, minority rights, the fight against organized criminality and the rule of law, remain still unresolved. The role of the European Union in this process must remain constructive. The non-integrated countries of Southeast Europe rely on our leadership and assistance in solving problems. But before these problems are really solved, it makes no sense to speculate on the date of the new extension. These states should be provided with assistance in the access process, but without giving false hopes.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am very pleased that today we are presenting a genuine Balkan strategy, that we are offering the countries a perspective, subject to conditions. We call for them to step up the pressure to implement the necessary reforms. And that's a good thing. We are asking for these reforms not only for the stability of our region, but we are asking for them primarily for the citizens on the ground. Because let's be honest, they've experienced enough war violence and they deserve a democratic country. But I've heard a lot here today. I've heard here: it's a perspective, it's not a real date. I would like to add one element in the debate. We in Europe must also be ready when we move towards the next phase of enlargement. We must have completed the Brexit properly by then. But we also need to reform the Union. We must go for a smaller Commission. We must move towards an abolition of the unanimity rule. So let us have a Balkan strategy with a view to possible accession, but let us reform Europe to be ready for that.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini and Mr Hahn, my country, Greece, and the Greek Government are very supportive of the enlargement of the European Union to the western Balkans. We support a roadmap for democratic change and reforms so that in the next decade the 27 Member States will become 33. This requires good neighbourly relations, border stability, peaceful coexistence, the rule of law, the fight against corruption, democracy, co-development and investment. All 6 Member States must do their own work, but the European Commission must also help in practice and not in words, because this was a strategy from Thessaloniki in 2003, and it was forgotten for 15 years. It is precisely this opportunity that the Tsipras governments and the new government of the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia are seeking to use to resolve a long-standing dispute over the name, which prevents the peaceful co-development of all Balkan peoples. I am pleased that both the Commission and almost all of the European Parliament, including the European People's Party and the Socialist Party, support this effort and not unnarrative populism and nationalism which harm the interests of both the Balkan peoples. as well as the European perspective. It's time to move on to action. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question pursuant to Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I still have fresh memories of Thessaloniki in 2003, which I remember was a great summit.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: blue card question. — (GR) Mr President, Mr Vice-President, Mr Papadimoulis, I should like to ask you, on the basis of your recommendation, whether or not you consider it important that, in relation to the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, the irreparable provisions in the Constitution and the formalities? I say this because you listened this morning to the President of the Commission, Mr Juncker, who said that a prerequisite for the normalization of relations between the two states is the settlement of bilateral disputes.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: 'Blue Card' response. — It goes without saying that a solution beneficial to Greece and the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia must ensure border stability, a complex name of common acceptance - erga omnes- against all and abandonment of all irredensities, either exist in regiments or not. Only in this way can we guarantee peaceful coexistence, which is the foundation for the accession of all Balkan states to the European Union. Mr Juncker said it, it is supported by the Greek Government and by the Foreign Minister and the Prime Minister. It goes without saying that I agree.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: — The announcement that Serbia and Montenegro will be ready to join the European Union in 2025 is both delighted and worried. As we all remember well, with the 2004 wave of enlargement, twelve Member States joined the European Union, whose population, according to some analysts, was called ideal Europeans. At the moment, including in this Chamber, we are also talking about the fact that part of the population of these countries consider themselves second-class Europeans, despite the active cohesion policy. Therefore, in welcoming the progress of the potential Member States, we must do our best to ensure that the enlargement of the European Union takes place without politicisation, because its price is the inexorable collapse of illusions and the entry into force of Eurosceptics not only in the new but also in the old countries of the European Union. Preparation for accession must take place pragmatically, both sides, as far as the European Union and candidate countries have an adequate and fair assessment of progress

name: Jörg MEUTHEN
text: Mr President! We are talking today about the plan presented by the Commission for the possible accession of the six Western Balkan states, including Macedonia, Kosovo and Albania, by 2025. Before we consider such enlargement of the EU, we should better first discuss the deplorable state of rule of law and democracy in the EU. The EU has often broken its own rules during the euro crisis and the migration crisis. This has divided and destabilised the EU. The consequences, see Brexit, are well known. If the EU wanted to join the EU in this Constitution, it would have to reject its own accession. It is also grotesque that the EU, which trusts its own right, wants to discipline Poland as supreme teachers because of alleged shortcomings in the rule of law. If this continues, the question will not arise which six states will join the EU next, but which six states will follow the British exit next. Preventing this through wise institutional consolidation is the imperative of the next few years. This is more important than the accession of other states before this task, which is completely subordinate.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Mr President! In September 2017, President Juncker called for a prospect of enlargement of the Western Balkans to ensure stability there, as he said. In the meantime, it has become apparent that this idea, which is certainly commendable at first glance, is more difficult to implement than it might seem in the flowery theory. The Commission itself regularly points out that the rule of law — politely — is in great need of reform in a large range of candidate countries. For example, the Commissioners, including Mr Hahn, have to deal almost every month with the fact that organised crime and corruption are widespread at all levels of government and administration. In addition, of course, at my written request in March 2017, the Commission itself acknowledged the knowledge of ISIS's recruitment camp in Montenegro and in May of the same year, again due to my concerns, had to admit Islamic radicalisation of the Western Balkans. So did the German Federal Intelligence Service — Mr President, you may have missed the fact that I have one and a half minutes to take account of this interruption, thank you very much. This was also the case with the German Federal Intelligence Service, which stated that Saudi Arabia in particular is installing radical Salafist-Wahabiti Islam in the Western Balkans through enormous financial resources. I don't think we should suffer from loss of reality. Indeed, it is to be feared that the Union will once again ignore its own concerns. And I predict that this planned and hasty enlargement will be the next ticking time bomb that the Union will take into its own house.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Obermayr, I apologise because I misread the line. It was a minute and a half, but I have given you extra seconds. Colleagues, I need to announce at this moment, bearing in mind that we have a long list on this item and we are behind schedule, that from now on I will not take any blue cards.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, I resolutely welcome the new enlargement strategy for the Western Balkans. We need a credible strategy which gives a clear enlargement perspective to the region and equally to us. It is needless to mention that it is in our strategic interest to integrate the countries of the Western Balkans into the Union. We all know it will not be an easy task. It will require efforts both from the region and from ourselves. We need to get ready for the enlargement in the same way that the countries of the region need to be ready to join the Union. It will require constant work and engagement on many levels, especially on the functioning of democratic institutions, the rule of law, civil liberties and freedom of the media, just to mention a few.  We also need to be clear about the resolution of bilateral issues. The EU should proactively work on their solution and find the mechanisms which would allow to solve them before they accede to the Union. I welcome this strategy; however I would also like to see a joint approach of the European Institutions. The European Parliament has been supportive to the enlargement process, and stepped up its efforts to solve political crises in the countries of the region. I am convinced that we are ready to assist and actively and effectively help the Commission in many initiatives aimed at facilitating democratic political processes in the region. Therefore, I would like to see in the future more thinking on our joint cooperation.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: — Mr. President, less than a year has passed since the presentation of the White Paper on the future of the European Union. It was worrying that only one of the then five proposed scenarios were open to a new cycle of expansion. However, today I express my satisfaction that, only five months since President Juncker's statement that the Western Balkan countries should provide a credible perspective of membership in the European Union, we have a presentation of this strategy. Today's European Union must overcome scepticism towards further enlargement, one of the bloc's most successful policies since its creation. The population of the Western Balkans accounts for only 3.6% of the population of the European Union, but its importance for upgrading the European project in the 21st century is far more significant. This is a time of far-reaching reforms to eliminate existing disputed generating instability and lagging. But resistance should be expected, especially from so-called veto groups to which the status quo ensures the enjoyment of unjustified privileges to the detriment of the majority in society. In addition, the Western Balkans are increasingly a point of intersection of the interests of different forces. With this document, the European Union demonstrates that it wants to invest in its own perspective, security and stability. The success of the process depends not only on the success of opening and closing negotiating chapters, but also on strong support from citizens in the candidate country. At this moment, this support for membership of the European Union among the citizens of the Western Balkans varies considerably. I welcome the proposal that European Union-Western Balkans meetings should be held every two years in the future. The Sofia rally will be the first such after too long fifteen years since the Thessaloniki summit took place.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the grand rallies in Athens and Thessaloniki sent a message with many recipients, even in this Chamber. They sent out the message that the Greek people do not tolerate the hijacking of the name of our Macedonia, nor of our history, from Skopje. They sent the message that for the name of Skopje they do not tolerate any use of the word “Macedonia “, nor any complex name with a geographical or other designation that uses the term “Macedonia”. They sent out the message that Skopje should renounce all irredeniability towards Greece and amend their Constitution. But Skopje's leadership insists on its uncompromising stance. This attitude is reinforced even by you, Mr Hahn, since in a recent interview with a German magazine you call Skopje “Macedonia”, even though the European Union recognises Skopje as “FYROM”. I therefore ask you, Mr Hahn, to recall here, as I requested this morning, from the Croatian Prime Minister, who, instead of calling Skopje 'FYROM', called them 'Macedonia'.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, the new EU strategy for enlargement which has been presented today is another step on the long path to bringing the Western Balkans into the European family. I appreciate the fact that the topic of the Western Balkans is at a higher level on the European agenda, but it is not enough to solve the problems of the region. In order to make real progress, the countries need a clear road map, and the period of the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council of the EU is the right time for this. The 2025 accession date proposed by the Commission for two of the countries is an appropriate timeframe. However, I do not believe that this will have a positive impact on the region. On the contrary, there are historical contradictions in the Balkans which can be solved only with the full membership of all six countries in the region. The idea of putting countries at different speeds is not good, and could undermine the fragile peace in the region. Europe should not worry about the Western Balkans. The people of the region deserve EU membership. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Nikolaos CHOUNTIS
text: Mr President, the situation in the Western Balkans region is characterised by enormous economic hardship, the development of organised crime, corruption, nationalism, irredensities, the absence of the rule of law and the repression of minorities. Problems which have largely arisen, and certainly exacerbated, following the dissolution of Yugoslavia, led by the European Union and NATO. Today, ladies and gentlemen, the Balkans generally lacks hope. The Greek people, due to economic crisis and memorandum, are poor and the country's public wealth is sold out. Countries such as Romania and Bulgaria continue to experience enormous economic problems, with extreme poverty and unemployment, despite their accession to the European Union. There is a European policy for the Balkans today, or what we are hearing is an opportunistic policy of using the Balkans to integrate the region into games of economic and geopolitical influence, with NATO and its continued enlargement and its selfish initiative Germany with the Berlin Process? The Balkan countries and their peoples need agreements of friendship, equal cooperation and co-development, without irredensities and antagonisms and without foreign interference.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: O’Flynn (EFDD) – Mr President, the prospect of EU membership for countries in line to become big net recipients from the budget can provide leverage over their conduct. If used wisely, this can foster a functioning democracy and other norms of an advanced society, so the potential is there for enlargement taking in the Western Balkans to be a good thing. But that potential is undermined by the EU’s determination to intrude ever further into a central national sovereignty. For example, commanding countries to take in large numbers of young men from Africa or the Middle East, which is naturally being resisted by newer members such as Hungary. The EU should also have more regard as to the likely consequences of further enlargement for current members, notably Greece and Italy, which are already suffering under EU policy in the areas of migration and the currency union. Were the EU a club of friendly advanced countries rather than a nascent superstate then the capacity of prospective membership to do good would be immeasurably improved.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, speaking of enlargement is of course about strategy but also pragmatism. Strategically, enlargement is obviously a good thing, both for the countries concerned but also — let us not forget it — for Europe. Accession has always been accompanied, for each country, by economic, social, political, democratic, technological development and the development of peace. But at the same time, in global economic competition as well as in the response to security challenges, Europe — let us not forget it — will meet the challenges of both demographic and economic challenges. Enlargement is therefore a good thing, but on one condition it is pragmatism in the process. Adhering countries must be able to integrate quickly. This indeed implies rights for them, but also duties, and the first of all duties is to fully fulfill the criteria which were recalled by yourself, by Mr McAllister or by Mr Preda earlier. Otherwise, let us not forget that we will all face difficulties, as you have pointed out, Commissioner, including the reluctance of public opinion in these countries and in our countries, and this psychological area is important. So this is an economic, democratic and social upgrade, and Europe must be able to effectively, seriously and publicly control what is happening in each of these countries. This implies, as Prime Minister Plenković recalled this morning, that everyone should assume and assume their full responsibilities.

name: David MARTIN
text: – Mr President, President Trump talks about military might, Russia utilises it. What I like about this document is that, as Commissioner Hahn has indicated, it demonstrates that soft power can really work. It is the attraction of soft power, the attraction of the European Union, that encourages the Western Balkans to go down the path of peaceful resolution of border disputes. It encourages them to continue on a democratic path, it encourages them to develop their human rights, and it encourages them to continue to promote the rule of law. It is a demonstration that the European Union can make a real difference to real people’s lives. Of course, it also demonstrates to the people of Western Europe and to the European Union as a whole that membership is not a mere bauble to be handed out, that it has to be earned, and they can be reassured that the Western Balkans will only be allowed to join the European Union if it meets our values and meets our expectations in terms of standards of behaviour.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - Mr President! Negotiations of Western Balkan countries for membership of the European Union have been underway for several years. Although some of the six Balkan countries are making good progress, the European Commission, in its strategy, assumes that they will join the Union in a term of seven years, or 2025. The acceleration of the integration process of the Western Balkans is advocated by many EU countries, particularly those from the Visegrad Group, including the Polish government, but also the Austrian, Slovenian and Croatian. European security considerations are in favour of this. However, the European Commission seems to be guided more by utilitarian considerations. Mr Hahn's earlier statements show that he is primarily counting on attractive outlets. But we must not forget that before we accept new members, Britain will leave our organisation, causing a budget uproar. A real reform of the Union must therefore be carried out first, taking into account not only economic aspects.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, 25 years ago I was stuck in a besieged Sarajevo that was being shelled daily. Friends were killed by snipers while searching for food; others got raped. All became refugees like myself. I can tell you that, afterwards, you become haunted by these memories almost every day. I hope that this step we are taking today towards enlargement will successfully close the door on that dark period, and open a new one to the brighter European future of the Balkans. Do we know why we are doing this? Yes, certainly. We don’t have any other choice. Do we know how we will do it? No, but we will find that out on the way. Do we know should we do it? Yes, certainly, without any doubt. My story is just one, just a small part of what has happened, and I hope this is the last time a Parliamentarian will share these stories in this Chamber. So, let’s start this enlargement now. This evening I will be in my room, working on this. (Applause)

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: Mr President, Commissioner, you are presenting an enlargement strategy with no substance. While you are supposedly invoking the Copenhagen political criteria, you are actually operating as in the past, on purely criteria of interest. We are tired of reading reports that embellish reality and hold back the progress of these countries. The worst example is FYROM. So far, your policy has maintained and infused nationalism and forgery of history, with obvious results. It is an oxymoron to say that in order for accession issues to be resolved open, while you are once again ready to recommend the opening of accession negotiations before the Przno reforms are even implemented. At the same time, at today's turning point in the nomenclature negotiations, you yourself use the term “Macedonia” in the recent interview at Spiegel, which you did not deny, undermining any efforts and continuing to send the wrong message to the government in Skopje. The Greek people have expressed their concerns about these issues and I would recommend that you, Commissioner, do not continue to ignore them.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I have listened to your speech and share many of the steps in the proposed strategy, although I believe it is still a bit of a dream book.
