It is clear that we all hope to see Europe completed from a geographical point of view, and the Balkans are certainly part of it, but it is true that history also teaches us that if we accelerate them too much processes, we risk having the opposite effect, the reverse effect. We are experiencing a crisis in this era within the European Union, where many things do not work and where we need to be careful when we speak to other countries that have not yet completed reforms and still have some serious problems. We have problems between Belgrade and Pristina, we have problems between a member country of the European Union, Greece, and the recognition of Macedonia, or FYROM as you prefer to call it. So, this process must be accompanied strongly and to achieve it you need to take steps one at a time.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: — Mr. President, thank you for this strategy, you and Mrs. Mogherini and the Commission. I also thank the Bulgarian Presidency, which has chosen for one of its priorities of the presidency the enlargement. Likewise, you can see the thread from September, from the “State of the Union” speech, Mr. Juncker announcing the extension and obviously the Commission is working on it and this strategy is precisely the elaboration of that idea that unfortunately at one point at the beginning of this term was stalled. It is clear that regional tensions need to be overcome, this is what is most important and hardest, probably. However, we must understand that the security of the European Union is precisely in the stability and security of this area, the so-called Western Balkans or Southeast Europe. It is therefore very important that the European Union is present, not to give this space to either Russia or Turkey, which at one point was threatened, and therefore I understand the reasons why the Commission finally realized that enlargement should be high on the agenda. I agree that everyone needs to meet the criteria, I know it from the Croatian experience, we heard our Prime Minister talk about it this morning and therefore I will join this sailing dictionary of yours where you said everyone according to merit, ie, this is a regatta, not a convoy. Therefore, I believe that there is room for Bosnia and Herzegovina to catch up with those you mention, two states, that 2025, means space is left, if there is political will to meet both the political and legal criteria for all countries to catch up with that date.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that the gradual approach of the Balkan area to the European Union is a fundamental instrument for the stabilisation of the area and the development of full democratic regimes. I think that the Sofia summit should serve above all to provide action plans for each country, without creating unrealistic expectations but with concrete steps to take, and having the forethought, as in the case of Serbia and Kosovo, to look at the path as something intimately linked. But we have to ask ourselves whether the EU is ready for all this. In 2004 we achieved a great enlargement in the East, an important enlargement. In that period two schools of thought in the world were confronted around the idea of the export of democracy: the one that someone had with weapons and we who posed the problem of enlargement as an export of democracy. But that enlargement, however, is not followed by an adequate integration policy and the political dynamics we are seeing today, if we reflect well, are also the consequence of this limit highlighted in these years. Then I believe that more awareness is useful because properly preparing 2025 means first of all preparing ourselves properly.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: — A new Presidency, a new list of priorities. The European perspective that Bulgaria wants to offer the Western Balkans can promote stability, prosperity and security in that region. In itself, this is a good thing provided that all conditions are carefully watched. Reforms guaranteeing democracy, the rule of law and the protection of universal human rights are therefore essential. Membership must be the end of the path taken by candidate countries. And that road is long, long. But, moreover, is a Union which itself has problems with respect to democratic principles ready for further enlargement? If the old Europe prefers to see democratically elected leaders behind bars rather than in parliament, the legitimacy to take in new members is required. And yet that is exactly what is happening today in Catalonia. At the moment, the EU is not really an example of democracy and unconditional respect for fundamental rights and freedoms. So let us first deepen before we dream of further expansion.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: Mr President, the choice of the Bulgarian Presidency for enlargement of the Union is in the right direction. The aim must be to enlarge the European Union, but with a common policy at all levels. A Europe, a voice and a policy, without national egos and without national entrenches. Enlargement countries must resolve their differences. Serbia and Montenegro have taken important steps and are expected to join in 2025. Albania and FYROM still have a lot to do, particularly as regards the rule of law. Bosnia and Herzegovina has a long way to go. You will ask me, of course, and reasonably: “Why have you Greeks not solved the problem with Skopje for 26 years? Is it a national whim, vanity or timidity?” The answer is that Greece has never left the negotiating table. Greece proposed FYROM joining NATO under an all-purpose name, erga omnes; others left. However, in no case can it accept irrepressive and aggressive aspirations, with unstoried maps claiming half the Greek territory, irrepressive references to the Constitution and forgery of history - such as that of the third Communist International and what Tito did in 1945. Thanks to Tito's aggressive aspirations for descent into the Aegean, this nation was named Macedonian and its language - a peculiar Bulgarian - was named Macedonian. Here we are to discuss with Skopje the solution of the problem without irrepressive tendencies.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Mr President, the accession of the Western Balkans, which in the past became a theatre of bloody conflict, is a historic window of opportunity for peace and prosperity in the wider region. As shadow rapporteur for Montenegro's accession, I would like to express my delight at the progress made in institutional reforms. I believe that before 2025 we will be able to welcome Montenegro as the 28th member of the Union. However, I would like to refer in particular to the FOM and the need to find a fair solution in the nomenclature, which is respected by both peoples. A solution without irredendences at the expense of Greece. Skopje cannot want to monopolise Macedonia's name and build false historical consciences using the history of neighbouring peoples. The Copenhagen criteria and good neighbourly relations are the imperatives of our common values towards the old demons of nationalism and intolerance which some, either for geopolitical reasons or in order to serve their internal political interests, are again trying to awaken.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Mr. President! At the beginning of the current legislative term, President Jean-Claude Juncker referred the integration of the Western Balkan countries into the precarious future. This circumstance has greatly pushed back the progress and performance of these countries. It is welcome that the current decision on the EU's enlargement strategy for the Western Balkans aims to give new impetus to the tired and stalled integration process. This is facilitated by the new Bulgarian Presidency making the accession of its neighbours to the Western Balkans a priority. Hungary and the Visegrád Four, as well as Romania, are also committed in this direction. An important step forward is that during his last visit to Belgrade, President Antonio Tajani predicted the accession of Serbia and Montenegro before 2025. Further concrete steps and results are needed. For Macedonia and Albania, a date should be set for the start of accession negotiations. Bosnia and Herzegovina shall be included in the nominees. The Kosovo issue must be resolved definitively. However, there are two of the fair. The Western Balkan countries must also fully fulfil their European commitments. Integration of countries in this region is also of common European interest for the protection of EU borders and the completion of the Balkan migration route.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: Mr President, the Western Balkans region is - quite rightly so - one of the priorities of the Bulgarian Presidency. There are many advantages of enlargement. Prosperity in all Member States and stability in the region, where the European Union is now becoming one of the most important security factors, while excluding the involvement of third countries trying to play a hegemonic role creating problems. It is imperative that we give new impetus to the enlargement process. But there is a need to solve problems in the areas of the rule of law, fundamental rights and the fight against corruption. It is clear to all the candidate countries that they must remain committed to the European path and fulfil all their obligations. The peoples of Europe are ready to welcome the Western Balkans within it, but without any rebates on principles, values and obligations. As shadow rapporteur for Bosnia and Herzegovina, I would like to stress that the country's European perspective will change the facts so far. It will positively influence the way politicians are civilized in the country and give hope for a better future to all its citizens. Reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina should be promoted in a balanced way and in a transparent and dialogue with the social partners, so as to bring about positive changes in the daily lives of all the inhabitants of the country. The difficulties remain, as the Commission's questionnaire has not yet been answered, and a lot of work is needed to implement what has been agreed.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, I would like to welcome the Commission’s Balkan strategy because it’s about our common strategic interests, but it also needs a transformation from both sides. The Western Balkans is not a neutral ground. Fake alternatives are promised by Russia, China, Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Islamist. The only chance for permanent stability and economic reforms, and also for reconciliation, is European integration. I agree with Commissioner Mogherini that the Western Balkan region will succeed together or fail together and this will be our shared opportunity and responsibility. However, strengthening democracy and the rule of law remains the concrete responsibility of each country in that region. Progress and stability cannot be achieved at the expense of good governance by neglecting the rule of law and respect for democratic procedure. I think the best chance to catch up with the 2025 target is a practical demonstration of political will to cooperate nationally in advancing the common EU goal. My final key word is about reconciliation, and here it is opportune to make reminder also of the former Macedonian President, Boris Trajkovski, who took a personal lead to bring the different Balkan leaders together for reconciliation, friendship and mutual understanding.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: – Mr President, I welcome the new Commission strategy on the Western Balkans enlargement. It is important not just for the countries of the region but also for the European Union itself: without providing a credible prospect of full membership for all the countries of the Western Balkans the EU global role will not be credible, because this is our region, this is our first commitment. We need to invest more, both politically and financially. Yes, it is a difficult process because enlargement is a joint effort. You need two to tango, and we are all aware of the efforts which have to be made by the candidate countries. But, at the same time, there is always an alternative that we should not forget, and the alternative is embracing nationalism and populism and creating rivalries and hostilities again. Where there is a will, there is always a way, and last year the Republic of Macedonia made tremendous progress towards realising that European perspective. I will quote Nelson Mandela: ‘It always seems impossible until it is done.’ So let’s do this process.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: — Mr. President, Honored Commissioner Hahn, Honored Commissioner Mogherini, personally, 15 years after the Thessaloniki summit, this is a great emotional event, both for the entire Western Balkans and for Bosnia and Herzegovina that was discussed. I hope sincerely that this year there will be major changes in Bosnia and Herzegovina, solely in finding a major compromise that will bring the country out of the dead end in which it has entered and which will take the path of integration, which will be the front runner as stated here. So 2025 was put as a limit for all countries in the Western Balkans. There is no limit for countries, the limit is only for people and in people's minds either peace is born or war is born. I welcome what Commissioner Hahn said. So we export stability so as not to import volatility and I consider this day a big day. After the Thessaloniki summit, I look forward to having a summit in Zagreb in 2020. I hope that by then we will have a stable Bosnia and Herzegovina on the path to the European Union and that we will have peace and stability in the Western Balkans because without that we leave this space to the forces already present there and unfortunately have been working beyond control for a long time.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the accession process of the countries of the Western Balkans needs mutual cooperation. It is important that the strategy includes measures such as the provision of funds, in addition to the already existing PAH Funds, which will help countries in the region achieve the conditions required for membership. Credibility must instead be the key word of the Western Balkans. Governments in the region must carry out responsible policies aimed at stability, protection of rights, combating corruption and economic development and effective transport linked to the Union. 2018 will be a favourable year to advance the enlargement process with the Bulgarian and Austrian Presidencies, but also with the new summit of the Berlin Process. In this summit, however, the intergovernmental system must be exceeded and there must be the participation of Members of the European Members who, as representatives of the citizens, cannot fail to play an active role in such a process.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: — Mr President, Mr Khan, the future enlargement of the European Union towards the Western Balkans will mean more security and stability for the Union, it will mean a stronger and united Europe. But the reception of the Western Balkan countries does not depend only on the Union's desire. The countries of the Western Balkans have a long and difficult road to go. They must have the political will to carry out decisive reforms, respect the rules and values of the European Union and meet the criteria for membership. Their path to Brussels goes through the deepening of regional cooperation and the development of good neighbourly relations. A key point for the region is also strengthening ethnic and religious tolerance, freedom of religion and faiths. Candidate Member States must put on the agenda the fundamental values of the European Union: tolerance, diversity and mutual respect. For its part, the European Union must accept the fact that the future of the Western Balkans lies in the Union. The European Union's commitment is to encourage and encourage these countries to implement the necessary reforms, to assist them in improving the transport, energy, communication and educational structure. The European Union must clearly and firmly state to the countries of the Western Balkans that in the near future, in meeting the criteria for membership, they will be accepted in the Union. It would be a big mistake to give the impression of the inhabitants of these countries that their countries will be the eternal candidates. For this reason, the European integration of the Western Balkans should be a top priority of the European Union, and not only the priority of the Bulgarian Presidency.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, it is at moments like this that we realise that the European Union is a community of values. We stand for freedom of democracy and of expression, and we stand for the strong rule of law. Clearly these six countries do not live up to these values yet. For example, for Serbia I am concerned with media freedom; I’m concerned with the attacks on members of the LGBTI community; I’m concerned about the relations with Kosovo. This shows that even a frontrunner still has a long way to go, and no specific dates can be attached to this.  I can only hope that Serbia and these other countries will choose the path of European values. But this path goes two ways. It’s good the Commission has given a real perspective to the Western Balkans, and as a community we should reach out and help to bring them closer.

name: Georgios KYRTSOS
text: Mr President, the European Commission's strategy for enlargement in the Western Balkans is, in my view, correct in theory. In practice, however, it can lead to adventures similar to those observed in connection with enlargement to Turkey. The chances of success may increase, in my view, if the following are done: firstly, we should abandon the over-ambitious objectives for the accession of Western Balkan states by 2025 and adopt a more realistic timetable, because usually after the great optimism comes the great pessimism; secondly, there must be a serious increase in the European Union's own resources to secure money for the Western Balkans and additional resources for the less developed Member States, otherwise the Union will turn into a kind of economic UN, with huge differences in development and great disagreement; thirdly, we must follow the line of the President of France, Macron, and go into a special relationship with Turkey, because the combination of enlargement to the Western Balkans and enlargement to Turkey may render the The European Union for the peoples of many Member States and to have a follow-up to the logic of Brexit; fourthly, bilateral issues must be tackled at their root and not covered up. Our aim must be the Europeanisation of the Western Balkans and not the Balkanisation of the European Union.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: — I welcome the strategy that raises doubts about the strategic importance of the Western Balkans to the European Union. It is important that it is open to all six countries in the region. It is also important that the European Union wants to regulate itself internally before enlargement. I am not a friend of dates, but I say again: credibility means that the European Union must be ready when one of the candidate countries is ready. Being prepared means sharing European values and principles, at home and with neighbours, and first of all full enforcement of the rule of law. Reconciliation is needed not only among neighbors, but also within countries with strong polarization. The strategy must be followed by such an action approach, so that there is no doubt that the European path for the Western Balkans has no alternative neither political nor by security or economic side. There was no longer a European Federate-Western Balkans summit since Thessaloniki. The first summit will happen again in Sofia in the spring. There must be the first added value after the adoption of this strategy, which has reserves in ambition. I suggest there would be more institutional osmosis at a high political level in the future. However, I want the Western Balkan countries to take advantage of the new moment as quickly as possible.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner Hahn. I warmly welcome the Western Balkans strategy that you have presented, Commissioner, and Mrs Mogherini. From a historical point of view, we Austrians have a special commitment to the people, regions and peoples in this area. But for us, the integration of the six states of the Western Balkans is a political, economic, moral and security issue. We can both benefit from this. We are therefore also reaching out our hands to the countries of the Western Balkans, but the states and the governments must take our own hands. The mention of a possible accession date for Serbia and Montenegro and all other countries is therefore not a rebate or a softening of the accession criteria. It's an incentive, it's a motivating factor. Incidentally, I would prefer to join the 2024 European Parliament elections — if the criteria are met — because then the people would also be able to take part in the elections for their Chamber of Citizens. However, many homework still needs to be done, and the European Union must also recognise the independence and sovereignty of Kosovo as a state by all states, for example. These issues need to be resolved between Serbia and Kosovo and the bilateral issues need to be resolved. We have a lot of work to do, but I am tempted to implement the perspective and thus give Europe even greater integrity and stability.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, today we are discussing the open door for the countries of the Western Balkans to join the European Union, something we considered unthinkable just a few years ago. What has changed is that the European Union has gone through many different crises. What is important is that through them we have realised that the role of the European Union as a global factor is highly contested even in our nearest neighbourhood. I am pleased that through the Bulgarian Presidency, the focus is once again on the Western Balkans — this common but somewhat forgotten European interest. I welcome that the enlargement strategy does not make promises in vain to the countries of the Western Balkans, but at the same time recognises that the European Union has a political commitment to the region. The prospect of potential membership could be a driving factor in reforms and improving stability in these countries. Let us recognise that the European Union also has its own interest in terms of security, immigration and in bringing these countries together. Therefore, the prospect of the Western Balkans must be a pan-European goal. I also welcome the fact that the European Commission is committed to a digital agenda for the Balkans. Technology and digital skills are the sector that has the greatest potential in the process of catching up to economies in the European Union.

name: Andor DELI
text: – Mr President, in 2014, at the beginning of our parliamentary term, it seemed like enlargement fatigue was irreversible. However, the migration crisis and the security challenges pointed up the fact that Europe needs the Western Balkans and that the EU cannot have white holes on its map. It also became clear that we simply cannot wait for all major political issues to be settled before we endeavour to have further enlargement. Therefore, I sincerely welcome the Commission strategy and the action plan as documents which will officially and permanently put Western Balkan enlargement back on the European agenda. Additionally, I would call on the Commission to draw up annual reports concerning the implementation of this strategy and the action plan, which should be discussed here in plenary. That would give enlargement a more prominent presence, supplementing the usual progress reports for the countries. All this could provide a strong political backdrop for the difficult work that lies ahead, on all sides, in order to welcome the front—runner countries, Serbia and Montenegro, as full members in 2025. Hungary and we in the Hungarian EPP Group delegation here in Parliament will do our best to help.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Mr President, the Western Balkan countries are a part of Europe and show clear intentions to become part of the Union. By achieving European integration, the four candidate countries and the two aspirant countries will achieve peace and stability. The Union has brought respect and successful collaboration between former long—time rivals, and I congratulate the Commission for the new strategy with concrete actions like this six flagship initiatives. Conflicts, violence and war and corruption need to be replaced by tolerance, strong democracies and proactive dialogue. European integration, as a common goal, can be a fundament of political consensus among all the actors in the region. One of the good examples of this is the agreement on good neighbourly relations signed by Bulgaria and fYROM after a long period of pressures and diplomatic tensions. I would like to remind our Balkan friends that we need reliable partners who share our values, especially in the context of current global challenges and the ones that are going to arise.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, one thing is certain, the path of the countries of Southeast Europe, namely the Western Balkans to the European Union, is set out and completely open. With this strategy, we stop thinking that it is negotiated with states without the real intention of actually becoming member states and that is a very important message. I have three key messages. One: six states are not at the same stage of the accession process, and this is especially pointed out by Commissioner Hahn Vi. If we want all six to have an equal chance in accession by 2025, then an individual approach is needed and the opening of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia, Albania and Kosovo as soon as possible. Otherwise, they will not be able to catch up with advanced Montenegro and Serbia. The second message: it is good that we are increasing IPE funding, but we also need to step up our efforts for successful use, especially in Bosnia and Herzegovina. The goal is to find solutions to use, not reasons for blocking. Likewise, the Juncker Fund to direct as much as possible towards these Member States, we don't really have projects there. And third: I particularly support the incentive to resolve unresolved issues with neighbours. It's all important. And the issue of borders, cultural treasures and respect for minority rights, but I would especially put the issue of the missing. And now I feel the pain of the people who were in the European Parliament at the conference on the missing MEPs and the only thing they want is to be able to come to the grave of their child, husband, wife, father, mother. Imagine, in the 21st century, that it was people's greatest wish. What democratic standards and the rule of law can we talk about until this is resolved.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: — Dear Commissioner Hahn, sincere congratulations and thank you for this document you brought to the European Parliament. The most in this document is worth it to be clear. It gives the six countries of the Western Balkans living among the five European Union countries that have a clear perspective that they can become members of the European Union. There is also a clear message that it is necessary to respect the criteria for joining the European Union, eliminating corruption, respecting the rule of law and, more importantly, to be able to participate in the region, establish mutual cooperation, forgive yourself for the past and move the view forward. This is also the guarantor of peace in this part of Europe, for peace in my immediate neighbourhood. What is also very important is that, for the first time, what I have been saying here in Parliament for three years is that these countries need to be helped more intensively than the European Union today. It is necessary to help primarily to make them stronger economically, that young people who are leaving today and are cheap labor in Austria, Germany, other European countries, that these people will stay home, to create the future at home and that they will be the guarantor of the prosperity of these countries. This is also important for us to have strong countries in Europe, with which countries such as Slovenia, which traditionally have good relations with these countries, will also trade in the future. My sincere congratulations, I hope that what the European Union has made is fulfilled, and above all, that countries will properly understand and fulfil what their commitments are.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I very much welcome the initiative to focus more on the Western Balkans and to help our partners in getting closer to the European Union. As Member of Parliament for the Czech Republic, I want to emphasize one aspect that has also been discussed here, namely the geopolitical aspect. The moment we are not active in the Balkans, the moment we let the Western Balkans be, then Russia is going to be strengthening there in this area. I say this as a Czech MP. We had a presidential election in the Czech Republic a few days ago. Unfortunately, the pro-Eastern candidate, the current President Zeman, won, and on our country we clearly see that, in short, Russia's interests in the former areas of the RVHP, in the former post-communist bloc remain and on the contrary, they are growing. So even from my own experience in the Czech Republic, I say, let's make a more active policy in the Balkans, because Europe and its values need to win here.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the debate on the relationship between the EU and the Western Balkans must fully take into account the perspectives of citizens, and more particularly the younger generation. The high youth unemployment rate in Western Balkan countries – for example, more than 60% youth unemployment in Bosnia and Herzegovina – and the overall lack of opportunities has led to an unprecedented and ongoing brain drain which could deprive the country of an entire generation of well—educated young leaders. So offering economic and social opportunities to young people, including ensuring the better representation of women and girls in the labour market, must be the top priority at every level of government. But most importantly, the youth must be trusted and allowed to actively participate in the decisions that affect the future of their country. We must support the emergence of a generation of young Balkans to lead their countries on this European path, and so that means we have to invest in people-to-people contacts, youth, culture and education.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Mr President, a fundamental prerequisite for the admission of a new Member State to the European Union must be regarded as respect for international law and, of course, a fundamental principle of international law is the inviolability of borders. However, FYROM, with its capital in Skopje, has for decades been fuming irredeniable aspirations and territorial claims against Greek Macedonia. At the same time, this state tries to usurp the Greek cultural heritage by projecting untold claims of continuity with Alexander the Great's ancient Macedonia, with which today's Slavophone residents of Skopje have nothing to do with it. All this indicates the beginning of the rise of issues of changing borders at the expense of Greece. It must be made clear to the Government of Skopje that this is completely incompatible with any thought of entering the Union.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Mr President, the entry of new members must be consistent with the Treaties but also with common sense. When shortcomings are identified in all the convergence criteria, from corruption to the rule of law, then the narrative that the only unfinished business is in detail, such as the issue of Macedonia's name, is grotesque. But beyond any criteria, it is foolish to trust a country, and above all its government, when it steals the name, language, history and culture of another state and has irreparable intentions at the expense of my country, Greece. And I ask: why Berlin, Brussels and America are pushing Greece to tolerate the false name and not pushing Skopje to accept the truth; that they are Slavs and not, of course, Macedonians? The deafening gathering of the Greek, and not only, people in Thessaloniki and Athens, but also of Greeks around the world, is a statement to Greek politicians and European partners that we do not discuss with usurpers.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: — I welcome the beginning of a political debate on the future of the Western Balkans, as it needs a clear European perspective. And only in this way will we motivate countries to meet political and economic conditions and introduce the necessary reforms. The membership of the Western Balkan countries in the European Union, which also enjoys high support among people, is a guarantor for the stability of the wider region and for the easing of certain tensions between the countries. The issue of enlargement of the European Union to the Western Balkans has been pushed to the brink in recent years due to many crises we have faced. Reform efforts in these countries have slowed down, the proportion of people who do not believe they will ever come to the European Union at all. In addition, we are witnessing the increased interest of some superpowers seeking to increase their influence in the Western Balkans. Because of all of the above, we need to pay more attention to countries in this region in the future.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, the six Western Balkan states have, admittedly, a future in our common European family, not so much because of geography, but as long as they apply the rule of law and international law in practice. However, not all Western Balkan states are in the same place. For example, if we compare the whereabouts of the present Turkey, which is already in accession status, with the whereabouts of some of these Member States, we will see that, admittedly, some states in the Western Balkans are in a better position. But, Mr President, 2018 is also a year of Cultural Heritage, which defines our values and our values determine our future. Be honest and rely on the truth: the so-called state in Skopje has nothing to do with Greek Macedonia and Alexander the Great. Let us finally be honest about having a common European future.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Mr President, I find the Commission optimistic about the question of the accession of the Western Balkan countries to the Union. It proposes, over time, the accession of five states and one province, but as usual overlooks the reality. Bosnia and Herzegovina is only an artificial state created by NATO raids and still exists only thanks to continued support from German interests. Serbia will soon meet the membership criteria, although I would advise Serbs to avoid it; so will Montenegro. Kosovo is only a province of Serbia, and the Commission would do well to respect the five Member States which only recognise it as a province. Albania, on the other hand, with its constant - almost official - expansionist aspirations and the long-term oppression of the Greek minority in Northern Epirus, must never join the Union. Finally, the state of Skopje, with the theft of the name, identity and history of Greek Macedonia, is called upon to forget once and for all any prospect of membership. Recently, the Greek people, with two gigantic rallies, made it clear that there is no negotiation with Skopje, and the only acceptable solution would be the adoption of a name without the term “Macedonia” or its derivative.

name: Milan ZVER
text: — Today is a happy day for all citizens living in the countries of the Western Balkans. This Communication or the deadline given by the European Union will surely be implemented or adopted in the coming years. However, I would like to point out the following: when they fulfil all the conditions for membership of the European Union must surely be accepted into the European Union. But it is not right that we are now putting additional conditions on them, as the President of the European Commission put forward in the morning, when he said that they must first resolve their border issues. All those who know the history, the geostrategic situation in the Balkans know that this is not easy and that this is an additional condition which can also become an obstacle to the integration of these countries even though they would meet all the conditions for full membership of the European Union.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr. President! The key issue for EU stability is to accelerate the integration of the Western Balkans, and the EU cannot stop talking about enlargement. In recent years, the Commission has followed this path, which has resulted in a decrease in interest in accession in the countries of the region. Other global and regional political actors have at the same time become extremely active in the region, providing a development perspective for the countries of the Western Balkans. Although there are people in Europe who would stop further enlargements, it should be noted that EU integration cannot be complete without the Western Balkans. The idea that ethnic conflicts in the region will become problems within the EU, utopia to think that after accession all historical grievances will be forgotten by these nations. The solution is therefore to develop an EU system for minority protection, which prepares for this situation, and not to hope that ethnic tensions will disappear after accession.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first and foremost I would like to thank you for this debate and, in particular, for the very strong and overwhelming support and commitment to the whole strategy which have been expressed by almost all of you. Secondly, we should not forget that we are talking about a region of 18 million people, surrounded by EU Member States, which is still in fragile and shaky shape. It is not necessary, I think, to reiterate why it is so important, not least in terms of European interests, to give those people a European perspective.  Thirdly, I have heard several times about an accession date of 2025; some Members even talked about all of the countries joining the Union by 2025. That is an indicative date, a prospect, and it should demonstrate that if there is strong political will, and dedication in the countries themselves, then it is possible to conclude negotiations and join the Union. But this means, once again, strong political will, a readiness to carry out necessary reforms and, in particular, to prove the sustainability of measures which have been called for. So in a way we have learned our lessons from previous accession negotiations and therefore we are now talking more and understand better that what matters is the process rather than negotiations.  A process takes time and therefore it is necessary to strike the right balance between the prospect of a lasting – not to say long-lasting – process and keeping motivation and stimulation alive. Therefore, it was necessary to indicate that there can be light at the end of the tunnel and link it to a certain date, but we are not saying that everything will happen without any fulfilment of conditions. It is important to stress this again and again.  Finally, I have two requests for Members. Firstly, I want to appeal to all of you. If we are to continue this process it is definitely necessary to have compromise in one form or another. That is democracy and democracy means finding a compromise in which everybody has to give in a little bit in order to get more. This is important for making the necessary progress. We also need to understand that on our side. The second request: I have felt this very strong support here, and I am also speaking on behalf of Federica Mogherini, but we are all responsible and called upon to communicate back home about what we are talking about here, what we are thinking, and what we believe to be necessary, for today I believe that the bigger challenge will be to convince our own citizens. We have to start communicating to our citizens why all this is necessary, why it is also in our interest, and we have to start doing it today and not in two or three years’ time. Therefore, we should bear in mind that either we as Europeans export stability or else we will import instability and keep the level of instability that we are still facing in the region today. So it is in our own interest, but of course our friends and partners in the region have to do their homework: they have to do what is necessary in order not only to meet European standards, but also to live up to the European values to which we are all committed and dedicated.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Thank you, Commissioner, for this conclusion, which you have very readily outlined. I'm closing the debate. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The integration of the Western Balkan countries continues to be a priority for Hungary, and therefore I am in favour of speeding up enlargement. Illegal migration can only be stopped with the help of these Balkan countries, so the countries in the region are rightfully making expectations of the European Union. Illegal immigration has brought great threats of terror and social tension into the EU, and it has proved that it still needs to be stopped at the EU's external borders. The Commission's enlargement strategy presented today redraws attention to the strategic role of the region. Raising integration to a higher level would help to reduce tensions within the region. But I see not only a political and security risk in deferring enlargement, but also an economic risk. The Commission also notes that shaping the future of the region is in the Union's own political, security and economic interest. By 2025, Montenegro and Serbia will be ready to join.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. — Diplomatic efforts by Brussels to speed up the accession of the Western Balkan countries to the EU are being multiplied these days, as evidenced by recent statements by the Commissioner Hahn and Juncker's trips planned soon to the area. The Union's totally unrealistic strategy is to provide for a normalization of relations between Serbia and Kosovo by 2019. However, it was enough the recent assassination of the leader of the moderate wing of the Serbian minority, Oliver Ivanovic, to disrupt the region again. Utopian stabilization, if we do not want to address the historical causes of ethnic feuds, primarily a strong and conflicted Islamic presence, as well as the progressive penetration of jihadist groups. But EU policy remains the same: with the promise of large European cohesion funds, to divert Serbia and other countries from the traditional closeness to Russia. A shortsighted and inconclusive policy!

name: Eugen FREUND
text: in writing. — Highest standards for EU enlargements: but this also means that existing border conflicts in the Western Balkans must be resolved before accession, and not after accession. Once before — and President Juncker has also pointed this out — these problems have simply been pushed aside before accession. This error must not happen again. However, there is still a lot of work to be done on a possible accession by 2025. It is necessary to ensure that such an accession process is guided not by a date but by the conditions fulfilled. A candidate country must meet the highest democratic standards. There is still a great need for improvement, particularly in the areas of rule of law, the judiciary, corruption, freedom of expression and the media. In the case of Serbia, there are still outstanding questions. The country's relations with Kosovo still cannot be described as normalised. Existing differences, particularly with regard to demarcation, must be clarified. With regard to Montenegro, I want clear democratic structures. Before enlargement takes place, we too need to consider how we strengthen the European institutions. In a larger Union, the ability to make decisions must be guaranteed.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – I welcome the reinforced Enlargement Strategy entitled ‘Credible Perspective of Enlargement to the Western Balkans’, which is in line with President Juncker’s announcement during the 2017 State of the Union address and reaffirms the European perspective for all Western Balkans countries, by recognising the efforts of the frontrunners, Serbia and Montenegro. Being recognised too by the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council of the EU as a main priority, further integration of Western Balkans countries will, I am certain, improve the stability of Europe as a whole. Accordingly, we need to encourage reforms, reconciliation, regional cooperation and good neighbourly relations. Indeed, the economic convergence of the Western Balkans may be a long-term process, taking into account the problems, such as high unemployment, low productivity and weak competitiveness, that some of these countries face. As a final remark, I would like to underline that ensuring a clear European perspective for these countries would stimulate the acceleration of reforms while also increasing youth opportunities for education and work and offering young people clear prospects for their future.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: in writing. — The countries of the Western Balkans should be in the European Union! They have had a troubled history, but they have culture and traditions that play their role in Europe. Important politicians say that if the Western Balkans had not existed, Western Europe would have invented them. Obviously, the Western Balkan states can contribute to diversity, increasing the consistency and strength of the European Union. I believe that the 2025 horizon is realistic if we, as the European Union, provide technical assistance with knowledge of European values. Just as the family with several children takes care of everyone to teach them respect for the value of their family, so should the European Union help the Balkan states and their citizens to understand European values.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. — I welcome the European Commission's initiative to present a strategy for the Western Balkans, reopening the option of accession of these countries to the EU as they meet the accession criteria. However, I regret that the same European Commission refuses to prepare a strategy for the Republic of Moldova as well. I believe that the Republic of Moldova must also be supported by the same instruments proposed for the Western Balkan countries, in order to meet the criteria for accession to the EU.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: in writing. — It is clear from the debate on the Western Balkans that the EU intends to proceed with further enlargement around 2025, provided that the conditions are met and cross-border problems are resolved, in which - as has been said - the EU will not be involved. Under these circumstances, if Skopje wants EU membership, it will have to abandon its irrebellious policy against Greece, which means that no complex name called Macedonia can be accepted. The attitude of the Commissioner for Enlargement, Johannes Han, who has refrained from recalling previous public references in which he called Macedonia Macedonia, is unacceptable. As far as Albania is concerned, if that country continues to cultivate the ideatism of Great Albania by coveting Kosovo, Tetovo and regions of Western Greece, and violently violating the human, religious, educational, cultural and property rights of its Greeks In Northern Epirus, the only certainty is that it will never join the EU. Kosovo, for the Republic of Cyprus, is still a province of Serbia.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. — The strategy for the accession of the Western Balkans to the EU opens up a wide window of opportunities for those countries, from which they should benefit to the maximum extent. Fifteen years after the Thessaloniki Declaration, the Western Balkans return to the EU enlargement agenda with a clear realization that without them the European project is incomplete and there are gaps in European security. A stable and secure EU is only possible with the Western Balkans integrated in it. The strategy opens doors for more intensive cooperation with the Western Balkans, for faster progress on their accession, with a clear horizon by 2025. Six major initiatives and dozens of concrete measures will help make this perspective irreversible, but before that it must be the choice of the peoples of these countries for their European future. No doubt the prospect of accession will speed up reforms in countries, encourage more people to maintain historical choices, help resolve many disputes between countries and heal wounds from past conflicts. The priorities of the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council of the EU towards the Western Balkans have moved the European political space. The momentum must be preserved with concrete steps from each country, with irrevocable commitments from the EU, in order to turn the Western Balkans into a region of peace, prosperity and tranquility.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item of order of the day is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Zimbabwe (2017/3022 (RSP)).

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, Zimbabwe has a unique opportunity for change. For the first time since independence, a transition of power has begun. We still do not know where this transition will end. Europeans would like, first and foremost, to accompany the people of Zimbabwe on the path of political and economic reform. We want to sustain their hope that real change is possible and help them realise their aspiration to democracy and social justice. This is our offer to the country: we are ready to intensify our cooperation and be with you in this moment of your history. It will be up to the people of Zimbabwe to decide the new course of the country. Yet I believe it is already quite clear what kind of change the people of Zimbabwe are asking for. Zimbabwe is a country of talented people with good education. They are asking for human rights, democracy and the rule of law. They are asking for an opportunity to prove their talents and put the country’s economy back on track. The country needs structural change that will require strong popular backing. Reconciliation and an inclusive dialogue are essential, and they are possible. They will require, first and foremost, respect for the constitutional order, the rule of law and the fundamental rights of all citizens. We then hope that the new authorities will organise inclusive, transparent and credible elections later this year. A peaceful electoral campaign and credible elections can set the country on track towards positive change. It is precisely for this reason that we have already started to assist the Zimbabwe Election Commission in establishing a credible electoral role through biometric voter registration. We are also supporting the local media with training on how to cover elections, and also inter-party dialogue and civic and voter education, and this support could be enhanced. I would also support the idea of an electoral observation mission by the European Union, provided that the required conditions are fulfilled and that we receive an invitation from the Government of the country. The economic situation also needs to be addressed as a matter of urgency. We count on the Government to reengage quickly and substantively with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. On our side, we will continue to work very closely with international financial institutions towards a package of measures to stabilise the economy and guarantee basic social services. The people of Zimbabwe have the opportunity to close a difficult chapter in their history and start anew. It is a delicate and decisive moment for the country. All those who are working for progress in Zimbabwe can count on us in strong cooperation with the United Nations, the African Union and the Southern African Development Community. It is now up to the new authorities to make the first move. A first and encouraging discussion took place in Addis Ababa last week between the President and Commissioner Mimica. Our next steps will depend entirely on the new Government’s actions and its commitment to change. We see an entire people hoping for progress and for true democracy. The aspirations of the people of Zimbabwe are our own aspirations and we want to make sure that this opportunity is not wasted and that the mistakes of the past do not happen again. But if Zimbabweans embraces the path of change, they can count on the European Union to be with them every step of the way.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President! High Madam Representative! In fact, I can repeat these encouraging words, although recent political developments in Zimbabwe show hope for democratisation of the country, restoring the rule of law and improving the standards of protection of human rights. I welcome President Mnangagwa's promise to hold free elections in the second half of 2018 and respect the will of the people regardless of the outcome. We count everyone that the president keeps his word and that power will be handed over and established in a fully democratic and peaceful manner. As you mentioned, the European Union is ready to support the elections by organising an observation mission in Zimbabwe. In addition, it was recently decided to launch three projects worth around 3 million euros to support the rule of law within the European Development Fund. Restoring democratic rule of law in Zimbabwe will make the international community more likely to provide development aid to the country. It is also important to maintain stability in this region of Africa. It is important to remember how the events of a few months ago affected the neighbouring countries of Zimbabwe. An example here is Botswana, which has welcomed thousands of refugees from this country in a short time. At the same time, ensuring internal stabilisation is crucial to boosting Zimbabwe's appeal to investors and opening up its economy to the world. These are extremely important issues in view of improving the economic situation after many years of stagnation and impoverishment of citizens due to high levels of inflation. We will closely follow developments in Zimbabwe in the coming months. I hope that the current changes in the country will open a new chapter in its relations with the European Union and the international community and allow for the creation of conditions for sustainable development in Zimbabwe.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the High Representative Federica Mogherini for his work and also for this statement. Emmerson Mnangagwa passed into power in Zimbabwe in November, following Mugabe's resignation, pressed by the army, ZANU-PF and popular mobilization. During the negotiations for the surrender of Mugabe, we were left with bated breath because we feared that the situation could get out of hand, resulting in violence. Fortunately the alternation took place peacefully and the new president took office without any particular problems. The international community even took part in the settlement ceremony, a sign that the handover of power between Mugabe and his former deputy has found liking. Today the country is aiming for the general election due by July, if we can give credence to the president's recent statement. That would be so respected the normal electoral process. On this, too, we must recognise that the country's new leaders are giving positive signals. Transparency and impartiality are at stake on the issue of election. The current president was the first to promise them, calling with serenity also the assumption of the involvement of an election observation mission by the European Union, as already mentioned by the High representative. The elections are dutiful, because the current power is marked by a lack of legitimacy as a transitional regime and must therefore be confronted with the people of Zimbabwe in an electoral match that we would like to compete. Herein lies my concern: Zimbabwe is today in a political situation of hegemony of ZANU-PF, the party of Mugabe and Mnangagwa. The opposition, once embodied by Morgan Tsvangirai, shows clear signs of fatigue and this could contribute to the devaluation of political offers, i.e., lowering the protections of the townspeople of Zimbabwe. On this point and on human rights we must remain vigilant and demanding of the new government of Zimbabwe.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I speak as Chairman of the Friends of Zimbabwe in the European Parliament. We can only welcome the overthrow of Mugabe’s tyranny that took place last November, but I want to look forward now and there is indeed hope for the people of Zimbabwe. The international community needs to help reinforce that hope. Morgan Tsvangirai was mentioned, and I want to put on record our admiration for Morgan Tsvangirai as the MDC leader who campaigned over so many years for democratic change in Zimbabwe. He seriously ill at the moment. I hope I can speak on behalf of all Parliament in saying we send our best wishes to him for a strong recovery. I wrote to Emerson Mnangagwa immediately before he became President urging him to initiate the much—needed political, economic and social changes to set Zimbabwe on a fresh course. He must be assured that if he does the right thing then we will give Zimbabwe every possible support, but we need to know that the Zimbabwean authorities are indeed committed to a new path. That means action against political thugs. Just four days ago Joice Mujuru and her supporters were injured by such thugs on their way to a political meeting in the Glen Norah suburb of Harare. Violence and intimidation has to stop.  I am most encouraged by what Ms Mogherini had to say on the subject of support for the elections to make sure they are indeed credible elections, and indeed on an economic package.  The possibility of Zimbabwe rejoining the Commonwealth is under active consideration. I very much hope the Zimbabwean Government will commit itself to this and it will be invited to send observers to the CHOGM meeting in London.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, a year ago, we warned about the situation in Zimbabwe and the role that the European Union was playing. We already reject any external operation, as well as interference in Zimbabwe's internal affairs for mere geostrategic purposes that are only in the European Union's economic interests. Let's face it because people suffer problems. Poverty, unemployment, chronic malnutrition are the main problems facing this country. And we believe that these problems can only be solved through government public policies, supported by solidarity and international cooperation. Zimbabwe is also one of the most indebted countries in the world and exemplifies, once again, that we need to address debt from a human rights-based approach and its long-term sustainability, as well as fair standards that redefine lending mechanisms. Without all this, we will remain inconsistent, we will use our declarations on third countries as stick and carrots in terms of economic interests and neglecting the real problems of an entire people.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (NL) Mr President, of course there is hope now that Mugabe has left and there is a new president in Zimbabwe. But Emmerson Mnangagwa has a history in that country. Emmerson Mnangagwa is a comrade of Mugabe, who was involved in the massacres in Matabeleland. Now you never make peace with nice people — I understand very well — and it is, of course, a step forward that this change has taken place peacefully. But we must also realise that there is much more wrong in that country than just an economic problem. Indeed, I believe that Emmerson Mnangagwa will pursue a different kind of economic policy, and that this is also good for international investors. But if we just gave him the benefit of the doubt because he's not Robert Mugabe, then we're gonna miss a chance. The elections are in July or June. After the elections, this government, which is made up of very many soldiers, gained new legitimacy. Before that time, they are looking for legitimacy. I think now is the time to ask for democratic change as well. For example, the public order security act can be changed. The country has been engaged in constitutional reforms for decades. There is no reason to wait until after the elections to drop that demand with Mr. Mnangagwa. Civil society is currently weak. This is also because, after that government of national unity, we Europeans said a few years ago: 'Let it be, we are now going to bet on the government'. The opposition is incredibly weak. So we can assume that after the elections in June or July there will be a ZANU-PF parliament. Then it is important to organize your checks and balances differently. So it is up to us now to ask questions about democratisation and now to help civil society.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Mr. Stuger wanted to ask the question by picking up a blue card. However, I have a request: The Lord will be the speaker, and since we have a delay that has already built up during previous speeches, I would like to ask that those of you who will be speakers do not ask questions in blue card mode.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am tentatively optimistic about the prospects for Zimbabwe under this new administration. The former breadbasket of Africa has been ruined by decades of misrule by a despot whose policies were built more on bitterness over old wounds than on optimism for Zimbabwe’s ‘home together’. Already there are signals coming from the Government for a fair resolution to the farming issue, which I welcome. Zimbabwe is a crucial cornerstone for the prosperity and security of Eastern and Southern Africa. The situation is, however, delicate, and we must be sure not to rush ahead with unfairly high standards pressured onto Zimbabwe, as the EU usually likes to do. If Zimbabwe is to progress it must be allowed to do so at a reasonable pace, led by its own domestic society with region—led support from the Southern African Development Community (SADC) and the African Union.  It would be a positive move for Zimbabwe to rekindle its relationship with the Commonwealth and build on the latent trade potential which an organisation of such historically and culturally close countries can provide.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, I would like to agree with all my UK colleagues who have spoken on Zimbabwe, and I have hope for that country too, but I do not want to talk about Zimbabwe, I want to talk about human rights in South Africa. We have spoken about Zimbabwe so many times in this Chamber, but why is South Africa not on the agenda? South Africa is the rape capital of the world and 109 rapes are recorded every day. In 2016, there were 42 000. They have one of the highest per capita murder rates in the world, with 52 murders every day. In 2017, there were 463 brutal farm attacks and 94 murders. So far in 2018, today, there have been 38 farm attacks, four murders – that is a 27% increase. But human rights is still not on the agenda. And racial discrimination. We all condemn that in this Parliament, yet do you condemn the Marxist ANC’s black economic-empowerment programme that discriminates against white people because of the colour of their skin? And do you condemn the racially motivated farm attacks and murders from blacks and whites? Why are we not having a discussion on the brutal attacks and the human rights abuses in South Africa?

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I would just like to ask your Member and others to talk about Zimbabwe, not other parts of Africa.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Mr President, back to Zimbabwe. I understand the current development in this country is a sign of hope. As previous speakers have pointed out, the 37 years of Mr Mugabe’s authoritarian regime caused Zimbabwe’s economy to plummet, created social unrest and isolated the country internationally. The rule of law was not only ignored, but police brutality against critics of the regime was commonplace. Now the path towards democracy seems to be in sight. Mr Mugabe’s decision to step down as President was the right choice and definitely overdue. The Zimbabwean people are now desperately seeking a government that is able to establish the necessary reforms, but first and foremost to listen to what the people are saying. The upcoming electoral process will be an essential step. We should welcome the commitment of the authorities in Harare to hold the elections in line with the Constitution, and underline the importance that the conditions are in place to allow those elections to be peaceful, inclusive, credible and transparent. I would like to acknowledge, and also commend, the efforts taken by the High Representative in offering assistance with reform processes in Zimbabwe. The European Parliament, as has been pointed out, is ready to start the preparation of an election observation as soon as we receive an invitation. We ought to stress firmly the responsibility and the accountability that lie in these promised elections. Democratic processes and the rule of law are the foundations of a peaceful society. I sincerely hope the Zimbabwean people will accomplish this through democratic and conflict-free elections.

name: Boris ZALA
text: – Mr President, the ongoing transition of power in Zimbabwe creates a new window of opportunity. The EU must be flexible and ready to deepen relations with Harare and provide economic and political support for positive change. But we must also set clear conditions. Most important of all is the return of the rule of law and political freedoms and the re-establishment of civilian rule over the military. It must also include a clear path to inclusive and fair elections in 2018, which could also be observed by the European Parliament. Moreover, the EU could – and should – be an important partner in the government’s effort to restore growth and create new jobs for Zimbabweans. The EU has an important role to play in Zimbabwe’s future, if Member States pursue a common position. We have to show a brighter perspective for Zimbabwe than other players, especially China. We possess potentially strong tools and leverage when it comes to supporting Zimbabwe’s transition. Let’s make sure we use our leverage wisely.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Mr President, I would agree with the High Representative that Zimbabwe entered a political transition period. I just hope that Mugabe's successors will not be as corrupt as his regime was. I do not believe that the only problem was Mugabe, whose biological cycle was coming to an end. Certainly the transition period will not end with the elections, however smoothly they may take place. There is a chronic hatred among citizens because of the practice of transferring tribes from one place to another to commit violence. So are white people, today, going through a very difficult time and have nothing to do with the past. The economic problems are enormous and neither the President nor the hegemonic policy of the European Union can solve them individually. Life is particularly hard in the countryside, although Zimbabwe could solve the food problem of the whole of Africa on its own, as it is a very fertile country. Let us not forget, too, that HIV-positive people exceed 50%. When I first went there, it was 75%. Moreover, infrastructure in hospitals and schools is non-existent, especially in the countryside.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: – Mr President, after a very long time of leadership, President Mugabe finally resigned from power, ceding to internal pressures and opening a new and delicate scenario. In a situation where the economy of Zimbabwe is on the brink of collapse, the upcoming electoral process will be critical for the future of the country and for the re-establishment of the rule of law. The new President, Emmerson Mnangagwa, recently said that a transparent election will be held by July and that he will respect the result if the opposition wins. Fair and free elections are essential in order to stand any chance of reviving the comatose economy and improving the country’s relations with the West. During previous elections Zimbabweans have suffered serious human rights violations and severe abuses, including killing and torture. We should manifest our support to the country to prevent the recurrence of such violence. As the forthcoming, pre—electoral period is crucial for Zimbabwe, I believe that the European Union should monitor this essential step and provide the support and the assets needed to achieve fair and transparent elections.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: Mr President, the enlargement of the EU always looks to the east, to corrupt and unstable countries such as Albania and Ukraine. But why not look south? Why is the South being discriminated against? Because if we look south, then at some point we encounter Zimbabwe. And I think Zimbabwe is the ideal new country for strengthening the EU. I'll explain to you why. Zimbabwe has historical links with Europe and the official language is English. In addition, Zimbabwe is capable, the people of Zimbabwe are able to start a revolution, in which the President is expelled without the help of Mr van Baalen or Mr Verhofstadt. Finally, it is a country that has already received so much aid from the EU — hundreds of millions of euros — that the accession funds have actually already been paid. So, Mr President, through you I would like to ask Mrs Mogherini to step over her own shadow and to offer Zimbabwe EU membership.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: – Mr President, I am aware that the carnival season is starting but I was not that aware that it had already cast its shadow over one or two colleagues! To return to more serious matters, I welcome every sentence that the High Representative has said about the involvement that the European Union intends to recommence with Zimbabwe, after a long period where our presence was not only not overwhelming but indeed not much welcomed. I want, however, to draw attention to the fact that such a state of affairs may well be lingering on, at least in part. Nearly four decades of Robert Mugabe’s rule have estranged the European continent from parts of the Zimbabwean population and we need to win back a significant share of trust – trust which has now, very intentionally, been shifted towards China and the general idea of the East. It is probably a good thing that, precisely at this time when we are reconsidering our strategic partnership with Africa, we should get the chance to prove what we can actually mean in terms of reconstituting a democratic state in the southern part of the African continent and helping it along both democratically and economically. Zimbabwe has tremendous possibilities that it could use in its relationship with Europe. We should seize all these opportunities, and maybe win back trust that was lost.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Mr President, when Mugabe finally resigned the people of Zimbabwe and the world applauded. A positive wave has arisen and a better future for Zimbabwe is coming. As if the misery and oppression of the regime had been the work of a single man. Those who removed Mugabe from power, like current President Emmerson Mnangagwa, have been accomplices and beneficiaries for decades. We must not forget the tremendous challenges facing the country. Corruption proliferates, millions emigrated, in 2017 there were floods, cholera outbreaks and typhoid fever. The economy is on the verge of collapse. The announced elections may be an opportunity, but will there be genuine competition? Will elections really be called? The European Union alongside the African Union must be at the forefront in supporting the forces of society that want Zimbabwe to begin the transition to democracy. It is essential that there is a clean and genuine transition and not merely cosmetic. In order to achieve this, the European Union must be involved, it must demand, must support structural reforms of governance including the justice sector, including the organisation of the electoral process and everything relating to the democratic empowerment of the party forces, the media and civil society that have to be included in a real dialogue for the democratic future of the country.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, I would like to reinforce everything Ms Atkinson had to say about the South African farm murders. And having lived in Zimbabwe in the 1970s I have witnessed how that country really can work to the benefit of all its citizens. So what needs to be done to get this show back on the road? First, repeal the law that requires 51% of a business to be owned by local people. This is restricting investment. Second, privatise the coal and steel industries to raise some immediate cash for the Government and allow investment to create jobs and exports. Third, privatise the railways, which have virtually ceased to function. They will be needed to transport this new coal and steel. Fourth, use the revenue raised from privatisation to compensate displaced white farmers in exchange for the return of their title deeds. Fifth, offer the resultant vacant farmland on 99-year assignable leases to competent commercial farmers who can use these leases as security for borrowing. This borrowing will allow them to restart the farm, creating jobs, food and exports. Ninety-five per cent of the potential workforce are unemployed. What good are nationalised industries doing them? Zimbabwe is the perfect example of how to destroy a country through well-meaning socialist policies.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: — Panie Przewodniczący! In 2000, I was the last head of an European Parliament election observation delegation in Zimbabwe. We have not been invited again since then, and that is why I am pleased to hear that it is apparently planned to invite us with other international observers this time. But I would also like to underline what other Members have already said: it is now also a matter of good words being followed by action. This means, in particular, that in the run-up to the elections, fair conditions prevail for all parties, for example, to update the electoral list in Zimbabwe. And it is also important to me that it should be possible for the many millions of Zimbabweans who have fled to South Africa, among other things, to register again in time in order to be able to participate in this election, because they have suffered most, even abroad, from the difficult conditions. need to. I hope that we do not have a situation where the old guard can hold on to power — only without Mugabe. If you look closely, there are a lot of military personnel in the cabinet, who have also enriched themselves for many years, and the old ruling class is unchallenged. That is why it is very important that we also call for the principles that we apply everywhere to free and fair elections. After that, a process of national reconciliation must also take place in this country. Here too, I think we might be able to help.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: — Mr President, High Commissioner, the outflow of power of dictator Mugabe was in itself a very positive event which was, moreover, duly welcomed by the people of Zimbabwe on the streets and by the general international community. It has thus opened up the possibility of moving towards a new phase, a new political cycle in Zimbabwe and the European Union naturally has responsibilities for various reasons, for historical reasons, for reasons which have to do with what is its own vision of the international framework in accompanying this new situation in Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe is now going through a phase of tension as is proper to these moments of great political change. The new president has already committed himself to promoting reforms aimed at democratizing society and promoting measures to promote the prosperity of the country, and has already made many positive announcements in this regard. Moreover, the European Council already welcomed this position on 22 January and clearly expressed positive expectations for a peaceful transition. But we must be aware that transitional periods are, by definition, periods of uncertainty, have potential but also dangers. The European Union must therefore be vigilant, especially at a time when there is an attempt to return former President Mugabe as part of the forthcoming electoral act. It would, moreover, be incomprehensible if there was no European Union election observation mission to monitor these elections in view of what has happened there so far, in other words, we have reason to hope, but we have an obligation to remain vigilant.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, the November 2017 events will go down in the history books as the days when the world’s attention was turned to President Mugabe and his long overdue resignation. I have been following Mr Mugabe’s political career from the beginning with great interest and I was deeply disappointed by his demise from a progressive leader to an authoritarian dictator in the last four decades. The world also watched the peaceful voices of many Zimbabweans, who clearly stated that their country deserves better. They want their country to get out of diplomatic isolation, they want an economic overhaul of their devastated and crippled economy, and they want functioning democratic institutions. And now, a historical opportunity for Zimbabwe is on the horizon. There is tangible hope on the streets of Harare. It is now more important than ever to stand by Zimbabwe in the upcoming difficult transition months and to make sure that President Emmerson Mnangagwa keeps his promise to hold free, fair and democratic elections without delay. The elections are crucial in this phase of political development in the country. If conditions are favourable, and if it is acceptable for Zimbabwe, I think it would make sense to send an observation mission to these presidential elections.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Mr President, it is high time for change because Zimbabwe since 2000 has struggled to feed its people. Poverty and unemployment are endemic. The history of Zimbabwe has been a history of mismanaged and misused opportunities. About three million people have fled the country, and politically-motivated violence since 1980 has taken the lives of approximately 200 000 people. Remember that the change is not a revolution. Yes, people supported the resignation of Mugabe enthusiastically, but now they must be guaranteed that real, lasting democratic change is going to happen. The only way to guarantee the legitimacy of this change is through fair and democratic elections. The future government has to be open to cooperation with different political forces.
