As it is now, Mr Mugabe, instead of taking responsibility for numerous crimes, is planning to establish a new political party. Important in terms of the legitimacy of the latest events is that millions of Zimbabwean citizens abroad, most of them having been forced to leave, should be able to participate freely and easily in the coming elections without having to face excessive bureaucratic obstacles. This should be seen as a litmus test of whether the new leaders are prepared to be leaders of all the nation.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen. After 37 years of dictatorship, the former president of Zimbabwe, Mugabe, was removed from office by a military coup. Local observers speak somewhat mockfully of the most polite revolution of all time — after all, it is those who have so far supported Mugabe's rule that has now themselves taken into their hands the shift levers of power, like Mugabe's longtime intelligence chief and close confidant of Mugabe — the current president — Mnangagwa. Obviously, the once rich country has been so downgraded by mismanagement, corruption and arbitrary rule that the members of the former power elite have pulled the emergency brake and exchanged the president and some members of government. The population, previously deprived of their civil and human rights, danced on the streets on the night of the change of power. The future will show whether something is really changing in Zimbabwe and whether the expectations of the population are met in terms of granting civil liberties. The new president has promised early elections. It must first be established whether freedom of the press is granted and whether opposition forces are given a chance to be able to engage in political activity. Mnangagwa has pledged early elections and international election observation. We should be very attentive to developments in Zimbabwe, to encourage and support civilian forces if there is real democratic change.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! Zimbabwe is an example of what authoritarian governments can lead to: corruption, economic crisis, unemployment (amounting to as much as 90% in some environments, which is unthinkable in Europe), as well as poverty. Today, there is a chance to change this situation, difficult for the state but even more difficult for its citizens. The first step to this may be democratic elections, so the European Union should be involved in the process leading to fair democratic elections. However, I want to say that elections are not the only condition for democracy and the rule of law to be established in the state. There must be action for the restoration of the institutions of the democratic state, as well as the empowerment of citizens, the construction of civil society. This is all needed so that the European Union can renew good relations with the country and start again supporting its development. I think there's a chance for that and that we should take it.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the whole debate and I must say that I am relatively sceptical of democratic developments in this country. The departure of Mugabe in November is sure to be joyous news, but the incumbent prime minister is more likely to talk about reforms so far, and elections have not yet been declared. So I welcome what the High Commissioner said, the European Union's efforts should be maximum. To help free elections not only by sending out the observation mission itself, but we should try to interfere with the very process of preparing for the election. To help ensure that, as far as possible, those elections are at least a little free and democratic. I really have to say that I do not move optimism yet, and if any election that will be free can be organised, it will be amazing, but then the process of reform is just beginning, for which we would also they should have stood and also supported them.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Mr President, some of us here in Parliament attended the last ACP-European Union Joint Parliamentary Assembly in Haiti and there was a special debate on Zimbabwe. This was no surprise because, after 37 years in a row, President Mugabe was compelled to resign, being the second longest serving ruler in Africa, after President Obiang of Equatorial Guinea. The legacy is repression, isolation and corruption, and there is an expectation of the new transition Government although it is chaired by a former Vice-President of Mugabe, Mr Mnangagwa. So the situation means requires a very clear message from the European Union. In order to lift the current dispensation of arms embargo, freezing of assets and lack of cooperation from the European Union towards Zimbabwe, there has to be European Union involvement and oversight, and the involvement of this Parliament, making sure, by watching over them, that the elections next June are free and fair.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, the situation in Zimbabwe, despite Mugabe's removal, remains critical. The new leadership is proceeding to further militarisation of the country's political system. Instead of relying on the citizens themselves and on democratic structures, the political system continues to rely on the military. In the field of economy, austerity is now on the agenda. The Minister of Finance is proceeding with a violent fiscal adjustment, with the redundancies of three thousand employees. It also enables multinationals in the energy sector not to pay taxes for five years. It is a fact that significant changes are needed in Zimbabwe. Democratic structures need to be strengthened. Democratic and free elections are needed in order for the citizens themselves to decide on the development of their country and to have the opportunity for themselves to exploit the resources of their home country.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for too many years Zimbabwe has not been a democratic country, and it is very difficult in the transition period. And a country could not be democratic when seven million people, more than half of its population, are still on the verge of starvation, not just poverty. The information, even if it is in the past, of violent torture with beatings, electroshock and poisoning, has dramatically worsened the image. But we are now in the transition period. Perhaps there is a great opportunity for the new leadership of the country to move decisively in the right direction. To collide by any means with corruption and mismanagement. It will have our support in this direction. But it's not enough. Everything, or much, will depend on the will of the people of the country and its leadership.

name: James CARVER
text: – Mr President, Southern Africa has, in the Southern African Development Community (SADC), a structure that can support Zimbabwe’s re-emergence as an important trading partner. I believe that support not just for Zimbabwe but also for the surrounding states, such as Botswana and Zambia, will help Zimbabwe to prosper both economically and politically. I urge Zimbabwe to rejoin the Commonwealth as soon as possible. Intra-Commonwealth trade, based on historic and cultural ties, can help Zimbabwe to prosper and not to be in thrall to yet another exploitative EU free trade agreement, a fate that has already befallen many African countries to their detriment. I am optimistic about Zimbabwe’s future, but we must work with them and certainly not dictate to them.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: — Mr President, High Commissioner, High Representative, I would like to address Mrs Atkinson, who is no longer here, to tell her that South Africa and Zimbabwe are completely different countries. I lived in South Africa and I know what I'm saying, although South Africa is next door. Ladies and gentlemen, four decades of Mugabe's government have been marked by repression, fraud and corruption and the abuse of state resources that led Zimbabwe to political conflict and endemic poverty. President Mnangagwa, since taking office in November, has favored strengthening the role of the military in power structures and the announcement of economic reforms to recover foreign investment, leaving behind legal reforms that guarantee the independence of the judiciary, the neutrality of the electoral commission, the voting rights of the diaspora and the extension of the area for participation of civil society and the political opposition, which are vital for this year's elections to be free, transparent and fair. Madam High Commissioner, High Representative - I apologise to be deceiving myself all the time - I would like the Union to make political dialogue with the Zimbabwean authorities conditional on the progress of these reforms and the immediate release of political prisoners currently detained.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it has taken thirty-seven years in power to transform Robert Mugabe from a liberation hero from a white and racist minority to an authoritarian despot, a symbol of that corruption and that nepotism that today characterize many countries of Africa. At 93 Mugabe was forced to give way to his right-hand man, Vice President Emmerson Mnangagwa, a member of his own party. This man promises free and democratic elections and seems ready to welcome international observers, but let us not be fooled by appearances. He is in fact the same man who, until a few years ago, carried out, without a blink, the dirtiest orders of the outgoing president, including torture and violence of all kinds. How can we not forget the Matabeleland massacre, where 20 000 people died, or the harsh opposition repression during the 2008 campaign? If the crocodile has the support it needs today, the people of Zimbabwe have not forgotten its past, and we must not forget it either. No effort must be spared on our part to ensure free and democratic elections. The voices of Zimbabwean citizens must finally be heard.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the speakers for having expressed not only their hopes but also their concerns and their support for the work we are doing, together with Commissioner Mimica, at this crucial moment for Zimbabwe. Let me say that this debate will also be useful for us, as Commissioner Mimica is planning to go to Harare in the coming months, so we will be able to follow up on the many elements that we have discussed here today and that we have shared, because I see a convergence of approach on this. It is quite easy to conclude from this exchange that the country is indeed at a crossroads, after 37 years of the same leadership since independence, and that we see two sides of the coin. We see the opportunity for a different kind of future lying ahead and for the potential of the country to be unleashed, and we also see the risk – as some of you said – that the country could go through a cosmetic operation and that change might not come. At this crossroads, I believe the key element for us will be the forthcoming elections. Many of you made that point, and this is also why I have insisted on the fact that we are ready – and will continue to be ready – to accompany Zimbabwe, with all our instruments and policies, through this transition and after, and especially with the hope that the new leadership will live up to the high expectations raised with the end of the Mugabe era. We understand very well that this remains to be done, but the expectations are there and we can help move in the right direction. Lastly, I would like to thank Parliament for your continuing work to promote and defend human rights and democratisation in Zimbabwe. I know that it has been long—standing, constant and consistent work, for which I thank you, and also for keeping the country on our international agenda. I am looking forward to continuing our good cooperation across the institutions in the European Union to make sure that the changes are not cosmetic and that progress is really made.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Zamykam debatę.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next point of the order of the day is the joint debate on: — Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the current human rights situation in Turkey and (2018/2527 (RSP)) — by the Vice-President Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Afrin (Syria) (2018/2563 (RSP)).

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by saying that this is not the first, and will not be the last, debate in this Chamber about Turkey. We are holding this debate, I believe, because we care. We care about Turkey, we care about the Turkish people, we care about Turkey’s democracy, security and stability, and we care about security and stability in the Turkish region because it is also our region. Sometimes we refer to Turkey only as a candidate country. Let me stress one thing that is obvious: it is first and foremost, through my lens, a regional player that shares the same geographic space with us. We have disagreements and we are extremely clear on them. We have what can probably be termed a frank dialogue and, let me say this very clearly: our dialogue with Turkey is today more important than ever. The negative trend of the human rights situation in the country has not been reversed. There have been some small steps in certain human rights cases, but violations have continued, affecting prominent civil society figures, users of social media, medical staff, and the list could continue. This is on top of the initial violations we have seen in recent years, which have not been resolved. Last Friday, Commissioner Hahn and I issued a statement focusing in particular on the unprecedented decision by the Turkish authorities to contradict a ruling by the Constitutional Court. This decision goes against the Turkish Constitution and it casts serious doubt on the independence of Turkey’s justice system. The ongoing state of emergency also remains a key issue of concern. We all know that it was established in one of the most difficult moments in Turkish history, we remember those hours very well, in which we expressed our concern, our proximity with the people and the leadership of Turkey after the attempted coup d’état. Yet, one-and-a-half years later, the state of emergency has allowed measures that go well beyond those initially foreseen, and this has to be clearly stated. In parallel, it is true, there has been some work to normalise bilateral relations between Turkey and the EU Member States, and this is good news but I want to be very clear: human rights and fundamental freedoms should apply to all Turkish citizens, to all of them in the same way. In our partnership with Turkey, as I said, we have always been open and frank. We know that Turkey has faced, and is facing, incredible challenges and we have to acknowledge this: terrorist attacks on its soil, an attempted coup, a difficult refugee crisis and a war just next door. We understand Turkey’s concerns, for instance, about the situation at its borders. Turkey has the full right, and I would even say the duty, to provide safety and security to Turkish citizens living near the border with Syria, yet we are deeply worried about the new front that has been opened in northern Syria. We are worried, first of all, for humanitarian reasons. The new clashes have already resulted in civilian casualties and thousands have been displaced. Humanitarian access must be guaranteed to all those in need. The United Nations is warning that the humanitarian situation right across Syria is definitely not improving, and the people of Syria cannot afford a new front and a new crisis, adding to the other ones still ongoing in the country.  Beyond the humanitarian tragedy, the Afrin offensive could have political consequences on the internal balances inside the future Syria, on the region at large and on the potential for political negotiations, because the new escalation of violence could push further away the chances of a political solution to the conflict. We need – all of us – to concentrate all our energies on supporting the UN-led negotiations in Geneva. That is where any concerns should be raised and addressed.  The war in Syria is not over yet. People are still dying even if it is not headline news. That is happening in Afrin as well as in Idlib and elsewhere. Opening new fronts is no solution and I am afraid it will not make Turkey more secure. Real security can come only from a negotiated political solution to the conflict. We believe that all military action should focus on UN-listed terrorist organisations, not others; and it should not make peace harder to achieve. Let me also reiterate that the European Union remains committed to the unity, sovereignty and territorial integrity of Syria. We have to be extremely careful about the moves we make today, in order to avoid consequences for the future set-up in the country. Peace in Syria will require everyone’s contribution and Turkey, as one of the guarantors of the Astana Process, has an essential role to play, as well as special responsibility. The agreement reached through the Astana Process on the escalation zones needs to be pursued and implemented, including in northern Syria. We are working, together with the United Nations and all the international community, to make sure that our second Brussels Conference on the future of Syria and the region, which we will host next spring, supports the UN-led process in an effective and, indeed, a decisive manner, in particular with regard to the prospects for the future, and the need to make sure that each and every Syrian citizen will find in Syria his or her own home, his or her own country, with a system and a prospect of inclusion, and recognition of diversity and the diverse composition of the country and society. That is the only way out of the conflict in a sustainable manner. Let me finish by saying that, as you probably know, President Erdoğan was in Rome yesterday, where he met Pope Francis. During the meeting – and I quote from the text supplied by the Holy See – ‘the Pope stressed the need to promote peace and reconciliation through dialogue and negotiation, with respect for human rights and international law’. I believe that we can all share the words of Pope Francis on this occasion. For our part, we will continue our dialogue with Turkey, as we do every single week and, indeed, on a daily basis. We will keep all channels of communication open, working to overcome our differences, working to manage our differences when they remain, and working to find common solutions. We do this for ourselves, we do it for the Turkish people, and we do it for peace, security and democracy in our common region, starting with Syria.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (FR) Madam President, first of all I would like to express my great concern about the human rights situation in Turkey. Last week, together with other colleagues, I had the opportunity to meet with Turkish academics and civil society organisations. The situation they portray, we know it, is always very serious. Since June 2016, thousands of people, government employees, military personnel, judges, journalists, teachers, civil society activists and academics have been acquainted with indictment, harassment, pressure and jail for imaginary crimes, which only serve to centralize power between hands of the current authorities. That is why we must put human rights at the heart of all discussions with the Turkish authorities, including at the forthcoming EU-Turkey summit. Moreover — and we have actively supported this position in this Parliament — we must redirect funds for Turkey's accession to civil society, to those who are committed to the preservation of freedoms. This is all the more urgent because I think it is impossible to continue to talk about membership. I have been a strong supporter of Turkey's enlargement for a long time. Today, in view of recent developments, I believe that a closer partnership is the way forward in the coming years. The question of human rights should, of course, be on the agenda. As part of this partnership, we must address issues of common interest, such as the Western Balkans. The discussion around our actions in this region should be frank and open, so that it can benefit the citizens of these countries and not be subject to hidden objectives. This also applies to the Syrian case because there is a real danger that the current Turkish offensive will endanger the low chances to build peace, which are now being sketched.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to say to Osman Kavala, Ahmet Şık and Selehattin Demirtaş that, at the moment, as Turkey is going through a difficult period, it needs brave people like you to stand up for human rights and respect for the rule of law. But, for having done exactly that, you are now in a prison cell. While you cannot follow this debate, I hope your lawyers and family will inform you that we have not forgotten you and we will continue to plead for your release, as your arrests were politicised and arbitrary. Osman Kavala, Ahmet Şık and Selehattin Demirtaş are not the only innocent people in jail in Turkey. While the perpetrators of the heinous coup attempt must be prosecuted and brought to justice, many, many people have become victims of the massive crackdown on all democratic opposition voices. The numbers are mind-boggling – more than 150 000 people fired and more than 50 000 imprisoned. But remember that all these people have a faith, have a family and have friends who are hoping that normalisation is still possible. The state of emergency has led to a situation where the Government can rule by decree without parliamentary or judicial scrutiny. Every aspect of Turkish society has become securitised, meaning that all those who voice criticism of the Government’s policies are being labelled as terrorists or terrorist supporters. Legitimate and peaceful opposition is thus being silenced, in real life and on social media. In the past two weeks, almost 500 people were detained for peacefully opposing Turkey’s military operation in Afrin. There is also a structural problem with the lack of independence of the judiciary, and we witnessed last month how big that problem is. First, there was a ruling by the Constitutional Court to release jailed journalists Mehmet Altan and Şahin Alpay as their rights had been violated and, although the orders of the highest court were crystal clear, a local penal court decided to keep them in detention. Last week, we witnessed another travesty of justice. The wife and daughters of Turkey’s Amnesty International Chair were waiting in front of the gates of the prison in Izmir to welcome their loved one after eight months’ imprisonment. A judge had ruled earlier that day that he should be released, but within a couple of hours the same judge decided to order his rearrest. And, for all those people who lost their jobs by decree, there is so far little hope of remedy. High Representative Mogherini, the EU is preparing a mini summit with Turkish President Erdogan at the end of March. We could read in the papers that no preconditions have been put on the table, but I hope you can tell us what you expect in terms of results from such a meeting. We in Parliament expect the EU to be loud and clear on human rights in Turkey, as you were in your introduction just now, not only because these are the values on which our Union is based, and which Turkey as a candidate should adhere to, but also because we risk losing credibility and the support of a majority in Turkish society if we don’t stand up for their rights in these dark times.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Turkey has been moving in the wrong direction for an EU candidate country for some time under President Erdoğan and, sadly, the war in Syria and the July 2016 coup attempt have provided ample opportunity for a more openly hostile approach by the AK Parti to Western democratic norms. We therefore see today a Turkey that openly violates civil and human rights at home and pursues a foreign policy objective directly opposed to the aims of its EU and NATO allies abroad.  The situation in Afrin is the starkest of those decisions yet, as only two days ago Turkey announced in somewhat sinister terms that nearly 1 000 so-called terrorists had been neutralised since the assault began on 20 January. By ‘neutralised’, we are to read ‘surrendered’, ‘captured’ or ‘killed’. By ‘terrorists’, we are to read ‘members of the Kurdish YPG’, who have been bravely fighting against Isis across northern Syria with the support of US troops, who continue to fight alongside the YPG. The Americans have refused Turkish requests to remove their troops, paving the way for a potential clash between Turkish and US forces. Such behaviour from a NATO ally and EU candidate country is extremely concerning. Finding a way back to the peace talks between Ankara and the Kurds in Turkey will be one of the keys to normalising politics in Turkey in future, but ahead of the presidential elections at the end of next year, such prospects seem a distant hope.  Furthermore, I hope that the welcomed re-election of President Anastasiades of Cyprus will lead to renewed reunification talks, where Turkish cooperation is again vital but has, to date, been lacking. Turkey has still not implemented the Ankara Protocols, recognised Cypriot rights to gas exploration, or accepted that it must withdraw its occupying forces from northern Cyprus. Turkey must do more, and it must do more to support the goodwill that exists on that island – but, sadly, that looks very unlikely in my opinion.

name: Nadja HIRSCH
text: Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen. President Erdoğan is taking Turkey further and further away from European values and thus away from the EU. Erdoğan's Turkey will continue to move towards an unjust state. I will give just a few examples: systematic silence of the political opposition, massive restrictions on freedom of the press and freedom of expression, detention of judges, journalists, activists and citizens, and increasingly state prosecution of critical voices in social media. This lacks any understanding of freedom, the rule of law and democracy according to European standards. One thing is clear: a prospect of accession must always be realistic and, above all, presuppose a willingness for the Turkish Government to meet these criteria. But I do not see this willingness in view of the continuing disregard of human rights, fundamental rights and liberties under Erdoğan's leadership. Europe must therefore draw conclusions from this development. I say quite clearly that even if the recent constitutional changes were to be withdrawn, the accession negotiations must remain frozen. Because it is a matter of credibility: the EU is a community of values, we defend civil and human rights, and we also call for binding compliance with the Copenhagen criteria. The Turkish government itself must ask itself: does it want to be a community of values with the EU or does it want to be an illiberal autocracy? The latter definitely has no place in the EU. The military solo action in Afrin also questions Turkey's ability to alliances. This applies to the European Union, which also applies to NATO membership. Defence alliances are tied to shared values. With its actions in Afrin, the Turkish government is moving further from this common base of values. We must therefore make clear the expectations of an alliance partner Turkey in dialogue.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (EL) Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am one of many people in this Chamber, but also more broadly, who have believed and worked for years in the belief that Turkey's accession process would lead to the democratisation of that country. I will not say that I have lost hope, because the worst death is the death of hope. However, this impression we have had for many years has been greatly degraded. I do not need to repeat the dramatic retreat of the rule of law in that country. However, support for the release of the leaders of the Peoples' Democratic Party, mayors, journalists, representatives of the judiciary and members of the Turkish National Assembly itself. Unfortunately, however, recently Erdogan's president tried to extend his authoritarianism to Cyprus, inviting his brothers in a speech in Bursa, as he said, to respond to the newspaper “Africa”, which wrote her opinion that the invasion of Afrin resembles invasion of Cyprus in 1974. And his brethren answered in Cyprus with vandalism against the newspaper. But I would like to tell you that a few days later, thousands of Turkish Cypriots found themselves on the streets supporting the newspaper's freedom of opinion and supporting their right to freely express themselves and to have an autonomous will for the future of their community and Cyprus. I shall conclude by calling on all of you to support the view that Turkey is now very close to the threshold of total removal from all notion of the rule of law, and this can be done with a clear mandate from the European Parliament to ourselves and to Turkey, that if it is not democratized the country will have to rethink the process before us.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: Please try to keep the time limits, we're 15 minutes late.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President! It was a very long time since something went in the right direction in Turkey, and I suffer with all the Turkish citizens from different peoples, professions, religions, political parties, with several seeing increasing numbers of their rights curtailed as President Erdogan takes a stronger hold on the whole society in its pursuit of opinion opponents, both inside and outside the country's borders. A candidate country is expected to live up to the fundamental values of the EU, that is, respect for the principles of the rule of law and for fundamental civil and human rights. But Turkey's courts are not independent. People are accused of terrorism for no reason and are years in prison without trial. Freedom of the press and freedom of speech do not exist. Since 2016, over 6 million Turkish residents have been subjected to judicial investigations on suspicion of crime, sometimes only because of a view expressed on social media; 107,000 have lost the job without legal basis. Violence is never a long-term solution, no matter who uses it. I also suffer with all those killed and still killed in the conflict in southeastern Turkey, in terror attacks around Turkey and now also in the totally unjust war in northern Syria. Erdogan's declaration that he wants to keep the border free of terrorists does not hold, and we all know it. Turkey's attacks are attacks on another state, not defense, and therefore violate international law. Today, the world should instead thank the resistance and military efforts of all these brave women and men to defeat Daesh. We have them to thank too much. But our response is to silence watch as Turkey, with the help of Syrian rebels, slaughters Kurdish children, women and men in one of the most peaceful areas of Syria. An area that has also received many Syrian internally displaced people. Even after the first days of the war, I received a variety of pictures of injured and dead children sent to my phone. If I don't misremind myself then meant Erdogan that al Assad is a child killer, which is correct, but then what does he call himself? I am clearly concerned by the message our inaction sends both to Erdogan and to the residents of Afrin and the rest of Rojava. If we want to live up to our own principles and to international law, then we should forcefully protest and condemn the ongoing attack on Afrin. For example, we can stop all arms exports to Turkey. Nato countries should consider what they have for a member really, and of course we should not give Mr Erdogan the favours he would like, like customs union and visa relief and other things.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the operation 'Olive twig' took place on 20 January 2018. The natural continuation of the previous operation “Euphrates Shield” is yet another installment of Erdogan's continued persecution of the Kurdish people. Never name was more tragically mocking. The twig that Erdogan juts towards Afrin, in fact, consists of the bombs of 72 warplanes assisted by dozens of tanks and land troops. A little more than two weeks after the start of operations begins the usual tragic numbers game. Civilian casualties could already be over 100. It therefore makes an impression to see Erdogan meet yesterday in Rome between armored streets and clashes between protesters and police, the Pope, the President of the Republic and Prime Minister Gentiloni. On the content of the talks maximum reserve. Surely, as a leak, a lot of space has been given to commercial themes, as Italy is one of Turkey's main partners. What I wonder and ask you: how much purges and violence does Erdogan have to carry out to spark at least a spark of outrage from European governments? A reaction that isn't facade? In less than a year since the attempted coup d'état, Turkey has become, as one well-known journalist calls it, a kind of autocracy with democratic simulacra. Anyone who dares to criticize Erdogan is jailed. At the same time, Syrian Kurds in Afrin, valiant soldiers in the war against Daesh, are killed in the embarrassed silence and complicit of the international community. How did we get to this point? The answers are many and range from economic entanglements to energy ones. But the real ace up Erdogan's sleeve is certainly that illegal migrant agreement accepted by the European Union in March 2016, which we repeatedly denounced. An agreement that allows him to keep up a surreal enlargement negotiation, which no one believes anymore and that goes permanently closed. It failed the EU and failed my government, the government of my country, by welcoming the Turkish Premier with the highest honours. We're under blackmail. It's time to admit it and to raise our heads again, to defend democracy, to defend our principles and to defend that courageous Turkish civil society that still wants to have a voice today and wants to have a democratic representation.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not greet the High Representative because, as with bad habits, you hear a couple of speeches, as soon as the most critical ones arrive cut the rope. Incredible and unpredictable the moves of this Islamist satrap. First it collides with Russia — let us remember the shooting down of a hunt — then deals with Moscow, then with Tehran to arrive at the Astana treaties, to counter the advance of the Kurds, brave protagonists of the defeat of Isis in Raqqa. Now it launches into a military venture aimed at crushing Kurdish-Syrian Ypg militias and securing a security zone on its border. But what is really happening in this war no one knows, is not very clear, even if some things seem to be certain, that is loss of life by the Syrian military, it seems at least about twenty only Saturday. But what should outrage us seems to be a hundred civilian casualties, according to Kurdish hospital sources, of whom many women and children. Women and children, the High Representative is not moved. It is true that the Pope received Erdogan, but knowing Pope Francis I am sure that, in addition to telling him about the human rights of persecuted Christians, he will also have accounted for him for these civilian casualties. But we know this Europe — the High Representative is master of it — in this compartmentmenting human rights. In some cases they are very serious and the international courts are invoked, in other cases it speaks so generically as if it had been, I don't know, a carnival joke. Instead this happens, it is true, in a region to which we also belong, even if Turkey is not in Europe. Someone who is now repentant and who says that he no longer wants Turkey's membership was telling us that Turkey is Europe. Well, let's leave it at that. An offensive that wants to continue a path that is decidedly contrasting with the strategy of NATO and the United States, and This should at some point be counted by the USA. Now this offensive, in Erdogan's textual words, aims to nip in the bud a force seen as open threat to his safety. So this Erdogan strategy, which is very dangerous for our future, for our security, is very dangerous. But this Europe is vile. The adjective is also addressed to those who forget to condemn, as Ms. Mogherini has forgotten, in harsh words, because hardness is needed when bombing women and children, as has been done in other cases. But here other obviously geopolitical and other interests impose this shameful vileness.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: — Madam President, because of and work, Turkey constantly confirms what Greece and Cyprus already know. That he is a cranky megalomaniac who despises any sense of justice and reason; a pariah of the international order. Of course, these are not of concern to liberals and ethnic nihilarists who approach Turkey on economic and micropolitical criteria. Those who have no moral values obviously have no scruples to negotiate with an unreliable and unpredictable oppressor. But the facts are not falsified. Western Turkey does not exist. Turkey has no relevance to the Union and does not belong to Europe geographically, ethnically, culturally, historically, state or institutional. Proof is the repeated and opportunistic violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms. The contempt of rules of international law and decisions of the UN and other international organizations. The imposition of Islamic terrorism and the persecution of any political opponent or dissident, including journalists, judiciary, military, teachers and even doctors.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Madam President! The human rights situation in Turkey is really shocking. Hardly another day goes by when we do not hear good news about the state of human rights in Turkey. There is an autocracy that is only a foretaste of what will await us when implementing the constitutional amendment in Turkey, when the presidential dictatorship comes into play. With the repeatedly prolonged state of emergency, the Turkish Government is permanently suspending the Convention on Human Rights. President Erdoğan obviously only uses this state of emergency to silence and remove from public life critics, political opponents and other believers. Oppositionists, journalists, human rights activists, academics, lawyers, all possible representatives of civil society are in prison. The Turkish judiciary has long ceased to be relied upon — the law of arbitrariness in courts and authorities is more likely to prevail. New groupings are always targeted. While Kurds and alleged Gülen supporters were initially targeting, almost everyone now has to fear for their freedom, who even makes an ill-considered statement. Any criticism seems to become a criminal offence and is equated with terrorism. Anyone who is not arrested will be released, expropriated, otherwise silenced — there are enough examples. All these people — including one-third of judges and lawyers, one-tenth of police officers, 110 000 civil servants and teachers, 5 000 academics — all dismissed; all these people are faced with nothing, no financial support, no pension entitlements, nowhere can they find a new job. You'll be beggar pretty fast. Obviously, examples are to be set here. The mood in the population is poisoned by inconspy, fear and agitation. The situation is really dramatic. If the European Union now does not act finally, it finally loses its credibility. Yes, the cut or redeployment of IPA funds was our first signal to Turkey. Obviously, this is not enough, and I wonder if this friendly dialogue, in which we are still moving, will mean that the human rights situation in Turkey will change. I think we need to wind other strings soon, and I would almost recommend taking a critical look at the Customs Union.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, I will focus today on the situation in Afrin, as I trust that the resolution on which we will vote on Thursday, and the introduction made by our colleague Kati Piri, have given us a clear picture of the grave violations of human rights in Turkey and a comprehensive and accurate picture of the situation on the ground.  It is the legitimate right of Turkey to ensure the security of its border. As the Turkish military operation in Afrin is unfolding, civilian casualty numbers – including women and children – are rising and the humanitarian situation is worsening day by day. Refugees and residents in the Afrin district of Syria are trapped once again between warring parties on the border, without any protection and any proper medical supplies or services. They are suffering daily attacks. These are people who have already fled their homes and suffered heavily from the longstanding Syrian war. The legitimate right of Turkey to ensure the security of its borders cannot be, and should not be, accepted as an excuse for the escalation and continuation of a military operation that seems to be much wider than initially announced. Furthermore, the YPG (People’s Protection Unit) made a great contribution in the fight against Daesh. This is something we, including the Commission, already know, and portraying all its fighters as terrorists is more than just an oversimplification.  The military operation against the Kurdish majority enclave of Afrin risks jeopardising the peace talks in Geneva, which remain the only possible way forward for a sustainable and lasting peace in Syria. Thus, we urge Turkey to ensure the cessation of hostilities and to devote its efforts to bringing back peace to Syria, as I trust this is in its own interests.  Finally, we call for an immediate halt to any indiscriminate targeting of civilians and we urge all parties to strictly respect humanitarian law and to guarantee full access to humanitarian aid in the belligerent areas.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, 100 kilometres to the south of Afrin, in the Syrian province of Idlib, chemical weapons were recently used once more. It happened five years after the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons was granted the Nobel Peace Prize for overseeing the disposal of chemical weapons. Debate in the UN Security Council has once again been blocked by Russia. I urge the Commissioner to take a clear position on the EU’s behalf on this issue.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, each time we debate Turkey more damage has been done to the rule of law, to the separation of powers, to the promise of Turkey’s European path and especially to the rights and freedoms of people. We have never questioned the legitimacy of bringing to justice those who perpetrated a failed coup. However, the measures taken, including the arrest of eight doctors last week when they called for peace after Turkish operations in Afrin, show that actions taken are often entirely unrelated to the failed coup and are certainly disproportionate. Even if the doctors have been released, another chilling message is sent that no one can assume freedom of expression, or freedom after expression. Not only countless journalists are imprisoned, including Ahmet Şık and others from Cumhuriyet, but also members of the parliamentary opposition, such as People’s Democratic Party (HDP) leader Selahattin Demirtas, and the head of Amnesty International. Additionally, more than 100 000 people have lost their jobs, wait endlessly in pre-trial detention and are de facto punished without trial. Those who do stand trial cannot be sure that the procedures are fair. The arrest of Osman Kavala is a case in point. Turkey is drifting further and further from anything that resembles a European dream. The Council of Europe’s Venice Commission assessed that the constitutional changes would ‘introduce a presidential regime which lacks the necessary checks and balances required to safeguard against becoming an authoritarian one’. Well, interestingly and sadly, even without these constitutional changes in place, that is what we are witnessing. We are witnessing NATO’s two largest armies opposing each other in Afrin. I believe that we as Europeans have to attach consequences to the de facto violation of the Copenhagen criteria. While we cannot prevent President Erdoğan and his AKP party from leading his country off the cliff, we can at least ensure that we are credible about the basic principles of the EU.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: — Madam President, since July 2016, the situation in Turkey has been steadily deteriorating. Thousands of people are crouping in prisons, including no real charges or access to a lawyer. Testimony of torture is increasing: civil servants, lawyers, magistrates, human rights defenders bear the costs of torture among others. Cumhuriyet journalists and Amnesty International officials are symbols of this, but minorities, especially the Kurds, are the main victims. The fight against terrorism has a good back. It is an all-round repression that is underway and the invasion of Afrin has allowed Recep Erdogan to harden the state of emergency a little further. How can Turkey intervene in Afrin with the help of terrorist groups against those who have been among the main actors in the fight against ISIS? Do the rule of law, human rights, international law still make sense for the European Union? It is time to arrest Mr Erdogan, Turkish troops must withdraw from Syria.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, it is true that in the last few years Turkey has faced unprecedented challenges, such as the arrival of hundreds of thousands of refugees, an increasing number of terrorist attacks, a failed coup d’état, and a troubled and unstable neighbourhood, but this should never justify the deterioration in democracy, the rule of law and human rights that we are seeing in Turkey. This should never be an excuse to violate, on a massive scale, fundamental freedoms and basic rights, and it can never be a reason for us, EU citizens, to stay silent on all these worrying trends. Turkey is a candidate country and, as such, it should comply with EU values and principles, which have been deeply eroded by the measures taken under the state of emergency that has been in place for more than one-and-a-half years now, while the opposition has been sidelined and silenced. I am thinking especially of the People’s Democratic Party situation. Regarding Afrin, I share the concerns over the Turkish military operation, as it could seriously undermine the resumption of peace talks in Geneva. I am also concerned about the fate of the civilian population on the ground and I am convinced that the Kurdish people, especially after their efforts in combating ISIS and other fundamentalists, do not deserve to be attacked as they are being. Once again, peace in the region will not be achieved without a permanent political solution to the Kurdish question.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, I would like to take this opportunity to comment not just on Turkish human rights abuses, but on Turkey’s general disregard for interests other than those of Turkey. For example, it would appear that US and Turkish troops are on a collision course in Manbij in Syria, whilst US forces allied with Kurdish and Arab forces are battling against Islamic State insurgents. The Turkish Government say that Manbij is a prime objective in wiping out Syrian Kurds. Turkey appears to be using the fight against Islamic State to perpetrate further human rights abuses against the Kurdish community, and appears to be willing to endanger a NATO ally to achieve those ends. We should condemn not just Turkish human rights abuses, but also strongly condemn President Erdoğan, his destabilising of foreign policy and his quest to crush all opposition to his despotic rule.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: — Madam President, we are still debating Mr Erdogan's regime, which is cheerfully trickling human rights in his own country, but also in Syria. During an interview, the day before his trip to Rome, the one who dreams of himself as a sultan of a reconstituted Ottoman empire assumes his heinous blackmail on migrants. The agreement signed in March 2016 requires Turkey to control illegal flows to Europe, in return for a huge envelope of €6 billion. It is the cowardice of our leaders that allowed Mr Erdogan to conclude this dupe deal, while continuing to demand accession to the European Union, for which he is already receiving a huge amount of money. In the face of Mr Erdogan's arrogance, we must be firm because European nations can control migration flows themselves. They must take example of what Bulgaria and Hungary are doing, which are giving themselves the means to effectively protect their borders, against the advice of the European Commissioners. Today, European migration policy is a “total failure”. This is how the Bulgarian Prime Minister, who now holds the rotating presidency of the European Union, qualified him last Thursday. Yes, as Boyko Borisov said, I quote: “We must now prepare migrants to return home”. In the meantime, I denounce the resolution on Turkey which will be put to the vote on Thursday. It still discusses the billions of euros that this country has received every year since 2002 as a candidate for the Union. Between 2007 and 2013, Turkey received more European subsidies than Slovenia, which is a member of the Union. Led by an Islamist party, Turkey is not European by its history or by its geography, but by the ends of territories it has kept after centuries of conquests and bloody settlements over European peoples. A century after the terrible Armenian genocide, the Turks continue to bully and even oppress some Christian communities, which remain in this country in full Islamization. After decades of Kemalism, where the secular state had at least a concern for Christian heritage, the remains classified as UNESCO heritage are dropped into ruins, as in the former Armenian capital, Ani. This is what we denounce in one of the amendments tabled by our Group Europe of Nations and Freedoms. Therefore, if Turkey can indeed be a partner, it cannot under any circumstances become a member of the Union. It is time to make this clear to Mr Erdogan and put an end to the accession process as well as the totally unjustified financing that is currently being practiced.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Madam President! How long is Turkey still acting as a candidate country here? What does the country have to do before it finally falls out of disgracs? We heard this morning in the case of Croatia that something would prevent admission until the border conflicts have been resolved. Turkey's border conflicts with Greece, with Cyprus, have not been resolved, obviously not with Syria, obviously not with Iraq. How can it be that Turkish troops invade abroad to kill Kurds, the US partners who have been partners of other NATO countries such as Germany, like EU countries, and have helped us fight Da'esh against ISIS? When will we finally move on to imposing sanctions on Turkey in order to speak a clear, clear language in foreign policy here?

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, it is with great concern that we need to repeatedly appeal to our principles and stand firmly behind them in the EU’s evolving relationship with Turkey. The rule of law and respect for fundamental freedoms have to be the main axes of our bilateral relations. We have just confirmed this in the previous debate on EU enlargement strategy with the same messages. Turkey is our partner and an ally in security—related matters, but we find ourselves reaching the limits of our partnership with Turkey over and over again. I believe that there is still some room for discussion to take place on the parliamentary level with MPs from the Turkish Parliament via the Joint Parliamentary Committee, which should meet tomorrow. I hope this could be a productive meeting in this period of partnership.  In the plethora of the wider crackdown on fundamental freedoms in Turkey, I would like to concentrate on the failure to implement the rulings of the Constitutional Court. This is a straightforward attack on the functioning of the judiciary in Turkey. In this respect, I would like to ask the High Representative or Commissioner Hahn to indicate in which strategic direction our bilateral relations will evolve with regard to the events since the beginning of this year. The human suffering of the people in Syria is beyond any possible words. Further assaults by a NATO member state are just unacceptable. Beyond the reprehensible damage to the most vulnerable population still left in northern Syria, this action directly endangers the possibility of successful talks in Geneva.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Madam President! Turkish intervention in Afrin is disturbing and paradoxical. For a long time, the Syrian civil war seemed to come to an end, but the attack on Afrin in violation of international law means a renewed flare of fighting. Above all, a peaceful settlement of the Kurdish question has moved far away — but without it there will be no peace. It is more than disturbing that there is a NATO Member State behind these incredible activities and that war material from other NATO Member States is being used. It is scandalous that Islamist extremists are on the side of those who pretend to fight against terrorism. These take place without consideration against minorities — minorities such as the Yazidis, who have just escaped genocide. Many innocent and innocent people — children — are victims of airstrikes. There must be an end to this!

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Mr Hahn, I understand that colleagues are slowly beginning to understand what Turkey is; not only today but also over time. Two years ago, from this Chamber I denounced a crime against humanity committed by the Turkish occupation army in Cyprus, the regular Turkish army. This was the movement from mass graves to an unknown part of the bones of hundreds of missing persons murdered in 1974 by the Turkish army in Cyprus, in the village of Assia. We also adopted a resolution at the time, if you remember, Commissioner. Finally, a conscientious citizen confessed, while Turkey denied it all these years, that the bones have been buried in a rubbish place in the village of Dikomo in Cyprus, occupied Cyprus, and on the rubbish land a park was created with European Union funds, which at this time adorns the area. Here's where the European Union's money goes. I wonder how it is possible that the value of respect for the deceased, recognised by all ancient civilizations, the Etrusks, the Egyptians, the Greeks, the Romans, is not recognised by anyone in the modern world and allows Turkey to continue this heinous crime.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we are concerned about the situation in Turkey. We have heard that many times here tonight. Whenever we discuss a report in the Committee on Foreign Affairs on Turkey's progress towards joining the European Union, it is in fact always a retrospective report. Freedom of the press is not a question of human rights violations in the flesh. Freedom of expression no longer exists. We can say very clearly today: this Turkey cannot join our European Union. We have to be tough on respect for human rights. Perhaps we should talk about a different kind of partnership. We may need to see what economic or diplomatic relations we can build with Turkey. Another aspect that we want and must raise here today is the Afrin offensive. The images and reports we see and read about the events there make it clear that we need to come up with a global strategy for Syria. People say they get used to human rights violations and attacks. Well, this can't get used to. Let us draw up a global strategy to end that conflict and get the peace negotiations smooth. I thank you.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Madam President! Erdoğan's decree 696 uspreded the death kick for a rule of law reappraisal of the 2016 coup attempt. Lynching justice is now welcome, while peaceful protest, political opposition and critical journalism are going to jail. The existence of many teachers and scientists has been destroyed, tens of thousands live in the houses in Cizre and Diyarbakır — expelled long before the state of emergency. And now the alleged terrorists who are threatening Erdoğan are also sitting in Syria and Afrin. I ask: where is the clear outlaw of this attack under international law by the EU, by the NATO partners, yes, and also by Russia? A peaceful solution to the Kurdish question would improve the human rights situation throughout the region. Instead of refugee deals and weapons, the region needs humanitarian aid corridors, an end to the war in Syria. Let us end the betrayal of human rights in Turkey by ending the EU's policy of looking away, isolating and outsourcing problems!

name: Michel REIMON
text: Madam President! A week ago, a demonstration took place here in Strasbourg on the situation in Turkey, the invasion of Afrin. Today, a few hours ago, a participant in this demonstration was arrested for this participation in Istanbul, Turkey: Mr Selçuk Duman an Austrian citizen, an EU citizen arrested in Turkey for a demonstration in the European Union. According to my informal information, it is already the third in recent days. I do not know how many EU citizens from other countries are there. Now this goes so far: we are no longer just talking about human rights violations in Turkey against Turks, where Europe is looking away. We are no longer just talking about the Kurds being abandoned, that the Jesidins will be abandoned, that the Alevitines will be abandoned. We are already talking about EU citizens who are being spied on in the Union and are being systematically arrested in Turkey. There is a step to be taken. We all know that Turkey will not become a member of the European Union in the next few decades. Threatening that this will no longer be enough. Commissioner — I welcome you — and I call on you to go one step further: if we increase the pressure on Erdoğan, let us increase the pressure on Turkey! There is this customs agreement, which is important for Turkey, which would put pressure. Let's put it up for discussion! We are unequivocally threatening that the European Union will exit this customs agreement if human rights continue to be violated and if Turkey acts as it is now internationally. Let's increase the pressure!

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is the return of the reality of geopolitics. We simply note that Ottoman policy is not a European policy. Only, in my opinion, naive and ideologists have been able to ignore what history describes us. But I would also like to speak to you about Turkey's violation of the sovereign territory of Syria. It is also clearly against international law. However, is the Union legitimate to condemn this violation? Have we not supported the Americans and the Gulf States in dismembering Syria? Did we not let Turkey arm the Islamic State, let it smuggled refugees and oil? Are we not subjected to Turkey in acts? Have we not demonized the decisive Russian intervention against the jihadists? So, in what capacity do we do the lesson? Too often, we cherish the causes by denouncing the effects. Thus also the elimination of Christians, through a lack of realism.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, for one minute I will focus on the situation of the Kurds in Turkey. Two-and-a-half years ago, a Kurdish delegation was in the European Parliament and I advised them to make a deal with Bashar al-Assad, who was then in a desperate situation and, I think, would have made any deal. But they responded by saying that they would not make any deal with a murderer. And nobody in the European Parliament supported me – nobody. The Kurds are now in a desperate situation: they are beaten by Turks from the north and by Bashar al-Assad from the south, and they are in a really desperate situation. They lost their chance. I am not saying that everybody who does not listen to me will end up like the Kurds now, but remember that even a nation that has good soldiers but is led by the wrong leaders will end up like the Kurds. Moreover, I think that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: — Madam President, the attack on Afrin has reopened a serious dilemma. A NATO member state, our military ally, is committing violence against the Kurdish national minority on its territory as well as against Kurds in foreign territory, in Syria and Iraq. The dilemma is hampered not only by the resolution of the Middle East conflict, but also by the continuation of the EU's constructive relationship with Turkey. It also threatens the EU-Turkey migration agreement on refugees. The dilemma arose takes on absurd to pitoresque proportions. The United States, Turkey's strongest ally in NATO, is airdropping ammunition and weapons to military units of the YPG armed forces now fighting Turkey, in Rodjava and Afrin. The U.S. Military Air Force directly undertook the air preparation of YPG ground operations. Moreover, unlike Turkey, the United States does not consider YPG troops to be terrorists. It takes a lot of diplomatic dexterity to solve the dilemma of who our ally is in Afrin. But it also requires the ability to answer the question of whether brutal human rights abuses by Turkey are acceptable at the cost of weakening the military alliance. I recently visited both Rodjava and Kurdish YPG troops. I recognized how bravely the Kurds had conquered the ISIS capital Rakka, how bravely they began to rebuild the city of Kobani destroyed by the ISIS organization. They are allies of our American allies. We can't throw them overboard just for the status quo between the NATO organization and Turkey to be maintained.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what more can be said now about Turkey, because what is happening is evident to everyone, including the stones. It is clear that democracy is being zeroed and we cannot think that it is a friend partner, Turkey, when it embodies people who protest peacefully, prevents freedom of expression and of information by arresting journalists and closing newsrooms, poisons the judicial system by removing freedom from magistrates and professors, affects human rights defenders and acts to eliminate the Kurds. I believe that the European Union, the European Commission, in the face of the things that we are discussing and which will emerge in the resolution must take a much clearer and clearer position and should review the relations with Turkey and placing, on all the agreements that are there, conditionalities as an essential element in order to move forward in the relationship with this country. Without that we are simply in danger of preaching. So we need a very strong act from the European Commission.

name: Marek JUREK
text: “Turkey is changing and it's not just about the relationship between the government and the opposition, the aftermath of the coup when Turkey was on the brink of civil war, but it's about profound changes that can unfortunately remain. An imam has already been officially appointed in Aja Sofia. The story goes back 80 years. It is still a museum, but its status is to be changed. This is not meant to be a place where one remembers at the same time a thousand years of Christian history and later history, only as I say, history goes back 80 years. I don't know if the European Commission was responding to this, but I strongly encourage you to issue a communication. It's about a simple signal that it's not indifferent to us. Chalki Island Seminary is still not restored. After all, this is fundamental to the functioning of the Constantinopolitan Patriarchate. This is part of our heritage. In this case, too, we should send a signal that these are indifferent things to us. It will not change these matters to strength, but Turkey should know clearly that we care about it, and that is what I ask the European Commission to do.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Madam President, we need a more balanced approach on the status of human rights in Turkey. Misunderstanding and bad judgment of the facts could create a rather negative picture of Turkish society. In order to have a proper EU reaction to the events in a neighbouring country, we need to take into account the real situation there and the reasons for it to emerge. Parliament should avoid strong condemnation of a country which is one of our closest partners, both in economic and political aspects. Recently, we have started to forget Turkey’s enormous efforts in dealing with the migration crisis and its role in providing asylum to millions of refugees. Despite the fact that this is organised just based on a statement by the EU and Turkey, it contributes effectively to the protection of the external borders of the Union. This is visible in south—east Europe and particularly in my country, Bulgaria. The positive results have been recognised many times by representatives of the Commission who are directly involved in the process. That is why we must show greater respect for our neighbour. Soon, a formal EU—Turkey meeting will be held, where we expect many of the contradictions to be overcome. At the same time, there are some proposals for the suspension of the accession negotiations. In this regard, questions arise. What is our goal? What kind of effect do we want to achieve? The only result would be the isolation of Turkey and pushing it in another direction. We need Turkey and Turkey needs us for the security of the whole region and the European Union. The aggressive tone of the discussion is not a productive one. I call for a more balanced approach and proposals.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: — Madam President, we cannot remain silent about what is happening in Afrine. Until now, Afrine was a relatively safe region and even received thousands of refugees. But that ended with the invasion and the unilateral offensive by Turkey, and that has resulted in many deaths. It is a clear violation of international law and a violation of human rights. The people of Afrine have been a guarantor of peace and has prevented the spread of terrorist forces. The European Union must support the peace efforts of the people of Afrine and must actively condemn what Erdogan's unilateral offensive is. It is also essential that the European Union decides to become involved so that the Kurdish peoples can participate in the political process for peace in Syria. And finally, fundamentally, it has to be told clearly to Mr. Erdogan that we do not accept blackmail and that there is no deal or deal worth more than human lives.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: — Madam President, dear Turkish guests! The clarification of the failed coup, which is undoubtedly necessary, is increasingly a justification in Turkey for burying the rule of law, separation of powers, freedom of expression and human rights. Tens of thousands of men and women — teachers, judges, lawyers, academics, opposition politicians, mayors, soldiers, human rights activists — and also hundreds of young children have been imprisoned in Turkey for months and years. More journalists are detained in Turkey than in any other country. Mehmet Altan and Şahin Alpay remain incarcerated despite the fact that the Constitutional Court has condemned their detention as unlawful. Similarly, the chairman of the Amnesty Group in Turkey, Taner Kılıç, and the cases of Deniz Yücel or my friends Ahmet Şık, Osman Kavala and Selahattin Demirtaş show that international pressure to return to the rule of law has so far failed. I would therefore like to urge the European Court of Human Rights to finally negotiate and decide these cases of injustice without further embarrassing. Thinking of Turkey, I am often angry, but also sad. It is horrible to see how much democratic spirit, so much future for the country disappears behind prison walls. Thinking of Afrin, I have to tell you, pure fear seizes me. What happens in Afrin and Idlib is again crimes against humanity, which violates international law in Afrin. There is a threat that the largest region of despots will be pushed into a new escalation. Mr Hahn and Mrs Mogherini have the difficult task of taking along from here that we are asking you to stop a new conflagration in this region. Because that's what I'm afraid of is that Afrin will turn into a wildfire. I also appeal to bring this message back to Turkey: Turkey has been stable for a long time and has been stable for a long time. a good way. Turkey, too — this is my great fear — can be dragged into this conflagration.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I came here to remind you of the complacency with which your European Union has treated Turkey, an officially candidate country for integration. Then, after reflection, I wondered what would prevent Turkey from joining this Union. Think about it. After all, there are more Roman remains in Turkish Anatolia than in the whole of Scandinavia gathered. This should even make the “identity rights” think, who should, if they were logical, support Turkey's accession. You will tell me that the European Union is first built around common values and Turkey is moving away from it, but that is not true. Turkey has never been closer to this authoritarian union that has put Greece under a regulated cut. Turkey has never been closer to our countries that criminalize freedom of expression in the name of the battle against so-called fake news. The truth is that this European Union is part of the forced coexistence of too different countries and does not give rise to any sense of belonging. This debate on Turkey is therefore a tremendous reminder to the citizens that this Union represents nothing and that only nations have a soul and values that bring their members together.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, we all agree that Turkey should remain a partner of the European Union, but that the situation there today is very serious, sad and alarming. Tackling migration, security, counterterrorism are as much a priority for Turkey as it is for the European Union. What has to be appreciated is how Turkey has dealt with refugees in taking, integrating them, and also that the EU-Turkey agreement is working in my opinion. Apparently also because it's in the interests of the Turks themselves. Having a dialogue with President Erdogan's regime is almost impossible at these moments. The president and his government behave authoritatively. Is it possible that this is the same president who has subscribed to European values? Which sought to join the European Union? How is it that today he is violently silencing the opposition, persecuting journalists, academics, persecuting anyone who calls for human rights? The list of prosecuted journalists in Turkey is growing. In February alone, more than a dozen journalists and media employees will stand trial in Turkey. I am personally following the case of Mr Akin Atalaye, managing director of the opposition daily Cumhuriyet. The latter has already been jailed for 14 months and is charged with allegedly supporting terrorism, and his trial bears every sign of trial on political order. I am very worried that the list of prosecuted journalists will expand again in connection with the military operation in northern Syria. According to the information available, the Turkish prime minister gave the media accurate instructions on how to report reporting. Journalists, in his words, should ignore foreign media coverage that it is a crackdown on Kurds. Colleagues and colleagues, we should seek a resumption of dialogue with the Parliament and with the Government of Turkey. We must not turn our backs on those millions of people who believe in democratic values. And they want to live in a country where the rule of law and an independent judiciary will be upheld. European funds should also be used to do this.

name: Soraya POST
text: – Madam President, last week Taner Kılıç, the Chair of Amnesty International Turkey, was rearrested by Turkish police and charged with membership of an armed terrorist organisation. Many other human rights activists have been arrested and labelled by the Turkish Government as terrorists. According to several reports from human rights organisations, since July 2016 the Turkish Government has started a crack—down on human rights. Civil servants, journalists, teachers, police, military, judges and prosecutors – anyone that does not openly support the government is at risk. Civil society is being paralysed. The Turkish Government is not only attacking human rights defenders; it is also attacking other countries, for example in its military operation in Afrin, Syria. I, as a feminist, with full respect for international human rights conventions, will not join the group of EU leaders that are ignoring attacks on human rights because of a migration deal.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Madam President, again we are talking about Turkey, which means that nothing has changed and things are getting worse, so we need to adopt a different style. Apart from debates we simply have to go to sanctions. Recent history has shown us that there are states, such as Turkey, for example, with the dictatorship of Erdogan, or like the Russian Federation, with the dictatorship of Putin, who do not even care about sanctions. The debates we can do, they are good, but they need much and much more severe sanctions, because otherwise they cannot be discussed with these countries. There are times and countries where diplomacy does not go and do not care about diplomacy. Erdogan is one of these people. We have over 5,000 dismissed judges, 2,500 in prison, including members of the Constitutional Court. In Turkey, most journalists in the world are arrested, so it's number one in the world. Many Turkish citizens in Europe are arrested in Turkey by the Erdogan regime and then arrest warrants are sent for extradition. It happened, for example, with Turkish citizens who were in Albania. Fortunately, the Albanian courts did not extradite them. A university professor, what danger was the university professor for Turkey to issue an arrest warrant and want to send him to prison in Turkey? So sanctions!

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: — Madam President, for four years in this Parliament I have participated in countless debates on the behaviour of the Turkish regime, which systematically and increasingly unintentionally violates every concept of human rights within Turkey and every concept of international law in the external. The massive invasion of Syria, with mass killings of Kurds by the Turkish armed forces, is only the latest episode in the show. It has become boring to hear all sides of the European Parliament condemn the criminal activities of the Erdogan regime - and sometimes the other institutions of the European Union do the same - and in practice do nothing to stop it. Only one language can understand Mr Erdogan, and that is the language we need to speak to him if we want to show elementary seriousness. It is the language of imposing economic and political sanctions.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: – Madam President, the human rights situation in Turkey is very critical. Abuses of human rights include the imprisonment of journalists and abuses of the human rights of ethnic minorities, especially Kurds. The ongoing Turkish state of emergency gave the pretext to imprison political opponents, businessmen and also human rights defenders and journalists. Furthermore, the lawyers of these human rights defenders are facing, on a daily basis, great barriers to performing their work and are at continuous risk of detention and prosecution. This situation is evidence of a well—developed pattern of silencing people whose work lawfully calls into question the policies of the Turkish Government. As representatives of European fundamental rights, we need to unify and strengthen our voices in order to urge the Turkish Government to stop these abuses against human rights.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! In the first sentence, I want to stress that I agree with very many statements expressing concern about developments in Turkey. At the same time, I welcome especially the last sentence of the High Commissioner's speech, who says: we want to maintain a line of dialogue, we just want to talk to Turkey, because there's something to talk about. Turkey is a member of NATO, it is our partner in NATO. Turkey is still in the way of association with the European Union. Turkey is a great state, a significant state. And what is very important from our point of view is that Turkey, the Turkish government comes to the realization that greatness, strength means responsibility. It means responsibility for peace in the region. It means responsibility for stability around and it also means responsibility for good, democratic governance of the state.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: — Madam President, Commissioners, for at least four years we have been repeating in this Chamber that Turkish President Erdogan is becoming a dictator. A dictator who does not respect human rights, a dictator who crushes human rights, a dictator who interferes in the internal affairs of neighbouring countries. A dictator who continues to occupy Cyprus, a dictator who continues to provoke Greece, a dictator trying to meddle in Bulgaria's internal affairs, including through his attempt in recent days to enforce Bulgarian citizenship for two million Turkish citizens. Today, this same dictator is waging war on the territory of a neighboring country. This is an intrusion into the territory of a neighboring country — the Syrian Arab Republic. It's an invasion, it's an invasion. Dear Members, it is high time to break and end this hypocrisy that we see in the circles of our colleagues on the left — Left, Zeleny, etc. Erdogan is a dictator who violates human rights. Erdogan is a man who clearly proves why Turkey has no place in the European Union. Financial sanctions and restrictions should be imposed on Erdogan this Turkey. Such are the rules, and he must clearly be shown that he has no place in the European Union and that he should be punished for his behaviour.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: Madam President, my colleagues have already portrayed the present and future consequences of the Turkish offensive against Afrin, so I shall proceed directly to inform the Commission of the statement that we have made MEPs from four political groups, a statement signed by exactly 100 representatives of this Chamber and which we have presented here today.
