We urge the Commission and the Member States to redouble their efforts to ensure that Turkey immediately halts its offensive. We demand a real and inclusive revival of dialogue within the framework of the Geneva process. We recognize that the struggle of the Kurdish forces against ISIS also contributes to European security. On the other hand, the Turkish attack constitutes a very serious threat to the security of the entire region. Mrs Mogherini, Mr Hahn, your voice must be raised with much, much more force in front of Erdogan. Today we perceive it more as silence and equidistance, and faced with such serious facts that is not an option, it is neither understandable nor admissible.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Madam President, yes, the Turkish Government is once again on the agenda of this House, and I am sorry because, once again, we are confronted with the repressive policy and abuses of President Erdogan, which is bringing his people and neighbouring countries into a warlike, dangerous and unfounded surge. The offensive launched in recent weeks against the Kurds in the Afrin region of north-western Syria is completely unjustified. The Syrian Kurds are, along with the Kurdistan Peshmerga, the best allies of Western forces in the war against ISIS. Thousands of them have died in this struggle for our freedom and security. It is thanks to them that ISIS has only controlled some 5% of the territory after many defeats. Once again, Erdogan uses the same strings: on the pretext of fighting terrorism, he bombed in the middle of winter a region that has never attacked or threatened Turkish territory and arrests anyone who rises in his country against this flagrant violation of international law. This offensive also threatens the search for a solution to the war in Syria. Our duty as Europeans is to demand the withdrawal of the Turkish army and the release of those who have been imprisoned very imprisoned in Turkey since July 2016.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: – Madam President, since 20 January we have received cries for help from the Kurdish Christians in Afrin – they have begged for an immediate end to the Turkish attacks. They clearly know that jihadi extremists, including al-Qa’ida, are part of the Turkish attempt to invade Afrin. Yes, I say ‘al-Qa’ida’: I already have a whole document demonstrating the cooperation between Turkey and al-Qa’ida in the Afrin operation. Turkey has been caught: it is not hunting terrorists; it is supporting terrorists in order to take Afrin.  Two questions for my fellow colleagues. Shall we allow Turkey to create another influx of refugees into Europe? Shall we allow a NATO member state to cooperate with a terrorist organisation? I challenge Ms Mogherini to show leadership in this situation and condemn this invasion without any reservation. Finally, I call on Ms Mogherini to recognise – now – that the Federation of Northern Syria should be part of the peace talks. Their Syrian democratic forces liberated one third of Syria from ISIS and cannot be ignored as a partner.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, the situation in Turkey is absolutely worrying. Erdogan is determined to continue prosecuting politicians, judges, journalists, and ordinary citizens. It prolongs the state of emergency to expand its power. Anyone who criticizes him is baptized the enemy of the nation. It forms an extreme nationalist alliance, even questioning the Treaty of Lausanne. Lately, Islamists and Kemalists have been competing for who will have the most aggressive rhetoric against neighbouring states. It attacks the decisions of the Greek justice system concerning asylum for Turkish citizens, because it obviously judges for itself what is different in terms of how decisions are taken. Finally, with the tolerance of the international community, he invades Syria by striking the Kurds. In fact, in Afrin it is fighting those who have defeated the Islamic State. After seven years of bloody civil war and while the conflict had begun to escalate, this Turkish invasion leads to a new humanitarian crisis. We must today condemn Erdogan's behaviour in absolute terms.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Madam President! The human rights situation in Turkey is in bad shape. We have seen that after 2016 — after the coup attempt in Turkey — many purges took place there, as well as many legal proceedings that far from satisfying the rule of law. And Turkey's dealings with its own Kurdish minority have been very problematic in recent years, even decades ago. Finally, Turkey's attack on the Kurdish regions of northern Syria shows that Turkey does not comply with current law or even international law. This is not just about a country's internal affairs. Turkey is still a candidate for EU accession, and we should put an end to this state of hypocrisy. Turkey does not have any prospects for joining the EU at the moment and for the time being. Building on this, however, we must also note that Turkey is strategically important both for the EU and for many other states in its environment. That is why we must strive, on the one hand, to close the accession negotiations, but at the same time remain in dialogue with Turkey and achieve a strategic partnership.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Madam President, in Kobani, the Kurdish warriors - men and women - decided to stop the brutality of the Islamic state and succeeded. Today, Turkey invades Syria, the Afrin region, as it invaded Cyprus in 1974; with the same propaganda. But the crimes remain the same. The population of Afrin sends a message to us here in Brussels, but also to all the capitals of the great powers. Let me tell you this: do not sacrifice us to a new genocide for the sake of your relations with Turkey. I wish that their cry could be heard here in Strasbourg. So, at last, let us move from words to deeds. Commissioner, there are two issues. Will we, at last, impose sanctions on Turkey as we impose on other states that do similar things? Secondly, the Kurds have a message: a no-fly zone. If we assure them, you can rest assured that they will stop the Turkish army in Afrin, as they did in Kobani.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: — How is it made up? Operation Olive Branch. Turkish bombers drop their deadly ballast over the Kurdish enclave Afrin, on Syrian territory. What cynicism. The olive branch is an ancient symbol. Originating from the slow growing and firm olive tree, it stands for peace, hope and reconciliation. So not for the Kurds of Afrin. Turkey is targeting the arguments of Kurdish fighters but is killing civilians, including women and children. The fact that Afrin's citizens are victims of the violence of the olive branch is outrageous. Our greatest ally in the fight against the dark forces of Islamic State is left to its fate. It is the Kurds who take the bullets of radical fundamentalism for us. And now they are getting a dagger stab in the backs of their neighbours, but also of the international community. We are cowardly, hypocritical and hypocrite. We bake sweet sandwiches and make shady deals with Ankara and give their death sowers free rein. Colleagues, we are not worthy of the friendship of the Kurdish people.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: Madam President, Turkey must be heard loud and clear that any relationship between the European Union and Turkey, present or future, will be conditional on the lifting of the state of emergency and the paralysis of the systematic violations we are experiencing in the areas of human rights, the rule of law, freedom of expression or respect for minorities. Hundreds of thousands of people, activists, judges, officials, journalists have been imprisoned, charged or violated their freedom in recent months. In recent weeks, also those who have daring to criticize military operations with enormous destabilizing potential in Syria, in an area that is already boiling. But our message has to be very clear. This is not a battle between Europe and Turkey. And Europe is not the enemy of Turkey. This is a battle of European Democratic citizens defending democracy, supporting Turkish Democrats.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, we are once again in the same work spectators, with Turkey attacking Kurds, imprisoning thousands of dissidents, harboring the slavers and filling the Aegean islands with thousands of illegal immigrants. Erdogan threatens Greece. It calls for a revision of the Lausanne Treaty and is claiming dozens of Greek islands in the Aegean. Turkish Foreign Minister Tsavusoglu is threatening Greece with war if 18 Greek islands are not given to Turkey. At the same time, violations of Greek airspace continue, Greek territorial waters are violated and Imia are excluded. The European Union must therefore leave the words and move on to the deeds. Firstly, an immediate halt to the accession negotiations. Secondly, an immediate cessation of funding for Turkey. Thirdly, the imposition of economic and political sanctions against Turkey. Fourthly, an embargo on exports of Turkish agricultural products to the European Union. Fifth, a freeze on assets of the Turkish government elite, burdened with violations of rights. Sixthly, a ban on entry into the European Union of Turkish officials who are also burdened. Specific measures here and now, Mr Hahn. No more talking and stroking in Turkey.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: Madam President! Turkey, Commissioner, is now being incarcerated just because they have pointed out the number of civilian casualties in the Syrian Kurdish regions and, as we have heard, an Austrian has now been arrested again. As a long-time journalist, I am particularly dismayed that 148 journalists, publishers and writers are in prison. You have never seen an indictment — probably because the government is having difficulty formulating such an indictment. Recent events in the city of Afrin also show that Turkey is literally transciting international, recognised borders. One thing is certain: only a part of the Turkish population is taking this course. It is therefore quite clear to me that we need to make it clear to the country's progressive forces that we are on their side, but on the other hand we are clearly demanding the rule of law and reliability from the Turkish side.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commission. Do you know the picture of the three monkeys who hear nothing, see nothing, say nothing? Frankly speaking, this is what the role of the EU and my German Government seems to me when it comes to human rights and the behaviour of Turkish leader Erdoğan in northern Syria. How long are we gonna be stupid? More than 100 journalists have been detained since 2016, and we see nothing. Erdoğan storms northern Syria without any mandate in violation of international law, fights the Kurdish-Christian YPG forces — our most reliable partner in the fight against ISIS — and we say nothing. His troops are shooting German weapons on the border at refugees, at 3,000 year old Christian sites, and we? Nothing heard. He imprisons Turkish doctors who demonstrate for peace, and, and, and. We continue to negotiate kindly to join the EU, paying billions for several thousand exchanged refugees. To whom do you want to explain this if you are labeling Israel at the same time and mistakenly responsible for conduct in democracy and the rule of law? Let's be honest! Let's stop any payment to Erdoğan! Let us stop all negotiations with Turkey and reprimand reprimand the conduct in northern Syria that is contrary to international law! Let us stand by our values!

name: Ana GOMES
text: — The Erdogan regime is violating all the Copenhagen criteria, as well as all Turkey's obligations as a member of the Council of Europe: thousands of political prisoners, including hundreds of journalists, closed media, persecution of human rights activists, justice system used for the repression, fear and persecution installed in Turkish society and outside doors. This disaster cannot be disconnected from the ongoing Turkish aggression in Syria with the bombing of civilians and against the Kurdish forces that bravely fought Daesh and al-Qaeda, which the Erdogan regime has duplicated in infiltrating Syria and Iraq. Afrine is not a case of self-defense, it's an assault involving war crimes against civilians. In addition to the humanitarian disaster, it causes a dangerous military escalation, as seen in the attack on the Russian plane, and there are irreparable tensions within NATO itself. The European Union must condemn Turkey, it must demand that the UN Security Council stop this aggression that compromises negotiations for a political solution in Syria and affects regional security, including the security of the European Union itself.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a year and a half after the attempted coup, we are still denouncing Erdogan's grip on the fundamental freedoms of its citizens, inside and outside the national territory. At the same time, the new offensive launched in Afrin against Kurdish militias, part of the international coalition against Daesh, worries not only for humanitarian reasons. Officially, the attack was launched against the terrorist threat. Turkey is entitled to defend its security, but here it is a disproportionate reaction to target an uncomfortable minority instead. The international repercussions resulting from the breakdown of the anti-ISIS front, a risk of destabilization from potential devastating effects, are not assessed either. Turkey is a strategic partner for Europe. Nevertheless, we must continue to condemn your government's actions and stand firm in the consequences in relations with the EU. As requested by Parliament, accession negotiations must be suspended and then formally halted, including in economic and financial cooperation, if Erdogan continues to destroy the rule of law. Europe must assert its weight.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, the repression in Turkey began long before the 2016 coup attempt, which has served to silence dissident voices. This situation tends to worsen with the arrest of more than five hundred citizens and all those who oppose the attack on Afrine. How much are Afrine's dead worth in the deal we made with Turkey? Turkey has the right to protect its borders, but it does not have the right to enter a country, in this case Syria, and decide who stays and who leaves. For now, we have about 70 dead civilians. The targets have been the Kurdish militias. It is not too much to remember that it is these same Kurds that the West has set up. It is these Kurds, courageous men and women, who have been effective in fighting the self-proclaimed Islamic State. Turkey's legitimate right to security cannot be done at the expense of freedom to exist, nor by sacrificing the rule of law. It's not a terrorist who thinks differently, it's not a terrorist who's different. It's a terrorist who kills out of hate.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, since mid—December, the fighting in northern Syria – both with airstrikes and ground operations – has forced thousands of people to flee. According to Human Rights Watch, refugees who succeeded in reaching Turkey have reported that Turkish guards shot at them whilst they were attempting to cross the border. In some cases, Syrian asylum seekers were denied medical assistance and forced to go back. As the military operations in Idlib and Afrin continue, the number of people in need of protection is only likely to increase. Turkey launched a heavy offensive in the Kurdish area, unilaterally and unprovoked. It must take responsibility and bear the consequences. This means respecting the principle of non-refoulement and keeping its borders open to refugees. Turkey must meet its human rights obligations and guarantee humanitarian assistance to all. We should not accept any deviation from that.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: — Mr President, Turkey makes sure to confirm itself every day. Turkey proves that it was, is, and remains, a country implementing the 'invading and occupying foreign territories' strategy. This is Turkey that is invading Afrin, Syria today. This is Turkey that invaded Cyprus 43 years ago and remains in a Member State of the European Union, violating every principle of international and European law. This is Turkey which, today, as we speak, is trying and violating the EEZ of the Republic of Cyprus, in an attempt to prevent the discovery of natural resources to be used for the European Union. It is Turkey that has hitherto been obstructing investigations into missing persons. The same happened with her atrocities regarding the missing Assians and the bones found in Ornithi, where she moved them so as not to be found by their relatives. This is Turkey, which will continue to create and cause problems. Commissioner, we must finally say to Turkey: enough is enough, and no more! It cannot continue to challenge, particularly the principles and values of the European Union. Measures must finally be taken and sanctions imposed against Turkey, otherwise it will continue in this provocative, expansive and unacceptable manner of conduct and policy.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini told us a moment ago that the European Union is honest with Turkey. But Turkey is also honest with the European Union; it has always treated it as a vassal. She threatens, blackmailing to get more benefits, indifferent to her sensitivities and constantly threatens. He threatens to get more money. It threatens Greece and Cyprus with war. He threatens Greece to blackmail the concession of eighteen Greek islands. It does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus. It violates human rights, violates international law, and all this is happening under the apathetic eyes or, at best, under the whining of the European Union. The European Union is now concerned about Turkey's invasion of the Afrin region. But has the European Union condemned Turkey's invasion of Cyprus in 1974? Has he demanded that troops be removed from the occupied territories? Has it threatened, made it clear to Turkey that the door of the European Union has been closed definitively for this - anyway - Asian state that has nothing to do with Europe's principles and values?

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, over the past year the Turkish Government has been organising a very worrying crackdown against members of the political opposition and representatives of civil society. Last week, we received the welcome news that Taner Kilic, Chair of Amnesty International, was released. However, the broader human rights and democracy situation generally continues to deteriorate, and there are still many political prisoners in Turkey. So I ask the High Representative and the EU Member States to step up their diplomatic efforts to end the crackdown against civil society in Turkey and push for the release of all political prisoners. As part of a project launched by the Committee to Protect Journalists and Human Rights Watch, I have been twinned with a Kurdish artist and journalist best known for being the editor of JINHA, a feminist Kurdish agency with a staff consisting entirely of women. In 2016, Turkish authorities prosecuted her with charges of terrorism for her journalistic activities, and after her release she was prosecuted again and jailed for posting a painting on social media depicting Turkish tanks as animals. I deplore the Turkish attacks on Afrin: this region has been a beacon of hope amidst the general despair, with the Kurdish people establishing new models of inclusive democracy that champion gender equality and pluralism as well as respect for the environment. We must do something.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: — Mr President, the Nobel Prize for Literature Orhan Pamuk argued that Europe's borders should not be defined on the basis of geographical and historical criteria, but by sharing a set of values. Unfortunately, instead of the respect for democracy and the rule of law defended by a large part of Turkish civil society, we see that Erdogan's country is now at the top of human rights violations in Europe. President Erdogan's regime, under the pretext of a successive and unconstitutionally renewed state of emergency, continues its purge, firing thousands of civil servants, arresting journalists and students, and fiercely persecuting human rights activists and LGBTI organisations. Commissioner, European citizens have already lost their temper with hypocrisy, the constant violations of human rights by Mr Erdogan, and the invasion of Afrine at the end of January was the straw that overflowed the bucket of patience towards Mr Erdogan. Ladies and gentlemen, the constant campaigns of terror against the brave Kurdish people, to whom we Europeans owe a great deal, intolerance, authoritarianism and sectarianism are not compatible with the Copenhagen criteria and make the negotiations for Turkey's full membership of the European Union permanently impossible. Ladies and gentlemen, we have to say once and for all to Mr Erdogan: Enough!

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, thank you for this important debate, which I believe creates the necessary international attention, and which, unfortunately, confirms once again that we are all equally fearful and concerned about the developments in Turkey and its neighbourhood. It is not the first time that we have discussed this issue, and I fear that it will not be the last time, but it will not be helpful to show disagreement, which I personally share, with a sign that is most likely within the legal framework but which is unnecessarily provocative. As Federica Mogherini and I stated last week, we keep seeing more worrying developments undermining the rule of law and the independence and impartiality of the judiciary in Turkey. We are following the case of Amnesty International’s Taner Kılıç very closely. In particular, the non—implementation of judgments – including the recent constitutional court ruling and continued detention of two journalists – could really undermine the judiciary. In the short term, this affects the cases of individuals, including EU citizens. In the longer term, this could significantly erode trust in the judiciary as a whole, which also affects issues like Turkey’s business climate. We must seek concrete and lasting improvements in the area of the rule of law and fundamental freedoms. This is an essential footing for EU—Turkey relations.  Many of you here today also alluded to the situation in the south—east of Turkey, which remains of great concern. It is essential that a political process start again as there can only be a political solution to the Kurdish issue. Nevertheless, like some other speakers, I believe it is necessary to keep our channels of communication open. This includes raising our voice regarding the current worrying situation. It is clear: Turkey needs to respect the values on which our Union is based as per its own commitments as a candidate country and through international treaties. For the benefit of their people, the Turkish authorities should take clear steps to urgently improve the human rights situation there and restore the rule of law.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I have received eight motions for resolutions in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. The discussion is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 8 February 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. — The deep erosion of the rule of law in Turkey is reaching very shameful levels, in what is now a country completely out of control. The fact that the Turkish government prolonged the state of emergency for the sixth time is a clear signal of Erdogan's intention to perpetuate this system until the next election in November 2019. This context, or perhaps a pretext, is blatantly instrumentalised by the government to continue to keep the constitutional guarantees of the Turkish people suspended. However, the most worrying element is not just the government's action, but the deterioration of the justice system, this being the ultimate guarantor of rule law. Those who are supposed to restrict government abuses either are themselves limited and threatened or, even worse, are being replaced by other oppressors. Who defenders then? I believe that this unhealthy relationship with one of the worst countries in Europe as human and civil rights violations must be urgently renegotiated. Billionaire funding and concessions to a country that systematically vets almost all of our principles of democracy and human rights is absolutely not justifiable solely on the basis of buffering of the migration crisis.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: in writing. — The situation of human rights in Turkey is extremely serious. We get reporting on case after case of fundamental rights violations. It deals with human rights activists, journalists, academics and oppositionals. It's about those who don't think like Erdoğan. It is also about those protesting Turkey's offensive against the population of Kurd-controlled Afrin. What is happening in Afrin is deeply troubling. Turkey's offensive against the Kurdish population in Afrin is a violation of international law. It undermines the work for peace, democracy and human rights. The offensive must bring an immediate end. The solution to the war in Syria can only be reached at the negotiating table, and we must remember that the Kurds have been an important ally in the fight against the terrorists in Daesh. The EU must not turn its gaze away from what is happening in Turkey and what is happening in Afrin. We need to step up political efforts for peace and against escalation. I would urge Foreign Representative Mogherini to place the utmost importance on the state of human rights in Turkey. I would also urge Mogherini to hear our deep concern for the people of Afrin, and work towards an immediate end to Turkey's destabilising offensive.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: in writing. — (NL) Now that Da'esh has almost been driven out of Syria, we are at a crucial moment for peace and reconstruction in the country. All the energy of the international stakeholders must now go to the Geneva peace process, not to waging wars that undermine this process. I therefore welcome the High Representative's statement against the Turkish attack on Afrin. However, our actions must not be limited to a strong statement here and there. I call on the High Representative and the Member States to take a more active role as mediator in the conflict. The EU is investing millions of euros in humanitarian aid and the reception of refugees in the region. But what is the point of this as long as the attacks continue? Everything that is rebuilt is destroyed again and millions of refugees and displaced persons remain stuck in precarious situations. Several citizens wrote to me with their concerns. They fear a new, prolonged escalation of violence and the future of the Syrian Kurds and democracy. Their eyes are on the EU. Let us take up that glove and use all the necessary diplomatic means to achieve a robust and inclusive peace agreement.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: in writing. — The Erdogan regime, under the pretext of the failed coup attempt in July 2016, is trying to “legitimise” any notion of breaking the rule of law within the country. The guarantees of independence of the judiciary have been severely undermined, with censorship and arrests of journalists growing. International organisations sound the alarm bells, stressing that the Turkish administrative and executive authorities have been granted almost unlimited powers, in derogation from the general principles of the rule of law and absolute guarantees on the basis of recent decrees. human rights, implemented in any democratic society. Although Turkey hosts over two million refugees on its territory, receiving generous EU funding for this, it grants them a massive temporary protection regime, which does not grant beneficiaries the rights and benefits under the Geneva Convention. At the same time, Turkey continues to directly and repeatedly threaten the sovereignty rights of two EU Member States, Greece and Cyprus, provocatively disregard international law. Europe must strengthen its stance and put pressure on Erdogan to return to legitimacy, respect for the rule of law and fundamental rights, which are undeniably the essence of democracy and the foundation stone of the EU.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Venezuela (2018/ 2559 (RSP)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by saying that what we see in Venezuela is obviously, first and foremost, a political crisis, but it is also an economic, social and refugee crisis, with serious repercussions on neighbouring countries, starting with Colombia and Brazil. Everything we are doing as the European Union aims at a peaceful and democratic solution to all these different layers of the crisis, through credible and serious negotiations. As we speak, other efforts are ongoing to resume negotiations, and we can just hope that, this time, we will see some credibility and some concrete steps and openness in place. That has not been the case so far but it is never too late. When we last discussed Venezuela in this plenary, last September, we indicated four main areas where steps needed to be taken: an agreed calendar and conditions for credible elections; the facilitation of an emergency access plan for external assistance; the liberation of political prisoners; and respect for democratically elected institutions, notably the National Assembly. Unfortunately, progress was not made on any of these points. Throughout this period we have repeatedly engaged, all together as the European Union and together with our Member States, in a well-coordinated approach. In several meetings with our Venezuelan interlocutors we have discussed the need to respect democratic principles, democratic institutions, human rights and fundamental freedoms. We have called for serious engagement and flexibility in the ongoing negotiations to achieve a political agreement as a matter of urgency. Again, let me stress that talks are restarting, hopefully within hours. It was with a heavy heart that Member States decided to adopt targeted restrictive measures, in the absence of concrete results and in view of the constant deterioration of the situation. It is the first time that we have imposed measures of this kind in a Latin American context, and the decision was not taken lightly, as you can imagine. On 13 November, the Council adopted together targeted, gradual and reversible restrictive measures. These comprised a ban on the export of arms and equipment for internal repression, and a framework decision for a travel ban and assets freeze. Two months later, the Council recognised the lack of progress in the national dialogue and the worrying deterioration of the political and social situation in the country. As a consequence, the Council adopted a list of seven individuals subject to these measures. These targeted restrictive measures do not harm the people of Venezuela, but are directed at seven individuals who are responsible for undermining democratic principles and the rule of law and for human rights violations. Our measures are a signal to the authorities of Venezuela, an invitation to engage seriously towards a negotiated solution to the crisis and to reverse the moves that have called into question Venezuela’s constitutional order. We continue to monitor events on the ground and we stand ready to take appropriate measures in one way or another if the situation in the country evolves, with the constant aim of supporting democratic and negotiated solutions.  The recent decision of the Government of Venezuela to declare the Spanish Ambassador persona non grata is wrong and unacceptable, first and foremost because closing diplomatic channels does not help at a time when it is more important than ever to keep them open and seek a solution. We expect the Government of Venezuela to show genuine engagement in the negotiations and openness to compromise. We also hope that the opposition can work in a united and constructive manner. This is what the country needs in order to address the current challenges. Both parties should agree on a mutually acceptable date for the presidential elections. Unilateral decisions will only create more polarisation and new obstacles to a peaceful solution. It is also essential to set up guarantees to ensure free, transparent and credible elections. No artificial conditions should be imposed to limit the participation of political parties. The Supreme Court has decided to block the participation of Mesa de la Unidad Democrática in the elections, and clearly this goes against the goal of free, fair and inclusive elections. The people’s trust in elections can be regained only through a credible electoral process, with the lifting of bans on political opponents, with independent international observers and a balanced composition of the National Electoral Council. The future of Venezuela should be determined by its people. This is what we are asking of the Venezuelan authorities and all national political forces: the future of Venezuela should be determined by its people. We do not take sides in Venezuela’s domestic debate but we do ask for this debate to be democratic and inclusive, in line with the Constitution of the country. We see that the people of Venezuela are suffering, including the many European Union citizens who are also Venezuelan citizens. We have a stake in this. Everything we do is to encourage and support the country to come out of this political, economic and social crisis.  We are also concerned about the progressive deterioration of the social situation. The reports we are receiving from the United Nations agencies are extremely worrying. More than one million people are currently food insecure and the percentage of children affected by global acute malnutrition has reached emergency levels. The lack of medicines is estimated at around 90% by the National Chamber of Pharmacists. Diseases such as malaria and diphtheria that had disappeared are now spreading across the country. And there are no signs of recovery from the economic crisis. According to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), more than 1.5 million Venezuelans have already left the country. I want to reiterate that the repercussions in the region – on the fragile process in Colombia, on Brazil, on the regional organisations that are trying to move forward the regional integration process of Latin America and the Caribbean – are particularly worrying. The European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations department (DG ECHO) is present in Bogotá and deploys regular missions to Venezuela and bordering regions to evaluate the humanitarian situation, including the humanitarian conditions of the numerous Venezuelans who are fleeing the country to neighbouring countries. We are exploring all possibilities to develop our support, together with Member States and also with other donors and partner agencies. Let me stress once again that we will adapt our policies to any change in the situation in Venezuela, in one sense or the other. We need to see progress in the negotiations. I believe progress is still possible. It is a matter of political will. It is in the hands of the parties. As I mentioned, the Government has a clear responsibility to show flexibility and to engage seriously in these negotiations, and we hope to see real, concrete, encouraging steps.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament must once again raise its voice to denounce a new attempt at usurpation of national sovereignty by the convening of elections which do not meet the slightest democratic standards and which will only aggravate the dramatic political, economic, humanitarian and human rights situation in Venezuela. Yesterday the Venezuelan Penal Forum denounced mass arrests last week, among others that of the respected and prestigious politician Enrique Aristeguieta, 84. And yesterday four journalists had to leave the country again. It seems to me that the comment made by the US Secretary of State on his tour of Latin America is an absolutely pertinent reflection: can the world stand by while democracy is destroyed in Venezuela? Clearly, the sanctions adopted by the European Union have made a dent on the Government. The declaration of persona non grata and the expulsion of the Spanish ambassador demand, Madam High Representative, beyond solidarity and sympathies — which are welcome — a strong reaction from the European Union. Because an attack on a Member State is an attack on the Union as a whole. The European Parliament, in the resolution which is going to vote next Thursday, will call for the extension of the list of sanctioned persons to include those who are most responsible for serious human rights violations. But beyond sanctions, Madam High Representative, it is important for the European Union to mobilize with the international community, with the Lima Group and the regional actors to, as you said, pursue the Venezuelan people to speak again through a credible process, an inclusive process, a process without pitfalls, without disqualifications, with all political parties and with the community international. Without these premises, the European Union cannot give credibility or legitimacy to these elections and must express its solidarity with those who are playing their lives every day for the cause of freedom.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, I think the European Parliament has already said many times, and I will say it again, that the Maduro Government, the Venezuelan Government, is seriously violating human rights and does not comply with the rules of a rule of law, of democracy. We know this, and unfortunately there are too many examples and evidence of what I have just said. This Parliament has said this many times and I repeat it again. Second conviction I want to convey to you, ladies and gentlemen. The so-called Chavista revolution and the Maduro revolution have failed, to the point that half of the population is living in a very serious humanitarian crisis. What I regret most is that this so-called revolution is called socialist, because it is neither revolution nor socialist. For me, socialism is freedom. It's equality, but it's also freedom. And the third conviction I want to transfer to you. Beyond convictions, beyond sanctions, ladies and gentlemen, my group's conviction is that only a serious dialogue, a national agreement between the Government and the opposition will give a democratic and peaceful way out of Venezuela's democratic crisis. And I think it is important to claim, as Mrs Mogherini has rightly said, that we must give the people a voice — with guarantees, of course, with transparency and equality, but we must give the voice to the people. And an agreement that is being reached in these very hours on these elections can be final. Let us wait for this agreement to make a resolution consistent with time and with the European position on this matter.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Years of Marxist rule in Venezuela have led to the ruin of this beautiful country, have also destroyed its social fabric, caused a humanitarian crisis in the region. The Catholic Church seeks to reverse the negative effects of these processes by encouraging the assumption of responsibility for the community. These actions cause waves of repression until too well known in the history of my country. I appeal to the High Representative to draw attention to this aspect of the threat of human rights in Venezuela as well.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, as we speak in this House, Venezuela is bleeding to death, the victim of corrupt and incompetent tyranny. While we are debating, Venezuelans have no food, no medicine, no freedom. They have no future and our duty is precisely to help them get it back. They, the Venezuelan people. The last time in Venezuela there were elections with a minimum of guarantees, the opposition won by thrashing. Since then, Maduro has manipulated, repressed and ignored the Constitution. Whoever defies him ends up disabled, exiled, imprisoned or killed. Because he's not interested in anything but power. That is why Europe cannot recognize fraudulent elections aimed at turning Venezuela into a one-party dictatorship, as in Cuba. We cannot recognize them when the regime has disabled almost all opposition leaders and their main alliance, when they are controlled by an electoral body that is the executing arm of the regime, a regime that has just executed Oscar Pérez, as it murdered many Venezuelans who went out to the streets in defense of their dignity. This call for presidential elections is a new mockery of the dialogue process that is taking place in the Dominican Republic, a process that is once again instrumentalized by Maduro to serve his sole interest: to perpetuate himself in power and preserve his corrupt network and that of his environment while the people suffer the consequences of his failed model. If the regime believed in dialogue, it would allow Venezuelans to express themselves in real elections: credible, transparent, free, inclusive, with international standards and independent observers who could ensure that they are a real election. I know that President Nicolás Maduro is interested in what we are discussing in this Parliament. That is why I say to you: for the people of Venezuela to decide their future, to release political prisoners, open a humanitarian channel, respect the Constitution and call for real elections. Because then he'll see that Venezuelans are not willing to continue to endure their incompetence and tyranny.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, Madam High Representative, look, when the European Union listers to extremists, confrontation, it is doing very badly. We have the case of Cuba: those who are driving this confrontation are those who supported the common position. We now have a normalization of relations — you were recently in Cuba — and a dialogue without any gaps. Unilateral sanctions were bad news, and don't cheat, Madam High Representative, because they were unilateral and partly. And from a part of that part of the opposition, redundancy is worth. In addition, it was a direct sabotage to the talks that have been taking place between the Government and the opposition for five months (since December 2011 in the Dominican Republic), with its president involved and with a former European president, Mr Rodríguez Zapatero, whom you should have appointed “special envoy for peace”. Funny, those extremists who talk about the whole of Venezuela but do not recognize the other, because, according to the CNE, the PSV is the first party; that CNE that gave its representation to Mr. Borges, who was awarded here. It's only good when theirs win. Some must have a bad time trying to end a democratic government. They believe that there are still colonies, but there are no colonies, because on one part of that Venezuelan people there is still blood of liberators and they will not accept impositions from you. Respect for the sovereignty of a country and a democratic government, and accompaniment of dialogue!

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Madam High Representative, I think we are all interested in the dialogue finding its way in Venezuela. From this point of view, we are looking forward to what can happen — as you have said — in the next few hours in the Dominican Republic, where we hope there will be good news. And I would like to urge the High Representative and the European External Action Service to support that process, which would obviously be the most positive thing we can do at this time. And from that point of view, I find it difficult to understand why in the midst of this scenario we intend to adopt a resolution which is not even going to mention in its articulated dialogue that is taking place; on the other hand, we are talking all the time about imposing more sanctions, not recognizing elections in any case, and so on. et cetera. I do not understand that resolution in that context and it will therefore be very difficult for my group to be able to subscribe to it. What I believe is that the European Union should give Venezuela a perspective, and the only prospect is that of agreement between the Government and the opposition and that of dialogue. That is what Parliament should do in support of the work of the Dominican Republic group and the High Representative.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, High Representative, the question here is not to judge Venezuela's domestic policy. Each of us will appreciate it according to our political sensitivity. But let's tell the truth. This country has been facing the imperialism of the United States since the 19th century, especially since Hugo Chavez came to power because of its oil resources. This imperialism is real, unlike the one you are accusing — of which we are accusing — Russia. Our Parliament has approved sanctions against Russia for — and I quote — destabilization of Ukraine. Where are the sanctions against those who destabilize Venezuela? Destabilization methods are the same as those used in Ukraine and elsewhere: insurrectional strikes, internal and external media denigration campaigns and, to top it off, an attempt at a coup d'état. The right of peoples to self-determination requires us never to confuse state and government. As I said, whatever our views on President Maduro's government, external interference is not justified.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: Mr President, let us be honest. Sadly in Venezuela there is no hope that something will change. Today's Venezuela suffers a pure and harsh dictatorship, and any well-meaning effort will be barren. It's been said here, and it's possible that's true. At this time, Maduro may reach his goals and get the opposition to split and claudize. That moment, under these conditions, will be the beginning of the end. They have recently expelled the ambassador from Spain because they do not want annoying witnesses to the activities of a regime that has imprisoned political adversaries, which is responsible for a terrible humanitarian crisis, which they also use to seem a compassionate State that provides small public palliatives to care for its citizens. an indigence for which he is responsible. They are old Cuban recipes, by which they instill the idea that outside the regime there is no way out of the regime. The most clearly illegitimate National Constituent Assembly convenes elections with previous fraudulent maneuvers to rig the result. The National Electoral Council, a sectarian body without any credibility, outlawed opposition parties, invoking alleged breaches of rules that are unacceptable as unjust and aberrant. How long, ladies and gentlemen, will satrapa Maduro abuse the patience of the democratic world? Ladies and gentlemen, they are no longer worth half words, there is no room for naivety, we cannot cooperate with a dictator because we would be accomplices. But it is lawful and even compulsory to punish the conduct of political leaders who do not respect human rights, who oppress their people, and who are not indecent to enrich themselves at their expense, subjudging and impoverishing them, to unacceptable levels. The European Parliament cannot remain impassive. We can and must publicly and forcefully condemn a totalitarian drift that is producing increasing tension at the borders with its neighbours and is a factor of regional instability. The Lima Group is setting guidelines on the measures to be taken. The OAS is speaking loud and clear, without hindrance, and we, ladies and gentlemen, have an inexcusable obligation to denounce and condemn the evils of Maduro and his regime.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: Mr President, I understand and share the exasperation of many Democrats at this kind of stopper on Venezuelan democracy Maduro represents. It is hopeless that we have been trying to make the agreement possible for months, but the truth is that it is still possible. And I find it very difficult to place myself in the place of the Venezuelan democratic opposition, which, however, is sitting at a table trying to deal. Until the Venezuelan opposition rises from the table, I don't see why we would have to go ahead. Everyone here knows that if there is any possibility in Venezuela, that is an agreement between the parties to open a democratic path of respect for human rights in Venezuela. There is no other way but democratic agreement. And as it turns out that these conversations are still taking place — exasperating, yes, but they are sitting there — let us respect the Venezuelan democratic opposition, see if an agreement is reached or not — hopefully so! —, let's look at the agreement and then decide what we have to do. I don't think we should anticipate the failure of an agreement that may not happen.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, these premature elections are another example that confirms what we all already know: dialogue is a charade of the regime, and Maduro has no intention of leaving power or restoring democracy in his country. Even more serious than the undermining of democracy are the various allegations of crimes against humanity committed by this dictatorship against its own people. We cannot allow this situation to continue. The European Union finally took a firm and necessary position in imposing targeted sanctions. We can't go back. We need to strengthen our position and do more. That is why I ask you and the Council to expand the list of sanctioned persons and extend it to your relatives. I ask you to start exploring additional measures such as an oil embargo and a ban on business with the state oil company. And I call on the International Criminal Court to investigate all those crimes committed in Venezuela. Too long passed before the first measures against the regime were adopted. And we cannot wait another three years for new measures to be implemented. We need to be prepared to take another step in the face of a situation that gets worse every day. Venezuela has been living hell for too long and it is our responsibility, our duty, to do everything we can to help them.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: — Mr President, the swell that this Parliament distilles to the Bolivarian revolution brings back Venezuela again. Irresponsibly and without legitimacy of any order, they massacre reality, shaping it to your interests. They fuel the destabilization of the country to the detriment of the Venezuelan people and the immigrant communities, such as the Portuguese one, that reside there. They talk about a humanitarian crisis that organizations like the UN, ECLAC or FAO reject, speak of violence, omitting the brutality of the actions of an opposition that they have laured here, responsible for the deaths of dozens of people. They call for dialogue, but with the neo-colonialist stance of permanent appeal to interference and aggression against a sovereign country, a common practice in this House, they ignore and compromise the process of dialogue under way in the Dominican Republic, which can reach agreement. They use the old maxim that a lie told often becomes reality. But the truth, this one, you can't change it. The truth that the Venezuelan people stated clearly in the last three electoral acts in support of the Bolivarian revolution.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: Mr President, the situation in Venezuela is dramatic and I remember, Mrs Mogherini, that there are very many ties that unite the Venezuelan people with Europe. From here I would like to make a kind of triple appeal. First, to the Venezuelan Government, which unjustly declared persona non grata a few days ago to the Spanish ambassador to Caracas. The regime must end its clear totalitarian drift, which now includes the convening of presidential elections without democratic guarantees and convened by an illegitimate body such as the National Constituent Assembly. In addition, democratic opposition parties were prohibited and political prisoners were not yet free. My second call is to the Venezuelan democratic opposition, persecuted by the regime. I ask that democratic opposition, to which the European Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize a few months ago, to seek unity and to be directed exclusively by the goal of achieving freedom, democracy and prosperity for the Venezuelan people. My third call is to you, Mrs Mogherini, even if you are talking without paying attention to the debate. My third call is to the EEAS, to you, Mrs Mogherini, and the Member States to pursue a genuine common European policy in relation to the crisis in Venezuela. That is, there is unity and consistency. And also, by the way, solidarity with Spain. And I would like, for example, to explain to us what specific measures it took, if even the EEAS called — as it should have done — the Venezuelan ambassador in Brussels to present a protest against the expulsion of the Spanish ambassador. Venezuela is suffering from a very serious political, economic and social crisis, and the European Union and its Member States must contribute, in close contact with the international community and our friends in the Americas, to tackle this situation and contribute to the search for a solution to a situation that should not be prolonged.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: — Mr President, High Commissioner, the glaring failure of the Bolivarian revolution is an absolutely obvious fact and which manifests itself dramatically in the living conditions of the Venezuelan people. The results of this failure are known: a suppression of civil liberties, disregard for human rights, a situation of economic and social misery, a very serious humanitarian crisis. Millions of Venezuelans have already had to flee their own country. This is the exact and objective picture of what is happening in Venezuela. And in view of this, we, of course, the European Parliament, have an obligation, as a large democratic parliament that we are, to condemn clearly and without any reservations this type of regime, which is a liberticidal regime, which is a regime which disrespects human rights, which is a regime of a dictatorial nature. Despite this, it is clear that, as a negotiating process is underway, however small the chances of it will succeed, we must maintain until the last moment a light of hope regarding the possibility of success himself, although we must also say that we have strong reason to believe that in this process power is not open-minded, it is not in a good spirit, as it has never been before. If there is an agreement, it will be a huge surprise, a positive surprise. We must not close the doors to this, but we must be particularly vigilant about what is happening in Venezuela.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, people, and Venezuelans, are the pagans of a crisis that has its origin in the totalitarianism of the Maduro regime. Our first obligation is to send them the humanitarian aid they need; the one they block from Caracas; the one that will solve hunger, malnutrition, lack of medicines, essential goods that will not be expelled by ambassadors. Nor with endless speeches of the warlord, who eats, who lives well, who gets rich. That is why his allegedly Bolivarian verborrhea insults the admired Liberator. It does not feed, no cure, does not create jobs, does not pay pensions, no longer convinces the microphone that amplifies it. To convene elections from a body that does not recognize the international community; to do so when at a supposed dialogue table that is one of the key points of negotiation between the parties; banning parties, imprisoning opponents, changing electoral rules every day are attacks on common sense, laws and rights fundamental. They deserve sanctions that must be extended to the Government of Venezuela and its surroundings. They deserve an arms embargo and any tool that can be used in internal repression. They deserve to explore all kinds of diplomatic and economic measures, including those that can focus on the state oil company. Venezuela needs transparency, contrast. That is why the necessary conditions must be achieved for a delegation from this Parliament to support peace and fundamental rights on the ground; for it to promote dialogue between all parties to a conflict that has no other way but to change repression and dictatorship for freedom and democracy.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: Mr President, in recent years there have been numerous times that we have spoken of this great country in Latin America and not always for the best reasons. Last year we awarded the Sakarov Prize to the Venezuelan opposition, but from then on, Venezuela's political, social and economic situation has worsened and is evolving into a humanitarian crisis and food famine that affects the most vulnerable groups of the population, particularly children. Mass economic emigration to neighbouring countries, particularly Colombia and Brazil, has strongly pressed the communities, administrations and the economy of the border areas of these countries. The country's hyperinflation situation is deeply worrying, projecting the IMF to be 13,000% this year and a contraction of 15% of GDP, which, at the end of 2018, could lead to a cumulative loss of 50% of the product since 2013. The coexistence of two legislative chambers is also a factor of strong instability, reminiscent of other world historical moments of strong social insurrection and even civil war. For this reason, we call once again for the Venezuelan Government's recognition of the legitimacy of the National Assembly as the only Legislative Chamber. A final word of solidarity for the strong immigrant and expatriate community of European citizens living and working in Venezuela, including the significant Portuguese community, who have experienced many difficulties in their daily lives, particularly in terms of security and access to goods food, medicines and health care. The new Ambassador of the European Union, the Portuguese Ambassador, Isabel Pedrosa, and you, High Representative, we simply ask that you continue to do everything possible to help all those who believe in the future of this great country.

name: Karoline GRASWANDER-HAINZ
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. The situation in Venezuela is both worrying and shocking. People in the country — especially children — are suffering from hunger and do not have access to medical care. Inflation in the country has risen rapidly. Looting takes place every day because people can no longer afford food. Leading opposition politicians are also imprisoned, under arrest, have fled into exile or are not allowed to compete in the upcoming elections. These are unacceptable conditions. The European Union has already taken action: sanctions have been imposed on Venezuela. We must set all the levers we have at our disposal in motion to improve the situation in Venezuela. Respect for human rights and for democratically elected institutions must be restored and political prisoners must be released. Above all, human suffering on the ground must end as soon as possible.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: — Mr President, Mr Vice-President, 23 January 1958 was known as the day of the birth of democracy in Venezuela, with the removal of dictator Pérez Jiménez. Sixty years later, democracy succumbs to Nicolás Maduro's ideological authoritarianism, the arrests and the inability of political dissidents and the fragmentation and demoralization of the opposition. The anticipation of the date of the presidential elections for 2018 and the exclusion of the Democratic Unity Bureau of this electoral act constitute another sad episode of this already long tragicomedia that aims to consolidate the dictatorial profile of the regime and illegitimately perpetuate Mr. Nicolás Maduro in power. Given the seriousness of the humanitarian crisis in Venezuela and the repeated violation of the civil and political rights of hundreds of prisoners in exile political exile, the selective sanctions imposed by the European Union on seven senior Venezuelan officials, who should, in my opinion, be extended to their families, are not, contrary to what the Venezuelan Government states, the result of an interventionist policy and submission to the Government of Mr. Trump. They are a diplomatic instrument in support of justice, respect for human rights and the defence of democracy. But ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Venezuela is untenable, and death hand in hand with terror and oppression have taken the streets. Madam Vice President, you said that Venezuela's future should be decided by your people, but that decision must be free, and that, however much will you have, will never happen if the international community continues to allow Mr Maduro to continue to bleed his people. I will conclude, Mr President, by saying, as I have said before, that I am undoubtedly Venezuelan and, as a Venezuelan, I ask this Parliament and the Commission to take more vigorous action against the Bolivarian Government of Venezuela which oppresses the Venezuelan people.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: — Mr President, High Commissioner, when more than 2 million people have to leave their country because of lack of safety conditions and because of the shortage of food and medicines affecting the most vulnerable populations in particular, we are no longer facing a serious political problem to a situation in a profound humanitarian crisis and the failure of a regime and a political system, with very serious political consequences. This Parliament has in the past adopted many recommendations which have not been followed. Therefore, without breaking the tenuous lines of dialogue that still remain, it is important to mobilize the international community, and in particular neighbouring countries, to put pressure on the Venezuelan Government to restore democratic normality and create conditions for a free, transparent and credible. In a deeply divided society such as Venezuelan, only the return of the voice to the people, in conditions of full freedom, can ensure Venezuela's reunion with itself, ensuring worthy living conditions for its citizens and a future equal to its history and the ambition of the new generations.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, the EU must put its full support behind reaching an agreement at the talks between the Venezuelan Government and the opposition being hosted by the president of the Dominican Republic. To that end, first the EU must reject in unequivocal terms the totally inadmissible threats by the US President and his administration to launch a military intervention against Venezuela; second, call for an immediate end to US-imposed financial sanctions, since starving the Venezuelan economy of its foreign currency earnings risks turning the country’s current humanitarian crisis into a full—blown humanitarian catastrophe; and, third, urge the representatives of the opposition to return to talks with the government in a joint effort to reach agreement on the upcoming presidential elections. The latest polls show that, as of today, fully 50% of Venezuelans consider that Hugo Chavez was a good president. The one and only way to overcome the deep polarisation of Venezuelan society is renouncing violence in favour of negotiations towards an agreement.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, economic stability and political stability are neither inextricably linked nor are they completely separate, but something between the two. They’re correlated, so I’ll focus therefore on the Venezuelan economy.  Venezuela should, given its natural resources, be a rich country. Yet the mistakes of the Chavez regime and its over-reliance on food imports, compounded under Maduro, led to this: to a society where GBP 100 couldn’t even buy you a dozen eggs; to 2000% inflation. And from a crumbling economy and from political idealism failing – as so often in history – flow human rights abuses. To the UK’s eternal shame, Corbyn promoted Venezuela as a shining example of socialism in action, rather than to read the warning signs that were there. But to save a country that is in such a state requires not idealism, but pragmatism. Malaria, diphtheria and starvation in a nation with Venezuela’s resources – or, frankly, in any nation – this should not be.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President – as, I think, all Members mentioned – there is only one way out of this crisis that is at the same time political, social and humanitarian, and that is a negotiated solution: a peaceful, constitutional outcome that brings the regime and the opposition together in a credible manner.  And this is the effort we are supporting with all the means we have and in constant contact with the regional players, because we have always invested in regional dynamics. This is particularly true for our Latin American partners, and that region is going to be at the same time more affected and hopefully also more influential. I say this with a deep respect for the institutional and political internal dynamics, but still recognising that what is happening there is not happening behind closed doors and concerns the international community. This concerns the European Union and this concerns many European Union citizens. Many of you have mentioned that European Union citizens that are suffering as a result of this crisis. So it is in our interest for a solution to be found. That can only be a political, negotiated solution in a peaceful and constitutional outcome of the crisis. I mention that a peaceful and constitutional outcome of the crisis is a key element because there could be a different outcome. And I think we have to be aware of the risks that a further deterioration of the situation could bring us. So we have mentioned the key elements that most of you have recalled today: credible elections, the release of all political prisoners, respect for democratically elected bodies, upholding of human rights and, very importantly, an alleviation of the suffering of the people of Venezuela. That would also imply a different trend in the fleeing of Venezuelans to neighbouring countries. That, as many of you recalled, might have a destabilising effect for different political situations in different countries that are also close to our hearts. We will continue to use all the different instruments we have, political support, diplomatic engagements, pressures, work with the international community and with the regional players, direct contacts with the opposition, but also with the authorities. And yes, we have had opportunities to pass very clear messages to the Venezuelan authorities, both locally and in Brussels, including messages that were very clear on our common position on the decisions that have been taken on the Spanish ambassador. I was very clear on that. Let me stress one thing – and I will close with this because I know we are running late – the unity of the European Union and its Member States is remarkable on this issue, maybe more than it is in this Chamber. But let me say, the work we have done both in Venezuela and in Brussels has shown unity of purpose, unity of action and coordinated efforts. I would like to thank the Member States for this, because this is what makes the difference when it comes to playing a role and making a difference, again with respect, with no interference. Venezuela is a sovereign country, but when there is a political crisis, when there is a social crisis, when there is an economic crisis, when there is a humanitarian crisis and also European interest and regional dynamics are at stake, we have a duty to support a positive outcome to the ongoing efforts. As I said, another attempt is being made at the present time. A solution is possible, we are not seeing this now, but I believe that it is our duty to invest in this possibility.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I have received six motions for resolutions in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. The discussion is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 8 February 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. — The possibility of reaching a solution to the terrible humanitarian and human rights crisis in Venezuela is blurred on the horizon. The Maduro regime is now proposing, through the illegitimate National Constituent Assembly, the holding of early presidential elections; elections without minimum democratic guarantees, with more than three hundred political opponents imprisoned and so many others disqualified from running for public office; elections that are would be held in a space where freedom of expression or association is not respected, where the judiciary works to comply with the Government's political agenda and where government measures were taken to restrict international funding of human rights NGOs. The Human Rights Watch report indicates that at least 124 people have died during incidents involving protests against the Government, and the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights himself, in his report last August, indicated that more than half of these deaths had been caused by security officers. This Parliament must forcefully reject the holding of these illegitimate elections. The EU will only be able to recognize elections based on a viable, fair and transparent electoral calendar.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation of UNRWA (2017/ 2553 (RSP)).

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Let me first of all thank you for this debate. It is timely and it is important. It is important first of all because millions of people – men, women and children – depend on the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for education, healthcare and social services, humanitarian assistance and employment. So, supporting UNWRA is a humanitarian duty and it is also in our collective interest for peace and security in the Middle East. I would like to mention a few reasons why it is essential to support UNWRA, its work and why the European Union not only is supporting it but is going to continue to support it and argue for continued or increased support from other international partners. Firstly, the work they do is crucial for the prospects of an agreement between Israel and Palestine. It is a key contribution that UNWRA is bringing to the prospect of relaunching a credible peace process, because a just, fair, agreed and realistic solution to the refugee question is one of the parameters of for peace negotiations, with the ultimate objective of achieving a two—state solution. The work that UNWRA does provides the political space towards achieving a peace deal and building a Palestinian State. Secondly, it is a matter of regional stability. This strikes me every time when international players don’t see the reality on the ground in the countries that have been hosting, for decades; a huge number of Palestinian refugees. Reducing the activities of UNWRA would cause instability and even security threats all around the region. This is true for the West Bank and Gaza, but this is also true for Lebanon and Jordan. They are themselves facing enormous challenges on other fronts and this is obvious to all of us I believe; there is no need for me to go into details about the huge pressure that both Lebanon and Jordan have been facing. Investing in UNWRA is also investing in our collective regional security. Thirdly, education. The European Union has always invested and will always continue to invest in the education of people and children to avoid any lost generation. For Palestinian kids, this means the possibility to keep hoping, to build their own future, and to believe in their own personal lives – which is no minor thing when you are a child; and it means also fighting radicalisation. So it’s also here an investment in our own security. Fourthly, UNWRA is particularly important for the political process in Gaza, where work is ongoing, efforts are ongoing for the return of the Palestinian Authority, and Palestinian reconciliation is essential for the prospect of a viable state of Palestine. So for all these reasons, we are – and we will continue to be – strong and reliable supporters of the work of UNWRA. Together with our Member States, we are doing all we can to avoid repercussions from the US decision to ensure that UNWRA can continue to operate and to ensure a continued engagement from all other international actors, but also from the United States. We have already increased our support in recent times. For 2018, the European Union will assist UNWRA by accelerating our first scheduled payment for this year, and I also count on donors around the world with whom we are in contact, including in coordination with other players. Here I would mention established partners for UNWRA, which already has important donors, but also all those that have so far been less engaged and who can step up their efforts in order to safeguard something that can be qualified as a global public good: the work that UNWRA does.  Peace between Israel and Palestine will clearly be built through negotiations, which requires a commitment from the two sides, but it must also be preserved every day on the ground and this is what UNWRA is doing with the Palestinian refugees. Investing in UNWRA is an interest we all share and the international community and the Palestinian refugees and the countries in the region can count on the European Union to continue to support its work.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I also welcome this timely opportunity to join some of you today to discuss UNRWA, which is currently facing unprecedented challenges. The European Union is convinced that the two-state solution is the only possible answer if we want to achieve lasting peace in the Middle East. We believe that any solution to the Israeli—Arab conflict will need to include an agreed just and fair solution to the refugee question. The Palestinian refugee question has existed for almost 70 years. The United Nations General Assembly established and mandated UNRWA to provide assistance and protection to registered Palestinian refugees until a just and lasting solution is found to their plight. This is the work that UNRWA continues to do, laying the groundwork for future development through its work in education and health, and contributing – as the High Representative has just said – to security and stability in the region. The Commission will disburse our scheduled payment for 2018, which is about EUR 82 million, by the end of February – much earlier than originally planned. Some of our Member States have also announced plans to accelerate their contributions for this year and I can tell you that we will also do so in 2019 and 2020, at least, in order to reassure UNRWA from our side. It is still too early to tell you how exactly UNRWA will be affected since the scope and nature of the cuts in US funding are not entirely clear. What we do know is that the EU will not be able to compensate for substantial US cuts, given the pressure on available funds. We can and will actively assist UNRWA in reaching out to non—traditional donors in order to help the agency to broaden its donor base and, given the magnitude of the problem, we also need to work with host governments on how they might consider providing certain services that UNRWA cannot and maybe should not provide. UNRWA needs reform. Some of its financial problems are structural and predate the US decision. The EU has long been calling on UNRWA to review its operational and financial planning approach in order to safeguard its basic and essential core services, intended to help the most marginalised refugees. We therefore commend UNRWA’s commitment to a process of comprehensive financial reforms, including measures sustaining institutional change and increasing the cost-effectiveness of its programmes. But, in order to achieve improvements, we will work on this together with – and not against – the agency. There should be no doubt that the EU is and will remain a staunch and reliable supporter of UNRWA, both politically and financially. The EU and its Member States are by far the largest provider of assistance to Palestinian refugees – they provide around EUR 460 million a year. In June 2017, a joint declaration was signed between the EU and UNRWA as a framework for our financial and political support for the agency as further proof of our continued commitment, not just this year, but also in the years to come.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, Madam High Representative, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the United States Administration has decided to freeze a substantial part of the aid to the United Nations Agency for Palestine Refugees. This decision is linked to the controversial transfer of the United States Embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem. This decision has caused serious concern to the Secretary-General of the United Nations and also, why not to say, deep concern among us. We may have differences with the United States in terms of the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, the Trans-Pacific Agreement, the Trade and Investment Agreement, the appointment of arbitrators in the World Trade Organization panels, but we are talking about people here, talking about millions of people: two million refugees in Lebanon; nearly 500 000 refugees in Jordan; 540,000 refugees in Syria; 1 400 000 in the Gaza Strip; 800 000 in the West Bank. And they are people who, as the High Representative has reminded us, have basic needs to cover, children to be educated and cared for and who play their future. I believe that we must strongly support the Commission's efforts to meet these needs in the short term and mobilize the international community to maintain commitments to Palestine. I hope, Madam Vice-President, Commissioner, that we can maintain the level of these commitments because the credibility of the European Union on such a sensitive issue as refugees is at stake.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
