text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, on the one hand are those who have been offering food, water, education, health to the parents, children and grandchildren of Palestine refugees for more than six decades, and on the other hand is the one who, by tweet, breaks the status quo and makes everything jump into the air without offering any alternative. And this Parliament must clearly and unequivocally say that UNRWA has all our effective support. Our trust. And that we are going to bet that UNRWA can continue to do the humanitarian work it is doing and that no one else can do. The harsh reality is that today, following the Trump Administration's decision, UNRWA is going to stop making more than $500 million, and that means a real risk that UNRWA will have to shut down completely, leaving more than five million human beings in need of dignity, security and help abandoned. As UNRWA said, dignity was priceless. Instead, the Trump Administration's irresponsibility does, and it is a very high price. That is why I think we must act and we will defend and support the holding of an international conference with all actors, because all hands are necessary: the European Union, the Member States, the international community as a whole and also the Arab countries, which must fulfil their commitments. We need every hand to support UNRWA, which, in turn, holds millions of human beings completely left behind. And to sustain UNRWA sends a message of hope to a region where messages of hope did not abound. Let us make that hope possible; let us act with dignity and responsibility because we all almost live in it.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — If, after several decades of broad-minded support for the humanitarian organization, in our case UNWRI, a government decides to drastically reduce support and virtually disable its normal functioning without advance, then it is allowed to ask: what? We're talking about US President Trump's decision, which has not only affected just over half a million girls and boys in schools maintained by UNWRA in areas where Palestinian refugees live, but about the millions of Palestinians living in the harshest conditions in camps in Jordan, Lebanon, Syria, the West Bank and Gaza. Because of the extreme distress into which the hard decision of the US government has plunged, it is our moral duty to come to the affected Palestinians and UNWRI for aid and try to make up for the income outage. Therefore, in the resolution to be decided tomorrow, we call for European Union countries to join solidarity action. Since back in 1950, when UNRWE's business first glassed, the United States has reliably and broadly supported its activity. It's probably not just a coincidence that the halving of funding for UNWRO directly followed the US president's announcement that he would formally recognize Jerusalem as the capital of the state of Israel. That announcement was followed by a statement by Palestinian President Abbas that he no longer sees the US as a possible intermediary in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process. To those who have had the opportunity to visit any Palestinian camp in the Middle East in the past years, it is clear that the work done by UNWRA is invaluable. While it is constantly faced with financial problems, and the number of aid needed is increasing, the organization not only maintains hope for a better refugee tomorrow, allows schooling children and comforting the elderly, through their self-sacrifice work and often, at the cost of their own sacrifice, keep it apolitical and neutral status of its organization and its institutions. Humanitarian aid is not a substitute for normal, man Worth a life. Such a life will only be allowed for Palestinian refugees once Israel and the Palestinians have permanently resolved their dispute with mutual respect and life in two sovereign states. Until then, UNWRA will be an irreplaceable foothold for those who suffer most in the Middle East. So we need to help the organization and do it immediately.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, the provocative decision by the US Government to announce on 16 January yet another cut-off from the UNRWA contribution is another blow to the Middle East peace process. The Trump administration has already led the peace process to an impasse by recognising Jerusalem as the capital of Israel and declaring its intention to move the country's embassy there. As GUE we condemn the US's action to cut aid to UNRWA. We acknowledge the great contribution of the organization and express our deep appreciation for the work and its people. Without UNRWA assistance, the humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip cannot be tackled. 70% of Gaza's inhabitants depend on UNRWA's support, which operates 700 schools, 137 clinics and provides food and financial support to 1.7 million Palestinians living in Lebanon, Jordan, Syria and the occupied Palestinian territories. We call on the European Union and its Member States to mobilise additional funding for UNRWA and to take the initiative to support UNRWA and find solutions to its economic situation. We, as GUE, remain firm in our position to end the occupation, return the refugees to their ancestral homes and a peaceful resolution of the Palestinian State at the base of the two states, at the 1967 border and with East Jerusalem as the capital of the Palestinian state.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I believe that when we talk about the current financial plight of UNRWA we need to talk about two things simultaneously. Firstly, we need to talk about the requirements of international humanitarian law. For all those who value and adhere to this part of international law, supporting this agency is an obligation, not a question of choice. Unfortunately, not all international actors subscribe to this view, and to be absolutely clear about it, the European Union is one of those, however, which does take it seriously, we, European Union and its Member States combined, are the largest donor to UNRWA. So we shoulder a fair share from the costs. However, this proud place comes with responsibilities. We need to look further, we need to address the major large-scale political question as well. We need to engage with the peace process, because otherwise UNRWA will remain in place indefinitely, and that is the worst possible outcome.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Trump's decision to drastically reduce aid to UNRWA is without ifs and without but to stigmatise and fits into the rut of a totally unbalanced US foreign policy. Let us also remember the decision to declare Jerusalem capital only of Israel. It enshrines the death of the already difficult hypothesis of the two-state solution. We ask the European Commission, the Vice-President: Is this not the time to show greater courage in the Middle East by the European Union and all the Member States? And boldly I mean an increase in financial contributions. The European Union financed the agency in 2017 with just over $143 million, less than half of US aid, to which the poor voluntary contributions from member states should be added. And I still mean political actions to truly ensure that Israel is respected for international law, which with impunity continues to build colonies in the West Bank, now reduced so many to enclave break from each other. The Vice-President is not there, but I am addressing the Commissioner and make a further appeal: recognition of the State of Palestine can no longer wait. We are already guilty late and if we don't act right away history will find us guilty of not having done enough for the Palestinian people.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: Mr President, to my colleagues on the left, of course anti-American, here in the European Parliament, I would like to tell you that if you look at the latest decision of the US administration in detail, whether it is Trump's question or not, it is obvious that UNRWA still has the support of the United States and that it continues to be supported by the United States. receiving their financial and political assistance. That's in the statement. What's happening is that the agency is undergoing reform. Normal and logical. A necessary reform, also, on the other hand, and which requires greater sources of voluntary contributions. Countries such as Belgium, the Netherlands and Sweden have already made progress to increase their contributions. I hope you will also remind the Arab countries that they have to do so, because so far they have not done so either. Of the top twenty donors, only three are Arabs. What the European Union must do was to establish an independent monitoring mission to ensure that the education and assistance provided by UNRWA were well used to promote a culture of peace and dialogue and not to misuse its hospitals and schools to recruit future terrorists. Finally, while we have this legitimate debate, let us not fall into the trap of questioning America's support for international relations. After all, we must not forget that the world order based on the rules we enjoy today, the one created by UNRWA or the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, was built and supported by our transatlantic partners. In this context, I again insist, regardless of any doubts that this Administration may cause some of you, I am convinced, and we must be, that the United States has not allowed and will not allow UNRWA to remain alone.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Mr President, I say to Commissioner Hahn that I think we’re hearing a pretty united House here, concerned about the cost to UNRWA and supporting the work which is being undertaken. Most people have underlined that this is about humanitarian aid, not about politics. It is about aid to vulnerable people. These people have a face, they want a future and find themselves as refugees, including in Syria today. This happens in many countries in the Middle East, and that’s why I’m very disappointed that the United States has decided to cut this budget, because, by breaking with their traditional support for UNRWA, they’re making political something which should not be so political. I hear what you say about how the EU cannot bridge the entire gap left by the United States, and that other countries have to step up. But we should also recognise that some of those countries – Lebanon and Jordan – are already dealing with the Syrian refugee crisis as well. It is a difficult time and at a time when we’ve got a humanitarian crisis arising in Gaza, in particular – Archer is telling us about the appalling situation there. I think it is good that the EU has fast-tracked its payments. It is good that EU Member States are doing the same. But we really must step up now. We must get other players to the table and get the funding guaranteed and get a long-term solution for UNRWA, not just in the short term, but a long-term solution at the United Nations so there is a secure funding base on which we can restart peace talks.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, initially designed to be a temporary one—year programme, 65 years later it is a damning indictment of the international community that the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) is still needed today. 5.6 million people are registered for services provided by UNRWA and there are hundreds of thousands more not registered but who still need UNRWA’s help.  UNRWA works to protect the rights of Palestinians, rights that are routinely trampled on and discarded by Israel, as illustrated in the case of Ahed Tamimi, a 17—year—old Palestinian child who should be in school, not in a prison dungeon.  Yet we have the international community – disgracefully, I believe – lacking the political will to address the root causes of the conflict in Palestine. Given the lack of that will, it should at the very least work to protect the most vulnerable, and there is no doubt the children imprisoned in Palestine have gone way past vulnerability. UNRWA absolutely needs to be adequately funded and Member States should increase their funding for the vital services it provides to millions and millions of people around the world.

name: Margrete AUKEN
text: Mr President! Thank you for finally having this debate on Palestine, which is good, but there is one mighty elephant in the room which is not mentioned: Israel's total disregard for the obligations under international law to pay what their occupation costs. Israel and the occupiers don't pay a single cent to UNRWA. In addition, the attacks on UNRWA are shocking, by the way. The thousands of dedicated employees stay at their post when others are evacuated. Dozens of them have been killed. They must be honored and thanked for the unique efforts they are making for the Palestinian refugees in Lebanon, Jordan, Syria, in the West Bank and especially in Gaza, who have suffered from Israel's siege for 10 years now. The sudden rupture of the United States with its obligations is shocking, and so is, as mentioned, the failure of the Gulf states. Therefore, thank you to the EU, which is making efforts to enable UNRWA to continue its impressive work. Finally, a question for Ms Mogherini: where is the clear protest over Israel's destruction of the EU-paid school in Abu Nawar in Area E1? Where is the requirement for Israel to pay reparations? We still miss hearing a clear message here.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: — Mr President, when we negotiated this resolution, we agreed that there would be no political statement. That this is going to be a resolution about an agency that is international does a great job, and we want, in a way, to continue that work. It's neither on the side of Israel nor on the side of Palestine. It's on the side of the people. Ordinary people suffering from a conflict of war, a conflict that should have been resolved. Yes, my speechwriters here have reminisced several times that the conflict is dragging on. The Palestinians were on the side of the losers, the Israelis on the side of the winners, but we're not the ones here to judge the conflict. We are the ones who are supposed to deal with the situation. And the situation came about that simply one of the biggest contributors said he would consider whether he would continue to contribute through the means he contributed to this day. And here, ladies and gentlemen, is a very important thing. Let's see how the European Union has responded. She said, “It doesn't concern us.”? No, she didn't. The European Union said: “In what way can we help? “She also said to the Member States, “Member States, come together to participate more in dealing with this situation.” And here, Commissioner, I want to thank you because you are one of those engines of this assistance. You are one of those looking for a way out of this, I would say, fairly impassive situation. I as an MEP have visited refugee camps, I don't know if it can be called refugee, if anyone over fifty years, sixty years old can be a refugee. But we just visited them. And those places look the way they look. And our aid should go for the poorest, for those who do not have education, and I think the European Union's response to this is very positive. We're looking for solutions. And that solution is not simple. And that, dear colleagues, is what we should be looking at. Looking at what it's going to look like for the future. This is the solution of the European Union.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: Mr President! The US government's decision to link aid payments to UNRWA to political demands is a dangerous politicisation of humanitarian aid. I am deeply concerned about the retention of payments. This includes medical care for three million Palestinian refugees, the supply of food to 1.7 million Palestinian refugees and the training of 500 000 children in over 700 UNRWA schools. There is a risk that such substantial cuts in humanitarian aid will lead to further instability in the region. The assessment is also shared by Israel and the chief of staff of the Israeli army Gadi Eizenkot. He goes even further in his appeal: he is calling for more humanitarian aid in the Gaza Strip, otherwise a war could be threatened this year because of the situation of the people. In his opinion, too, the issue of humanitarian aid must be dealt with separately from other issues. I welcome the EU's decision to provide additional funding to UNRWA in a fast-track procedure in some Member States, including Germany. However, we also need a multilateral global financing framework for long-term financing. In this regard, I would particularly like to appeal to the funding commitments of the members of the Arab League. The EU must continue to support UNRWA as a reliable partner to develop a global financing plan. I call on the European Parliament to send a clear, non-partisan message to the international community in this regard in the vote on Thursday. My negotiations on our resolution between all political groups give me confidence in this.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: - Mr President! Commissioner! Two years ago I stood here in the House talking about the fact that the UN aid agency UNRWA had the smallest budget in 10 years while the international community had failed to give people in Gaza even a modicum of help. Today I am standing here again after the US message to greatly reduce aid to UNRWA. History repeats itself. Now it is being made $500 million, while at the same time over 5 million Palestinian refugees are entirely dependent on humanitarian support. We know the importance of UNRWA's mission and we know that reduced funding has very difficult humanitarian and political consequences in one of the most vulnerable regions in the world. It must not happen that these savings are driven on. I still find it very uplifting to listen to Mogherini and Hahn and others here. We are very much in agreement across all party boundaries and it still makes me a little hopeful. I will not be standing here in a number of years again and be worried about the exposure that Palestinians continue to live in, and which is a risk to the entire international community. So thanks for a good debate. And now we have to actually execute things. We're not supposed to be community builders to the Palestinians. They are supposed to be allowed to build their communities themselves and feel strong and free.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: – Mr President, I say to the Commissioner that this should come as no surprise – a president who is throwing all conventional norms overboard has no empathy for the victims of his policy. And yes, that we are stuck in a mess in the Middle East is certainly the result of US action or inaction, and now we come to UNRWA. We all know that the United Nations is doing an excellent job in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank. Without the dedicated support of the UN we would have no schools, no hospitals and probably no food for about a million people who live under dire circumstances. The commitment of the European Union to allocate an additional EUR 42 million for the Palestinian territories and east Jerusalem is a very positive step. It is, in addition, an important signal by the European Union at a time when the US administration is retreating more and more from its international commitments. It could and should also open a window for the EU to revert from being a mere payer to becoming more of a player in the Middle East.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the American decision to drastically reduce UNRWA funds is a major blow to the more than 5 million Palestinian refugees in the region. The Agency's work is now the only support for many of them with regard to food, health and education, in the absence of a lasting solution to the Middle East conflict. Putting his activities at risk for political ends, as the Trump administration is doing, can have devastating effects for all the countries involved, including Israel, as some of its officers know well. In addition to renewing its diplomatic and financial support, as High Representative Federica Mogherini did not fail to do, Europe must work together with the UN to spur other countries — I think in particular to some Gulf countries — to renew their commitment, at the same time seeking solutions to make the agency's operation financially sustainable in the long term, which must no longer be in mercy of unilateral decisions. Europe can and should play an even stronger role.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: — Mr President, the underfunding of this UN agency is not from now, but the fundamental problem is Israel's continued and growing aggression against Palestine and its martyred people, an aggression that is aggravated by the recognition of Jerusalem as capital of Israel by the US administration. , in explicit support for Israel's Zionist policy, expressed in violation of international law, a position that is not disconnected from its strategy of destabilising the Middle East. Firm action is required, particularly in the context of the UN, with a view to reversal of this decision, to end Israel's aggression against Palestine and to recognize the right of the Palestinian people to build the State of Palestine on the frontiers prior to 1967 and with capital in East Jerusalem. We reiterate the usual solidarity with the Palestinian people and their legitimate and heroic seven-decade struggle for the right to establish a sovereign and viable state and respect for the right of return of Palestinian refugees that Israel's policy of expansion and occupation of Palestine has generated.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Thank you, Mr President, and I thank the honourable Members for this debate which has highlighted the importance of UNRWA once again. It’s clear that we have to assist UNRWA in overcoming it current financial crisis. Unfortunately, it’s not the first one, but this time it has been triggered by one of the main donors. From this debate I conclude that we all join in a common call for support to UNRWA as an important stabilising factor in the region and an important element in ensuring the viability of the two-state solution. Without UNRWA, millions of people, especially children, would lose access to essential services like education and health care. We all are aware of what it means to lose one generation, or even several generations, if we fail to provide the necessary education and professional training and everything related to this. Such a failure might lead to radicalisation and other things which are definitely not in our, or the world’s, interests in future. Today, as many Members have said, UNRWA provides assistance and protection for more than five million Palestinian refugees. The European Union enjoys a strong and dynamic partnership with UNRWA. I see Pierre Krähenbühl at least twice to three times a year to discuss with him what needs to be done to improve UNRWA’s performance in terms of the services it provides We also discuss its internal structural needs and challenges and how UNRWA should be reformed. I can tell you that a lot of important measures have already taken. We should further support all the reform measures taken by UNRWA itself. So I really appreciate all the support we gained today from Parliament, but I’m pretty sure that it will not be the last discussion about UNRWA and the Palestinians here in plenary.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I have received six motions for resolutions in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure. The discussion is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday 8 February 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. — Every day, more than 500 thousand Palestinian children learn to read and write in schools run by UNRWA, the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees. Nine million are the medical visits that this same agency finances in a year through 140 health centres, strewn across the devastated territories of the Gaza Strip, the West Bank and Syria. Assistance nothing short of indispensable, which at a critical time like the current one, is cut by as much as 65 million dollars by its largest donor, the USA, just because it would lack that “respect” and” appreciation” to the administration's Trump led picks. A decision with tragic implications, both for innocent civilians whose survival depends on humanitarian aid, and for Europe itself. Extreme poverty, in fact, only increases the risk of radicalisation and multiply the migration flows of refugees to our countries. It is, therefore, with satisfaction that I welcome the new €42.5 million EU package to help the Palestinians in the construction of their future state, which can co-exist together with Israel's. Today more than ever there is a need for Europe to make a collective effort to raise UNRWA and ask Trump to reconsider his choice.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: in writing. — I have welcomed with great concern the decision of the current United States Administration to drastically reduce humanitarian aid funding for Palestinian refugees under UNRWA. According to President Trump's announcement in 2018, the US intends to donate $65m to the agency instead of the planned 125m. Aid provided by the agency is crucial to the survival of more than 5 million Palestinians, including women and children, to whom UNRWA provides food, drinking water, shelter, medical care and education. Depriving the agency of financial resources is tantamount to taking away those persons from the right to said benefits. I appeal to the American administration to reconsider the decision to cut funding for UNRWA, mindful of the fate of those to whom it ensures daily survival and dignified living conditions. As a last resort, I propose replacing the withdrawn funds with other programs for the benefit of the Palestinians, or at least spreading the planned reduction over time so that the international community can take appropriate compensatory action. At the same time, I ask the European Union and the Member States to coordinate efforts to fill the UNRWA budget gap so as to maintain the continuity of humanitarian aid provided to Palestinian refugees.
